title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Liposomes were prepared using multiple freeze/thaw cycles and characterized by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). 
Increasing the total liposome concentration caused the majority of PLIN3 to bind membranes, but 5% of PLIN3 remained in the soluble fraction (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). DLS characterization indicated DAG enriched liposomes had two populations based on size (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] , d [this file] ), which is likely due to the fusogenic properties of DAG . The addition of DOPA or PLIN3 protein decreased or eliminated the population of the larger (>400 nm) liposomes (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] , d [this file] ). 
ALDs with 80 mol% DOPC and 20 mol% DOPE showed 50% binding of PLIN3 (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ). 
In the presence of membranes, striking differences in deuterium exchange were observed throughout the PLIN3 sequence (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
Notably, many of the peptides with the PAT domain and 11-mer repeats displayed a bimodal distribution of deuterium exchange upon membrane binding (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] , b [this file] ). 
The protection from deuterium exchange and the non-gaussian bimodal distribution for most peptides in the PAT domain persisted over a longer time course (~300 sec) in comparison to peptides within the 11-mer repeat regions (~30 sec) (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). 
In contrast to the N-terminal PAT domain and 11-mer repeats, the C-terminal 4-helix bundle displayed a large increase in deuterium exchange (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). 
In line with of previous HDX-MS and liposome sedimentation experiments, we observed protection from H-D exchange in the PAT domain and 11-mer repeats using 4ME-PC/PE and DOPC/PE/DAG liposomes, with the magnitude and duration of H-D exchange protection in these regions correlating with the observed fraction of PLIN3 bound in liposome sedimentation assays (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] , Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] d, g [rid=Fig1] ). 
We first sought to confirm the effects of liposome binding on the secondary structure of PLIN3 by circular dichroism (CD) (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
We do however see from continuous wave (CW) ESR of 37C/114C (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ) that there might be a sizeable fraction of spins in the 15-20 Å range whose contribution to the distance distribution will be significantly attenuated since DEER has low sensitivity to distances in this range. 
Interestingly, constructs containing only the PAT domain (residues 1–116) or only the 11-mer repeats (residues 114–204), which bound to DEVs in a DAG-dependent manner, remained cytoplasmic under all conditions (Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] d, e [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
The data analysis statistics for all HDX-MS experiments are in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] according to the guidelines of .

title: Document S1. S1–S7 and Tables S1 and S2
caption: No description
description: Document  S1.  S1–S7  and  Tables  S1  and  S2
context_description:
SARS-CoV-2-reactive CD4 T cells were detected based on the upregulation of CD154 (CD40L) after 7 h stimulation of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) with overlapping peptide pools of the different proteins and subsequent magnetic enrichment (antigen-reactive T cell enrichment [ARTE]) ( Bacher et al., 2016 [rid=bib5] ; Bacher et al., 2019 [rid=bib6] ) ( Figure S1 [this file] A). SARS-CoV-2 exposure versus non-exposure of blood donors was verified by SARS-CoV-2 PCR and/or serology testing ( Tables S1 [this file] and S2 [this file] ). 
The specificity of the SARS-CoV-2-reactive cells in unexposed as well as exposed donors was confirmed by reactivity of expanded CD154 T cells toward SARS-CoV-2, but not control antigens ( Figures S1 [this file] B and S1C). 
In particular, Tfh-like, transitional, and central memory T cells showed a related profile with variable gene expression of , , , , and ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] B, S2 [this file] A, and S2B). Similar clusters were also identified in SARS-CoV-2-reactive memory T cells from unexposed individuals, and we were not able to clearly separate unexposed donors from COVID-19 patients or between patients with different disease severity only based on qualitative differences of the reactive T cells ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] C and S2 [this file] B). 
Increased expression of the acute and chronic activation markers Ki-67 and CD38 was confirmed by flow cytometry ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] D and S3 [this file] A) and declined with time after infection ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] E), in contrast to the frequencies of reactive T cells ( Figure S3 [this file] B). Relative, but especially absolute amounts of inflammatory cytokines were increased in COVID-19, such as interleukin-2 (IL-2), IFN-γ and IL-21, compared with those in unexposed individuals ( Figures S3 [this file] C and S3D). Whereas inflammatory cytokines increased with time after infection, IL-10 was mainly produced during active disease ( Figure S3 [this file] E). We observed no differences in the cytokine response or phenotype between the individual SARS-CoV-2 proteins ( Figure S4 [this file] ). 
A substantial fraction of SARS-CoV-2-reactive cells from unexposed donors but not COVID-19 patients displayed a naive phenotype, as evidenced by expression of CD45RA, CCR7, and CD27 and lack of CD45RO, CD95, and CD11a ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] A, 3B, and S5 [this file] A). 
A similar tendency was also seen for the absolute frequencies of pre-existing memory T cells among CD4 T cells ( Figure S5 [this file] B). In contrast, we detected no correlation of pre-existing T cell frequency with donor age ( Figure S5 [this file] C). A comparable correlation with the total CD4 memory compartment was observed for pre-existing CMV-reactive memory T cells from CMV-sero-negative donors ( Figure 3 [rid=fig3] E), as well as for memory T cells reactive against the neoantigen keyhole limpet hemocyanin (KLH) ( Figure S5 [this file] D). 
In line with that, CCCoV-spike-reactive T cells showed higher production of the inflammatory cytokines IFN-γ, tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α), IL-2, and IL-21 than in SARS-CoV-2-spike-reactive T cells from unexposed individuals ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] G, 4H, and S4 [this file] ). 
Only a weak correlation was observed between SARS-CoV-2 memory T cells and individual CCCoV strains ( Figure 5 [rid=fig5] D), which was similar to other common viral antigens ( Figure S6 [this file] ). 
Classification was based on World Health Organization (WHO) criteria, whereby WHO groups 3–5 (moderate) and 6–7 (severe) were combined to increase statistical power (see Table S1 [this file] ). The increased frequencies in severe disease were not due to an age bias as shown for a selected group of donors in the age range of 50–65 years ( Figures 6 [rid=fig6] B, 6C, and S7 [this file] ). 
The COVID-19 severity level was assessed on the basis of WHO criteria, whereby WHO groups 3–5 (moderate) and 6 and 7 (severe) were combined to increase statistical power (see Table S1 [this file] ). 
Peripheral EDTA blood samples were collected between April and September 2020 from 56 COVID-19 patients and from 64 in-house volunteers as unexposed controls (see Tables S1 [this file] and S2 [this file] for further details). 51 of 56 COVID-19 patients were tested positive and for SARS-CoV-2 RNA.

context_description:
Identified peptides with sequences that are found in more than one protein are identified in Table S2 in file S2 [this file] , and the corresponding proteins containing these peptides are listed in Table S3 in file S2 [this file] . 
Transcriptomic analysis indicated the upregulation of genes for tryptophan synthesis (ZMO0584-7, which forms an operon with two other genes of ZMO0582 and ZMO0583), however; when all variables were taken into consideration together the changes were less than the cutoff value of at least 2 fold (Table S7, Table S13 in file S2 [this file] ). 
We identified 942 proteins, which is about 55% of the total predicted ZM4 proteins (Table S6 in file S2 [this file]. This is the largest number of expressed proteins described for to date (Table S2, Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). 
We identified 95 differentially detected proteins based on a comparison of spectrum count values (i.e., the number of tandem mass spectra that identify tryptic peptides of a particular protein) [52] [rid=pone.0068886-Hendrickson1] , [53] [rid=pone.0068886-Zhang3] , [54] [rid=pone.0068886-Cooper1] , of which 84 had at least a 1.5-fold change and 61 had a 2-fold or higher difference ( Table 1 [rid=pone-0068886-t001] and Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). Two differentially detected proteins (ZMO0593 and ZMO0734) contain peptides that also could be assigned to other proteins; Table S3 in file S2 [this file] lists the 30 identified proteins that contain non-unique peptides. We identified 53 up-regulated proteins and 31 down-regulated proteins for the ethanol treatment at exponential phase compared to the untreated control in the same growth phase at the 1.5-fold cutoff (Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ), and these were sub-grouped by their COG (Clusters of Orthologous Groups of proteins) functional categories [60] [rid=pone.0068886-Tatusov1] separately ( Fig. 2 [rid=pone-0068886-g002] and Table S6 in file S2 [this file]. About one-third of the up-regulated proteins are within the metabolism category, and most are related to energy production/conversion, as well as nucleotide transport proteins ( Fig. 2 [rid=pone-0068886-g002] and Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). Among the 31 ethanol down-regulated proteins with at least 1.5-fold change, ribosomal proteins as well as proteins involved in flagellar synthesis and DNA replication have been shown to interact with each other ( Fig. 3A [rid=pone-0068886-g003] and Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). The 53 ethanol up-regulated proteins with at least 1.5-fold change had fewer interactions; chaperone proteins, DNA and protein repair proteins, as well as alcohol dehydrogenase and proteins involved in the ED pathway and energy metabolism showed stronger linkages than the rest of the ethanol up-regulated proteins ( Fig. 3A [rid=pone-0068886-g003] and Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). 
Among proteins with highest normalized spectrum counts, and therefore likely to be abundant [61] [rid=pone.0068886-Liu1] , were ribosomal proteins, enzymes involved in the ED pathway, and chaperones (Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). Enzymes that were abundant in both the ethanol-treated and control conditions included key enzymes such as pyruvate kinase (Pyk, ZMO0152), phosphopyruvate hydratase (Eno, ZMO1608), and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (Gap, ZMO0177); as well as proteins like chaperone DnaK (ZMO0660) and chaperonin GroEL (ZMO1929)(Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). 
In the absence of any fold-change filtering, about seventeen hundred genes were identified to be significantly differentially expressed using the ANOVA with treatment and time as variables (Table S7 in file S2 [this file] ), covering nearly all of the ZM4 genes reannotated by our group [14] [rid=pone.0068886-Yang1] indicating a dynamic gene expression for ethanol responses. 
By comparing gene expression between ethanol-treated and control cells at the same growth phase, 483 genes were significant with at least a 2-fold change (Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S8 in file S2 [this file] ). The majority of differentially expressed genes responded to the transition from exponential phase to stationary phase (Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S8 in file S2 [this file] ). Similar to proteomic data ( Table 1 [rid=pone-0068886-t001] ), ethanol treatment repressed the expression of genes related to the function of information storage and processing, with more genes associated with cellular processes being up-regulated in response to the treatment (Table S8 in file S2 [this file] ). Five genes were constitutively down-regulated with the ethanol treatment, which are a subfamily IA HAD-superfamily hydrolase (ZMO1862), Beta-fructofuranosidase (ZMO0375), exodeoxyribonuclease III Xth (ZMO1699), DNA primase (ZMO1622), and a hypothetical protein (ZMO0930) (Table S8 in file S2 [this file] ). Only two genes were constitutively ethanol upregulated, namely a putative oxidoreductase (ZMO0101) and an YceI family protein (ZMO1334) (Table S8 in file S2 [this file] ). 
With a cut-off value of at least a 2-fold change, a time series comparison identified 571 genes significantly expressed in ethanol-treated cells (Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S9 in file S2 [this file] ). 112 genes were identified to be related to ethanol stress but not growth phase (Table S10 in file S2 [this file] ). The time series gene expression of ethanol-treated cells had a different pattern of functional categories from the treatment versus control comparison, with more genes related to cellular processes down-regulated and more genes associated with metabolism and information storage and processing up-regulated (Table S10 in file S2 [this file] ). 
Thirty-four genes were identified to be ethanol-induced in both the comparison of ethanol-treated to control and time series ethanol responsive genes (Table S11 in file S2 [this file] ). In addition, responded to ethanol stress primarily by repressing the gene expression at an early stage such as the exponential phase treatment and control comparison and the time-series study of the treated-cells from 6 h to 10 h (Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] ; Table S9, Table S10 in file S2 [this file] ). For example, 32 genes were down-regulated comparing the treated to the control cells during the exponential phase, which was twice as many as the up-regulated ones (Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S9 in file S2 [this file] ). Time series studies of the ethanol-treated cells’ response from 6 h to 10 h also identified 19 genes down-regulated compared to 2 up-regulated ones only (Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S10 in file S2 [this file] ). 
Among the twelve hopanoid biosynthesis proteins identified by proteomic study, none were significantly different between the treatment and control conditions (Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). 
Nine hundred and twenty five proteins identified by proteomic study also yielded corresponding gene-expression data, which formed 925 gene-protein pairs (Table S6, Table S7 in file S2 [this file] ). At the same exponential phase as used in the proteomic study, 500 genes were found to be significantly expressed based on JMP Genomics analysis out of the total 925 genes from all the conditions (Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). The number of significantly expressed genes was more than that of the 95 significantly expressed proteins by the G-test analysis ( Table 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ), which is likely due to technical differences between the proteomic and transcriptomic techniques and analyses. Only one protein out of the 95 significantly expressed proteins had no corresponding gene expression data, and there is a correlation coefficient R-squared value (R ) of 0.33 between these 94 gene-protein pairs ( Table 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [rid=pone.0068886.s005] , Table S6 in file S2 [this file] ). 
We identified nine examples where gene expression and protein levels changed in opposite directions, likely pointing to differences in regulation between transcripts and proteins (Table S12 in file S2 [this file] ). Other example includes six genes such as heat shock protein DnaJ domain-containing gene (ZMO1690), protease ClpA gene (ZMO0405), short-chain dehydrogenase/reductase SDR gene (ZMO0318), alcohol dehydrogenase (ZMO1236) etc., which had a reduced gene expression (ca 1.6-fold to more than 2-fold change) but an increased protein expression (ca 1.6- to more than 8-fold change) levels with the ethanol treatment (Table S12 in file S2 [this file] ). 
The new operon predictions consist of 366 multi-gene transcripts and 651 single-gene transcripts (Table S13 in file S2 [this file] ). 
Differences between ethanol-treated cells and control cells were largely due to growth differences (Table S7 in file S2 [this file] ). 
In this study, we updated operon predictions for and this may aid future metabolic engineering endeavors (Table S13 in file S2 [this file] ), just as a prior study joined two genes into the gene for increased tolerance to sodium acetate when over-expressed [22] [rid=pone.0068886-Yang2] .

context_description: HPLC was used to quantify and compare glucose consumption and the kinetics of ethanol, lactate, and acetate production either with or without added ethanol. consumed glucose more slowly with ethanol supplementation; more than 71% of the initial glucose was not utilized by at 10 h post-inoculation, and an additional 4.5 h was needed to fully utilize the remaining glucose ( Fig. 1 [rid=pone-0068886-g001] ; file S3 [this file] ). In contrast, only 2.9% of the initial glucose concentration (98 mM or 0.053 g/L) remained at 10 h post-inoculation in the absence of added ethanol ( Fig. 1 [rid=pone-0068886-g001] ; file S3 [this file] ). ethanol production was correlated with substrate (glucose) consumption. Where growth was reduced with supplemental ethanol, slower ethanol production was seen compared to control cells ( Fig. 1 [rid=pone-0068886-g001] ; file S3 [this file] ). In addition, ethanol-treated had a reduced net ethanol production with a highest net ethanol production of 6.1 g/L compared to that of 8.3 g/L for control cells ( Fig. 1 [rid=pone-0068886-g001] ; file S3 [this file] ). The majority of lactate was produced after exponential growth and in contrast with ethanol and acetate production, lactate production in ethanol-treated increased about one-fifth to 0.046±0.001 g/L after 14.5 h post inoculation compared to that of control, and remained relatively steady through the end of the experiment ( file S3 [this file] ).

context_description:
Metabolite identification and analysis gave 45 metabolites that were present at different abundance levels between with and without ethanol treatment ( file S4 [this file] ). Fewer metabolites had at least a 1.5-fold or greater change during exponential phase growth compared to that of earlier stationary or stationary phase comparisons ( file S4 [this file] ). 
In this study, we identified several metabolites related to lipid metabolism, such as glyceric acid, palmitic acid, and stearic acid, which were present at elevated levels in the ethanol-stressed compared to those of the control cells at 10 h but not at other sampling points ( file S4 [this file] ). They accumulated in the early stationary phase in response to ethanol treatment, but treatment differences were again absent in the stationary phase, although the relative amount of fatty acids was only a small fraction of the total metabolites identified ( file S4 [this file] ). 
Based on our results ( file S4 [this file] ) and previous studies, we investigated whether or not the supplementation of glycerol or tryptophan in the fermentation media could improve ethanol tolerance.

Treatment  arrays  are  shown  in  red  and  control  arrays  are  colored  blue.  Fig.  S5:  Flowchart  of  metabolite,  protein,  and  gene  numbers  .  The  among  metabolome  (light  yellow  boxes),  proteome  (pale  blue  boxes),  transcriptome  (pink  box)  of  ethanol  treatment  versus  control  (rose  boxes)  or  time  course  studies  of  ethanol-treated  cells  (purple  boxes)  and  control  cells(grey  boxes),  and  different  comparisons  used  in  this  study  to  investigate  their  connections.  The  boxes  drawn  with  dashed  lines  indicate  the  comparison  across  different  omics  platforms  of  metabolomics,  proteomics  and  transcriptomics.  Samples  were  taken  at  6,  10,  13.5  or  26  h  post-inoculation.  Three  phase  comparisons  of  ethanol  treated  versus  control  cells  at  exponential  phase  (  EP  ),  early  stationary  phase  (  ESP  )  and  late  stationary  phase  (  LSP  )  for  metabolomic  and  transcriptomic  studies  as  well  as  an  exponential  phase  proteomic  comparison  study  were  conducted.  SM  :  significant  metabolites;  SM1.5  :  significant  metabolites  with  at  least  1.5-fold  changes;  SM2.0  :  significant  metabolites  with  at  least  2-fold  changes;  P  :  all  the  proteins  identified  from  proteomics;  SP  :  proteins  with  significant  changes  based  on  G-test  result;  SP1.5  :  significant  proteins  with  at  least  1.5-fold  changes;  SP2.0  :  significant  proteins  with  at  least  2-fold  changes;  A  :  all  the  genes  identified  from  transcriptomics;  SA  :  significant  genes  identified  from  transcriptomics;  SA1.5  :  significant  genes  with  at  least  1.5-fold  changes;  SA2.0  :  significant  genes  with  at  least  2-fold  changes.  The  numbers  after  above  symbols  are  the  total  number  identified,  and  the  numbers  underneath  the  symbols  are  ethanol  up-regulated  with  red  font  followed  by  ethanol  down-regulated  with  blue  font.  The  arrows  indicate  connection  between  each  omics  comparison,  the  orientation  of  arrow  indicates  the  comparison  direction.  (DOCX)  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
The growth of supplemented with 0, 16, 32, 47, 63, 79, 95 or 118 g/L ethanol was assessed using a Bioscreen C instrument under anaerobic conditions to determine an appropriate ethanol concentration for systems biology studies. growth was arrested when ethanol was added to the medium at or above 79 g/L, and minor differences were observed between untreated control cultures and where ethanol was added at concentrations of 16 and 32 g/L (Fig. S1 in file S5 [this file] ). showed intermediate growth rate decreases when rich medium (RM) cultures were amended with 47 g/L (6% v/v) ethanol, and cultures treated with this concentration of ethanol attained final cell densities similar to untreated control cultures (Fig. S1 in file S5 [this file] ). 
While the addition of supplemental tryptophan did not appear to have an effect on ethanol tolerance (data not shown), medium supplementation with glycerol at low concentrations (0.001%) improved growth marginally as it entered stationary phase under ethanol stress conditions on a consistent basis but not at levels considered significant in this study (Fig. S2 in file S5 [this file] ). 
The isoelectric point and molecular mass distributions for the identified proteins were similar to the corresponding distributions for all proteins in the revised genome annotation of[14] [rid=pone.0068886-Yang1] (Fig. S3 in file S5 [this file] ). 
The correlation coefficients for microarray data from biological replicates were good, with r >0.98 for each comparison (Fig. S4A in file S5 [this file] ). In addition, the microarray data of biological replicates were also grouped together closely based on the hierarchical clustering and principal components analyses (Fig. S4B–C in file S5 [this file] ), and that data can be grouped or separated as time points advance through the experiment and also by treatment before the application of the ANOVA testing. 
Two comparisons were then carried out to identify the ethanol-responsive genes, by comparing the significant genes between the ethanol-treated cells and the control cells at different growth phases, as well as by comparing the time series of differentially expressed genes within ethanol-treated cells (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] ). Differentially expressed genes identified from both the treatment versus control study and the ethanol-treatment time series study but not from the control time series study were regarded as ethanol-responsive genes (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] ). 
By comparing gene expression between ethanol-treated and control cells at the same growth phase, 483 genes were significant with at least a 2-fold change (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S8 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). The majority of differentially expressed genes responded to the transition from exponential phase to stationary phase (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S8 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). 
With a cut-off value of at least a 2-fold change, a time series comparison identified 571 genes significantly expressed in ethanol-treated cells (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S9 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). 112 genes were identified to be related to ethanol stress but not growth phase (Table S10 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). 
In addition, responded to ethanol stress primarily by repressing the gene expression at an early stage such as the exponential phase treatment and control comparison and the time-series study of the treated-cells from 6 h to 10 h (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] ; Table S9, Table S10 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). For example, 32 genes were down-regulated comparing the treated to the control cells during the exponential phase, which was twice as many as the up-regulated ones (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S9 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). Time series studies of the ethanol-treated cells’ response from 6 h to 10 h also identified 19 genes down-regulated compared to 2 up-regulated ones only (Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S10 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). 
The number of significantly expressed genes was more than that of the 95 significantly expressed proteins by the G-test analysis ( Table 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S6 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ), which is likely due to technical differences between the proteomic and transcriptomic techniques and analyses. Only one protein out of the 95 significantly expressed proteins had no corresponding gene expression data, and there is a correlation coefficient R-squared value (R ) of 0.33 between these 94 gene-protein pairs ( Table 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] , Table S6 in file S2 [rid=pone.0068886.s002] ). We can also see a better correlation between proteomic and transcriptomic data for the significantly differentially expressed gene-protein pairs with increasing gene expression differences ( Table 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] ). For example, when we selected the significantly expressed proteins with at least 1.5 or 2-fold change and then compared their correlations to their corresponding genes with significant gene expression, the R values are 0.49 (49 protein-gene pairs) or 0.50 (40 protein-gene pairs) respectively ( Table 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] ). 
In growth studies the addition of glycerol to the medium appeared to have a marginal effect on ethanol stress (Fig. S2 in file S5 [this file] ). 
We observe better correlations between proteomic and transcriptomic data for the significantly differentially expressed gene-protein pairs with increasing gene expression differences ( Table 1 [rid=pone-0068886-t001] , 2 [rid=pone-0068886-t002] , Fig. S5 in file S5 [this file] ).

context_description:
Transgenic plants that rescued the phenotype were selected, and the expression of the GI‐3F6H protein was verified by western blotting (as in Fig. S1 [this file] ; Methods S1 [rid=feb213311-sup-0002] ). 
Two microgram of total RNA was reverse‐transcribed using the iScript cDNA synthesis kit (Bio‐Rad, Hercules, CA, USA) according to the manufacturer's instructions. cDNA was diluted five times with water, and 2 μL was used as a template for quantitative PCR (qPCR) analysis using primers as shown in Table S1 [this file] . ( ) was used as an internal control for normalization. 
For export, an ion‐cutoff of 20 was chosen (exported peptide measurements: Data S9 [this file] ). Technical outliers were identified using correlation analysis and principal component analysis (PCA) of protein abundance data implemented by an R script (Data S5 [this file] ). The average Pearson correlation coefficient of each GI‐TAP replicate with the other replicates of the same time point was above 95% for all GI‐3F6H samples apart from sample 19E (Fig. S2 [this file] ), which was also clearly separated from all other samples by PCA and was therefore discarded. 
A custom R script performed further statistical analysis and plotting (Data S7 [this file] ). To assess rhythmicity, we used the JTK_CYCLE tool 53 [rid=feb213311-bib-0053] to analyze periods of 22–26 h (Data S8 [this file] ). Gene ontology (GO) analysis was performed using ( http://bioconductor.org/biocLite.R (http://bioconductor.org/biocLite.R) , version: 2.16.0, 55 [rid=feb213311-bib-0055] , 56 [rid=feb213311-bib-0056] , using a node size of 3, as described by 57 [rid=feb213311-bib-0057] (Data S6 [this file] ). 
Full‐length coding sequence was PCR‐amplified using cDNA as template with primers shown in Table S1 [this file] , cloned into pENTR/D‐TOPO (Invitrogen) and sequence‐verified. 
As a first experiment, we performed a preliminary study where we used TAP of GI‐3F6H followed by silver‐staining of a protein gel separation and LC‐MS of excised gel bands (Fig. 1 [rid=feb213311-fig-0001] F, Fig. S1 [this file] , Data S1 [this file] ). Our GI‐3F6H line expressed sufficient GI protein for effective TAP and analysis of gel bands by MS identified GI and known interactors (Fig. S1 [this file] , Data S1 [this file] ). 
In order to exclude known nonspecific interactors, we eliminated all proteins from our list that were previously reported to be purified by GFP‐3F6H with the same sample preparation protocol 48 [rid=feb213311-bib-0048] (Data S3 [this file] ). Therefore, we also excluded proteins from further analyses that are located in the chloroplast or mitochondria but not in the cytoplasm or nucleus according to their GO annotation 63 [rid=feb213311-bib-0063] (Table 1 [rid=feb213311-tbl-0001] ; full results in Data S2 [this file] ). 
After identification and quantification of proteins (Fig. 2 [rid=feb213311-fig-0002] C), one outlier (GI‐3F6H sample at ZT19, replicate E) was excluded from subsequent analysis (see Experimental Procedures; Fig. S2 [this file] ). 
In order to exclude known unspecific interactors, we used the same strategy as for the qualitative study, eliminating 80 proteins previously purified by GFP‐3F6H 48 [rid=feb213311-bib-0048] and 169 chloroplast and mitochondrial proteins 63 [rid=feb213311-bib-0063] (Data S3 [this file] , S4 [this file] and S6 [this file] ). Subsequent analysis used raw abundance data exported from Progenesis as opposed to the abundance which is normalized by the sum of all intensities of ions with the chosen inclusion criteria (see Materials and methods [rid=feb213311-sec-0003] ) in each mass spectrometric analysis; however, analysis of normalized data gave very similar results (data not shown and Data S3 [this file] ). 
The raw data of the Progenesis output file and the raw data after removing likely unspecific proteins (GFP interacting proteins 48 [rid=feb213311-bib-0048] ) and plastid or mitochondrial proteins, (see Data S3 [this file] ) was used for statistics 
Among these 88 proteins, 13 changed significantly in abundance within the time series (assessed for any change by ANOVA, ‐value < 0.05) or 10 as assessed for rhythmic profiles (by JTK_CYCLE ‐value < 0.05; Table 2 [rid=feb213311-tbl-0002] and Data S3 [this file] ; Data S8 [this file] ). 
GO terms related to protein degradation were overrepresented among the candidates, as well as light response related terms, some metabolic processes, and flower development (Data S4 [this file] and S6 [this file] ). 
The direct interactors FKF1, ZTL, and LKP2 showed temporal profiles consistent with their mRNA expression patterns 65 [rid=feb213311-bib-0065] , 66 [rid=feb213311-bib-0066] , 67 [rid=feb213311-bib-0067] , 68 [rid=feb213311-bib-0068] (Fig. S3 [this file] ). 
The abundant, plastid‐localized proteins enriched as interactors (Data S3 [this file] and S4 [this file] ) likely reflect unspecific binding, at least in the case of chloroplast‐encoded proteins, which was an expected cost of detecting low‐abundance and indirect interactors. Conservatively, we excluded mitochondrial and chloroplast proteins (see Materials and methods [rid=feb213311-sec-0003] ; Data S3 [this file] ) from the candidate interactors (Tables 1 [rid=feb213311-tbl-0001] and 3 [rid=feb213311-tbl-0003] ).

context_description:
Compared to OTCD and ASSD, patients with ASLD had significantly higher mean plasma concentrations of metabolites contributing to glutathione biosynthesis: homocysteine ( Figure 1B [rid=F1] ) and glycine ( Figure S1A [this file] ). Plasma concentrations of glutamate, another precursor metabolite of glutathione, was not increased ( Figure S1B [this file] ). Plasma total homocysteine did not differ between early- and late-onset ASA ( Figure S1C [this file] ). Since follow-up, total plasma homocysteine ( Figure S1D [this file] ), glycine ( Figure S1E [this file] ) and glutamate ( Figure S1F [this file] ) concentrations remained significantly elevated for all patients with ASLD compared to those with OTCD and ASSD. 
No sex difference was observed for plasma homocysteine and glycine ( Table S1 [this file] ). Glutamate concentrations, however, were significantly elevated in females with OTCD and ASLD compared to males ( Table S1 [this file] ). Clinical information regarding these patients with OTCD, ASSD, and ASLD are presented in Table S2 [this file] . No vitamin B12 deficiency was observed in the patients ( Figure S1G [this file] ). 
Corroborating human data, plasma total ( Figure 1C [rid=F1] ) and free ( Figure S2A [this file] ) homocysteine concentrations in 2-week-old mice were significantly elevated compared to WT littermates. Other plasma metabolites of the glutathione biosynthesis pathway, total ( Figure 1D [rid=F1] ) and free ( Figure S2B [this file] ) cysteine were also significantly increased in mice compared to WT. Total -glutamyl-cysteine ( Figure 1E [rid=F1] ) and free -glutamyl-cysteine ( Figure S2C [this file] ) showed no difference. Similar to plasma, liver concentrations of total ( Figure 1G [rid=F1] ) and free ( Figure S2D [this file] ) homocysteine, total ( Figure 1H [rid=F1] ) and free ( Figure S2E [this file] ) cysteine, and total -glutamyl-cysteine ( Figure 1I [rid=F1] ) showed a significant increase in mice compared to WT. Liver free -glutamyl-cysteine ( Figure S2F [this file] ) showed no difference. 
GGT activity and expression in liver showed a significant 5-fold increase in mice compared to WT ( Figure 1K [rid=F1] and Figure S2G [this file] ). Total cysteine-glycine synthesised from glutathione catabolism by GGT was also increased in liver ( Figure S2H [this file] ), although free cysteine-glycine was unchanged ( Figure S2I [this file] ). mice ( 4 [rid=R4] ) and patients with ASA ( 26 [rid=R26] , 27 [rid=R27] ) may present chronic kidney disease and renal failure. Supporting this, urine glutathione concentrations were significantly increased in mice compared to WT, suggesting defective renal glutathione reabsorption ( Figure S2J [this file] ). Urine cysteine concentrations were also significantly increased in mice compared to WT ( Figures S2K [this file] ), in line with an elevation of these metabolites in the plasma and livers, a consequence which is partially explained by increased GGT activity. Urine cysteine-glycine concentrations, however, were not significantly increased ( Figure S2L [this file] ). 
Here the liver GSH:GSSG ratio did not differ between and WT littermates ( Figure S2M [this file] ), indicating that the reduction of total glutathione pool in mice was not associated with increased glutathione oxidation. 
The steady-state concentration of the oxidative breakdown products of NO, nitrite (NO ) and nitrate (NO ), were significantly lower in plasma ( Figure S2N [this file] ) and liver ( Figure 1M [rid=F1] ), as previously reported in this disorder ( 4 [rid=R4] , 5 [rid=R5] ). Nitroso-species showed no difference between livers versus WT, and did not support NO deficiency as a critical pathophysiological mechanism in the liver ( Figure S2O [this file] ). The lack of difference in nitrotyrosine concentrations by western blot in livers versus WT confirmed the absence of nitro-oxidative stress ( Figure 1N [rid=F1] , Figure S2P [this file] ). Nrf2 protein abundances did not differ between WT and livers ( Figure S2Q [this file] ). 
Supporting this, untargeted proteomics comparing WT and livers highlighted glutathione function as downregulated ( Figure 1R [rid=F1] , Figure S3A-C [this file] ). 
Conversely, it was challenging to distinguish between pancreatic and liver [ F]FSPG retention in mice ( Figures 2B, 2C [rid=F2] , Figure S4A [this file] ). High [ F]FSPG retention was also present in the skin of mice (13 ± 1.8% ID/g) which was not the case in WT littermates (5.3 ± 2.3% ID/g; Figure 2B, 2E [rid=F2] ; =0.002; Figure S4B [this file] ). 
S5A, B [this file] ) and activity ( fig. S5C [this file] ) in ASL-deficient fibroblasts from patients with ASA compared to a mRNA control lipid nanoparticle. mRNA therapy has transient efficacy and requires re-administration to enable a sustained effect. No effect on arginine concentrations was observed ( Figure S6A [this file] ). Western blot and immunohistochemistry data in liver showed restored ASL protein abundance at physiological levels at 24h post-administration of mRNA ( Figures 3F-I [rid=F3] , Figure S6B-D [this file] ). 
This twice higher dose was based on liver biodistribution between IV and IP routes, which showed that a two-fold higher IP dose has a similar liver biodistribution as a single IV dose ( Figures S7A, 7B [this file] ). The macroscopic phenotype of mice was restored to that of WT littermates in the mRNA treatment group, with normalisation of survival ( Figure 4B [rid=F4] , =0.002), growth ( Figure 4C [rid=F4] , Figure S8A [this file] ), fur ( Figure 4D [rid=F4] ), and hepatomegaly ( Figure S8B [this file] ). 
No significant differences in arginine concentrations in dried blood spots between WT or mRNA- or mRNA-treated mice were observed ( Figure S8C [this file] ). Elevated plasma amino transferase (ALT) was normalized in the mRNA-treated mice ( Figure S8D [this file] ). Longitudinal analysis of plasma ammonia ( Figure S8E [this file] ), argininosuccinic acid, ( Figure S8F [this file] ), and citrulline ( Figure S8G [this file] ) concentrations in dried blood spots, and urinary orotate concentrations ( Figure S8H [this file] ) in mRNA-treated mice showed sustained therapeutic benefit over time. Gender analysis showed that there were no sex-related differences in the different efficacy endpoints in the mRNA-treated group ( Table S3 [this file] ). 
In contrast, mRNA-treated mice only survived up to day 37 of life, with most animals dying before day 30 ( Figure 5B [rid=F5] , =0.002). mRNA-treated mice showed significantly improved growth compared to mRNA littermates, however the body weight remained significantly lower than WT littermates ( Figure 5C [rid=F5] , Figure S9A [this file] ). Liver to body weight ratio remained significantly elevated in both treated mice groups ( Figure S9B [this file] ). There were no significant differences in arginine concentrations between WT, mRNA and mRNA-treated groups ( Figure S9C [this file] ). ALT concentrations indicated an absence of liver toxicity in the mRNA-treated mice compared to WT littermates ( Figure S9D [this file] ). Gender analysis could not determine any sex differences between the different efficacy endpoints in the mRNA-treated group ( Figure S10 and Table S4 [this file] ). 
Supporting our functional and metabolic data, [ F]FSPG retention was halved in mRNA-treated (11 ± 2.0% ID/g) versus untreated mice (22 ± 2.3% ID/g; = 0.026; Figure 6A, 6B [rid=F6] , Figure S11A [this file] ). Conversely, skin [ F]FSPG retention was not affected by mRNA therapy. [ F]FSPG skin retention was 4.2 ± 3.4% ID/g in WT mice, compared to 15 ± 3.7% ID/g and 15 ± 4.2% ID/g in untreated and mRNA treated mice, respectively ( Figures S11B, S11C [this file] ). 
No pathway correlation was observed between these genes, which had different localisation and function ( Table S5 [this file] ). 
This suggests that the normalisation of ASL expression corrects hepatic glutathione metabolism by restoring the NO availability and thereby GCL upregulation ( Figure S12 [this file] ). 
All statistical results for figures 1 [rid=F1] - 7 [rid=F7] are summarised in table S6A-G [this file] .
pub_title: mRNA therapy corrects defective glutathione metabolism and restores ureagenesis in preclinical argininosuccinic aciduria

RASSF1C oncogene elicits amoeboid invasion, cancer stemness, and extracellular vesicle release via a SRC/Rho axis
RASSF1C oncogene elicits amoeboid invasion, cancer stemness, and extracellular vesicle release via a SRC/Rho axis

title: No Title
caption: Appendix
description: Appendix  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
We observed that ZsRASSF1C‐expressing cells grown on 2D surface displayed a progressive decrease of diameter within 12 h of expression of the construct compared to control (Fig 1A [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] , Appendix Fig S1 [this file] A, Movie EV1 [rid=embj2021107680-sup-0003] ). We observed increased numbers of RASSF1C‐expressing cells that exhibited rounded morphology in 3D collagen matrix in mesenchymal (MDA‐MB‐231) (Fig 1B [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] , bottom) and also in epithelial (MCF7 from 80% of epithelial‐polygonal to 85% rounded morphology and H1299 from 81% epithelial‐polygonal to 88% rounded shape) cell lines (Fig 1B [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] top, Appendix Fig S1 [this file] B and C), suggesting that RASSF1C may be involved not only in mesenchymal‐amoeboid but also in epithelial‐amoeboid transition (EAT). However, while control cells maintained a typically elongated, fibroblast‐like, shape, cells transfected with RASSF1C showed rounded morphology (Appendix Fig S1 [this file] D). 
We detected increased activity of MMP‐9 metalloprotease in control MDA‐MB‐231 cells compared to cells expressing RASSF1C (Fig 1E [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] , Appendix Fig S1 [this file] E for quantification). To further investigate this, we performed an invasion assay using hydrogel matrix, which is not degradable by metalloproteases (Fig 1F [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] , right bar graph, and Appendix Fig S1 [this file] F). Using ROCK (Y27632) and Rho (C3) inhibitors, we could demonstrate that Matrigel invasion by ZsRASSF1C‐expressing MDA‐MB‐231 cells was greatly impaired by both inhibitors, thus demonstrating Rho/ROCK dependency (Fig 1G [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] and Appendix Fig S1 [this file] G). However, the treatment of control cells with both drugs resulted in no effect on their ability to invade (Fig 1G [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] and Appendix Fig S1 [this file] G). To further support Rho/ROCK dependency, we could show that expression of ZsRASSF1C and a dominant‐negative RhoA derivative (RhoA‐DN) suppressed ZsRASSF1C‐driven invasion in both MDA‐MB‐231 and MCF7, while a catalytically active RhoA derivative (RhoA‐CA) enhanced invasion upon RASSF1C expression (Appendix Fig S1 [this file] H and I). 
Previously used RhoA and RASSF1C constructs (Appendix Fig S1 [this file] H, Fig 2 [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0002] F–H) were expressed in MDA‐MB‐231 cells and EVs were isolated as described before. 
At higher doses (40 ng/μl, Appendix Fig S2 [this file] A), EVs derived from control cells were able to promote recipient cell migration at similar rates to EVs derived from RASSF1C or RhoA. 
Strikingly, the number of invaded cells was significantly higher when cells were treated with 20 ng/μl of RASSF1C or RhoA EVs, compared to control EVs and untreated cells (Fig 3F [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0003] , Appendix Fig S2 [this file] B for a comparison of both concentrations). 
To further establish whether the small EVs population is mediating the invasive phenotype observed in the small EV fraction recovered from ultracentrifugation (Fig 3G [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0003] ), we employed a Tangential Flow Filtration/Size Exclusion Chromatography isolation protocol and incubated recipient cells with RASSF1C or control small EVs (Appendix Fig S2 [this file] C). EVs displayed protein markers already detected with the ultracentrifugation protocol (Appendix Fig S2 [this file] C, left) and NTA showed similar particle number between RASSF1C and control EVs, with this isolation method (Appendix Fig S2 [this file] C, middle). Importantly, RASSF1C small EVs still induced a significantly higher number of recipient cells to invade the Matrigel membrane, compared to control small EVs (Appendix Fig S2 [this file] C, right). 
It is important to note that, throughout our study, the treatment of recipient cells with MDA‐MB‐231 derived control EVs (expressing a control vector) already induced an increase in cell migration or invasion, compared to untreated cells (Fig 3 [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0003] E–G, Appendix Fig S2 [this file] C). 
Individual CpG site analysis allows separation of epigenetic silencing at from and therefore study of the differential contribution of the tumor suppressor RASSF1A from the oncogenic RASSF1C isoform to disease progression (Fig 6A [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0006] , Appendix Fig S3 [this file] A). 
In general, breast cancer patients that were alive at follow‐up had lower median methylation of , in agreement with the tumor suppressor role of RASSF1A, than those stages I and II patients that had died of breast cancer (Appendix Fig S3 [this file] B). In line with our data supporting a pro‐oncogenic role for RASSF1C, deceased patients had lower median methylation of , implying that expression from this promoter was active in these tumors (Appendix Fig S3 [this file] B). Intriguingly, increased methylation of (reduced RASSF1A expression) has greater significance in stage I tumors ( = 0.000001), whereas reduced methylation (increased RASSF1C expression) has more prognostic influence in late‐stage tumors ( = 7 × 10 Mann–Whitney) (Appendix Fig S3 [this file] B table). This indicates that patients with RASSF1C‐expressing tumors were at over 6‐fold higher risk of death than patients likely to express RASSF1A ( = 0.02, Appendix Fig S3 [this file] C). 
RASSF1C‐driven pathway activation leads to morphological changes in mesenchymal and epithelial cells (Fig 1 [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] A and B) that can be referred to as mesenchymal and epithelial to amoeboid transition, resulting in cytoskeleton reorganization, higher cell invasion (Fig 1 [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] C,F,G, Appendix Fig S1 [this file] F–I) and dissemination (Fig 1I [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0001] ). 
RASSF1C‐derived EVs fall in the small EVs category (Fig 3B [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0003] , Appendix Fig S2 [this file] C), and their secretion appears to be sustained by RhoA (Fig 3 [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0003] D,F,G). 
Furthermore, we highlight the relevance of the described biological mechanisms by providing a direct clinical correlation between methylation pattern and survival in breast cancer patients (Fig 6C [rid=embj2021107680-fig-0006] , Appendix Fig S3 [this file] C).
pub_title: RASSF1C oncogene elicits amoeboid invasion, cancer stemness, and extracellular vesicle release via a SRC/Rho axis

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Cerebral organoids were generated from human iPSCs according to the protocol described by Lancaster et al. with some minor modifications (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). Two of the three iPSC lines used for the organoid cultures have previously been described by us (iPSC 1, 3) and iPSC 5 was similarly generated and characterized (Supplementary Fig. 1a–h [this file] ; Table 1 [rid=Tab1] ). The presence of neuronal architecture and of astrocytes was confirmed by using a range of markers at day 31 (Supplementary Fig. 1i–p [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] , 2 [this file] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
The fraction IBA-1 cells within organoids showed limited variation between batches, timepoints, and donors (Supplementary Fig. 2a–c [this file] ), and microglia quantity was positively correlated with TUJ1 expression (Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] ). Furthermore, microglia-containing organoids demonstrated proper neuronal development and cortical layer organization, based on expression of NEUN, PAX6, CTIP2, and TBR1 (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). 
At this timepoint a clear increase in expression of other classical microglia markers was observed, i.e., IBA-1 CD11b (Fig. 2a [rid=Fig2] ), , , and CD45 (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] . , Double immunostainings of IBA-1 combined with nuclear PU.1 ( ) and CD68 ( ) at day 52. 
Inter-donor variability was small (oMG = 0.91 ± 0.001) when examined with Spearman correlation coefficients (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). Unsupervised hierarchical clustering shows that oMG clustered separately from adult microglia (adult MG1) (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). When comparing the data with the original iPSC lines and fibroblasts from the same donors, unsupervised hierarchical clustering, Spearman correlation coefficients, and principal component analyses (PCA) (Fig. 3a, b [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ) showed that both at day 38 and day 52 oMG closely resemble adult MG1. 
See also Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] , and Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM3] and 2 [rid=MOESM4] 
Despite this clustering, Spearman correlation coefficients showed that the transcriptomic profiles of all microglia and microglia-like cells were relatively similar ( = 0.7 ± 0.07) (Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] ). The Spearman correlation analyses of the transcriptomes of oMG day 52, adult MG1, iPSC MG and fetal MG by using microglia-specific transcription factors (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ) showed a strong correlation between iPSC MG and fetal MG ( = 0.96), whereas transcription factor profiles of oMG correlated most with those of adult MG1 ( = 0.8). The correlation between adult MG1 and fetal MG was low ( = 0.37) in this analysis (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ). 
To further analyze differences in gene expression between oMG and adult MG, we analyzed transcriptomic differences between day oMG and adult MG1 (Supplementary Fig. 4f–h [this file] ). Sample variability and size resulted in high Log2fold changes and therefore shrinkage correction was performed. 1220 genes remained that were significantly upregulated in oMG day 52 and 1271 genes in MG1 (FDR < 0.05) whereas 2400 genes were significantly upregulated in oMG at day 38 and 2070 in adult MG1 (Supplementary Fig. 4i, j [this file] ). 
The transcriptomes of day 38 and day 52 oMG were most similar with 2160 differentially expressed genes (Supplementary Fig. 4k [this file] , FDR < 0.05). 
Indeed, postsynaptic responses to presynaptic release of glutamate were detected at day 52 as evidenced by spontaneous excitatory postsynaptic currents (sEPSCs) (Supplementary Fig. 1q [this file] ). Further, voltage-dependent sodium channels were present as inward currents were registered in response to evoked increases in membrane potential (Supplementary Fig. 1r, s [this file] ). 
Organoids were differentiated using a modified version of a previously published protocol (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) . 
Cells were sorted/gated that were alive, single, and CD11b /CD45 with the FACSAria III (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). The mean percentage of CD11b /CD45 cells of iPSC donors 1, 3, and 5 was 0.83% ± 0.3 at both timepoints for oMG (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ). 
Absolute levels of expression were determined (2 ) and normalized with the geomean of two reference genes and (see primer sequences in Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
Sorting efficiency was confirmed by assessing the expression of specific microglia- and non-microglia-related genes in three batches of oMG 1 and adult MG1 (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). 
See Supplementary Table 4 [this file] for antibodies used in this study. 
A macro in FIJI was created with the following steps: background subtraction (rollingbal set to 10 (hoechst) or 78 (TUJ1, IBA-1) pixels; contrast was automatically enhanced; automated default threshold applied; particles were quantified with size of > 5 (hoechst) or > 10 (TUJ1, IBA-1) pixels; positive area was summarized; TUJ1 and IBA-1 was normalized by dividing the positive area by the hoechst positive nuclear area (Supplementary Fig. 2a, b, d [this file] ). 
A panel of microglia markers was selected based on literature (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
Protein expression was measured in cells that were gated to be alive, single, and CD11b (Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] ). 
The voltage-dependent sodium currents were activated with depolarizing voltage steps with duration of 100 ms starting from –60 mV with increments of 10 mV to + 40 mV (Supplementary Fig. S2E [this file] ).

GO-pathway analysis on all DEGs did not show any significantly enriched pathways in adult MG1 vs. oMG, whereas oMG showed enrichment for “collagen catabolic process”, “extracellular matrix organization”, “negative chemotaxis”, “positive regulation of synapse assembly”, and “endodermal cell differentiation” compared to adult MG1 (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). Myeloid function-related terms were detected by GO-pathway analysis of common genes (between adult MG1 and day 52 oMG), such as “nervous system development”, “interleukin-12-mediated signaling pathway”, and “neutrophil degranulation” (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). 
Several development-related terms were shared between day 38 and day 52 oMG, such as “nervous system development”, “neutrophil degranulation”, “cell adhesion”, and “receptor internalization” (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ).

Column  headings  are  as  follows:  A:  contig_name;  B:  Operon  ID  (probe  identification  of  the  manufacturer);  C:  oligo  sequence;  D:  Annotation  source  (sequences  used  to  identify  the  best  TAIR  10  BLAST  HIT.  "Original  contig"  means  that  the  sequence  used  comes  from  the  older  database,  while  "454"  indicates  that  a  new  sequence,  longer  than  the  original  one,  has  been  used);  E:  source  ID  (database  from  which  sequences  used  for  the  annotation.  Nucleotide  sequences  are  available  as  additional  file  7  ("454")  and  8  ("Original  contigs");  F:  TAIR  10  best  hit  (against  μPEACH1.0  transcripts);  G:  Sequence  description  (annotation  of  the  TAIR  10  best  hit);  H:  μPEACH1.0  original  annotation;  I  to  P:  mean  and  standard  deviation  of  the  mean  of  normalized  signal  values  in  the  different  comparisons  (ES/EM,  LS/LM,  LS/ES,  LM/EM);  Q  and  R:  tags  for  the  identification  of  genes  included  in  the  Venn  diagrams  (Figure  2);  S:  probes  positive  to  SAM  in  all  4  comparisons.  From  column  T  to  AA:  genes  involved  in  hormone  metabolism  and  signaling  for  auxin,  CKs,  GAs,  ABA,  ethylene,  jasmonate,  salicylate  and  brassinosteroids  are  marked. context_description:
The microarray expression data (see Additional file 1 [this file] ), validated by means of qRT-PCR on 29 randomly selected genes, showed a Pearson correlation coefficient ranging, in the four comparisons, from 0.79 to 0.84 (see Additional file 2 [rid=S2] ). 
Annotations of genes included in Figure 2 [rid=F2] are reported with microarray expression data in Additional file 1 [this file] . 
The letters inside the sectors are tags for the identification of the genes listed in Additional file 1 [this file] . 
Among the mesocarp auxin responsive genes, several encode elements regulating transport (ctg2448, ctg2449 and ctg2789 [ 25 [rid=B25] ] Additional file 1 [this file] ), indicating that auxin movement in this tissue is a relevant process, thus strengthening the hypothesis that auxin produced by the seed may behave as a signal efficiently transported to and within the mesocarp. 
The CK-mediated up-regulation of genes encoding sorbitol dehydrogenases (ctg636 and ctg1378, Additional file 1 [this file] ) appears particularly interesting, as this might increase the sink strength of the seed and attract photoassimilates to the entire fruit, which become more competitive in the partitioning process [ 33 [rid=B33] ]. 
In fact, during late seed development, ABA levels are known to increase and GA-related genes such as ctg3430, encoding a LTP-like, are down-regulated (Figure 3 [rid=F3] and Additional file 1 [this file] ). 
The 454 reads have been obtained from a normalized library constructed by pooling equal amounts of mesocarp RNA from stages S1, S2, S3 and S4 (GenXPro GmbH, Germany). Based on the best BLAST search results and using a cut-off e value of 1*e- , the peach genes were assigned to the categories according to the most similar genes (Additional file 1 [this file] ).
pub_title: A microarray approach to identify genes involved in seed-pericarp cross-talk and development in peach

context_description:
For seed development, ctg3431, coding for a lipid transfer protein (LTP), ctg1026, coding for a pathogenesis related (PR) protein, ctg1540, coding for a prunin, and ctg3563, coding for a late embryogenesis abundant (LEA) protein, have been chosen as S1, S2, S3 and S4 markers, respectively. Concerning mesocarp development, ctg2909, coding for a RD22-like protein, ctg1751, coding for serine carboxypeptidase, ctg1823, coding for a senescent associated protein, and ctg57, coding for an AUX/IAA protein, have been selected as S1, S2, S3 and S4 markers, respectively (Figure 3 [rid=F3] ). The function as stage markers has been confirmed on the same genotype for an additional growing season (Additional file 3 [this file] ). 
Data from 2010 are given in the supplementary material (Additional file 3 [this file] ).
pub_title: A microarray approach to identify genes involved in seed-pericarp cross-talk and development in peach

context_description:
The anticodon region within the cloverleaf structure of tRNAs is indicated (see also Supplementary Figure S2B [this file] for a detailed example of anticodon structure). ( ) I34 in Bacteria is catalysed by the homodimeric TadA enzyme, from which the eukaryotic ADAT2/ADAT3 heterodimeric enzyme evolved. 
Guide strands were designed using public resources ( http://crispr.mit.edu (http://crispr.mit.edu) ) (see Supplementary Table S1 [this file] for detailed oligonucleotide sequences), and were cloned into px330 SV40-GFP vector (gift from Dr Eduard Batlle, IRB Barcelona) ( 43 [rid=B43] ) as described in ( 44 [rid=B44] ). 
Plasmid for hADAT2 over expression was generated by Gateway cloning system following the manufacturer's protocol (hADAT2-pDONR221) using specific oligonucleotides ( Supplementary Table S1 [this file] ; and see Supplementary methods). hADAT2 gene was amplified from HEK293T cDNA. hADAT2-pLenti construct was generated by performing an LR reaction using hADAT2-pDONR221 and pLenti vector (Adgene plasmid 19068: pLenti PGK Puro DEST W529-2) following the manufacturer's protocol. 
See Supplementary methods [this file] for details on antibodies used in this study. 
Details on primers used are shown in Supplementary Table S1 [this file] ( 17 [rid=B17] , 47–49 [rid=B47] ). 
For control experiments depicted in Supplementary Figure S3E [this file] , cells were harvested with Trypsin instead of PBS/2 mM EDTA. 
Each dish contained 1 × 10 cells (for experiments carried out 24 h after plating; Figure 6A [rid=F6] ) or 1 × 10 cells (for experiments carried out 72 h after plating; Supplementary Figure S4A [this file] ). 
Statistical significance of the enrichment of transcripts encoding low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins among those down-regulated in the interaction analysis was assessed via Fisher Exact Test. ( Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
Oligonucleotides used are depicted in Supplementary Table S1 [this file] (see Supplementary methods [this file] for further details). 
See Supplementary methods [this file] for further details. 
Representative plots showing the gating strategy are shown in Supplementary Figure S6D and E [this file] . 
For correlation tests reported in Figure 10C [rid=F10] , seven species with an unusual number of A34-tRNA genes (>400 genes) were excluded from the analyses and are reported in Supplementary Table S6 [this file] . For results depicted in Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] , 1324 species from Bacteria and 114 species from Archaea were analysed ( Supplementary Table S6 [this file] ). 
Thus, as expected, we were unable to obtain full ADAT2 or ADAT3 knockout clones (see Materials and methods), but we did obtain heterozygous clones carrying wild type (WT) and edited alleles (‘HEK293T ADAT2 KD’ or ‘HEK293T ADAT3 KD’) ( Supplementary Figure S1 [this file] ). Editing of the ADAT2 allele resulted in the generation of a premature stop codon eight amino acids downstream of the edited site ( Supplementary Figure S1A [this file] ); while editing of the ADAT3 allele resulted in the elimination of seven residues mapping to the deaminase domain of the protein without changes in the translation reading frame ( Supplementary Figure S1B [this file] ). 
ADAT2 KD did not affect the levels of ADAT3, but we observed a mild decrease in ADAT2 protein abundance upon ADAT3 KD ( Supplementary Figure S2A [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Figure S2A [this file] . ( ) I34 levels in HEK293T CTRL (blue) and ADAT2 KD (red) cells as evaluated by tRNA-Seq. See also Supplementary Figure S2B [this file] . ( ) Heatmap visualization of tRNA gene expression at isodecoder level (tRNAs with the same anticodon) in HEK293T CTRL and ADAT2 KD cells as evaluated by tRNA-Seq. See also Supplementary Figure S2C [this file] and Supplementary Table S2 [this file] . 
Upon ADAT2 KD, we detected reduced levels of I34 on all its tRNA substrates, as seen by next generation sequencing of tRNAs (Figure 2B [rid=F2] ), without significant variations in tRNA transcript abundance (Figure 2C [rid=F2] and Supplementary Table S2 [this file] ). As a control, we verified that the amount of the unrelated tRNA modification 1-methylinosine (m I) present at position 37 of tRNA , and catalysed by ADAT1 ( 67 [rid=B67] ), was not affected ( Supplementary Figure S2B [this file] ). Similar results were observed upon shRNA-mediated KD of ADAT2 ( 17 [rid=B17] ) ( Supplementary Figure S2B-C [this file] ). 
However, pulse-chase analyses of general protein synthesis did not reveal defects in overall translation efficiency in ADAT2 KD and shADAT2 cells (Figure 3A [rid=F3] and Supplementary Figure S2D [this file] ). As a control, cycloheximide (CHX) treatment abolished the incorporation of radiolabeled amino acid into proteins in both cell lines ( Supplementary Figure S2E [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Figure S2D [this file] . ( ) Kinetics of protein synthesis in HEK293T CTRL (blue) and ADAT2 KD (red) cells upon monitoring the amount of TCA-precipitable label ( S-Met/Cys) from each cell lysate at the indicated time-points. See also Supplementary Figure S2E [this file] . ( ) Analyses of UPR markers on the indicated cell lines in the presence (+) or absence (−) of thapsigargin (Tg), that induces UPR. See also Supplementary Table S3 [this file] . 
We also performed mass spectrometry-based whole proteomics analyses (iTRAQ) and found only 7 differentially expressed proteins (|FC| > 1.5; adj. -value < 0.1) among 2280 detected proteins (Figure 3G [rid=F3] and Supplementary Table S3 [this file] ), indicating that 99.7% of detected proteins present unaltered levels under these conditions. 
We measured cell growth to assess the general physiological state of the cell after silencing ADAT2 or ADAT3, and found a reduced growth rate caused by a general deceleration of the cell cycle (Figure 4A [rid=F4] , B and Supplementary Figure S3A [this file] ). We observed similar phenotypes in different shADAT2 human cell lines ( Supplementary Figure S3B and C [this file] ), and we were able to fully recover growth rates in ADAT2 KD cells by introduction of a lentiviral ADAT2 expression system (‘HEK293T ADAT2 KD pLenti-hADAT2′) (Figure 4C [rid=F4] ). This phenotype was transient (Figure 4D [rid=F4] ), and absent in cells detached using PBS-EDTA ( Supplementary Figure S3D [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Figure S3A–C [this file] . ( ) Cell cycle analysis of HEK293T CTRL (blue-bordered bars) and ADAT2 KD (red-bordered bars) cells as evaluated by FACS over a 12-h period. See also Supplementary Figure S3D [this file] . 
See also Supplementary Figure S3E [this file] . 
We found that ADAT2 KD cells display impaired adhesion to collagens (Col II, Col IV) and vitronectin (VN), but not to fibronectin (FN), laminin (LN) or tenascin (TN) (Figure 5C [rid=F5] and Supplementary Figure S3E [this file] ). 
At 72 h after trypsin treatment and plating, we observed these differences substantially reduced, consistent with proteome normalization after protease treatment ( Supplementary Figure S4A [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Figure S4A [this file] . ( ) Polysome to Monosome ratio (P/M) obtained from experiments as in (A). See also Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . 
We found that ADAT2 KD cells presented a significant depletion in the P/M ratio at 24 h after trypsin treatment (Figure 6B [rid=F6] ), a difference that disappeared at 72 h after treatment ( Supplementary Figure S4B [this file] ). 
We detected a significant depletion of ADAT2 transcripts (FC < 1.5; adj. -value < 0.1) in the HP fraction of the ADAT2 KD cell line without significant changes in total RNA ( Supplementary Figure S4C [this file] ), indicating translational impairment. This is consistent with ribosomal drop-off caused by the premature stop codon introduced in this gene by CRISPR/Cas9 editing ( Supplementary Figure S1A [this file] , see also Figure 2A [rid=F2] ). In agreement with previous observations, we did not observe alterations of ADAT3 transcript levels in total RNA or HP fractions in this cell line ( Supplementary Figure S4C [this file] , see also Figure 2A [rid=F2] and Supplementary Figure S2A [this file] ). 
Although we found 726 differentially enriched or depleted (|FC| > 1.5; adj. -value < 0.1) protein-coding genes in the HP fractions of ADAT2 KD cells ( Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ), a global analysis of translation efficiency (TE) (cumulative log FC HP versus total) found no major differences in ADAT2 KD cells compared to CTRL cells ( -value = 0.49; Figure 6C [rid=F6] ). 
On the other hand, HP fractions after ADAT2 KD are significantly enriched in transcripts linked to cellular differentiation, calcium signalling, protein and mRNA stabilization, telomere maintenance, and protein ubiquitination (Figure 6D [rid=F6] , E and Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Figure S5A–C [this file] . ( ) Evaluation of eGFP fluorescence by FACS in the indicated cell lines when transfected with eGFP constructs depicted in (A). See also Supplementary Figure S5D [this file] . 
Likewise, we detected equivalent eGFP production in HEK293T shCV and shADAT2 cells, and for both expression constructs ( Supplementary Figure S5A and B [this file] ). In addition, we did not find signs of mistranslation based on peptide analysis by mass spectrometry ( Supplementary Figure S5C [this file] ). 
First, we identified human transcripts encoding proteins with low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich regions, and ranked them according to the size of these regions, and their relative enrichment in TAPSLIVR codons cognate for I34-tRNAs ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). We found that this subset of the human proteome is associated to cellular structure, morphology, adhesion, cell signalling, and interaction with the extracellular space ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). We further found that these low-complexity regions are characteristic of mucin-like domains (MLDs) ( 75 [rid=B75] ), and are abundant in Mucins (MUC) and other proteins involved in ECM regulation and adhesion ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). 
We purified SDC3-RLuc and SDC3(G-end)-RLuc from all cell lines and found their protein sequences to be identical by mass spectrometry ( Supplementary Figure S5D [this file] ). 
Using an interaction analysis (see Materials and methods) we found that 7 out of the 36 genes with impaired TE in ADAT2 KD cells (FC HP versus total < 1.5; -value < 0.05) encoded proteins with TAPSLIVR-rich low-complexity regions (Figure 8A [rid=F8] and Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . ( ) Histogram of a permutation test using 10 000 sets of 31 random transcripts detected in experiments shown in (A). 
This significance is increased when the analysis is restricted to highly translated transcripts in CTRL cells (i.e. FC HP CTRL versus Total CTRL > 0) (550 transcripts encoding low-complexity TAPSLIVR regions; -value = 4.985e–14; Fisher exact test) ( Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
First, we examined the expression of Dystroglycan 1 (coded by the gene ) (Figure 9A [rid=F9] ) in HT29-M6 shCV and shADAT2 cells ( Supplementary Figure S3B, C [this file] and Supplementary Figure S6A [this file] ). 
ADAT2 levels in each protein extract is shown in Supplementary Figure S6A [this file] . ( ) DAG1 transcript levels relative to GAPDH in the indicated cell lines. See also Supplementary Figure S6B-C [this file] . ( ) Distribution of TAPSLIVR (ADAT amino acids; green curve) and of codons decoded by I34-tRNAs (ADAT codons; orange curve) along the coding sequence of MUC5AC. See also Supplementary Figure S6D and E [this file] . ( ) MUC5AC expression in NCI-H292 shCV and shADAT2 cells treated (+) or not (−) with AREG, quantified by confocal microscopy. 
We evaluated a number of molecular markers of AREG-induced signalling and found that ADAT2 depletion did not generally affect the cellular response to AREG treatment ( Supplementary Figure S6B-C [this file] ). 
However, we detected a strong reduction in MUC5AC protein levels in shADAT2 cells, both by FACS analyses (∼ 30% reduction, Figure 9G [rid=F9] and Supplementary Figure S6D-E [this file] ) and immunohistochemistry (∼70% reduction, Figure 9H [rid=F9] ), consistent with a severe translational defect. 
See also Supplementary Table S6 [this file] and Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] . ( ) Histogram of permutation tests using 5000 sets of random human proteins, showing the distribution of homologs in unicellular eukaryotes relative to multicellular in eukaryotes (average ratio) for each random set analysed (subsamplings). See also Supplementary Table S7 [this file] . ( ) Boxplot representation of the abundance of homologs to low-complexity TASPLIVR-rich human proteins, and that contain low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich regions, in unicellular and multicellular eukaryotes. 
We found a positive trend ( = 0.53, -value = 3.7e–13, Spearman) between the abundance of low-complexity TASPLIVR-rich proteins and A34-tRNA gene content (Figure 10C [rid=F10] and Supplementary Table S6 [this file] ). Of note and as expected, proteins with low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich regions are rare in bacterial and archaeal genomes (Figure 10B [rid=F10] ), which are depleted of I34-tRNAs ( Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] ). 
The capacity to synthesize cell adhesion molecules was instrumental for the origin of multicellularity ( 81–84 [rid=B81] ), and low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins are involved in cell adhesion and extracellular matrix interactions ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). We further evaluated the presence of low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich regions within these proteins and detected a 7.3-fold enrichment in multicellular species (Figure 10E [rid=F10] and Supplementary Table S7 [this file] ). 
This depletion is achieved without causing additional alterations to the tRNA pool, and the resulting cells are still viable (Figures 2 [rid=F2] and 4 [rid=F4] , Supplementary Figure S2B-C [this file] and Supplementary Table S2 [this file] ). Moreover, we observe that reduced I34 levels cause an abnormal cellular morphology upon trypsin treatments (Figure 4D [rid=F4] and Supplementary Figure S3D [this file] ), indicating that I34-tRNAs are required for the synthesis of membrane proteins involved in interactions with the extracellular environment. Silencing of ADAT2 also causes a notable decrease in transcripts with high ribosomal occupancy after trypsin treatment (Figure 6A [rid=F6] ), and within this group, we find an overrepresentation of genes linked to cell adhesion, response to extracellular stimuli and cell-cell signalling (Figure 6D [rid=F6] and Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ), indicating that extracellular polypeptides predominate among those affected by a partial depletion of I34-tRNAs. 
Indeed, we do not find translation to be generally compromised when I34-tRNA levels are reduced, as shown by monitoring protein synthesis rates through metabolic labelling, analysing soluble and insoluble protein fractions, and evaluating UPR markers and levels of protein ubiquitination (Figure 3A [rid=F3] – F [rid=F3] and Supplementary Figure S2D [this file] ). Furthermore, whole proteome mass spectrometry analyses revealed only 7 proteins out of 2280 to be differentially expressed (2 proteins upregulated and 5 downregulated) (Figure 3G [rid=F3] and Supplementary Table S3 [this file] ). This indicates that the majority of the differential abundance of transcripts associated to ribosomes found in ADAT2 KD cells could be explained by changes in transcriptional rates (Figure 6 [rid=F6] and Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
An analysis of low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins functionally links this subset of the human proteome to cellular integrity, adhesion, and generation of, and interaction with the ECM, among others ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). We detected translational defects in membrane-associated proteins such as LIPE, SPNS2, ORAI3, PIANP and SEMA6C (Figure 8A [rid=F8] and Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ) ( 90 [rid=B90] ), and in proteins containing MLDs ( 75–77 [rid=B75] ) such as SDC3, Dystroglycan and MUC5AC (Figures 7D [rid=F7] – F [rid=F7] and Figure 9 [rid=F9] ). Notably, not all low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins are transmembrane or secretory proteins ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ), thus I34-tRNA depletion may affect translation of proteins both in the cytosol and the endoplasmic reticulum ( 91 [rid=B91] ). The most striking translational phenotype caused by ADAT2 silencing was the reduction in the synthesis of MUC5AC protein in NCI-H292 cells stimulated with AREG, despite a ∼1000-fold transcriptional activation of the gene (Figure 9D [rid=F9] – H [rid=F9] and Supplementary Figure S6B–E [this file] ). 
Our polysome profiling data detects translational impairment on transcripts encoding low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins that are highly translated in CTRL cells (Figure 8 [rid=F8] and Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
We determined that depletion of I34-tRNAs primarily affects translational efficiency, but not accuracy, of low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins, as seen by the time-dependent recovery of phenotypes (Figures 4D [rid=F4] and 6A [rid=F6] - B [rid=F6] and Supplementary Figure S4A-B [this file] ), time-course analysis of translation (Figure 7I [rid=F7] ), and mass spectrometry analyses ( Supplementary Figure S5D [this file] ). 
We characterized the phylogenetic distribution of homologs to human proteins with low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich regions that depend on I34-tRNAs for their synthesis, and found that they are almost limited to eukaryotic species that abundantly utilize I34-tRNAs (Figure 10A [rid=F10] , B and Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] ). Here we show that, although I34-tRNAs exist in deeply-rooted eukaryotic groups ( 10 [rid=B10] , 24 [rid=B24] , 25 [rid=B25] ), their abundance correlates with that of proteins with low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich regions (Figure 10C [rid=F10] , Supplementary Table S6 [this file] and Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] ). Strikingly, we find such proteins to be scarce in unicellular eukaryotes, with the sole exception of holozoan protists (the closest known relatives of metazoans ( 25 [rid=B25] )), where the abundance of low-complexity TAPSLIVR-rich proteins is comparable to that of multicellular species (Figure 10D [rid=F10] - E [rid=F10] and Supplementary Table S7 [this file] )
pub_title: Human tRNAs with inosine 34 are essential to efficiently translate eukarya-specific low-complexity proteins

title: NIHMS519954-supplement-Supp_Fig_S1.tif
description: Figure S1. Mutant 11-104A4 displays temperature sensitive growth leading to an increase in cell size. (A) The growth of mutant 11-104A4 parasites was monitored in populations partially synchronized by limited invasion over a 32 h period at 34°C and 40°C. The arrow indicates a post-invasion time when cultures were shifted to 40°C. To determine average vacuole sizes, randomly selected vacuoles (>50) in three independent cultures per strain and temperature condition were directly monitored by light microscopy. Note that mutant 11-104A4 showed a slower rate at the permissive temperature then the parental RHΔhxgprt strain. (B) The lethality of the temperature defect in mutant 11-104A4 was determined by plaque assay. Freshly invaded mutant parasites were incubated at 40°C for the indicated times before the cultures were shifted to the permissive temperature (34°C) to allow for plaque development. Plaque numbers represent the average of six independent measurements. (C) Morphological changes in the mutant 11-104A4 were quantified in populations grown at two temperatures (34°C and 40°C). Images of the fifty cells stained with αIMC1 antibodies were measured in two dimensions, along (conoid to basal complex ring: Length) and across (Width) the central axis using AxioVision software. Only parasites without visible internal daughters were counted at 34°C. Estimated mean and SD values are shown on the graph (*** - p < 0.005). Mutant parasites arrested at 40°C were significantly bigger in diameter consistent with the observed morphological defect.
