title: NIHMS519954-supplement-Supp_Fig_S2.tif
description: Figure S2. TgNoAP1 is cell cycle regulated at mRNA and protein levels. (A) The encoded protein of gene TGGT1_114070 (TgNoAP1) is predicted to have two AAA+ domains, D1 and D2 (http://smart.embl-heidelberg.de/). Domain coordinates are indicated at the bottom of the diagram. Each AAA+ ATPase domain contains two signature Walker A P-loop and Walker B motif that are essential for ATP hydrolysis (White & Lauring, 2007). The mutation Y984C responsible for conditional growth arrest of mutant 11-104A4 is located at the N-terminus of the D2 domain and is shown in red. Canonical lysine residues in the Walker A motifs were mutated to alanine (shown in red in the Walker A mutants panel) and tested in genetic rescue of the mutant 11-104A4. Dead ATPase mutant K495A/K992A did not rescue growth of the mutant at 40°C confirming that active ATPase domains in TgNoAP1 are required for the protein function. (B) Parasites expressing TgNoAP1myc (clone C6wt) were grown for 24 h (37°C) and co-stained with antibodies for the myc epitope (green) and nucleolar factor TgNF3 (red) as well as for genomic DNA with DAPI (blue). The TgNoAP1myc protein forms a ring arrangement and partially overlaps with nucleolar staining by TgNF3 (inset merge image shows the red stain encircled by green). Scale bar = 2μm. (C) Cyclical expression of TgNoAP1myc is clearly evident in parasite vacuoles from a single microscopic field (clone C6wt see Experimental Procedures). The top vacuole of eight parasites showing peak expression is in the G1 phase while the bottom vacuole has initiated daughter budding (late S-early mitosis). In this second vacuole of four parasites, TgNoAP1myc expression is rapidly declining. The IFA samples were stained with αMyc (green), αIMC1 (red), and DAPI (blue). Scale bar = 2μm. (D) TgNoAP1 mRNA is cyclical with maximum levels in early G1 before declining in late S phase, which is a nearly identical cell cycle profile as the encoded TgNoAP1myc protein. Black solid line represents the spline interpretation for this mRNA, while the light grey line plots the 12 point synchronous data from the established cell cycle transcriptome (Behnke et al., 2010).

title: NIHMS519954-supplement-Supp_Fig_S4.tif
description: Figure S4. Localization and expression of the TgWdr74 is not affected in the mutant 11-104A4. (A) The WD repeat protein Wdr74 from human and Nsa-1 from yeast is required for ribosome biogenesis where it regulates the assembly of the pre-60S particle (Kressler et al., 2012). Alignment of putative pre-60S ribosome factor TgWdr74 with human ortholog Wdr74. Amino acid sequences of TgWdr74 and human Wdr74 were aligned using ClustalW. The asterisk indicates amino acid positions of fully conserved residues, colons indicate conservative substitutions between residues with similar biochemical properties (scoring > 0.5 in the Gonnet PAM 250 matrix), and periods indicate conservation between groups of weakly similar properties (scoring < 0.5 in the Gonnet PAM 250 matrix). Human Wdr74 is protein NP_060563.2 (ncbi.org), TgWdr74 is protein TGGT1_080560 (toxodb.org). Amino acid residues 310-756 (TgWdr74) and 45-300 (human Wdr74) encompass the WD repeat region. (B) The ortholog of Wdr74/Nsa-1 was expressed as a fusion protein with 3xmyc epitope tag (see Experimental Procedures). IFA analysis of TgWdr74myc demonstrated that this protein was localized to the parasite nucleolus in a manner unaffected by temperature in mutant 11-104A4 parasites.

title: NIHMS519954-supplement-Supp_Table_S1.doc
description: Table S1 Primers used in the study.
context_description:
For direct complementation with DNA fragments, the TGGT1_117040 gene locus was amplified from genomic DNA isolated from the parental strain RHΔ or the mutant 11-104A4 using forward primer TgNoAP1_FOR located at −1000bp in the 5′ UTR and reverse primer TgNoAP1_REV located 12bp downstream of the stop codon of TGGT1_117040 gene ( Table S1 [href=this file] ). (TOXOV53 and PSBLD53) or PCR fragments were transfected into 1×10 parasites using 6-10 μg of purified DNA.
To reintroduce the Y984C mutation into a new genomic background, we PCR amplified a 3,163bp DNA fragment from mutant 11-104A4 that includes the 3′ end of the TGGT1_117040 (ts-TgNoAP1) using primers LIC-TgNoAP1_FOR and LIC-TgNoAP1_REV ( Table S1 [href=this file] ).
PCR DNA fragments encompassing the 3′-end of the nucleolin gene were used to construct the plasmid, pLIC-TgNucleolin-HA / -DHFR-TS (see Table S1 [href=this file] for primers designs) and the construct electroporated into the clone F10 that expresses ts-TgNoAP1 protein.
The coding sequences of TgRPL36 (TGGT1_052600) and TgWdr74 (TGGT1_080560) were amplified from a parental RHΔ cDNA library (see Table S1 [href=this file] for primers designs) and the DNA fragments cloned into the pDEST_gra-myc /sag-HXGPRT vector by recombination (Gateway cloning, Life Technologies), which fuses a triple myc tag to the C-terminus of each protein.

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
We confirmed by western blot analysis that the 70 bp fragments contain a lower ratio of H2A and H2B to H3 and H4 as that found in the nucleosome particles (150 bp fragments), as well as a higher ratio of HMGB1 to H4, and a similar ratio of HMGN2 to H4 (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
Therefore, to reveal how the three types of H3/H4-containing particles are distributed along sperm DNA, we performed paired-end sequencing of DNA fragments generated by MNase digestion of sperm chromatin (~7 × genome coverage, Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
We used internal standard calibrated chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ICeChIP-seq ) to estimate the percentage of histone H3 methylation at a given locus in a sperm population (apparent histone methylation density, HMD) (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] and ‘Methods’). 
To test this hypothesis, we first incubated permeabilised sperm in egg extract to mimic the chromatin assembly and replication steps associated with the first embryonic cycle (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). However, the context within which high histone H3 methylation occurs (with or without enrichment for a given H3 particle) is not generally predictive of the fate of the methylated histone post replication (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). Finally, sperm incubation with extracts containing the DNA replication inhibitor geminin suggests that most histone methylation peak loss following treatment is associated with chromatin assembly on sperm DNA rather than with DNA replication (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
In addition, a significant proportion of genes sensitive to both demethylation of H3K27 and depletion for the maternally provided factor Ascl1 harbour homogeneously methylated H3K27 and the binding motif for this transcription factor (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
To that end human sperm from a fertile individual were treated with an MNase concentration that yields nucleosome-sized fragments as well as smaller fragments (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). Interestingly, in human, H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 ChIP recovers only nucleosome-sized fragment (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
Overall, the peaks identified are well conserved between our study and previous work indicating that peak calling is consistent across a range of MNase treatments (Supplementary Data 7 [this file0] ). Nonetheless, some human sperm genes have peaks of high density of histone H3K4me3 (130 genes) or H3K27me3 (320 genes) around their TSSs (i.e., BMI1, TBX3, Fig. 7c [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Data 8 [this file1] ). However, in both species the set of genes with high H3K27me3 HMD is related to developmental functions (Supplementary Tables 3 [this file] and 7 [this file] ). 
The source data underlying Figs. 1a [rid=Fig1] , b [rid=Fig1] , d [rid=Fig1] , e [rid=Fig1] , 3a [rid=Fig3] , b [rid=Fig3] , d [rid=Fig3] , e [rid=Fig3] , 4c [rid=Fig4] and 7b [rid=Fig7] , e [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Figs. 1a–c [this file] , 2a [this file] , c [this file] , g, 3c, d, 4c, e and 8a [this file] are provided as a Source Data file.

Hepatocytes differentiate into intestinal epithelial cells through a hybrid epithelial/mesenchymal cell state in culture

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Two independent experiments demonstrated that YFP was expressed in more than 99% of cultured cells derived from the liver of TM-treated ; mice, indicating that their hepatocyte progenies can proliferate and expand in long-term culture (Supplementary Fig. 1a, b [this file] ). Moreover, similar to hepatocytes isolated form ; mice, those from untreated wild-type mice were also capable of propagating in culture (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). 
The changes in gene expression were promptly induced starting from 1 day of 3D culture (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). The hepatic maturation of dediHep aggregates could also be induced from dediHeps propagated in long-term monolayer culture (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
These dediHep-derived hepatocytes did not express the mesenchymal cell markers Vim and α-smooth muscle actin (αSMA) (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
Cdx2 was co-expressed with Alb in dediHeps (Fig. 4c [rid=Fig4] ) and gradually disappeared from dediHeps during re-differentiation into hepatocytes (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
These SOs were composed of actively proliferating, polarized intestinal epithelial cells that express E-cad basolaterally, Villin (also known as Vil1) apically, and nuclear Cdx2 and Sox9 (Fig. 5c [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ), similar to FIPC-derived SOs . Also, dediHep-derived SOs were formed by cells expressing CK19 and Hnf4α but not Alb, indicating that these SOs were not biliary organoids that express CK19 but not Hnf4α and Alb (Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). Moreover, addition of forskolin (FSK) with or without the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) inhibitor CFTRinh-172 to the culture media blocked or induced the swelling of dediHep-derived SOs, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
Forced expression of promotes the generation of SOs from dediHeps (Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). Changing the additives in the medium from WCENR to ENR is necessary for the efficient formation of BOs even from dediHeps overexpressing (Supplementary Fig. 8b, c [this file] ). dediHep-derived BOs could be maintained by repeated passaging in long-term 3D culture (Supplementary Fig. 8d [this file] ). 
Quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) analyses also revealed that the expression levels of differentiated intestinal epithelial cell markers, such as , , and , and those of dediHep markers, such as and , significantly increased and decreased, respectively, in BOs derived from exogenous -expressing dediHeps (Fig. 6g [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). 
In fact, the proliferative capacity of CLiPs was significantly lower than that of dediHeps (Supplementary Fig. 10a [this file] ). Dedifferentiation of human hepatocytes into CLiPs also activates the expression of the mesenchymal cell markers and , in addition to , , and (Supplementary Fig. 10b [this file] ). 
Meanwhile, Yap immediately disappeared from the nucleus of dediHeps as a result of cell-aggregate formation that induced re-differentiation of dediHeps into growth-arrested functional hepatocytes under 3D culture conditions (Fig. 8e [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
This inactivation blocked the conversion of hepatocytes to dediHeps in a concentration-dependent manner in verteporfin (Fig. 8g, h [rid=Fig8] ) and led to higher expression of several genes encoding liver enzymes and lower expression of and than hepatocytes cultured without verteporfin (Fig. 8i [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 12 [this file] ). Our data demonstrated that dediHep-derived SOs were composed of cells marked with nuclear Yap, and their formation was nearly completely blocked in culture with verteporfin (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] ). 
The primary and secondary antibodies used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
To examine the expression of additional genes, qPCR was performed using the THUNDERBIRD SYBR qPCR Mix (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. qPCR primers for , , , , , , , , and are listed in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] .

Orb6  Inhibition  Leads  to  Increased  Cell  Width,  Cessation  of  Cell  Elongation,  and  Cell-Separation  Defects  in  Both  Wild-Type  and  gef1Δ  Cells,  Related  to  Figure  1  Cdc42-GTP  reporter  CRIB-3mCitrine  and  F-actin  reporter  Lifeact-mCherry  in  orb6-as2  and  gef1Δ  orb6-as2  cells  before  and  after  3-BrB-PP1  addition  (indicated  by  “+3-BrB-PP1”). context_description:
Consistent with previous work ( Das et al., 2009 [rid=bib17] , Nuñez et al., 2016 [rid=bib56] ), Orb6 inhibition led to an increase in cell width, partial ectopic localization of Cdc42-GTP (imaged with CRIB-3mCitrine) ( Mutavchiev et al., 2016 [rid=bib54] ) and the actin cytoskeleton away from cell tips (i.e., on cell sides), and cell-separation defects during septation ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] A, 1C, S1 [rid=mmc1] C, and S1D; Video S1 [this file] ). Also consistent with previous work, ectopic localization of Cdc42-GTP and actin in Orb6-inhibited cells was suppressed by ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] A, S1 [rid=mmc1] C, and S1D; Video S1 [this file] ) ( Das et al., 2009 [rid=bib17] ). 
Video S1 [this file] shows more cells, with Lifeact-3mCherry. Blue arrowheads indicate the absence of CRIB-3mCitrine at comparable stages in cells ( Video S1 [this file] ). 
However, in apparent contrast to the same previous work ( Das et al., 2009 [rid=bib17] ), we found that increased cell width in Orb6-inhibited cells was not suppressed by ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] A and 1C; Video S1 [this file] ).

context_description:
Video S4 [this file] shows the same cells. 
Videos show that slightly positive values for cell elongation rates in and cells are due to cell swelling in all directions and not to polarized elongation ( Video S4 [this file] ). 
Time-lapse observation of Cdc42-GTP localization revealed that Orb6-inhibited cells almost completely ceased to elongate, even when they remained largely polarized (based on Cdc42-GTP retention at cell tips) ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] D and 1E; Video S4 [this file] ). Cessation of elongation also occurred in Orb6-inhibited cells ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] D–1G; Video S4 [this file] ), which do not show ectopic Cdc42-GTP localization.

context_description:
Within 12–15 min after Orb6 inhibition, Bgs4 was almost completely lost from cell tips in both wild-type (i.e., ) and backgrounds, although in a small proportion of cells, some Bgs4 remained either at or just underneath cell tips ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] A, 2B, and 2D; Video S5 [this file] ). 
Video S5 [this file] shows the same cells. 
Video S5 [this file] shows more cells, including these. 
In Orb6-inhibited cells attempting to divide, Bgs4 accumulated at the septation zone for long periods ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] B; Video S5 [this file] ), consistent with observed cell-separation defects. In both cases, Bgs4 was quickly lost from cell tips for the duration of imaging (∼2 h) ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] C and 2D; Video S5 [this file] ).

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S5
caption: No description
context_description:
To investigate Orb6 function at native expression levels, we introduced the same mutation (M170A) at the endogenous locus; throughout this work, we refer to our new allele as We inhibited Orb6-as2 using the nucleotide competitive analog 3-BrB-PP1, although other analogs were equally effective ( Figures S1 [this file] A and S1B). Consistent with previous work ( Das et al., 2009 [rid=bib17] , Nuñez et al., 2016 [rid=bib56] ), Orb6 inhibition led to an increase in cell width, partial ectopic localization of Cdc42-GTP (imaged with CRIB-3mCitrine) ( Mutavchiev et al., 2016 [rid=bib54] ) and the actin cytoskeleton away from cell tips (i.e., on cell sides), and cell-separation defects during septation ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] A, 1C, S1 [this file] C, and S1D; Video S1 [rid=mmc5] ). These phenotypes were specific to cells treated with 3-BrB-PP1 ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] C and S1 [this file] B; Videos S2 [rid=mmc6] and S3 [rid=mmc7] ). Also consistent with previous work, ectopic localization of Cdc42-GTP and actin in Orb6-inhibited cells was suppressed by ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] A, S1 [this file] C, and S1D; Video S1 [rid=mmc5] ) ( Das et al., 2009 [rid=bib17] ). 
See also Figure S1 [this file] and Videos S2 [rid=mmc6] and S3 [rid=mmc7] . 
The width increase of cells at 37°C (restrictive temperature) was greater than that of Orb6-inhibited cells at 25°C, with many cells becoming round ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] B, 1C, and S1 [this file] B) ( Verde et al., 1998 [rid=bib76] ). 
This was surprising, because Cdc42-GTP enrichment on the plasma membrane is normally closely correlated with active cell growth ( Figure S1 [this file] E) ( Tatebe et al., 2008 [rid=bib73] ). 
To further characterize cessation of elongation and decreased cell-volume expansion in Orb6-inhibited cells, we imaged mCherry-tagged beta-glucan synthase subunit Bgs4, a multipass transmembrane protein required for cell wall synthesis at sites of active growth (i.e., cell tips during interphase and the cell midzone during cytokinesis) ( Figure S1 [this file] E) ( Cortés et al., 2005 [rid=bib13] , Cortés et al., 2015 [rid=bib14] ). Control wild-type ( ) cells treated with 3-BrB-PP1 showed no change in mCherry-Bgs4 localization and continued to elongate ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] A and S1 [this file] F). 
See also Figure S1 [this file] . 
In mass spectrometry experiments associated with phosphoproteomics analysis after Orb6 inhibition (described later), we found that 3-BrB-PP1 treatment leads to increased intracellular levels of the major acid phosphatase Pho1 ( Figure S2 [this file] B). Increased Pho1 levels likely account for the increased ACP secretion seen in 3-BrB-PP1-treated wild-type cells as a result of mass action. 3-BrB-PP1 treatment also led to increased intracellular Pho1 levels in cells ( Figure S2 [this file] B), even though these cells showed decreased ACP secretion. 
To identify Orb6 substrates, we combined stable isotope labeling with amino acids in culture (SILAC) ( Bicho et al., 2010 [rid=bib6] , Macek et al., 2017 [rid=bib44] , Ong and Mann, 2006 [rid=bib58] ) with global phosphoproteomics analysis ( Figure S2 [this file] A). 
See also Figures S2 [this file] and S3 [this file] . 
Among the 55 phosphosites with significantly decreased phosphorylation in all three experiments, 36 (65%) contained a basic amino acid (histidine, arginine, or lysine) at the −3 position relative to the phosphorylated residue ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B, S2 [this file] C, and S2D; Table S2 [rid=mmc3] ). 
In Sec5-mCherry immunoprecipitates, levels of all other exocyst proteins (Sec3, Sec6, Sec8, Sec10, Sec15, Exo70, and Exo84) were similar between control and Orb6-inhibited cells, suggesting that exocyst assembly is not grossly affected by Orb6 inhibition ( Figures S3 [this file] A and S3B). Consistent with global phosphoproteomics data, immunoprecipitates from Orb6-inhibited cells showed decreased phosphorylation of Sec3 serine-201 and Sec5 serine-50, as well as decreased phosphorylation of a novel site, Sec8 serine-440 ( Figures S3 [this file] C and S3D; the Sec8 site does not correspond to the NDR/LATS consensus). We also found that unlike Sec5 and Sec8, Sec3 contains numerous additional phosphosites with modestly increased or decreased phosphorylation after Orb6 inhibition ( Figures S3 [this file] C and S3D). 
In untreated cells, fluorescent-tagged exocyst proteins Sec3, Sec5, Sec8, and Exo70 localized to cell tips in interphase and the septation zone during division, while after Orb6 inhibition, these proteins showed decreased localization at cell tips and ectopic puncta on the peripheral cortex ( Figure 6 [rid=fig6] ; Video S7 [this file1] ). By contrast, 3-BrB-PP1-treated wild-type ( ) cells displayed normal exocyst localization ( Figure S4 [this file] ). 
Video S7 [this file1] shows changes in Sec3-3mCherry and Sec5-3mCherry localization at a higher time resolution. See also Figure S4 [this file] . 
To test the role of Sec3 serine-201 and Sec5 serine-50 phosphorylation in exocytosis, we mutated these residues to non-phosphorylatable alanine at their endogenous loci to make the mutants and Both single mutants, as well as a double mutant, were viable under normal growth conditions at 25°C and 36°C ( Figures 7 [rid=fig7] and S5 [this file] A). 
See also Figure S5 [this file] and Video S8 [this file2] . 
Neither and single mutants nor the double mutant showed an increased septation index relative to wild-type cells ( Figures 7 [rid=fig7] C, 7D, and S5 [this file] A). 
All mutant combinations were viable at 25°C and 36°C ( Figures 7 [rid=fig7] and S5 [this file] A). However, the septation index was significantly increased in double mutants compared to either single mutant at both 25°C and 36°C; more than 75% of cells contained at least one septum, and 25% of cells contained multiple septa ( Figures 7 [rid=fig7] C, 7D, and S5 [this file] A). This was not altered by further deletion of ( Figures S5 [this file] B and S5C). The septation index in and mutants was not greatly altered by the mutation, although there were somewhat fewer multi-septate cells at 25°C compared to 36°C ( Figures 7 [rid=fig7] C, 7D, and S5 [this file] A); the reasons for this are not yet clear. 
However, because spores of the double-mutant failed to germinate ( Figure S5 [this file] D), we were unable to test this directly. Both proteins localized normally to cell tips and the septation zone, indicating that exocyst localization per se was not adversely affected ( Figures S5 [this file] E and S5F). 
Orb6 inhibition leads to cessation of cell elongation and decreased exocyst at cell tips, whereas cells, despite impaired ACP secretion and cell-separation defects, can grow in a polarized fashion and maintain exocyst at cell tips ( Figures 7 [rid=fig7] and S5 [this file] ). Nearly all of the highest-ranking phosphosites (i.e., those with highest reproducibility and greatest fold decrease after Orb6 inhibition) match the NDR/LATS consensus ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] and S2 [this file] ; Table S2 [rid=mmc3] ), suggesting that they are direct substrates of Orb6.
pub_title: Fission Yeast NDR/LATS Kinase Orb6 Regulates Exocytosis via Phosphorylation of the Exocyst Complex

title: Table S1. Summary of Phosphoproteomics Data for Orb6 Inhibition, Related to Figure 4
caption: No description
description: Table  S1.  Summary  of  Phosphoproteomics  Data  for  Orb6  Inhibition,  Related  to  Figure  4
context_description:
Overall results from SILAC phosphoproteomics are presented in Table S1 [this file] . 
The inset shows Pearson correlation coefficients for three biological replicates ( Table S1 [this file] ). 
Although we identified several phosphosites in the previously characterized Orb6 targets Gef1 and Sts5, none of these sites showed significant decreased phosphorylation after Orb6 inhibition (i.e., 2-fold or greater) ( Table S1 [this file] ). 
For summaries of global phosphoproteomics results, presented in Table S1 [this file] , selected MaxQuant fields from individual biological-replicate experiments are shown in separate tabs (full datasets containing all fields are available via the PRIDE repository; see below). 
To populate the different tabs in Table S2 [rid=mmc3] , data from the “Orb6_inhibition summary” tab in Table S1 [this file] were used as initial input. Third, the same phosphosite was required not to have a greater-than-two-fold decrease in the corresponding control experiment in which wild-type cells were treated with 3-BrB-PP1 (i.e., the “mean log (fold-change) after 3-BrB-PP1 addition” in the Control tab in Table S1 [this file] was not allowed to be more negative than −1.0).
pub_title: Fission Yeast NDR/LATS Kinase Orb6 Regulates Exocytosis via Phosphorylation of the Exocyst Complex

title: Table S2. Orb6-Dependent Phosphosites in Relation to NDR/LATS Kinase Consensus Motif, Related to Figure 4
caption: No description
description: Table  S2.  Orb6-Dependent  Phosphosites  in  Relation  to  NDR/LATS  Kinase  Consensus  Motif,  Related  to  Figure  4
context_description:
Among the quantified phosphosites, 326 (4%) showed a 2-fold or greater decrease in phosphorylation after Orb6 inhibition in at least one experiment, 121 (1.5%) showed this decrease in at least two experiments, and 55 (0.7%) showed this decrease in all three experiments ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
Phosphosites were ranked by fold decrease in phosphorylation, independent of whether they matched the NDR/LATS motif ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
Among the 55 phosphosites with significantly decreased phosphorylation in all three experiments, 36 (65%) contained a basic amino acid (histidine, arginine, or lysine) at the −3 position relative to the phosphorylated residue ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B, S2 [rid=mmc1] C, and S2D; Table S2 [this file] ). Among the 15 phosphosites with 4-fold or greater decreased phosphorylation in all three experiments, 12 showed a perfect match to the NDR/LATS consensus, including histidine at the −5 position, suggesting that they are direct Orb6 targets ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] B; Table S2 [this file] ). 
Nearly all of the highest-ranking phosphosites (i.e., those with highest reproducibility and greatest fold decrease after Orb6 inhibition) match the NDR/LATS consensus ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] and S2 [rid=mmc1] ; Table S2 [this file] ), suggesting that they are direct substrates of Orb6. 
For ranking of Orb6-dependent phosphosites (based on fold-change in phosphorylation after Orb6 inhibition) in relation to the NDR/LATS consensus motif, presented in Table S2 [this file] , different “stringency” tabs were made in order to take into consideration the reproducibility of phosphosite quantification in different biological-replicate experiments. To populate the different tabs in Table S2 [this file] , data from the “Orb6_inhibition summary” tab in Table S1 [rid=mmc2] were used as initial input.
pub_title: Fission Yeast NDR/LATS Kinase Orb6 Regulates Exocytosis via Phosphorylation of the Exocyst Complex

context_description:
The results demonstrated that CRC patients with lower mRNA-expressing tumors had improved prognosis (Fig. 1d, e [rid=Fig1] ), and the mRNA levels of were closely associated with CRC TNM (tumor, lymph node, and metastasis) stages, and liver and lung metastasis (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). The results in Fig. 1f [rid=Fig1] showed that, in contrast to the adjacent tumor tissues, ITGBL1 was overexpressed in CRC tumor tissues, and its expression levels were reversely correlated with overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS) of CRC patients (Supplementary Fig. 1a, b [this file] ). 
Again, significantly higher protein levels of ITGBL1 were found in primary CRC tumors, and matched lung and liver metastasis (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] , Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). The mRNA expression was inversely correlated with OS (Supplementary Fig. 2a–c [this file] ). A wide range of protein expression levels of ITGBL1 was also detected in 90 CRC tissues (only five cases overlapping with above 467 CRC cases), and the protein expressions of ITGBL1 were inversely correlated with lymphovascular invasion (Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] ). 
Moreover, the mRNA expression of ITGBL1 in human CRC tumor samples had strong correlation with the ITGBL1 levels in corresponding plasma EVs of CRC patients (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). Multivariate Cox regression analysis further revealed that both ITGBL1 levels in EVs and distant metastasis served as independent predictors of poor prognosis in CRC patients (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). In addition to ITGBL1, several other integrins, including ITGα6, ITGβ4, and ITGβ1 were also packed in the plasma EVs of CRC patients with lung metastases, whereas ITGα5 and ITGβ5 were found in liver metastases (Supplementary Fig. 3b–f [this file] ). 
Genetic gain- and loss-of-function experiments further supported the finding that RUNX2 may regulate mRNA and protein expression (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] , Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] ). 
The total numbers of EVs from an equal number of cells were also upregulated by overexpressing RUNX2, whereas KD of RUNX2 produced the opposite effect (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] , Fig. 2k [rid=Fig2] ). ITGBL1 levels in EVs from an equal number of cells were upregulated in nSMase2-overexpressing cells, but downregulated in nSMase2 KD cells (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] , Fig. 2p [rid=Fig2] ). 
In vivo tracing of the injected EVs showed that CRC-derived EVs were accumulated in lung or liver, and very weak signals in the brain and bone marrow (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). Notably, CRC-ITGBL1-enriched EVs increased the frequency of α-SMA + hStCs, myofibroblasts, FN deposition, and recruitments of F4/80 macrophage, and Ly6G myeloid cells to the liver (Fig. 3e [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 5b–e [this file] ) or lung (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 5f–i [this file] ). 
In contrast to liver and lung, the brain and bone tissues lacked detectable metastases (Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ). Immunofluenrescence assay of α-SMA, a known myofibroblastic marker, demonstrated that treatment with ITGBL1-enriched EVs increased the α-SMA + CAFs in metastatic lesions (Fig. 4g [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 6c–e [this file] ). 
Among various CRC cell lines, ITGBL1 was more highly expressed in the EVs of SW620 and LoVo, relative to others (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). The structure, size, and numbers of the isolated EVs were identified by electron microscopy and Nanosight particle tracking analysis (Supplementary Fig. 7b, c [this file] ). Especially, abundant EVs were secreted from high-metastatic cancer cells than low-metastatic ones through a quantitative analysis of EVs isolated from an equal number of cells (Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] ). HSP70, CD63, and CD9, characteristic proteins for EVs further validated the isolated EVs (Supplementary Fig. 7d, e [this file] ). EVs isolated from normal colonic epithelial cells NCM-460 were chosen as the control EVs and their structures, sizes, numbers, and characteristics were shown in Supplementary Fig. 7f–h [this file] . 
After incubation, confocal imaging showed the presence of PKH67 spots in recipient fibroblasts and stellate cells, suggesting that EVs released by different tumor cells could be successfully delivered to fibroblasts and stellate cells in vitro (Fig. 5a, b [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Fig. 8a, b [this file] ). Consistent with in vivo data (Fig. 4h–j [rid=Fig4] ), the highly metastatic CRC cell-EVs-educated fibroblasts and stellate cells upregulated pro-inflammatory genes, myofibroblastic markers, and chemokines, including , , , , , and (Supplementary Fig. 9a–d [this file] ). More important, elevated mRNA levels of , , , , , and were detected in SW480- or SW620-derived high ITGBL1-EVs-treated fibroblasts and stellate cells, but ITGBL1-silencing ablated these effects (Supplementary Fig. 10a–d [this file] ). 
As shown in the Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] , highly metastatic CRC-derived EVs increased the expression of phosphorylated NF-κB, decreased IkappaBalpha (IκBα), and activated NF-κB signaling in WI-38 and LX-2. Detection of the relative luciferase activity of NF-κB in WI-38 and LX-2 further validated these findings (Supplementary Fig. 11c, d [this file] ). 
Treatment of fibroblasts or stellate cells with ITGBL1-enriched EVs from CRC cells showed co-location of ITGBL1 with TNFAIP3 by Co-IP and immunofluorescence detection (Supplementary Fig. 12a–d [this file] ). The subsequent Co-IP in combination with western blot experiments further validated no direct binding between ITGBL1 and other integrins (Supplementary Fig. 13a, b [this file] ). Moreover, KD of integrin β1 barely affected the regulatory effect of ITGBL1 on the NF-κB signaling pathway (Supplementary Fig. 13c, d [this file] ). 
In the subcutaneous transplantation tumors, we further confirmed the enhancement of stemness genes expression in tumors treated with conditioned medium from ITGBL1-overexpressing WI-38 or LX-2 (Supplementary Fig. 14a [this file] ). 
As shown in Fig. 8c, d [rid=Fig8] , the conditioned medium-treated HCT116 cells showed increased motility, but blocking IL-6 or IL-8 with their respective neutralizing antibodies partially reversed this increased motility (Supplementary Fig. 15a, b [this file] ). In the lung and liver metastatic tumors from Fig. 8e, f [rid=Fig8] , we further confirmed the positive adjustment of EMT-associated genes expression in metastatic tumors pretreated with conditioned medium from ITGBL1-overexpressing WI-38 or LX-2 (Supplementary Fig. 14b, c [this file] ). 
Using above lung and liver metastatic tissues from CRC patients, we detected the α-SMA (characteric marker for myofibroblastic CAFs) expression by IHC staining analysis, and the results showed high density of α-SMA + myofibroblasts around the metastatic tumors (Supplementary Fig. 16 [this file] ), implying the important function of α-SMA + myofibroblasts on metastatic CRC development. CAFs with low ITGBL1 and high ITGBL1 expression were applied for further experimentation (Supplementary Fig. 17a, b [this file] ). Expectedly, primary CAFs with high ITGBL1 expression secreted higher levels of IL-6 and IL-8 relative to low ITGBL1-expressing CAFs and NFs (Supplementary Fig. 17c, d [this file] ). Similar to fibroblasts educated by ITGBL1-enriched EVs, primary CAFs with high ITGBL1 expression promoted tumorigenicity (Supplementary Fig. 17e, f [this file] ), tumor stemness (Supplementary Fig. 17g [this file] ), metastatic growth (Supplementary Fig. 17h, i [this file] ), and EMT (Supplementary Fig. 17j [this file] ). In vitro experiments validated the fact that primary CAFs with high ITGBL1 increased expression levels of stemness-related genes and the spheroid formation (Supplementary Fig. 18a, b [this file] ). Additionally, ITGBL1 increased the expression levels of EMT-associated genes and tumor cells migration (Supplementary Fig. 18c, d [this file] ). 
Additionally, RUNX2 promotes the CRC EMT through activation of fibroblasts, i.e., the transition into myofibroblasts, which are known to facilitate tumor growth and invasiveness (Supplementary Fig. 19 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, our preliminary study also showed that TGF-β in the EVs was not alerted in ITGBL1 overexpressing or silencing CRC cells (Supplementary Fig. 20a [this file] ), and their effect on TGF-β/Smads signaling pathway was little in the targeted HCT116 cells and CAFs from liver metastatic tumors (Supplementary Fig. 20b, c [this file] ). Nevertheless, we observed the increased secretion of cytokines TGF-β in the activated hepatic stellate cells LX-2 upon indicated EVs treatment (Supplementary Fig. 20d [this file] ), companying with positive effect on TGF-β/Smads signaling pathway in HCT116 cells (Supplementary Fig. 20e, f [this file] ). 
Consistent with the results in immunedeficient nude mice, education of CRC-ITGBL1-enriched EVs increased recruitment of α-SMA + hStCs, myofibroblasts, FN deposition, F4/80 macrophage, and Ly6G myeloid cells migration to the liver and lung of C57Bl/6 mice (Supplementary Fig. 21a, b [this file] ), supporting the concept of a pre-metastatic niche formation. Importantly, the experimental lung and liver metastasis model, and the cecum orthotopic tumor metastasis model validate ITGBL1-enriched EVs accelerated metastatic growth (Supplementary Fig. 22a–c [this file] ). Expression levels of , , , , , and are increased in ITGBL1-enriched EVs-treated CAFs (Supplementary Fig. 22d–f [this file] ). 
The general clinical information of all the 124 CRC patients was included in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] . 
Human , , and genes were amplified by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and sub-cloned into the expression vector pcDNA3.1, and were named pcDNA3.1-ITGBL1, pcDNA3.1-RUNX2, and pcDNA3.1-nSMase2, respectively (Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ). 
Recombinant lentiviruses containing pLV4-shRNA-ITGBL1, pLV4-shRNA-RUNX2, pLV4-shRNA-nSMase2, pLV4-shRNA-TNFAIP3, pLV4-shRNA-ITGβ1, and pLV4-shRNA-NC (non-targeting control) were constructed, and the suitable shRNA sequences were listed in Supplementary Table 6 [this file] . 
The primers used for reverse transcription and PCR analysis were listed in the Supplementary Table 7 [this file] . 
The primers for the amplification of the promoter regions −825 to +36 containing the putative OSE2 element −793/−786 relative to the TSS were listed in Supplementary Table 7 [this file] . Uncropped versions of gels shown in figures are supplied in the Supplementary Information [this file] . 
Uncropped versions of all blots shown in main figures are supplied in the Supplementary Fig. 23 [this file] – 33 [this file] . 
All the source data supporting the findings of this study are available within the article and its Supplementary Information [this file] files and from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

title: Document S1. Transparent Methods, Figures S1–S8, and Tables S1–S3
caption: No description
description: Document  S1.  Transparent  Methods,  Figures  S1–S8,  and  Tables  S1–S3
context_description:
In the screen, we found nearly 4,000 imidazopyridine derivatives with significantly differential luciferase activities in the HEK-OCT4 reporter cell line ( Figure S1 [this file] A). 
Red, upregulated genes; blue, downregulated genes. p values represent values after multitest adjustment (see details in Transparent Methods [this file] ). 
We found nearly 10-fold inductions of both OCT4 and NANOG by compound 1 at low nanomolar doses when compared with untreated cells ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] B, 1C, and S1 [this file] B). We found the induction of T and GATA4 in human PSCs (hPSCs) treated with 10 μM O4I3 ( Figure S1 [this file] C), suggesting that O4I3 might transiently hyperactivate OCT4 at high concentrations, which led to the differentiation and reduction of OCT4 activity ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] B). We also tested the activity of zolpidem (containing the imidazopyridine backbone) in both reporter cell lines and detected an approximate 2-fold induction in NCCIT-OCT4 and NANOG reporter cells at a concentration of 10 μM ( Figures S1 [this file] D and S1E). 
We chemically expanded O4I3 by replacing the CH group at the phenyl moiety with various substituents on the aryl moiety ( Table S1 [this file] ) and found that compounds induced drug-like, structure-dependent activations in NCCIT-OCT4 cells ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] D). 
Functional annotation and enrichment analysis of DNA microarray in O4I3-treated hPSCs showed that O4I3 (10 nM) promoted hPSC homeostasis and repressed cellular differentiation ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] E and S2 [this file] A). qRT-PCR results confirmed that O4I3 stabilized or slightly increased the expression of pluripotency-associated genes (OCT4, SOX2, NANOG, and NODAL) and suppressed differentiation-related gene expression (GATA4, GATA6, PAX6, and SOX7) ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] F). Cellular viability of hPSCs was increased up to 4-fold at low nanomolar concentrations of O4I3 when compared with cells treated with Rock inhibitor (Y-27632) ( Figure S2 [this file] B), a small molecule able to increase hPSC survival ( Watanabe et al., 2007 [rid=bib44] ). Fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) analysis confirmed that O4I3 (10 nM) supports pluripotency during the maintenance of hPSCs after at least 30 passages under feeder-free conditions as shown by the expression of TRA-1-81 and OCT4 ( Figure S2 [this file] C). In addition, zolpidem also promoted the maintenance of iPSCs at a concentration of 10 μM ( Figure S2 [this file] B). 
Analyzing the effects of O4I3 on HFs, we detected the activation of reprogramming-associated genes at the mRNA level ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] A, 2B, and S3 [this file] A), which included an approximately 10-fold induction of OCT4 (∼0.1% versus in hPSCs) and NANOG (∼1% versus hPSCs) and an about 100-fold increase of SOX2 (∼1% versus hPSCs) and CDH1 (∼10% versus hPSCs). 
For this, the following two HF cell lines resistant to OSKM-mediated reprogramming were selected: (1) the HFF-LTR7-EGFP cell line (at passage >40), which expresses EGFP under the control of the LTR7 promoter, known to be activated during reprogramming ( Wang et al., 2014 [rid=bib42] ), and (2) HF4, isolated from a patient sample ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] C). iPSC-like colonies appeared in both cases in the presence of O4I3 ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] C and 2D) as well as in the presence of zolpidem at a concentration of 10 μM ( Figure S3 [this file] B). 
More than 95% of new hiPSCs co-expressed TRA-1-60 and E-Cadherin, as well as TRA-1-81 and OCT4 analyzed by FACS ( Figure S3 [this file] C). Comparative DNA microarray data showed that pluripotency-associated genes (Pou5F1 encoding OCT4, CDH1 encoding E-Cadherin, EPCAM, and DNMT3B) were highly expressed in hiPSC_1 and hiPSC_2, whereas fibroblast-related genes (CDH2, TWIST1, TWIST2, and SNAI2) were suppressed ( Figure S4 [this file] A). Visualization of global gene expression profiles by both scatterplots and heatmap shows a higher similarity of gene expression patterns between the newly generated hiPSCs and hPSCs (as positive controls) when compared with that of HF ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] H and S4 [this file] B). Moreover, differentiated hiPSCs showed expression of markers of mesoderm (T, SLUG, and SNAI1), ectoderm (PAX6, Nestin, and Tuj1), and endoderm (AFP, FOXA2, and SOX17) ( Figures S4 [this file] C and S4D) using respective standard protocols, which further confirmed the pluripotency properties of the new hiPSCs. 
More than 30% of them were found to be involved in epigenetic modification and chromatin remodeling ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] B and S5 [this file] A), for example, OCT4 (POU5F1), LIN28, MYCN, KIFs, DNMT3B, HDAC2, TET1, EZH2, and JARID2, which are of importance in somatic reprogramming and maintenance of pluripotency ( Apostolou and Hochedlinger, 2013 [rid=bib1] , Mikkelsen et al., 2008 [rid=bib19] ). Gene enrichment analysis on RNA sequencing also showed that the top signaling pathways regulated by O4I3 in HFs included regulation of organismal process, system development and embryo implantation, as well as cell differentiation ( Figure S5 [this file] A) 
We found that O4I3 significantly repressed six of these nine genes, including DOT1L ( Figure S5 [this file] B). 
We could not observe a significant difference between two cell lines, as determined by FACS analysis ( Figure S5 [this file] C). Chromatin immunoprecipitation-qPCR results in two reprogrammable fibroblasts (HF1 and HF2) and in two reprogramming-resistant fibroblasts (HF3 and HF4) showed that OSKM was sufficient to induce abundant occupation of H3K4Me3 at the promoter of OCT4 in HF1 and HF2 in a comparable manner to those in iPSCs, while producing 1,000- to 10,000-fold less in reprogramming-resistant cells ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] C and S5 [this file] D). Analysis on the global level of H3K4Me3 by immunocytochemistry showed the increase of H3K4Me3 upon O4I3 treatment ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] D and S5 [this file] E). Accordingly, we found the reduction of global H3K9Me3 posterior to H3K4Me3 activation ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] E and S5 [this file] F). 
As expected, zolpidem protected H3K4 methylation and inhibited the expression of both KDM5 and KDM4 at micromolar concentrations ( Figure S6 [this file] A). We detected the induction of OCT4, SOX2, and E-Cadherin expression in JIB-04-treated HFs ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] D and S6 [this file] B). 
KDM5B showed a similar expression pattern to OCT4 and NANOG, whereas KDM5A behaved oppositely ( Figure S6 [this file] C). In the case of KDM5D, the difference was not significant and KDM5C remained unaffected between ESC and oocyte ( Figure S6 [this file] C). We further compared the expression of KDM5A-5D in fibroblasts, reprogrammed fibroblasts by OSKM, iPSCs, and NCCIT ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] E and S7 [this file] A). KDM5A was preferentially expressed in reprogramming-resistant fibroblasts, whereas KDM5B was more pluripotency related ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] E), which was in agreement with previous gene expression profiling data ( Figure S7 [this file] B) ( Takahashi et al., 2014 [rid=bib36] ), as well as immunoblotting results ( Figure S7 [this file] C). As JIB-04 also inhibits KDM4 and KDM6 demethylases, we repressed the expression of KDM5A-D using RNA interference (small interfering RNA [siRNA]) and found significantly higher OCT4 reporter activity in NCCIT-OCT4 cells ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] F), as well as higher mRNA levels of OCT4 and SOX2 in HFs in the absence of KDM5A and KDM5D expression, but not in KDM5B and KDM5C knockdown cells ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] G and S7 [this file] D). Notably, the effects of KDM5D repression were found to be less significant when compared with those of KDM5A knockdown, most probably due to the various transfection efficiencies ( Figure S7 [this file] D). Moreover, knockdown of KDM5A also increased the global levels of H3K4Me3 with or without OSKM ( Figure S7 [this file] E). Overexpression of KDM5A compromised these effects caused by KDM5A inhibition (either O4I3 or JIB-04) in NCCIT-OCT4 reporter cells in a concentration-dependent manner, as well as in HEK-OCT4 reporter cells ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] H, S7 [this file] F, and S7G). Conversely, cells were resistant to KDM5A chemical inhibitors in the absence of KDM5A expression ( Figure S7 [this file] G). Of note, at concentrations of 10 and 100 nM, O413 treatment alone showed higher OCT4 levels when compared with that of O4I3 combined with siRNA-mediated KDM5A inhibition ( Figure S7 [this file] G), which may be due to the insufficient knockdown efficiency ( Figure S7 [this file] D). 
Moreover, KDM5A siRNA increased the global level of H3K4Me3 in a dose-dependent manner ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] E and S7 [this file] E). 
Transient suppression of KDM5A expression with either KDM5A siRNA or chemical inhibition mimicked the effect of O4I3 to either increase the episomal-based reprogramming efficiency in normal fibroblasts or to facilitate the formation of ESC-like TRA-1-60-positive colonies in reprogramming-resistant fibroblasts ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] F and S8 [this file] A). These ESC-like colonies could be isolated and expanded to establish stable hiPSC cell lines with the expression of pluripotency markers, like OCT4, SOX2, E-Cadherin, TRA-1-60, and TRA-1-81, and full differentiation potential ( Figures S8 [this file] B and S8C). 
All methods can be found in the accompanying Transparent Methods supplemental file [this file] .

context_description:
Out of 6848 quantified proteins, we found 166 receptors with known ligand interactions (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ), showing that ECs possess a wide array of receptors that can interact with ligands present in their microenvironment. 
Inserts show zooms of example cytokine-receptor interactions; for network with labels, see Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] . 
This library contained 46 proteins from the ImmuneXpresso search including both TNFα and (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). We quantified a total of 4790 proteins with an overall median Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.96 (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). To visualize response similarities between stimuli, we constructed a network of the number of differentially abundant proteins and overlap per stimulus (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). There was no significant enrichment for module 4 (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 3b, c [this file] ). 
See Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] for non-summarized network. 
Initially, we performed a concentration range of TNFα and IFNγ separately and observed similar proteomic profiles for stimulation at 10 and 100 ng/ml (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
Principal component analysis showed high overlap with HUVECs in Rombouts et al. and BOECs and pulmonary ECs in Long et al. (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). However, the correlation of transcriptome signatures also highlighted study-induced variation (Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] ). Relative expression levels of key EC genes as well as TNFα and IFNγ receptors were similar between the majority of EC types (Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). 
This resulted in a network containing 2306 interactions, revealing 9 high-density hubs summarized in biological processes: “ ”, “ ”, “ ”, “ ”, “ ”, “ ”, “ ”, “ ” and “ ” (Fig. 5d [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, in contrast to MHCI proteins, which were detected abundantly on the protein level, we were only able to detect and in separate LFQ workflow experiments (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). MHCI showed a clear distribution over the cell membrane, also in steady-state condition (Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] ) and in line with both transcriptome and protein data, was only observed in IFNγ stimulated conditions. 
Time-dependent changes were most apparent in the secretome as proteins were excreted into the supernatant over time (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ) and we observed limited protein changes due to stimulation at early timepoints (30 m and 4 h). 
Variability in donor-to-donor responses is a point of concern as well , but throughout this study, we employed BOECs derived from 19 different donors (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ) and observed consistent inflammatory signatures throughout. 
For all experiments, except the multi-omics and secretome experiments, three different pools of three unique BOEC donors (mixed sexes and ages) were used (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
All recombinant human cytokines used for stimulations were obtained from Peprotech (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
For reproducibility, ECs from 19 different donors were randomly combined in different pools of three donors (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ).

context_description:
Remarkably, 67 out of the 68 top DE proteins are mitochondrial proteins (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] b, c), and most of them are tightly correlated with the others (Fig. S 1 [this file] ). 
While a small fraction of these mitochondrial proteins starts to show up with the depth of 2000–3000 proteins, the majority of these proteins are revealed with the depth of at least 4000 proteins (Fig. S 2 [this file] ). 
Notably, most of these module proteins are correlated with the amyloid level (Fig. S 3 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, 4 out of the 6 mitochondrial proteins that decreased in AD in both human and mouse CSFs were also reduced in the AD serum (i.e. ALDH6A1, ETFB, SOD2, and PRDX3), highlighting their robustness as the AD biofluid signature (Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] b, Fig. S 4 [this file] ).
pub_title: Integrated analysis of ultra-deep proteomes in cortex, cerebrospinal fluid and serum reveals a mitochondrial signature in Alzheimer’s disease

We first examined the proteomic data quality of our 5 discovery datasets from cortex, CSF and serum (Supplementary Table S 1 [this file] , S 2 [this file] , S 3 [this file] , S 4 [this file] and S 5 [this file] ). 
Our ultra-deep CSF proteome identified most of previously reported AD CSF biomarker candidates (12 out of 13, Supplemental Table S 6 [this file] ), however, the majority of them displayed no statistical significance except SMOC1 and TGFB2, which may be due to the small sample size in our pilot study and/or the small changes of these proteins in AD (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] b). 
Finally, the three ranks were integrated into a final rank (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] a, Supplemental Table S 7 [this file] ).

context_description:
After computational quality control (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ), 4580 cells were assigned to 7 transcriptional cell states using Shared Nearest Neighbour (SNN) and -Distributed Stochastic Neighbour Embedding ( -SNE) methods. The top 10 differentially expressed genes (DEG) between the 7 cell states are presented as a heatmap (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] & Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM3] ). This precipitous transcriptomic response is in keeping with an acute cellular stress response and coincided with a transient rise in IL-6 and IL-8 secretion independent of transcription (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). Analysis of independent EnSC cultures confirmed that decidualization polarizes cells into two subsets (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Known decidual stress defence genes (e.g. , and ) were enriched in S5 (designated DC) whereas genes involved in oxidative stress signalling and cellular senescence, including , and , prevailed in S6 (designated snDC) (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). Notably, on day 6, the proportion of DC and snDC was 78% and 13%, respectively (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). Withdrawal of the decidualization signal on day 8 elicited a further transcriptional change (S7), which was accounted for by partial de-differentiation of >95% of DC (Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM3] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
To test this hypothesis, uNK cells were isolated from the supernatants of freshly cultured EnSC using magnetic-activated cell sorting (MACS) and the purity and viability of cells confirmed by flow cytometry (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). As shown in Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] , dasatinib also markedly reduced SAβG activity and selectively inhibited CLU whereas the effect on sST2 secretion was minimal, thus recapitulating the actions of uNK cells. 
Following quality control (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ), -SNE analysis assigned 2847 cells to 5 clusters colour-coded to indicate the day of biopsy (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] ). EpC2 are ciliated epithelial cells found interspersed throughout endometrial glands (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). The abundance of various cell types and subsets in each biopsy is tabulated in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
Congruency was defined as the sum of correlation coefficients of >1 or <−1 for positively and negatively co-regulated genes, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ). 
As shown in Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] , / cells are characterized by the expression of multiple decidual TF and stress-resistance genes whereas a stress gene signature was prominent in / cells (Supplementary Data 8 [rid=MOESM3] ).

The top 10 differentially expressed genes (DEG) between the 7 cell states are presented as a heatmap (Supplementary Fig. 2 [rid=MOESM1] & Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). By day 2 of decidualization, most cells had transitioned to S3, which differed from S2 by 898 DEG (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). Withdrawal of the decidualization signal on day 8 elicited a further transcriptional change (S7), which was accounted for by partial de-differentiation of >95% of DC (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] and Supplementary Table 1 [rid=MOESM1] ). 
We used k-means cluster analysis to identify networks of co-regulated genes across the decidual pathway (Supplementary Data 3 [this file] ). Interestingly, this network is enriched in gene ontology terms ‘secreted’ (Benjamini adjusted = 3.7 × 10 , modified Fisher Exact test) and ‘type I interferon signalling pathway’ (Benjamini adjusted = 1.4 × 10 , modified Fisher Exact test) (Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ), both canonical features of cellular senescence . 
Clusters were designated based on canonical marker genes as endothelial cells (EC; = 141), epithelial cells (EpC; = 395), immune cells (IC; = 352) and EnSC ( = 1943) (Fig. 4c [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ). Based on CIBERSORT analysis, the remaining immune populations were identified as naive B-cells (IC1), monocytes (IC2), and macrophage/dendritic cells (IC3) (Fig. 4d [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Data 6 [this file] ). 
Progression from LH + 8 to LH + 10 was associated with altered expression of 518 genes in EnSC (Supplementary Data 7 [this file] ), 49% of which are also part of the 7 co-regulated gene networks in vitro ( < 10 , hypergeometric test). 
As shown in Supplementary Fig. 11 [rid=MOESM1] , / cells are characterized by the expression of multiple decidual TF and stress-resistance genes whereas a stress gene signature was prominent in / cells (Supplementary Data 8 [this file] ).

context_description:
In addition, expression of SENP1 in mouse liver was also markedly decreased through feeding with a high-fat diet (HFD) (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). 
We found that SENP1 is specifically reduced in hepatocytes during NAFLD (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). we then generated hepatocyte-specific SENP1-knockout mice by crossing mice with ( ) Tg mice to elucidate the function of SENP1 in NAFLD. The efficient deletion of SENP1 in hepatocytes was confirmed by immunoblot analysis of whole liver and isolated primary hepatocytes (Supplementary Fig. 1c, d [this file] ). 
Knockdown of SENP1 has been found in a focused genome-wide siRNA screen to sensitize to RIPK1-dependent cell death in mouse fibroblast L929 cells (Z-score = −3.88) (Supplementary Fig. 1e [this file] ), suggesting a potential role of SENP1 in suppressing RIPK1 activation. We detected RIPK1 activation as determined by substantial amount of p-S166 RIPK1 positive cells in liver sections of ; mice and increased p-S166 RIPK1 in primary hepatocytes isolated from 8 months old ; mice (Fig. 1g [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1f [this file] ). The death of hepatocytes is mainly apoptosis as determined by increased levels of cleaved caspase 3 (CC3) in SENP1-deficient hepatocytes, which is blocked in ; ; hepatocytes (Supplementary Fig. 1f [this file] ). However, we did not detect apparent signal of p-T231/S232 RIPK3, the hallmark of necroptosis , by immunoblotting in SENP1-deficient hepatocytes (Supplementary Fig. 1f [this file] ). 
We found increased inflammatory CD45 cell infiltration in ; mice at early stage (3 months of age) (Supplementary Fig. 1g [this file] ). Hepatic mRNA expression of inflammatory genes, including , , and , were increased in 3-month-old ; mice compared with WT littermates (Supplementary Fig. 1h [this file] ). The gene transcriptional patterns from the livers of 3-month-old ; mice showed dramatic changes compared to that of mice (Supplementary Fig. 1i [this file] ). Gene ontology (GO) analysis showed that hepatic SENP1 deficiency led to significant increase in the expression levels of those genes involved in mediating inflammatory response, such as TNFR1 signaling and NF-κB pathway (genes including , , , and ), and apoptotic process (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 1j [this file] ). In addition, multiple homeostatic and metabolic pathways were downregulated in ; mice (Supplementary Fig. 1k [this file] ). Strikingly, the up-regulation of these pro-inflammatory genes, including , , , , and were restored to that of control levels in ; ; livers and primary hepatocytes (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 1l [this file] ). 
We found that ; mice displayed steatosis, as determined by oil red O (ORO) staining, as early as at 3-month of age (Supplementary Fig. 1m [this file] ), and remained elevated at 8 months old (Fig. 2d [rid=Fig2] ). The deposition of lipid in ; livers and primary hepatocytes was further confirmed by measuring hepatic concentrations of triglyceride (TG) and total cholesterol (TC) (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 1n [this file] ). Interestingly, inhibition of RIPK1 in ; ; mice strongly suppressed steatosis (Fig. 2d, e [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 1n [this file] ). 
The fibrillary collagen deposition in the livers of ; mice was confirmed by Masson’s trichrome staining (MTS) (Fig. 2f [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 1o [this file] ). 
After AAV infection for 2 months (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ), we detected RIPK1 activation in livers of ; ; -C599S (SENP1-C599S) mice, but not that of SENP1-WT mice (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ). Consistently, SENP1-C599S but not SENP1-WT livers showed CC3 cells (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ). SENP1-C599S livers also showed elevated inflammatory cytokine production than that of SENP1-WT livers (Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] ). SENP1-C599S but not SENP1-WT livers display apparent steatosis (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). 
Consistent with previous study , SENP1 knockdown (KD) greatly sensitized cells to RDA (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ), which was also confirmed in cells expressing SENP1-specific short hairpin RNA (shRNA) (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). The death of SENP1-KD MEFs induced by TNFα/5z7 was fully protected by RIPK1 kinase inhibitor necrostatin-1s (Nec-1s) (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). SENP1 KD enhanced RIPK1 activation, as shown by increased activation biomarker p-S166 RIPK1, and apoptosis as shown by increased levels of the cleaved-caspase-3 (CC3) (Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ). 
We found that SENP1 KD has minor effect on NF-κB and MAPK pathway activation in TNFα-treated MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 3e [this file] ). Interestingly, SENP1 KD sensitized to cell death induced by TNFα alone, a condition that cannot induce the death of wild-type (WT) MEFs (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 3f, g [this file] ). 
Cycloheximide (CHX) blocks the translation downstream of NF-κB pathway activated by TNFα and promotes RIPK1-independent apoptosis (RIA) of WT MEFs when treated with TNFα, which cannot be blocked by RIPK1 inhibitor Nec-1s (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). In contrast, SENP1-KD MEFs showed greater levels of cell death in response to TNFα/CHX, which was blunted by treatment with Nec-1s (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). Furthermore, TNFα/CHX-treated SENP1-KD MEFs, but not WT MEFs, induced p-S166 RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). 
We found that SENP1 KD greatly sensitized cells to TNFα/CHX/zVAD-induced necroptosis (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). The increased sensitivity of SENP1-KD MEFs to necroptosis was also marked by the increased levels of the necroptotic biomarkers p-S166 RIPK1, p-T231/S232 RIPK3, and p-S345 MLKL relative to that of WT MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] ). Consistent with increased activation of necroptosis, we found that SENP1-KD MEFs showed more necrosome formation than that of WT MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ). 
We detected substantial increases in activated p-S166 RIPK1 cells throughout fetal liver (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). 
Compared to WT fetal livers, fetal livers showed markedly elevated expression of genes involved in apoptotic process and immune response, which is in line with the increased levels of cell death and pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines in fetal livers (Supplementary Fig. 5b, c [this file] ). mRNA levels can be upregulated during RIPK1-dependent cell death in certain cells . The elevated expression of mRNA levels was reduced in ; fetal livers (Fig. 3l [rid=Fig3] ). embryos have poor blood vessel development and anemia ; consistently, fetal livers showed downregulation of multiple blood vessel development pathways (Supplementary Fig. 5d [this file] ). Interestingly, the gene expression abnormalities of 278 genes (~30% genes upregulated in relative to WT), including these involved in apoptotic process and immune response, were restored to WT levels by genetic inhibition of RIPK1 in ; fetal livers (Fig. 3m, n [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] ). 
However, we were unable to obtain viable ; mice despite the prevention of cell death in fetal livers of these mice (Supplementary Fig. 5f [this file] ). Similarly, RIPK1-D138N mutation does not alter the downregulation of genes that are involved in blood vessel development in embryos (Supplementary Fig. 5g, h [this file] ). We found that RIPK1-D138N mutation could not rescue the deficient EPO production in ; embryos (Supplementary Fig. 5i [this file] ). Defective rescue of the expression of EPO and its receptor EPOR in ; embryos were further confirmed by quantitative RT-PCR (Supplementary Fig. 5j [this file] ). 
To explore this possibility, we conducted a mass spectrometry analysis of SUMOylated proteins in WT and SENP1-KD MEFs stimulated by TNFα for 5 min (Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ). 
We then performed in vitro SUMOylation assays in which RIPK1 was purified from HEK293T cells and pretreated with pan-deubiquitylase USP2 to completely remove ubiquitination to avoid its interference with SUMOylation (Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). 
We found that ectopically expressed RIPK1 was co-immunoprecipitated with SENP1 (Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] ). In contrast, A20 does not interact with SENP1 (Supplementary Fig. 6d [this file] ). We found that the intermediate domain (ID) of RIPK1 was mainly required for the interaction of RIPK1 and SENP1 (Supplementary Fig. 6e [this file] ). Similarly, we found that the N-terminus, but not the C-terminus of SENP1 interacted with RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 6f [this file] ). 
In cell SUMOylation assays using nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid (Ni-NTA) purification showed that WT SENP1, but not its catalytically inactive mutant, significantly reduced the SUMOylation levels of exogenous RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). 
We found that RIPK1 SUMOylation is substantially increased in the livers of individuals with NASH than that in the nonsteatotic controls (Supplementary Fig. 6h [this file] ). Consistently, RIPK1 SUMOylation is also increased in the livers of mice with NAFLD than that in control mice (Supplementary Fig. 6i [this file] ). 
To determine the relevant lysine(s) that can be modified by SUMO in the RIPK1 protein, we conducted a mass spectrometry analysis of SUMOylated RIPK1 by using in cell SUMOylation assays, in which T90R-mutated SUMO3 was exogenously expressed to promote modified substrates that when digested with trypsin produce remnants of two amino acids that can be detected by MS to identify SUMO conjugation sites (Supplementary Fig. 7a, b [this file] ). We found that overexpressing SUMO3-T90R and Ubc9 induced the SUMOylation of RIPK1 at multiple lysine residues with a conserved Lys550 (K550, mouse RIPK1) and K132 residues being the main SUMOylation sites of RIPK1 (Fig. 6a [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] ). Mutation of K550 to Ala reduced SUMOylation of exogenously expressed RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 7d [this file] ). In contrast, mutation of both K550 and K132 to Ala did not offer additional reduction of SUMOylation levels of RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 7d [this file] ), thus RIPK1 is dominantly SUMOylated at K550. 
To address a requirement for the SUMOylation of RIPK1 in controlling its activity and cell death, we reconstituted RIPK1 and SENP1 double-deficient MEFs with WT RIPK1 and K550A mutant RIPK1, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 7e [this file] ). Moreover, disruption of RIPK1 SUMOylation by K550A mutation increased the recruitment of A20, while decreased the recruitment of LUBAC into TNF-RSC in TNFα-stimulated SENP1-KD cells (Fig. 6d [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 7f [this file] ). 
We found that PIAS1 was present in RIPK1 immunoprecipitates when co-expressing PIAS1 and RIPK1 in HEK293T cells (Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). Similar to SENP1, we found that PIAS1 also interacted with the intermediate domain (ID) of RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 8b [this file] ). 
To examine whether PIAS1 SUMOylates RIPK1, we performed in cell SUMOylation assays using Ni-NTA purification, which showed that PIAS1 significantly increased the SUMOylation of exogenous RIPK1 (Supplementary Fig. 8c [this file] ). We next tested whether the SUMOylation of RIPK1 in TNF-RSC of TNFα-stimulated SENP1-KD cells was mediated by PIAS1, we performed a tandem IP of TNF-RSC to isolate SUMOylated RIPK1 in SENP1 and PIAS1 double knockdown cells (Supplementary Fig. 8d [this file] ). We found that PIAS1 knockdown reduced RIPK1 SUMOylation in TNF-RSC of SENP1-KD cells that were stimulated with TNFα (Supplementary Fig. 8e [this file] ). 
We found that PIAS1 was also recruited to the TNF-RSC within minutes of TNFα stimulation (Supplementary Fig. 8f [this file] ). Consistent with the interaction of PIAS1 and RIPK1, the recruitment of PIAS1 into TNF-RSC was totally blocked in MEFs stimulated by TNFα (Supplementary Fig. 8f [this file] ). We found that the recruitment of SENP1 in TNF-RSC is reduced in PIAS1-KO cells when compared to that in PIAS1-WT cells (Supplementary Fig. 8g [this file] ), while the recruitment of PIAS1 is not altered in SENP1-KO cells (Supplementary Fig. 8h [this file] ), suggesting that PIAS1 is at least partially required for the recruitment of SENP1. 
We found that PIAS1 knockdown dramatically reduced cell death in SENP1-KD cells that were treated with TNFα (Supplementary Fig. 8i [this file] ). PIAS1 knockdown also inhibited RIPK1 activation and the levels of CC3 (Supplementary Fig. 8j [this file] ). 
We used 2 months old mice, when spontaneous liver damage are not observed in ; mice (Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] ). After LPS injection for 4 h, we observed substantial liver damage in ; mice compared to littermate controls as determined by ALT, AST levels and histology stains (Supplementary Fig. 9b, c [this file] ). Consistently, ; livers displayed increased number of TUNEL and p-S166 RIPK1 cells compared to livers after LPS stimulation (Supplementary Fig. 9d [this file] ). In addition, the mRNA levels of inflammatory cytokines, including , , , , , and were substantially higher in ; livers than that in livers (Supplementary Fig. 9e [this file] ). Strikingly, RIPK1-D138N mutation largely reduced the liver damage and inflammation in ; ; mice (Supplementary Fig. 9b–e [this file] ). 
In primary mouse hepatocytes, SENP1 deficiency substantially increased RIPK1 SUMOylation levels after exposure to palmitic acid (PA), which \was performed to mimic in vivo NAFLD pathologies (Supplementary Fig. 9f [this file] ). We also observed substantial cell death in SENP1-deficient hepatocytes treated with PA (Supplementary Fig. 9g [this file] ). Consistently, RIPK1 activation as determined by its S166 phosphorylation, and apoptosis as shown by increased levels of CC3 are increased in ; hepatocytes treated with PA (Supplementary Fig. 9h [this file] ). In addition, the apoptosis of ; hepatocytes induced by PA was fully protected by RIPK1-D138N mutation (Supplementary Fig. 9g, h [this file] ). 
H&E staining revealed that the hepatic steatosis and lipid accumulation were markedly aggravated in HFD-fed ; mice compared with that of HFD-fed mice (Fig. 7d [rid=Fig7] ), which was further confirmed by ORO staining and measuring hepatic concentrations of triglyceride (TG) and total cholesterol (TC) (Fig. 7e [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 9i [this file] ). In comparison, the hepatic steatosis and lipid accumulation in the liver of HFD-fed ; ; mice were considerably lower (Fig. 7d, e [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 9i [this file] ).

description: Fig.  S1.  CDK2AP1  interacts  with  the  C‐terminal  of  GATAD2B.  Fig.  S2.  Enriched  proteins  with  CHD4‐M.  Fig.  S3.  Cancer‐associated  missense  mutation  in  the  C‐terminal  region  of  CHD4  may  change  the  balance  of  CHD4/NuRD  vs  CHD4/ChAHP.  Fig.  S4. context_description:
Examination of intensity‐based absolute quantification (iBAQ) values in all GATAD2B bait replicates revealed that all three replicates of GATAD2B (full‐length) and two replicates of GATAD2B‐C but not GATAD2B‐N had high‐intensity values for CDK2AP1 (Fig. S1 [this file] ), indicating the C‐terminal GATAD2B binding preference of CDK2AP1. 
This result is supported by the number of unique NCOR complex peptides obtained as well as the low representation of these proteins in databases of common mass spectrometry (MS) contaminants (Table S1 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, CDK2AP1 enrichment was seen only with CHD4‐C but not with CHD4‐N and CHD4‐M (Figs 5D [rid=febs16112-fig-0005] and S2 [this file] ), indicating that CDK2AP1 only recognises the C‐terminal half of CHD4 (Fig. 5A [rid=febs16112-fig-0005] ). 
We therefore examined the six missense mutations in CHD4 within or adjacent to this region, which could potentially affect the interaction of CHD4 with either ADNP or GATAD2B (Fig. S3 [this file] A). Four of these mutations (D1867N, P1879S, R1890C and N1891D) had no impact on CHD4 interaction with either GATAD2B or ADNP (D1867N is exemplified in Fig. S3 [this file] B, Lane 2). However, a reduction in CHD4‐C interaction with full‐length ADNP was observed, when compared to WT CHD4‐C (Fig. S3 [this file] B). With regard to GATAD2B, only CHD4‐C showed a clear effect on the interaction when compared to WT (Fig. S3 [this file] C). 
Further investigation of the number of unique peptides detected for HDAC2 vs HDAC1 in CDK2AP1 PD‐MS was 6 to 2, respectively (Fig. S4 [this file] A). We conclude that this observation is linked to the assembly and architecture and consequently interaction of the HDAC1 with the CDK2AP1/NuRD complex (Fig. S4 [this file] B,C).
pub_title: Unique protein interaction networks define the chromatin remodelling module of the NuRD complex
