title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
These two domains both adopt a similar compact α/β fold, thus constituting a dual-BRCT-like domain (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). However, at the primary protein sequence level, all the XIP isoforms, even the largest XIP-L, had an identity of no more than 25% with the animal MDC1 proteins only within the BRCT-like domain(s) (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ), without any significant similarity found in the rest of these proteins (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
In addition to the above retriever peptides p1 and p2, we synthesized another peptide p3, in which S139 was replaced by glutamic acid, mimicking the negatively-charged phosphorylated serine (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). Our ppd experiment showed that both dual-BRCT-like domains (XIP-L and -M), but not single-BRCT-like domain (XIP-S), specifically interacted with peptide p2 but not p1 (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ), indicating that the second insignificant BRCT domain is indispensable to the first RTT107_BRCT_5 domain in γ-H2A.X recognition. 
Reverse transcription-quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) result showed that NM_001340429.1 (NM_001340429.1) was the major transcript isoform of in all the examined plant organs (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] , b [this file] ). The transcript levels of three isoforms were not significantly affected by exogenous replicative or genotoxic stresses (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). Again, the full-length XIP-M interacted specifically with both p2 and p3 retrievers, but not p1 (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ), suggesting that dual-BRCT-like domain contributes to the specificity of XIP recognition to γ-H2A.X. 
We expressed YFP-fused XIP-M in mesophyll protoplasts (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). After longer BLM treatment (3 h), the immunostaining assay revealed that, in contrast to the largely dispersed distribution under mock condition (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ), the XIP signals became focused and co-localized well with all the observed BLM-induced γ-H2A.X foci in DAPI-stained nuclei, although with a slight diffusion around (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] ). 
This mutant was verified as a functional knock-out mutant by RT-qPCR and RACE analyses (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] , b). In consistence, we observed smaller meristem zone in root tips (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). Both HU and BLM treatments significantly inhibited seedling growth, the root meristem zones within root tips, and primary root elongation (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] a– c [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). Till now, the biological significance of each transcript isoform cannot be fully elucidated (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Therefore, we cloned the entire genomic DNA of (including 2 kb of promoter and 1 kb of terminator of the longest ) and transformed it into (named as in ), which complemented the growth inhibition of and recovered the WT-like root meristem zone (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] a– d [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
After normalization, those genes with both fold change of transcript level ≥2 and -value ≤0.05 were considered as differentially expressed genes (DEGs) (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] and Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ). Among them, we noticed that the DEG number in after BLM treatment ( -BLM/ -Mock) was obviously smaller (338 up- and 144 downregulated genes) when compared to those in WT after BLM treatment (WT-BLM/WT-Mock, 771 up- and 742 downregulated genes), suggesting that the transcriptional response to BLM challenge may be less severe in mutant when compared with that in WT (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ), which was in line with our quantitative RT-qPCR examination (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ), and was further supported by the principal component analysis (PCA) (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
In the most enriched GO category ‘response to stress (GO: 0006950)’, we noticed that 132 out of the 264 upregulated DEGs (50%) in mutant were overlapped with those in WT-HU/WT-Mock and WT-BLM/WT-Mock (Supplementary Fig. 12 [this file] ), supporting that -depletion partially mimics the WT plants under replication and/or genotoxin stresses in activating diverse responsive genes. 
We found 37 upregulated DPPs in WT-BLM/WT-Mock in this study, including the best-studied γ-H2A.X (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] ). 
Our quantitative parallel reaction monitoring (PRM) analysis confirmed the significant activation of γ-H2A.X (H2A.X-S139) after BLM treatment (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] and Data 6 [this file0] ). Besides, Ser or Thr residue within proteins implicated in cell cycle progression and cell death were found significantly hyper-phosphorylated in mutant compared to WT after BLM treatment (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] and Supplementary Data 6 [this file0] ). 
The difference was much more obvious and significant after BLM treatment (Supplementary Fig. 14a [this file] ). 
In comparison, the root apical meristem of mutants showed sporadic cell death even under mock growth condition, and more PI-stained cell death was found under BLM treatment (Supplementary Figs . 14b [this file] and 15 [this file] ), indicating that is required to impede spontaneous and DSB-induced cell death in vivo. Complete gene sequence ( in ) complemented the phenotype of mutants in plant cell death and genomic instability (Supplementary Fig. 14a [this file] , b [this file] ), indicating the lose-of-function of was the cause of these phenotypes. 
Similarly, the [Col] also showed more cell death phenotype at both mock and BLM conditions when compared to WT [Col] (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 15 [this file] ). 
We also verified their interaction via bimolecular fluorescence complementation (BiFC) experiment (Supplementary Fig. 16 [this file] ). 
While the precise molecular function of XIP remains to be determined, based on the phenotype and the protein data showing XIP can interact with γ-H2A.X and RAD51, we propose a possible model for how XIP could contribute to HR and the maintenance of genome stability (Supplementary Fig. 17 [this file] ).

title: No Title
caption: Appendix
description: Appendix  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
We used our AP‐MS results to build a KZFP interactome global network (Fig 1 [rid=embj2018101220-fig-0001] B and Appendix Fig S1 [this file] ). 
The capture of ZNF282 by ZNF398 attracted our attention, as both of these KZFPs contain a DUF3669 domain, and interactions between DUF3669‐containing KZFPs were previously recorded (Gao , 2008 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0014] ; Kang & Shin, 2015 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0026] ; Huttlin , 2017 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0019] ) ( Appendix Fig S2 [this file] ). 
Those found together with KAP1 related to nucleosome formation and modification or involved other TRIM family proteins or cytoplasmic chaperones sharing subcellular localizations with their baits as for ZNF546, ZNF304, and ZNF283 (Fig 1 [rid=embj2018101220-fig-0001] A, Appendix Fig S3A [this file] ). 
Several of these unique preys pointed to RNA‐related functions such as unique partners detected with the eIF3‐associated ZKSCAN4 and ZNF746 or the RNA‐processing paraspeckle‐forming proteins PSPC1, NONO, and SFPQ for ZNF213, corroborated by their similar sub‐nuclear localization patterns in these structures (Hata , 2008 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0016] ) ( Appendix Fig S3B [this file] ). 
Except for the MER51A/E‐binding ZNF20, TE‐binding KZFPs displaying unique interactomes were enriched over LINEs, which often recruited several of them (Imbeault , 2017 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0021] ) ( Appendix Fig S4 [this file] ). 
For some, this might have been due to lack of expression of their functional partners in 293T cells, although these KZFPs themselves did not display abnormally low levels in these cells ( Appendix Fig S5A [this file] ). In contrast, more than half of the KZFPs associated with more than three unique interactors segregated in a small cluster characterized by a higher expression in testis and blood according to the GTEx database (The GTEx consortium, 2013 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0062] ) ( Appendix Fig S5B [this file] ).

context_description:
We further documented the genomic recruitment of the 16 KZFPs interacting with 3 or more unique preys, completing a previously established dataset (Imbeault , 2017 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0021] ) with additional ChIP‐seq studies ( Table EV3 [this file] ). 
For the ChIP‐exo ( Table EV3 [this file] ), the samples were processed as described in our previous study (Imbeault , 2017 [rid=embj2018101220-bib-0021] ), and the libraries were pooled and sequenced 12 per lane on an Illumina HiSeq 2500 to a minimum depth of around 15 million 100 bp single‐end reads. For the ChIP‐seq experiments ( Table EV3 [this file] ), libraries were ligated with Illumina adaptors, and samples were pooled and sequenced on the same lane on an NextSeq 500 to a minimum depth of around 27 million 85 bp single‐end reads.

title: NIHMS1594342-supplement-1.pdf
context_description:
Unsupervised hierarchical clustering analysis of the mass spectrometry data showed that SCLC and NSCLC samples clustered according to their biological identity ( Figure S1A [href=this file] - B [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S1 [href=this file] , and Table S1 [href=#SD2] .
PKA in its inactive form is a tetramer of two catalytic and two regulatory subunits; dissociation of the regulatory subunits upon binding to cyclic AMP (cAMP) results in the activation of the kinase. , which codes for the catalytic subunit α of PKA (PKA-Cα) identified in the MIBs assays, is the dominant catalytic subunit expressed in SCLC ( Figure 1D [href=#F1] , Figure S1C [href=this file] , and Table S1 [href=#SD2] ). Tissue microarrays probed with an antibody recognizing phosphorylated CREB (pCREB, cAMP Response Binding Element factor 1, CREB), a well-known target of PKA, suggested activation of the PKA/CREB pathway in 17.5% of tumors ( Figure S1D [href=this file] ).
Switching from PKA-Cα to PKA-Cα at the time of cancer initiation in TKO; mice ( Figure S2A [href=this file] - C [href=this file] ) led to a significant inhibition of SCLC development compared to control TKO mice ( Figure 2A [href=#F2] - C [href=#F2] ).
Day 10 p=0.036*, 21 p=0.041*, 24 p=0.040*, 26 p=0.032*, 28 p=0.024*. (J) Quantification of expression of PKA-Cα and cleaved PARP (Cl-PARP) by immunoassay (n=6 tumors closest to the mean) (see Figure S2K [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S2 [href=this file] .
SCLC cell lines derived from PKA-Cα TKO tumors showed decreased survival in culture compared to TKO cells ( Figure S2D [href=this file] ). Knockdown of PKA-Cα in KP1 ( mutant) and KP11 ( mutant) cell lines also led to decreased growth and increased apoptosis ( Figure S2E [href=this file] - H [href=this file] ). Similar phenotypes were observed with allografts from KP1 cells ( Figure S2I [href=this file] - J [href=this file] ). Indeed, knockdown of PKA-Cα in these cells led to an increase in apoptosis and a significant inhibition of tumor growth in mice ( Figure 2H [href=#F2] - J [href=#F2] and Figure S2K [href=this file] ).
We found that treatment with the PP2A inhibitor (PP2Ai) cantharidin inhibited PP2A activity ( Figure S3A [href=this file] ) and enhanced the phosphorylation of PKA substrates in SCLC cells, including VASP (Vasodilator-stimulated phosphoprotein) and CREB ( Figure 3A [href=#F3] - B [href=#F3] ). This was prevented by pre-treatment with a PKA inhibitor (PKAi) ( Figure 3B [href=#F3] ), supporting a model in which PP2A activity counteracts PKA activity in SCLC cells. is the most highly expressed PP2A α subunit in human SCLC, and SCLC cells are dependent on expression for their growth in the DepMap dataset ( Figure S3B [href=this file] - C [href=this file] ). Treatment of SCLC cells with two independent small molecule activators of PP2A (or SMAPs), which act via inhibition of PPP2R1A ( Grossman et al., 2017 [href=#R27] ; Kastrinsky et al., 2015 [href=#R42] ; Sangodkar et al., 2017 [href=#R82] ), suppressed PKA substrate phosphorylation and induced apoptosis in SCLC cells ( Figure 3C [href=#F3] and Figure S3D [href=this file] - E [href=this file] ). PP2A has multiple targets in cells, and we found that SMAP treatment also had potent effects on c-MYC expression and mTOR activity in cells ( Figure S3F [href=this file] ), indicating that PKA signaling inhibition may represent only a fraction of the effects of PP2A activation in SCLC cells. Nevertheless, treatment with the SMAP-1154 tool compound as a single agent led to suppression of tumor growth in NJH29 SCLC xenografts ( Figure S3G [href=this file] ), with decreased phosphorylation of PKA substrates ( Figure S3H [href=this file] ). Treatment with a more bioavailable compound (SMAP DT-061) ( Sangodkar et al., 2017 [href=#R82] ) had a potent inhibitory effect with induction of apoptosis in a different SCLC xenograft model (NCI-H69 cells) in combination with chemotherapy treatment (cisplatin) ( Figure 3D [href=#F3] - F [href=#F3] and Figure S3I [href=this file] - J [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S3 [href=this file] .
We found Gαs (encoded by to be the most highly expressed G-protein α subunits in human SCLC ( Figure S4A [href=this file] ). In a clinical sequencing cohort of over 300 patients at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 5 tumors had amplification of and one tumor had a known oncogenic R201C mutation in Gαs ( Landis et al., 1989 [href=#R46] ) ( Figure S4B [href=this file] ).
To test the role of Gαs in SCLC, we crossed mice to TKO mice ( Figure S4C [href=this file] ). deletion in this context ( Figure S4D [href=this file] ) led to decreased tumor development compared to TKO mice ( Figure 4A [href=#F4] - D [href=#F4] ), indicating that Gαs is required for optimal cancer initiation in this model. To next determine if Gαs activation could promote SCLC development, we crossed TKO mice to transgenic mice expressing a constitutive active form of Gαs ( allele) following Cre expression and doxycycline (Dox) treatment ( Iglesias-Bartolome et al., 2015 [href=#R34] ) ( Figure S4E [href=this file] ). TKO; mice developed both SCLC tumors and non-SCLC tumors 3.5 months after Ad-Cre instillation ( Figure S4F [href=this file] ), indicating that Gαs strongly promotes lung cancer development in this genetic context. Nevertheless, TKO; mice still developed more and larger SCLC tumors compared to TKO controls, as determined by immunostaining for the neuroendocrine marker synaptophysin (SYP) ( Figure S4G [href=this file] - I [href=this file] ). When we analyzed tumor sections from TKO and TKO; SCLC tumors, as well as TKO; SCLC tumors, we found no differences in cell death or proliferation associated with changes in Gαs activity ( Figure S4J [href=this file] - M [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S4 [href=this file] .
We expressed LAP-tagged forms (localization and affinity purification tag, LAP-tag) of PKA-Cα, PKA-Cβ, and PKA-R1A in NCI-H446 SCLC cells ( Torres et al., 2009 [href=#R97] ) and performed mass spectrometry on the eluted fractions after purification ( Figure 5A [href=#F5] and Figure S5A [href=this file] ). We found complex interactions between catalytic and regulatory PKA subunits, suggesting that loss or inhibition of a single catalytic enzyme may not fully reveal the function of PKA in SCLC cells ( Figure S5B [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S5 [href=this file] and Table S2 [href=#SD3] .
When we knocked down the PKA target CREB in murine SCLC cells, we did not observe any inhibition of SCLC cell growth in culture or in mice ( Figure S6A [href=this file] - D [href=this file] ). We selected two PDX models (NJH29 and LX102), one allograft model (derived from a TKO mouse, 5BI), and one human cell line (NCI-H82), which are representative of the diversity of molecular phenotypes in human SCLC ( Rudin et al., 2019 [href=#R78] ) ( Figure S6E [href=this file] ). As expected, recombinant active PKA (rPKA) was better able to phosphorylate substrates with ATP while rAS-PKA (PKA-Cα ) was better at using Bn-ATPγS ( Figure 6B [href=#F6] - C [href=#F6] and Figure S6F [href=this file] - G [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S6 [href=this file] , and Tables S3 [href=#SD4] - S5 [href=#SD6] .
To gain further insight into the downstream consequences of PKA activation in SCLC cells, we next performed a global phosphoproteomic analysis in NCI-H526 cells (highly dependent on PKA activity, Figure 2G [href=#F2] - I [href=#F2] ) and NCI-H69 cells (which have relatively high PKA activity, Figure S6H [href=this file] ). However, GO term analysis for the phosphoproteome affected by cAMP in both cell lines showed enrichment for a variety of pathways implicated in cell proliferation and cancer ( Tables S4 [href=#SD5] , Figure 6G [href=#F6] , and Figure S6I [href=this file] ), similar to the pathways enriched in the AS-PKA experiments. 54 PKA substrates identified using the AS-PKA approach were also identified using the global phosphoproteomic approach ( Table S5 [href=#SD6] ).
To investigate the cellular consequences of PKA activation in SCLC cells, we expressed a doxycycline-inducible version of PKA-Cα with reduced capability for inhibition by regulatory subunits (active PKA, or aPKA) ( Orellana and McKnight, 1992 [href=#R68] ) or a GFP control in human NCI-H82 and NJH29 SCLC cells, which have relatively low PKA activity when compared to other SCLC cell lines ( Figure S6H [href=this file] ). Expression of aPKA led to a moderate increase in PKA signaling and a significant increase in the growth of xenografts ( Figure 7A [href=#F7] and Figure S7A [href=this file] - D [href=this file] ). PANTHER pathway analysis on the genes downregulated in both models (P<0.05) revealed changes in various signaling pathways, including cell adhesion and cell death ( Figure S7E [href=this file] ). Analysis of the upregulated genes in aPKA-expressing tumors revealed pathways associated with neuronal and neuroendocrine features ( Figure S7F [href=this file] ). In particular, we noticed a significant up-regulation of a number of markers of SCLC cancer stem cells ( Jahchan et al., 2016 [href=#R38] ), including , and ( Table S6 [href=#SD7] , Figure 7B [href=#F7] and Figure S7G [href=this file] - H [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S7 [href=this file] and Table S6 [href=#SD2] .
-benzyl-2-chloro- -(2,3-dihydrobenzo[ ][1,4]dioxin-6-yl)acetamide (JNS-1-40) ( Figure S3E [href=this file] , left panel): To a round bottom flask charged with a stir bar and 4 Å molecular sieves was added 1,4-Benzodioxan-6-amine (2.267 g, 15 mmol, 1.5 equiv.).
The product was analyzed by Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) ( Figure S3E [href=this file] , right panels).

The 20 kinases have a wide range of mRNA expression levels in human SCLC tumors ( Table S1 [href=this file] ), indicating that the MIBs approach was not biased towards highly expressed proteins.

description: Table S3, related to Figure 6: PKA substrates identified using the analog-sensitive (AS-PKA) approach
context_description:
Large-scale labeling reactions were performed, and mass spectrometry identified ~200 substrates that were labeled by rAS-PKA but not by wild-type rPKA ( Table S3 [href=this file] ). Among the identified substrates, at least 31 have been described before ( Baba et al., 2011 [href=#R3] ; Imamura et al., 2014 [href=#R35] ; Isobe et al., 2017 [href=#R36] ; Moore et al., 2009 [href=#R62] ; Nagai et al., 2016 [href=#R66] ) ( Table S3 [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S6 [href=#SD1] , and Tables S3 [href=this file] - S5 [href=#SD6] .
This connection between PKA activation and cancer stem cell phenotypes was supported by the interaction between PKA and SOX2 ( Figure 5B [href=#F5] ), which is a known regulator of stem cells ( Novak et al., 2019 [href=#R67] ), as well as the identification of the histone demethylase PHF2 as a direct PKA substrate ( Table S3 [href=this file] ), PHF2 having been implicated in the expansion of breast cancer stem cells ( Pattabiraman et al., 2016 [href=#R71] ).

context_description: Upon PKA activation with a long-acting analog of cAMP (8-Br-cAMP) ( Figure 6F [href=#F6] ), we identified thousands of phosphorylation sites, both gains and losses, which changed in response to 8-Br-cAMP ( Tables S4 [href=this file] ). However, GO term analysis for the phosphoproteome affected by cAMP in both cell lines showed enrichment for a variety of pathways implicated in cell proliferation and cancer ( Tables S4 [href=this file] , Figure 6G [href=#F6] , and Figure S6I [href=#SD1] ), similar to the pathways enriched in the AS-PKA experiments. 54 PKA substrates identified using the AS-PKA approach were also identified using the global phosphoproteomic approach ( Table S5 [href=#SD6] ).

title: mmc1.pdf
context_description:
Details of sequencing and analysis pipelines are described in the Supplemental Data [href=this file] .
Primers for RT-qPCR analysis for the experiments shown in Figure 3 [href=#fig3] are listed in Table S1 [href=this file] .
Variant constructs (TRX domain SNDC to SNDG p.Cys170Gly [c.508T>G] and affected individuals’ variants p.Arg53Cys [c.157C>T] and p.Arg231Trp [c.691C>T]) were generated according to manufacturers’ procedures via the QuikChange II XL Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit (Agilent), wild-type purified construct dilution (10 ng/μL), and 100 ng/μL primers specified in Table S2 [href=this file] .
Sanger sequencing of wild-type and variant plasmid DNA was performed as earlier described. 31 [href=#bib31] In brief, amplification reactions were performed in a total volume of 20 μl, containing 1 × PCR buffer with Mg (Roche), 200 μM of each deoxyribonucleotide triphosphate (dNTP), 1 μM forward and reverse primer (specified in Table S3 [href=this file] ), 0.1 units of Fast Start Taq DNA polymerase (Roche), and 25 ng genomic DNA.
Transfection was also stable after 48 and 72 h ( Figure S3 [href=this file] ).
The clinical features observed in all 14 affected individuals, in whom we detected variants, have been summarized in Table 1 [href=#tbl1] , and full clinical and MRI descriptions are available in the Supplemental Note [href=this file] , Table S4 [href=#mmc2] , and Figure 1 [href=#fig1] .
P indicates the code of the probands as used in Tables 1 [href=#tbl1] and S4 [href=this file] .
To determine which of the alleles was still expressed, we performed allele-specific RT-qPCR (primers specified in Table S1 [href=this file] ).
Individual reads of each transcript are shown in Figure S1 [href=this file] .
Compared to other TMX family members, only is expressed steadily from week 8 throughout fetal brain development, even increasing during postnatal life (information about mRNA expression during human brain development was retrieved from the Allen Human Brain Atlas (see Web Resources [href=#app4] ); Figure S3 [href=this file] ).
Immunocytochemistry of exogenous TMX2 localized the protein to the MAM through co-localization with the marker calnexin (CNX) ( Figure S4 [href=this file] A) and in the vicinity of the mitochondria, visualized by mitochondrial marker HSP60 ( Figure S4 [href=this file] B).
Quantification of cellular ATP levels showed no differences between -variant affected individuals and controls ( Figure S5 [href=this file] ).
DTT treatment partially shifted the redox state to a more reduced TMX2 ( Figure 7 [href=#fig7] A, lane 3), and TMX2 was completely reduced in the presence of β-mercaptoethanol ( Figures 5 [href=#fig5] B and S6 [href=this file] ), indicating that at least part of the TMX2 redox state is thiol-mediated.
The dimer was still present when SDS-PAGE was performed in reducing conditions with β-mercaptoethanol and without NEM, although the ratio of dimer/monomer was almost inverted, and the monomer represented the major band ( Figure S6 [href=this file] ). Homodimerization was confirmed through linear correlation between the observed molecular weight on blot (average 57.8 kDa, n = 18) and the calculated expected molecular weight with the method of Lambin for a gradient SDS-PAGE gel (4%–15%) ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ). 47 [href=#bib47]
On the basis of the linear correlation between observed and expected mass, these bands seem to represent homotrimers and tetramers of TMX2 ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ). DTT treatment prevented polymerization of the variants almost completely, confirming that polymerization is (at least partially) mediated by disulfide bridge formation ( Figure 7 [href=#fig7] E, third graph, and Figure S6 [href=this file] ). Notably, mutagenized Myc-tagged TMX2 was still able to bind both CNX and SERCA2 ( Figure S8 [href=this file] ).
These results reflect a physiological sensitivity of TMX2 to H O , possibly mimicking an adaptive response to oxidative eustress, regulating physiological steps in development. 52 [href=#bib52] 54 [href=#bib54] The wild-type TMX2 dimer was still slightly present under β-mercaptoethanol reducing conditions ( Figure S6 [href=this file] ), indicating that it is partially formed through inter-disulfide bonds.
pub_title: TMX2 Is a Crucial Regulator of Cellular Redox State, and Its Dysfunction Causes Severe Brain Developmental Abnormalities - PMC

context_description:
All of them had 16S rRNA sequences that were highly similar (> 99.9%) to those of symbionts found in the two individuals sampled from Chapopote in 2006 28 [rid=R28] based on sequence analyses of PCR products ( Supplementary Methods [this file] ). The relative abundance of in five individuals, based on estimates from Illumina metagenomic reads that mapped to the 16S rRNA gene, ranged from 5.1 – 10.7% ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). We also examined four individuals co-occurring with in Chapopote using sequencing (15 - 49 million Illumina reads), FISH and PCR (see Supplementary Methods [this file] ). 
were found in all three sponge individuals collected at Chapopote and Mictlan ( Fig. 2c and d [rid=F2] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). Their abundances ranged between 4.1% and 8.0% based on the number of reads that mapped to the 16S rRNA gene of the sponge ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). The two encrusting sponges collected from Chapopote and Mictlan belonged to the same species based on 100% identical cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) gene sequences, while the branching sponge individual belonged to a different species based on COI comparisons (10% nucleotide difference to COI of the encrusting sponge) and phylogenetic analyses ( Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). Both the encrusting and the branching sponge belong to the order Poecilosclerida based on their COI phylogeny ( Suppplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
The genomes had estimated sizes of 2.1-2.2 Mb, GC contents of 42% and were 93-97% complete ( Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). The genomes from the four individuals were highly similar based on their average nucleotide identity (ANI) (≥ 99.95%, Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) and phylogenomic analyses based on eleven single copy genes ( Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] ). 
Draft genomes from the two sponge species had estimated sizes of 1.6-2.3 Mb, GC contents of 43-44%, and were 90-95% complete ( Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). Their genomes differed considerably from the genome of the branching sponge (ANI = 79.8%) and the mussels (ANI values below 80%, Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ). 
Correspondingly, the genomes of cultivated contain multiple clusters of genes involved in the degradation of PAHs ( Supplementary Fig. 3, Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ). Remarkably, none of the symbiotic genomes examined in this study, neither from the mussels nor the two sponge species, contained genes or transcripts attributable to PAH degradation ( Supplementary Note 1-2, Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). These genomic and transcriptomic results were supported by incubation experiments on board with -bearing gill tissues: Despite numerous attempts, we never observed oxidation of C-labelled naphthalene to CO by gill tissues, while control experiments with ATCC 51542 always showed naphthalene oxidation (see Supplementary Note 1 and Supplementary Methods [this file] ). 
Transcriptomic analyses of the symbiotic from four individuals and the two encrusting sponge individuals revealed that their pHMO genes were the most highly expressed genes compared to all other genes involved in carbon metabolism ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] , Supplementary Tables 6, 7 [this file] ) (transcriptomic sequencing of the branching sponge was not possible, as insufficient RNA was recovered). Proteomics revealed that the subunit A of Group Z pHMO was among the most highly expressed proteins in three individuals ( Supplementary Table 8 [this file] ). 
Indeed, we found genes encoding PQQ-ADHs in the symbiotic of all three host species, and these were also highly expressed in their transcriptomes ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] , Supplementary Tables 6 and 7 [this file] ). The membrane-bound PQQ-ADH was also found in the proteome of one individual ( Supplementary Table 8 [this file] ). The symbiotic PQQ-ADH sequences were highly similar (91%) to PQQ-ADHs assumed to oxidize ethanol and higher alcohols, rather than methanol 36 [rid=R36] ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
AORs were highly expressed in the transcriptomes of symbionts of all three host species, and also present in the proteomes of from two individuals ( Supplementary Table 8, 9 [this file] ). 
These pathways are discussed in detail in the Supplementary Notes 7 - 8 [this file] . 
AORs, the third group of enzymes, are present in the genomes of cultivated but their protein sequences are only 70% similar to those of the symbiotic ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
We found genes encoding the first three enzymes central to the oxidation of short-chain alkanes, pHMO, PQQ-ADH and AOR, in genomes and transcriptomes from the DWH hydrocarbon plume that were highly similar to those of the symbiotic from Campeche Knoll hosts ( Fig. 5 [rid=F5] , Supplementary Fig. 4 and 5 [this file] ). 
As with the pHMOs, the PQQ-ADH sequences of the symbionts were most closely related to PQQ-ADH sequences from DWH bacteria, and formed a highly supported clade with SAG AC281-P21, as well as transcripts from the hydrocarbon plume, with the latter constituting 38% of the total PQQ-ADH transcripts in the plume 36 [rid=R36] ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Symbiotic, free-living and cultivated contain AORs ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
Following homogenization, DNA was extracted from six individuals ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ), according to the standard protocol 50 [rid=R50] , with the following adaptations: 25 μl homogenate aliquots were treated with 40 μl proteinase k and with 20 μl of 20 mg μl RNase for 5 min at 37 °C. RNA was extracted using the AllPrep DNA/RNA Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) following manufacturer’s instructions for both gill and sponge samples ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
Genomic DNA was sequenced as follows: 12.5 million 250 bp paired-end reads were generated, while further sequencing was done as 150 bp paired-end reads ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). cDNA libraries were sequenced as 100 bp paired-end reads. 
The symbiont genomes were binned based on genome coverage, GC content and taxonomic affiliation using gbtools 52 [rid=R52] , and the differential coverage approach 53 [rid=R53] when applicable ( Supplementary Figure 3 [this file] ). Following manual removal of contigs shorter than 800 bp and contamination screening, quality metrics were calculated with Quast 56 [rid=R56] and CheckM 57 [rid=R57] ( Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
We also mapped our metagenomic reads with BBMap using a minimum identity of 0.6 to the genome (GenBank accession number: NZ_ARVU01000001 (NZ_ARVU01000001) ), to verify the results of the BLAST analyses ( Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ). 
The identified proteins are summarized in Supplementary Table 8 [this file] . 
The NSAF% gives the relative abundance of a protein in a sample in % as compared to all other proteins ( Supplementary Table 9 [this file] ). 
Genomes with curated metadata are available through the Integrated Microbial Genome (IMG) database 78 [rid=R78] (analysis project GOLD IDs are summarized in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
High-resolution image of sponge tissue framed with a white box in (c), showing within the sponge tissues (For a 3D reconstruction from 2D z-stacks, see Supplement [this file] ). 
Pathways used for the assimilation of C1-C4 alkanes, as well as for respiration and sulfur oxidation (see Supplementary Notes 7, 10 [this file] ) are shown. These values are described in detail in Supplementary Tables 5 and 6 [this file] .

We found that the number of complexes undergoing stoichiometry changes increases from 11% (16 out of 140) between 5 and 12 wph to 30% (39 out of 129) between 12 and 39 wph (Fig 2 [rid=msb209596-fig-0002] G and Dataset EV6 [this file] ). 
When individual complexes were ranked according to the difference of IQR between the two age comparisons, the majority of the complexes showed an increase in IQR (76 out of 124, 61%, Fig EV3 [rid=msb209596-fig-0003ev] F and Dataset EV6 [this file] ). Many of these complexes are affected by stoichiometry changes already at the adult stage ( Dataset EV6 [this file] ), identifying these alterations as early events during aging progression. 
The same complex definitions used for stoichiometry analysis were used ( Dataset EV6 [this file] ). 
The results are reported in Dataset EV6 [this file] for aging and Dataset EV8 [rid=msb209596-sup-0010] for proteasome inhibition experiment.

We also identified several ubiquitin ligases in the K6‐linked ubiquitin‐specific pull downs, among which the HECT‐type E3 ligase HUWE1 was most strongly enriched (Fig 2 [href=#embr201744754-fig-0002] D, Dataset EV3 [href=this file] ).

In accordance, ubiquitylation of a large number of proteins identified in the K6‐linked ubiquitin‐specific pull downs decreased at least twofold after knockdown of HUWE1 (Fig 2 [href=#embr201744754-fig-0002] D, Dataset EV4 [href=this file] ). The abundance of K48‐linked ubiquitylation also decreased after knockdown of HUWE1, suggesting that HUWE1 assembles heterotypic (mixed or branched) K6/K48‐linked ubiquitin chains (Fig 2 [href=#embr201744754-fig-0002] E, Dataset EV4 [href=this file] ).

Proteins whose ubiquitylation increases after VCP and proteasome inhibition are involved in the mitotic nuclear envelope disassembly, cell cycle regulation, gene expression, and DNA repair (Fig 4 [href=#embr201744754-fig-0004] B–D, Dataset EV5 [href=this file] ).

context_description:
We observed a maximal TPM value of 4.3 for these transcripts and consequently set a threshold of 5 TPM for a transcript to be considered as detected (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S1). 
In total, 12,606 and 12,684 different transcripts were detected across all developmental stages under CO and HS, respectively (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2A and B). Under CO 4538 (36.0%) and under HS 4332 (34.2%) are common to all stages. (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2A and B). The total number of detected protein groups across all stages was 957 in CO and 1062 in HS samples, whereby the fraction of common protein groups between the stages was much lower (~ 20%) than the fraction of common transcripts (~ 35%) (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2C and D). 
Interestingly, inclusion of PC2 revealed no better separation of the developmental stages for the analysis of both, transcriptome and proteome levels (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S3). 
Next, we calculated an overlap matrix, which indicated the number of shared genes between transcript and protein cluster pairs (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S4). 
To compare transcriptome and proteome alterations in response to HS, we generated an overlap matrix for each developmental stage (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5). 
Next, we analyzed the genes with a protein assigned to clusters with strong down- and upregulation (left- and rightmost clusters in Fig. 4c [rid=Fig4] , Pr1 and Pr7 clusters in Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5). 
We could show that the transcriptome of developing tomato pollen comprises about 12,600 transcripts across the three analyzed stages (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2A). The proteome size we identified for tomato pollen was 1000 protein groups along the course of development (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2A). 
The number of proteins changed in their abundance is drastically higher for tetrads (~ 30%) and post-meiotic pollen (40%) than for mature pollen (9%, Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] , Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5). 
Further, to determine if a gene was actually detected at the transcriptome level, we determined a threshold based on the established method of Loraine et al. [ 35 [rid=CR35] ] by analyzing the TPM values of genes encoding for LHC proteins (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S1), which are not supposed to be detected due to the absence of chloroplasts in pollen. 
To analyze the behavior of genes at both transcript and protein level along the course of development, we first took the transcript and protein clusters obtained from the first clustering approach (developmental stages under CO) and created an overlap matrix, which indicated the overlap of genes between transcript and protein clusters (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S4). 
Here, clusters were ordered from a high abundance in CO to a high abundance in HS (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5). The findings of this step were verified by analyzing the TPM log -ratios of HS to CO (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S6).
pub_title: The coupling of transcriptome and proteome adaptation during development and heat stress response of tomato pollen

After filtering the content of these clusters for genes detected at both, the transcriptome and proteome level, we identified 229 tetrad (Tr1 and Tr2), 109 post-meiotic (Tr3 and Tr4) and 58 mature (Tr5 and Tr6) increased transcripts as well as 25 tetrad (Pr1), 141 post-meiotic (Pr2 and Pr3) and 520 mature (Pr4, Pr5 and Pr6) increased proteins (Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S2 highlighted in bold).

context_description:
Subsequently, we determined the distribution of the genes among the different functional categories (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] ; Additional file 5 [this file] : Table S4) to identify whether the different genes with direct and delayed translation are related to specific cellular functions. 
The majority of the genes with direct translation in tetrads (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] green) was assigned to the category of ‘chaperones & protein turnover’ (Additional file 5 [this file] : Table S4), comprising among others two Hsp90s (Hsp90–4 and Hsp90–3), one Hsp70 (BIP4) and one sHsp (Hsp23.8-MI). 
Genes with delayed translation in post-meiotic pollen (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] ) are largely involved in metabolic processes (Additional file 5 [this file] : Table S4). 
The majority of genes with direct translation in tetrads was assigned to the ‘chaperones & protein turnover’ category (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] tetrads direct; Additional file 5 [this file] : Table S4) including a sHsp, BIP4 of the Hsp70 family as well as two Hsp90s. Similarly, also for genes with delayed translation we observed high assignment to ‘chaperones & protein turnover’ (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] tetrads delay; Additional file 5 [this file] : Table S4). 
Proteins accumulating in mature pollen by either direct or delayed translation were assigned to different metabolic processes as well as ‘cytoskeleton’, ‘signal transduction’ and ‘trafficking & secretion’ (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] post-meiotic delay and mature direct; Additional file 5 [this file] : Table S4).

context_description:
We performed k-means clustering (k = 7) on the relative transcript and protein levels across CO and HS for pollen from all three developmental stages independently (Additional file 6 [this file] : Table S5). 
Next, we focused on those genes detectable at transcriptome and proteome level of the pollen stages to have a common starting point for the comparison of the transcriptome and proteome response (Additional file 6 [this file] : Table S5 highlighted in bold). 
We categorized all Hsps and Hsfs detected by transcriptome clustering (Additional file 6 [this file] : Table S5) as downregulated (cluster Tr1), not altered (stable, clusters Tr2 to Tr6) or upregulated (cluster Tr7) for all developmental stages. We additionally classified them based on their proteome clustering (Additional file 6 [this file] : Table S5) as reduced (down, cluster Pr1), not altered (stable, clusters Pr2 to Pr6) or accumulated (up, cluster Pr7). 
Next, we defined the members with respect to their assignment in the HS clustering (Additional file 6 [this file] : Table S5) as either downregulated (clusters Tr1 and Pr1), showing stable levels (clusters Tr2 to Tr6 and Pr2 to Pr6) or as upregulated (clusters Tr7 and Pr7).

A second enriched functional category is the ‘translation & ribosomes’ class (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] ; Additional file 8 [this file] : Table S7). 
Most affected during heat stress were proteins assigned to ‘chaperones & protein turnover’ or ‘translation & ribosomes’ (Fig. 9 [rid=Fig9] ; Additional file 8 [this file] : Table S7). 
For instance in post-meiotic pollen, we observed a downregulation of RPL10 proteins after HS (Additional file 8 [this file] : Table S7). 
In mature pollen, nearly no regulation of Hsps could be observed (Fig. 9 [rid=Fig9] ; Additional file 8 [this file] : Table S7).

Surprisingly, for tetrads we observed only a HS induced increase of ClpB3 protein but not of transcript levels, whereas for post-meiotic and mature pollen we observed the transcript increase (Additional file 9 [this file] : Table S8).

context_description:
To investigate how DNA topological change influences R-loops, we applied CPT treatment in different genetic backgrounds of (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). We found the root growth of wild-type Col-0 was significantly inhibited in the presence of 30 nM CPT compared to the control treated with DMSO, a solvent used to dissolve CPT (Supplementary Fig. 1a, b [this file] ). However, the root growth of , another protein kinase required for DNA damage repair , was much more resistant than (Supplementary Fig. 1a, b [this file] ), suggesting a specific defect of TOP1i in the mutant. Additionally, by staining the root of Col-0 with propidium iodide (PI), a counterstain marking dead cells, we found that CPT treatment could induce the death of root stem cells and reduce the length of meristem zones (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). These growth defects were intensified in mutant, as the root tips of showed severe damage and disorganized morphology, while cell death in was comparable to that in Col-0 (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a–c [this file] ). 
The results of principal components analysis showed that these samples were clustered in replicates and the -CPT sample presented distinctive R-loop patterns compared to others, consistent with the results of the slot-blot assay and the severe root developmental phenotype of CPT-treated (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). Further analysis of R-loops on all annotated elements observed that showed a higher level of R-loops near TSS than Col-0 (Supplementary Fig. 2b, c [this file] ). Interestingly, TOP1i promoted accumulations of R-loops located on TSS in Col-0, while elevating the R-loops on gene body in (Supplementary Fig. 2b, c [this file] ). Moreover, a large number of R-loops were remarkably increased on genes in after CPT treatment, but more genes showed decreased R-loops in Col-0 after CPT treatment (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). There are little overlapped genes that are commonly regulated in and Col-0 after CPT treatment (Supplementary Fig. 2f [this file] ), indicating R-loop dynamics triggered by CPT vary in different backgrounds. In addition, our analysis showed that the topoR-loops do not correlate with mRNA levels after CPT treatment (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ), suggesting that they do not result from gene expression differences. 
The immunostaining results confirmed that CPT increased γH2AX signals in Col-0 and root tips (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] ), which is consistent with its phosphorylation activity of H2AX. 
The recombinant protein AtRNH1A has RNA:DNA cleavage activities in vitro, and a mutation D160N in the RNase H domain could disturb its catalytic activity (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
R-loop levels indicated by S9.6 in mutants related to Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] . DNA damage levels indicated by γH2AX in mutants related to Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] . 
We then performed further analysis of R-loop and DNA damage levels with S9.6 and γH2AX immunostaining (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
We re-sequenced the mutant population and located the mutation in chromosome 1 (Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ) , and found there were 5 genes with mutations in the regions (Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ). After allelic crossing with mutants of candidate genes with , we verified that (G522N) and (G469R) could rescue CPT-induced defects in (Supplementary Fig. 6b–f [this file] ). Both and are weak alleles of , and their mutation sites are closed to (L473F) (Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). These three mutants have mutations at highly conserved positions among model species (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). Mutant (G522N) is mutated inside the DNA polymerase domain of POL2A (closed to the left border), while (G469R) and (L473F) carry mutations in the junction domain between exonuclease and DNA polymerase domains, within a very conserved region (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). The root lengths of / and / are significantly longer than that of in the presence of CPT (Supplementary Fig. 6c–f [this file] ). Interestingly, and / were blocked with an increasing concentration of CPT (Supplementary Fig. 7a, b [this file] ), whereas both — the single mutant separated from — and showed significant resistance to CPT compared with Col-0 (Supplementary Fig. 7a, b [this file] ). In addition, the root length of was longer than that of and had fewer dead cells under high a concentration of CPT (Supplementary Fig. 7a–c [this file] ), and showed a more structured root morphology compared with / (Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] ). These results suggest the conserved junction domain of POL2A should have an essential role in modulating topological stress during replication, and residue mutations in the junction and DNA polymerase domain of POL2A have conserved effects of varying degrees on the release of topological stress and then the topoR-loops, which is in line with the location of the mutations in the functional domain of the POL2A protein (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). 
Further analysis observed that R-loop levels at protein-coding genes decreased significantly in compared with Col-0 and , and CPT treatment had little additive effect on increasing R-loop levels (Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). had lower overall R-loop levels than Col-0 and , but higher levels than , and CPT elevated the R-loop levels(Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). The antisense R-loops that enriched in the transcription start sites resembled trends of un-stranded R-loop variations(Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). However, the sense R-loops decreased only near TTS sites in , and the extent of the decrease was magnified in (Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). 
Venn diagram of overlap between up-regulated R-loop genes in after CPT treatment in Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] (left), and up-regulated R-loop genes in compared to in Fig. 4b (right). 
To explore the features of differential R-loops on genes in , we intersected the genes possessing up-regulated R-loops in with the genes having CPT-induced R-loops in (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). 
However, R-loops remained stable around the origins, with a low level in , regardless of CPT treatment, that was even lower than that in Col-0 (Fig. 4e, g [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 8b, c [this file] ). 
Accordingly, we treated the plants with a DNA synthesis inhibitor, hydroxyurea (HU), that arrests DNA replication by depleting dNTPs pools , and found that, , , and were tolerant to HU (Supplementary Fig. 9a, b [this file] ). Additionally, a low dosage of HU (0.25 mM) affected the relative relief of TOP1i-induced root growth defects when the mutants were treated with HU and CPT together (Supplementary Fig. 9a–c [this file] ). Global R-loop levels detected by slot-blot assay decreased after HU treatment in all tested mutants (Supplementary Fig. 9d [this file] ). 
After 2 h of DMSO treatment (T2) and an additional 4 h of recovery (T2 + R4) (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ), EdU-positive (EdU + ) cells of were similar to that of Col-0, while and had more EdU+ cells than Col-0, but the increasing speed of EdU+ cells in and is slower than in Col-0 and (Supplementary Fig. 10b [this file] , left). However, at 4 h after CPT removal, and showed many more EdU+ cells (Supplementary Fig. 10b [this file] ), suggesting that DNA replication and cell cycle in is not efficiently inhibited with TOP1i, or that the repairing system is activated to maintain the cell cycle progress in . Meanwhile, the EdU+ cells in were more than that in after CPT removal (Supplementary Fig. 10b [this file] , CPT T2 + R4), indicating recovers DNA replication process from topology stress faster than , and ATM is involved in this progress of in responding to topology stress. 
Accumulated R-loops at TTS regions promote TRCs , up-regulated sense R-loops increased at TTS of coding genes and the locations of the genes were enriched with the DNA origins (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). Together with the findings that R-loops on DNA origins decreased in and stayed stable after CPT treatment (Fig. 4e [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 8b, c [this file] ), and the fact that genome replication initiates from multiple origins, these results suggest that DSBs could result mainly from the TRCs induced by topoR-loops and the replication stress which could be weakened by POL2A mutation, thus generating less DNA damage. 
Through RNase HII digestion, we detected a high level of rNTPs in the genome after CPT treatment (Fig. 7a, b [rid=Fig7] ), while showed a similar rNTPs incorporation pattern (Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] ). We found the root growth of and / was inhibited by TOP1i compared to the individual single mutants (Fig. 7c, d [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 11c, d [this file] ). 
We expressed and purified the catalytic core of WT (POL2A ) and mutant (POL2A ) POL2A (1-1123aa) proteins (Supplementary Fig. 12a, b [this file] ), including polymerase and exonuclease domains which are sufficient for DNA synthesis . The results showed that POL2A synthesized slightly less DNA than POL2A under the same conditions (Supplementary Fig. 12c [this file] ), indicating L473F mutation impaired DNA polymerase activity, in line with the double-labeling results (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] ). Besides, we performed rNTPs insertion experiments in vitro using POL2A and POL2A , and the rGTP incorporation levels are comparable between WT and mutant POL2A (Supplementary Fig. 12d [this file] ). Combining the in vivo results (Fig. 7a, b [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] ) which showed high levels of rNTPs were detected only in after CPT treatment, we conclude that TOP1, ATM and POL2A could cooperatively participate in DNA replication progression and replication fidelity in different conditions. 
The mutant was sensitive to MMS as previously reported ; however, did not show MMS sensitivity (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] ). Root lengths of both and were restrained by MMS, and were obviously shorter than those of and (Supplementary Fig. 13a, b [this file] ). The number of dead cells stained with PI was consistent with the inhibited root length (Supplementary Fig. 13b, c [this file] ). Mutations of activated the response to DNA damage and replication fork blockage induced by MMS, and this effect varied with different mutation sites (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ), especially the mutation located in the Type-B polymerase domain that is responsible for DNA synthesis, while the and mutations are in the conserved junction domain (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). 
However, and presented insensitivity to CPT, and the roots of both and were slightly inhibited by CPT, which is different from the single mutant (Fig. 8e, f [rid=Fig8] , Supplementary Fig. 13d [this file] ). 
Notably, the severely aberrant root growth of mutant treated with CPT resulted from increased topoR-loop accumulation and DNA breaks (Figs. 1 [rid=Fig1] , 2 [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
POL2A is relatively conserved in eukaryotes (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ), and it is known that its DNA polymerase domain and exonuclease domain are crucial for DNA replication and nucleotide excision repair (NER) . Here we identified is the suppressor under topological stress (TOP1i), rescuing the short and abnormal root growth of under CPT treatment (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). We showed that is resistant to CPT (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ), while showed higher γH2AX levels than Col-0 (Fig. 3f–h [rid=Fig3] ), suggesting could activate ATR-dependent signaling and WEE1-dependent cell cycle regulation. Only treated with TOP1i accumulated a very high level of ribonucleotides (Fig. 7a, b [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] ), -caused ribonucleotides incorporation is TOP1-dependent, and further lead to DNA breaks, and this relies on ATM for repair (Fig. 9 [rid=Fig9] ). In addition, combining with genetic results that abolished the resistance of to TOP1i (Fig. 7c, d [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] and 11c, d [this file] ), and R-loops near DNA origins decreased in (Fig. 4f [rid=Fig4] ), we speculate that AtRNH2A could remove R-loops near DNA replication regions, especially on nascent DNA containing high ribonucleotides (Fig. 9 [rid=Fig9] ). 
The mutations that we used are located in the conserved and uncharacterized junction domain (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). 
DNA synthesis reactions were assayed with 10 nM DNA template 1 or 2, indicated amount of POL2A proteins in Supplementary Fig. 12 [this file] , 10 µM dATP/dGTP/dTTP, and 2 µCi of [α−32P]-dCTP (NEG513H) in a buffer containing 40 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 10 mM MgCl , 50 mM potassium glutamate and 10 mM DTT.

title: No Title
caption: Figures S1, Tables S1-S9.
description: Additional  File  1  Figures  S1,  Tables  S1-S9.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
The majority of these reads were 23 nucleotides in size for both parental and spheroids ( Additional File 1 [this file] : Figure S1). The summary for small RNA library in parental and spheroids was shown in Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S1. The top ten most abundant miRNAs with expression values observed in parental and spheroids were listed in Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S2. Using 2-fold expression difference as a cut-off level, 25 up-regulated and 109 down-regulated miRNAs were identified ( Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S3), indicating that there were marked changes in their miRNAs content between the two cell types. 
The top five up- and down- regulated miRNAs which were >2-fold differentially expressed and contained broad range of predicted target genes are as listed in Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S4 and S5. 
The detailed information of the GO analysis is tabulated in Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S6 and S7. 
Based on the inferred KEGG pathways for the miRNAs, one was related to self-renewal (Wnt signaling pathway), four related to drug resistance (pathways in cancer, MAPK signaling pathway, and axon guidance), and one related to structure (Actin cytoskeleton) (Figure 9 [rid=F9] and Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S8). 
The selected microRNAs and their targeted sequence were listed in Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S9. 
The pathway analysis revealed that these genes were significantly related to the “axon guidance pathway”, “pathways in cancer”, “MAPK signalling pathway”, “Wnt signalling pathway”, “regulation of actin cytoskeleton”, “insulin signalling”, “regulation of actin cytoskeleton”, “mTor signalling pathway” and “ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis” ( Additional File 1 [this file] : Table S8).

context_description:
A flowchart of this study is shown in supplementary material, Figure S1 [this file] . Looking at the proteome and peptidome profiles in each group, the patients with HCC had the lowest median number of proteins (303) and peptides (2086) in plasma (see supplementary material, Figure S2 [this file] ). 
Proteins that were associated with the tumor stage, tumor grade, recurrence‐free survival, and overall survival of HCC, CCA, and cHCC‐CCA, respectively, are shown in Figure 2 [rid=cjp2136-fig-0002] A and see supplementary material, Figures S3 [this file] and S4 [this file] . Strong correlations between emPAI % values and actual amounts of these essential proteins were observed (see supplementary material, Figure S5 [this file] ). 
The concentration of complement C3 with Man5, Man6, or Man7 glycoform at Asn85 closely linked to the tumor grade (Figure 2 [rid=cjp2136-fig-0002] B) and the association was stronger than did α‐fetoprotein, a renowned HCC biomarker (see supplementary material, Figure S6 [this file] ).

PASS1, PASS3 and PAO1 shared a similar organization of flagellar biogenesis genes, while PASS2 and PASS4 showed distinct differences ( S1A Fig [this file] ). 
Strains PASS2 and PASS4 exhibited little or no flagellum-dependent swimming motility as opposed to PAO1, PASS1 and PASS3 ( S1B Fig [this file] ); whether this is a general feature of type A flagellin has yet to be elucidated.

title: Pathway Tools 17.5 cellular overview diagram showing proteins/pathways expressed uniquely by PAO1, in red.
caption: The shapes on the diagram represent specific types of compounds as follows: square—carbohydrate, triangle—amino acid, upside down triangle—cofactor, ellipse (horizontal)—purine, ellipse (vertical)—pyrimidine, diamond—proteins, T-shape—tRNA, circle—all other compounds. The shading of the icon indicates the phosphorylation state of the compound: shaded compounds are phosphorylated; unshaded compounds are unphosphorylated. Shapes/paths located on outer rectangles represent transporters/membrane proteins. The arrows indicate the direction of the transport: pointing in—uptake, pointing out—export.

context_description:
The proteins uniquely expressed by PAO1 (827 in total) and those uniquely shared by PASS1-4 strains (703 in total), were mapped onto the metabolic pathways of PAO1 using Pathway Tools 17.5 ( Fig 10 [rid=pone.0138527.g010] , S2 [this file] and S3 [rid=pone.0138527.s003] Figs). There was essentially no expression of biosynthetic genes involved in amino acid, polyamine, carbohydrates, nucleoside or nucleotide biosynthesis ( Fig 10A [rid=pone.0138527.g010] , S2 Fig [this file] ). 
Full details of the Pathway Tools analysis are shown in S2 [this file] and S3 [rid=pone.0138527.s003] Figs, and the full list of express proteins for each strain is provided in S2 Table [rid=pone.0138527.s005] .

Chp1 is a dedicated chaperone at the ribosome that safeguards eEF1A biogenesis
Chp1 is a dedicated chaperone at the ribosome that safeguards eEF1A biogenesis
Chp1 is a dedicated chaperone at the ribosome that safeguards eEF1A biogenesis

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
As evidenced by structural comparison, encodes a highly conserved eukaryotic protein, yet, the function of Chp1 and its orthologs, including the human ortholog PBDC1, remains to be elucidated (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). The Bpa substitution at position Leu12 was chosen after testing a number of conserved residues (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). 24% and 19% of the identified Chp1-crosslinking partners were found to be involved in translation and protein quality control, respectively (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM4] ). The α-subunit of NAC, Egd2, was ranked as a top hit and using serum detecting Egd1 and Egd2 we found that NAC directly crosslinked with Chp1-L12Bpa (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). Despite that the models did not recapitulate all 12 strands of the β-barrel-like heterodimer determined by crystallography for the human NAC heterodimerization domain they both suggested that Chp1 binds NAC via direct interaction with the UBA domain of its α-subunit, Egd2 (Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] and Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ) . Co-immunoprecipitation (co-IP) of GFP-tagged Chp1 from yeast cells and purification of Chp1 from co-expressing NAC (Egd1 and Egd2) validated that Chp1 forms a complex with NAC via direct binding to Egd2 (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1e [this file] ). 
We confirmed by sedimentation experiments and co-IP that Chp1 associates with the ribosome (Fig. 1e, f [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1f [this file] ). The association with the ribosome was reduced when was deleted (Fig. 1f [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1f [this file] ). Polysome profile analysis revealed that nascent chain release upon puromycin treatment abrogated the interaction of Chp1 with translating ribosomes, demonstrating the key role of the nascent polypeptides in Chp1 recruitment to the 80 S ribosomes (Supplementary Fig. 1g [this file] ). 
The most enriched transcripts identified by Chp1-SeRP belonged to the near-identical and ( ), encoding eEF1A, suggesting that eEF1A is the sole nascent-chain substrate of Chp1 (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). 
In addition, size-exclusion chromatography analysis of the copurified fraction from the recombinant system confirmed the presence of a stable Chp1-eEF1A domain I complex (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ). Having established the Chp1-eEF1A domain I complex, we used in vitro site-specific UV crosslinking between purified Chp1 with single Bpa substitutions in the N-terminal α-helix (Q18, V21 or E25) and domain I of eEF1A to test the involvement of this helix in the interaction (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ). All three positions harboring the zero-spacer crosslinker Bpa formed specific crosslinks with eEF1A domain I, demonstrating direct interaction with the domain (Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] ). Upon mutational analysis we found using the heterologous coexpression system that alanine substitutions of Chp1 residues predicted to interact with eEF1A, or complete removal of residues 2 to 28 significantly decreased the interaction (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). 
Consistent with previous reports we found that full-length eEF1A quantitatively aggregated when expressed in (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). In contrast, when Chp1 was coexpressed, eEF1A solubility was significantly increased and this soluble fraction could be copurified with Chp1 (Supplementary Fig. 3a–e [this file] ). The copurified complex contained many contaminating proteins not observed in the control purifications suggesting that eEF1A was misfolded and unspecifically interacted with these species (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). Indeed, only minimal interaction between Chp1 and eEF1A could be observed with the highest interaction being detected in the presence of EDTA (10% of purified Chp1 was bound to eEF1A), a treatment that impedes nucleotide binding and thus destabilizes the GTPase domain (Supplementary Fig. 3f [this file] ). In a parallel approach, in vitro site-specific UV crosslinking between Chp1 with Bpa substitution at position E25 and eEF1A demonstrated impaired interaction between the proteins in the presence of nucleotide or high glycerol concentration (Supplementary Fig. 3g [this file] ). 
The analysis mapped eEF1A-related functions including tRNA biogenesis, aminoacylation and the structural itself (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). Looking exclusively at the negative genetic interactions of , we substantiated the finding of an involvement in translation (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). This was further supported by finding that 7 of the negative interactors involved in translation and protein quality control ( , J-domain protein for Hsp70; , eEF1A; , eEF1Bγ; , ubiquitin E3 ligase; , eIF5A; , ribosomal 40 S subunit protein S0A; , ATPase 19 S proteosome) were also identified as physical interactors in our MS analysis (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). Direct testing by construction of a Δ Δ mutant, revealed a more severe growth impairment at 30 °C and 37 °C compared to Δ cells (Fig. 3a, b [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 5a, b [this file] ). 
We quantified eEF1A levels in the mutants using western blot analysis (Fig. 3c [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). Inactivation of NAC ( ) alone or in combination with Chp1 caused no further reduction of the total eEF1A levels (Supplementary Fig. 5d [this file] ). Since total and mRNA levels were not reduced in the Δ cells (Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] ), we investigated whether Chp1 is required for the efficient biogenesis of eEF1A. To investigate the biogenesis defect, we isolated protein aggregates and found that while the amount of ubiquitylated protein aggregates were increased in Δ cells, eEF1A did not accumulate in the aggregates (Supplementary Fig. 5f [this file] ). Additionally, ribosome profiling (RP) analysis showed the same ribosome density along the / transcripts for WT and Δ cells ruling out a defect in the translation of these transcripts in the absence of Chp1 (Supplementary Fig. 5g [this file] ). 
Metagene profiles of Δ cells showed a typical enrichment of ribosomes at the start of the coding sequences of all translated genes, followed by an overall uniform ribosome distribution, indicating that the reduced levels of eEF1A did not cause major global changes in the translation process (Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] , = 0.99, < 2.2e ). In contrast to Zpr1 depletion, the integrated stressed response was only weakly induced as evidenced by a mere 1.5-fold increased translation of (Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] ). 
In line, + induced a pronounced growth defect in Δ cells at the stressful temperature of 39 °C (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). While Δ cells displayed a growth defect at 39 °C, Δ cells grew indistinguishable from WT cells, and the Δ Δ double mutant phenocopied Δ cells (Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] ). In the same line, unlike Δ cells Δ cells did not activate Hsf1 or promote cytosolic protein aggregation (Supplementary Fig. 7c–e [this file] ). 
Sequence variants in have been found in patients with neurodevelopmental epilepsy and intellectual disability (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). All mutants but one (R421C) exhibited significantly reduced protein levels in WT cells with even further reduced levels in Δ cells (Supplementary Fig. 8b [this file] ). The mutants appeared to represent recessive destabilized variants, since they did not cause prominent growth impairment (Supplementary Fig. 8c, d [this file] ). When G70S and F98C eEF1A variants were expressed from the induced promoter, the rate of their production was significantly reduced in Δ cells, indicating that Chp1 plays a major role in de novo synthesis of also the eEF1A variants (Fig. 5c, d [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 8e [this file] ). Upon translation arrest, the F98C variant was found to be significantly less stable than WT or the G70S variant, and the turnover of the F98C variant was significantly accelerated in Δ cells (Fig. 5e, f [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 8f [this file] ). 
Yeast strains and plasmids used in this study are listed in Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] and 2 [this file] , respectively.
pub_title: Chp1 is a dedicated chaperone at the ribosome that safeguards eEF1A biogenesis

Models 1-5 (ranked by average plDDT values for the entire chain length), for the complexes Chp1:Egd2:Egd1 (Uniprot accessions; Q0897: P38879 (P38879) : Q02642 (Q02642) ), αNAC:βNAC:PBDC1 ( Q13765 (Q13765) : P20290 (P20290) : Q9BVG4 (Q9BVG4) ) and eEF1A domain I:Chp1 ( P02994 (P02994) residues 1 to 250:Q0897) are supplied as Supplementary Data 2 [this file] and 3 [rid=MOESM6] , respectively together with sequence coverage, predicted lDDT per position, predicted aligned error (PAE) and javascript object notation files (.json) for the runs.
pub_title: Chp1 is a dedicated chaperone at the ribosome that safeguards eEF1A biogenesis

context_description:
Transcripts derived from a total number of 13,197 genes were identified in the EVs for the analyzed stages of the estrous cycle (after filtering for a minimum number of read counts, see Methods section) (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S0). 
The total number of differential transcripts (FDR 0.001) for these comparisons was 854 (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4). Hierarchical cluster analysis of the differential transcripts confirmed that the main difference in mRNA abundance was between S1 and the other stages and that transcript frequency between S2, S3, S4 was more or less similar (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] ; Additional file 1 [this file] : Tables S1-S3 and Additional file 2 [rid=MOESM2] : Figure S2.). 
Functional analysis of the top 500 most abundant mRNAs identified in EVs across the bovine estrous cycle was performed using DAVID functional annotation clustering (list of 500 most abundant transcripts in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S5). 
Complete lists of identified and differentially abundant proteins are shown in Additional file 1 [this file] (Tables S6-S8). 
Moreover, a very low number of sequences for a few mRNAs was identified (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S9). The sequences assigned to known or predicted miRNAs comprised 189 different miRNAs based on sequence comparisons to known bovine, human, and porcine miRNAs, miRNA precursors, and predicted precursor sequences (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S10).
pub_title: Deciphering the oviductal extracellular vesicles content across the estrous cycle: implications for the gametes-oviduct interactions and the environment of the potential embryo

context_description:
The distribution of the normalized read counts across all transcripts showed that most of the transcripts occurred in low copy numbers and only the top 500 most abundant transcripts/genes showed a frequency of more than 25 transcripts per million. (Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S1). 
Hierarchical cluster analysis of the differential transcripts confirmed that the main difference in mRNA abundance was between S1 and the other stages and that transcript frequency between S2, S3, S4 was more or less similar (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] ; Additional file 1 [rid=MOESM1] : Tables S1-S3 and Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S2.). 
Comparative analysis of all small ncRNA content including rRNA and tRNA fragments and for each individual RNA type across the bovine estrous cycle is represented by several MDS plots in Additional file 2 [this file] : (Figure S3). 
When all small ncRNA sequences were analyzed, higher differences were found between stage 4 and stage 1 than between stage 3 and stage 1, with 1036 and 535 differentially abundant sequences (FDR < 0.05), respectively (Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S4). For rRNA fragments, 580 differential sequences were found between stage 4 and stage 1 and 318 between stage 3 and stage 1 FDR (< 0.05) (Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S5). For miRNA, Table 3 [rid=Tab3] shows differential miRNAs among stages with 8 differentially regulated miRNAs (20 sequences) between S4 vs S1, while 5 miRNAs (8 sequences) between S3 vs S1 (FDR < 0.05; Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S6) (13 differentially regulated miRNAs (39 sequences) S4 vs S1; 9 miRNAs (21 sequences) S3 vs S1; FDR < 1). Only for differential tRNA (Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S7) and snRNA (Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S8), higher differences were observed between stage 3 and stage 1 than for the comparison of stage 4 and stage 1 (tRNA: 29 (S3 vs S1) and 6 (S4 vs S1); snRNA: 93 (S3 vs S1) and 85 (S4 vs S1), FDR (< 0.05)). Hierarchical cluster analyses of the differential sequences identified for each type of small ncRNA between stage 3–4 and stage 1 are provided in Additional file 2 [this file] : Figures S4-S9. 
Furthermore, the analysis of exon coverage of the RNA-seq data (Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S12, IGV Sashimi plots) suggested the presence of complete undegraded transcripts.
pub_title: Deciphering the oviductal extracellular vesicles content across the estrous cycle: implications for the gametes-oviduct interactions and the environment of the potential embryo

context_description:
A complete list of the GO terms with a score ≥ 1.3 for the 500 most abundant mRNAs are provided in Additional file 3 [this file] (Table S0). 
A list of the categories shown in the network and assigned genes/transcripts can be found in Additional file 3 [this file] (Table S1). 
Functional annotation of all 336 clusters of proteins identified in oEVs across the bovine estrous cycle was performed using DAVID functional annotation clustering (Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S2). 
A list of the categories shown in the network and assigned genes/transcripts can be found in Additional file 3 [this file] (Table S3). Five clusters of proteins showing specific profiles across stages were used for this purpose (clusters of proteins are pointed with dotted squares: a, b-b’, c, d and e, in Fig. 4C [rid=Fig4] and listed in Additional file 3 [this file] : Tables S4-S8). For the cluster of proteins with lower abundance in stage 1 and upregulated in stage 4 (Fig. 4C [rid=Fig4] , a) GO terms related to vesicles, focal adhesion, cytoskeleton, cell surface, metalloexopeptidase activity, and innate immune system were found as overrepresented (Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S3). This group of proteins showed specific enrichment for fructose/lipid/GDP binding, categories related to cytoskeleton organization and cell motility, cytoplasmic vesicles, signal transduction, and secretory processes (Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S3). 
The selected miRNAs, pathways involved and the number of genes and gene symbols of the target genes in each pathway are shown in Table 4 [rid=Tab4] and Additional file 3 [this file] (Table S9–10).
