context_description:
We subjected HeLa cells to 2.5 mM DTT‐induced ER stress over a 30‐h period, sampling at eight time points (0, 0.5, 1, 2, 8, 16, 24, and 30 h) ( Appendix Fig S1 [this file] ). In this setup, DTT had a half‐life of ~4 h ( Appendix Fig S2 [this file] ). We first conducted a number of assays to characterize the cellular phenotype in response to the treatment (Fig 1 [rid=msb156423-fig-0001] A, Appendix Fig S3 [this file] ). 
The complete data are in Appendix Fig S3 [this file] . 
The corresponding expression data are shown in Appendix Fig S5 [this file] . 
This interpretation was confirmed by assays monitoring cell cycle progression and apoptosis: While apoptosis occurred during the first two hours of the experiment, later time points showed a continued division of the majority cells (Fig 1 [rid=msb156423-fig-0001] A, middle/lower panel; Appendix Fig S3 [this file] ). 
Genome‐wide transcriptomics measurements confirmed this view and manifested roughly three phases of the response where concerted changes happened: (<2 h), (2–8 h), and (> 8 h) (Fig 1 [rid=msb156423-fig-0001] B, Appendix Fig S5 [this file] ). 
A variety of tests confirmed the quality of the proteomic data, for example, Western blots of selected proteins and analysis of housekeeping genes, and its reproducibility across the two biological replicates (Appendix Figs S11 [this file]S12 [this file] and S13 [this file] ). We also constructed an extended dataset with 2,131 proteins which showed similar results ( Appendix Fig S19 [this file] ). 
Protein concentrations spanned about five orders of magnitude ( Appendix Table S1 [this file] ), which is similar to what other large‐scale studies observe (Schwanhausser , 2011 [rid=msb156423-bib-0048] ). Their reproducibility was high ( > 0.94 for seven of the eight time points, Appendix Fig S10 [this file] ); the correlation with the corresponding mRNA concentrations was consistent across samples ( Appendix Fig S13 [this file] ). Heatmaps of the integrated and clustered mRNA and protein expression values show that overall expression changes were similar between the two biological replicates (Fig 2 [rid=msb156423-fig-0002] , Appendix Figs S5 [this file] , S9 [this file] and S14 [this file] ), but some discrepancies existed. Appendix Fig S13 [this file] displays the frequency distributions of all RCM values and shows a bias toward high values. 
For example, genes involved in the general stress response were significantly up‐regulated during the intermediate and late phase of the experiment both at the mRNA and at the protein level ( Appendix Fig S14 [this file] ). 
This regulatory event is also an example of the sometimes counterbalancing effects of RNA‐ and protein‐level regulation (discussed below and in Appendix Fig S16 [this file] ). 
In contrast, protein concentrations continuously diverged from the beginning until the end of the experiment, with much less change during the late phase (Fig 4 [rid=msb156423-fig-0004] , Appendix Fig S15 [this file] ). The magnitude of change was also more pronounced for proteins than for mRNAs, illustrated by the average (and range) of expression fold changes which were larger than those for mRNAs (Fig 4 [rid=msb156423-fig-0004] , Appendix Table S1 [this file] ). 
An alternative way to identify discordant regulation confirmed this result, that is, via filtering for negative correlation between PECA's mRNA and protein time‐course rate ratios in both replicates ( Dataset EV1 [rid=msb156423-sup-0002] , Appendix Fig S16A and B [this file] ). Three out of the 75 genes passed this additional filtering and are shown in Appendix Fig S16C [this file] . 
The pulse‐like or transient behavior of the RNA‐level regulation was confirmed both for the extended dataset (2,131 genes) and for the entire transcriptome (> 18,000 genes) ( Appendix Figs S19 [this file] and S21 [this file] ), indicating that the high‐confidence dataset delivers representative results. 
It is also present in the extended dataset ( Appendix Fig S19 [this file] ). 
This behavior makes HSC70 one of the three examples for potential buffering discussed above ( Appendix Fig S16 [this file] ). 
The second example group comprises 196 genes with invariable RNA concentrations, but whose protein concentrations increased during the late phase ( Appendix Fig S14 [this file] , Dataset EV1 [rid=msb156423-sup-0002] , cluster 8). 
To generate hypotheses on possible mechanisms for the up‐regulation of these proteins, we collected > 160 sequence features, including length, signal sequences, nucleotide composition, amino acid composition, translation regulatory elements, RNA secondary structures, and post‐translation modifications ( Appendix Table S2 [this file] ). 
The aminoacyl‐tRNA synthetases are shown in Fig 6 [rid=msb156423-fig-0006] C and are examined in more detail in Appendix Figs S17 [this file] and S18 [this file] . 
Based on these findings, we hypothesized that the discrepancy between mRNA and protein expression patterns for some genes might be explained by the differential expression of splice variants, and we examined the proteomics data manually for such examples ( Appendix Figs S17 [this file] and S18 [this file] ). 
While the major results from this study have been confirmed by analysis of the total transcriptome ( Appendix Fig S21 [this file] ) and an extended mRNA/protein dataset ( Appendix Fig S19 [this file] ), our discussions are still restricted to a comparatively small subset of the proteome. 
In both the ER stress response described here and the published data on the LPS response, regulation at both RNA and protein level contributes to the change in the system, and protein expression changes drive the synthesis and turnover of highly abundant molecules ( Appendix Figs S22 [this file] and S23 [this file] , Appendix Tables S1 [this file] , S3 [this file] and S4 [this file] ). 
We aimed to estimate the generality of these findings by re‐analyzing the published dataset on the LPS response with PECA ( Appendix Figs S22 [this file] and S23 [this file] , Appendix Tables S3 [this file] and S4 [this file] ) (Jovanovic , 2015 [rid=msb156423-bib-0020] ). 
To account for different cellular ages at harvest, the experiment was conducted so that the experiment started with the 30‐h treatment period, and the cells were then collected at the same time ( Appendix Fig S1 [this file] ). 
To confirm the accuracy of the transcriptomics experiments, selected time points were compared to data collected from the same samples, but using RNA‐seq ( Appendix Fig S8 [this file] ). 
The final mRNA expression data for the two replicates are shown in Appendix Fig S5 [this file] . As described in the Results [rid=msb156423-sec-0002] and Appendix [this file] , several tests, for example, comparison to RNA‐sequencing data, validated the accuracy of the transcriptome data ( Appendix Figs S6 [this file] and S7 [this file] ). 
MaxQuant was used to combine the cytosolic and pellet samples as different fractions in the same experiment, after testing different options ( Appendix Fig S8 [this file] ). 
Appendix Fig S19 [this file] describes the details of this analysis and the results, which were consistent with those from the high‐confidence dataset. Several tests, for example, Western blotting, validated the quality of the proteomics data as described in the Results [rid=msb156423-sec-0002] and Appendix [this file] ( Appendix Figs S11 [this file] and S12 [this file] ). 
For further cluster analysis, 164 sequence features from various databases and tools were assembled ( Appendix Table S2 [this file] ).

title: Statistical analysis of protein association with ME/CFS.
caption: The aOR, 95% confidence levels and p-values from the logistic regression model in which only the linear term of the protein levels was fitted as an independent variable are shown. Quadratic effect p-value corresponds to the likelihood ratio tests comparing the goodness-of-fit of the model with both linear and quadratic terms of the protein levels to the goodness-of-fit of the model with only the linear term. aOR: adjusted odds ratio, CI: confidence interval.  1 Quadratic effect p-value: crude p-value of the likelihood ratio test comparing the goodness-of-fit between the logistic regression model with both linear and quadratic terms of the protein level and the model with only the linear term. Hochberg step-up procedure was applied to correct for the multiple tests over the annotated proteins controlling the family-wise error rate (FWER) at the level of 0.05.

description: kiab135_Supplementary_Data  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
To obtain more information on the correct N-terminus of the mature KEA3 protein, we analyzed a data set that we obtained from proteomics analysis of immunoprecipitated KEA3 ( Supplemental Figure S1 and Supplemental Data Set S1 [this file] ). From seven independent experiments, we obtained a total number of 717 spectra that were assigned to KEA3 peptides ( Supplementary Data Set S1 [this file] ). 
We selected plants expressing and and Col-0 plants expressing ( Figure 2, B [rid=kiab135-F2] and Supplemental Figure S2, A [this file] ). In line with the phenotype of and ( Armbruster et al., 2016 [rid=kiab135-B4] ), these plants were visually indistinguishable from WT (Col-0, Supplemental Figure S2, B [this file] ). Still, KEA3.3 levels in L2 were much lower than in the line #1 that was previously shown to have nine-fold higher KEA3 content than WT ( Supplemental Figure S2, A [this file] ; Armbruster et al., 2016 [rid=kiab135-B4] ). The newly generated plants ( Figure 2, B [rid=kiab135-F2] and Supplemental Figure S2, B [this file] ) were measured for NPQ behavior during an alternating light regime of dark to low light to high light, back to low light, and finally dark, together with the WT Col-0 and line #1 ( Armbruster et al., 2016 [rid=kiab135-B4] ). 
Indeed, when we expressed from the promoter in Col-0, the resulting plants exhibited reduced NPQ in high light ( Supplemental Figure S3, A–D [this file] ). 
Protein levels of these lines were determined by gradient Western blots ( Supplemental Figure S4, A [this file] ). This analysis revealed that / L1 had slightly less than 50% of WT KEA3 levels, while both / L2 and / had approximately twice the amount of WT KEA3 ( Supplemental Figure S4, A [this file] ). Consequently, the lines were renamed ( / L1), ( / L2), and ( / ) for a shortened and more descriptive representation. 77K Chl fluorescence emission spectra of these lines together with WT and showed no genotype-specific differences in the relative antenna cross sections, and excitation energy distribution between both photosystems ( Supplemental Figure S4, B [this file] ). Likewise, total chlorophyll (Chl) content per leaf area ( Supplemental Figure S4, C [this file] ), the Chl a/b ratio ( Supplemental Figure S4, D [this file] ), and the maximum amplitude of difference transmittance signals of P , the Chl dimer in the PSI reaction center ( Supplemental Figure S4, E [this file] ), and plastocyanin ( Supplemental Figure S4, F [this file] ), both normalized to the Chl content, did not reveal any significant differences. Finally, also the maximum quantum efficiency of PSII in the dark-adapted state ( / ; Supplemental Figure S4, G [this file] ) was indistinguishable between WT and all mutant lines. 
In line with the results obtained during the shifts from low to high light ( Figure 2, C [rid=kiab135-F2] and Supplemental Figure S3, B [this file] ), NPQ was initially significantly lower in dark-acclimated KEA3.3 containing plants after shift to high light by about 10% when compared with the other lines ( Figure 3, B [rid=kiab135-F3] ). Moreover, also differing from the results of the previous shorter fluctuations, where all expressing plants continued to have lower NPQ than the expressing lines up to 5 min after shift from low to high light ( Figure 2, C [rid=kiab135-F2] and Supplemental Figure S3, B [this file] ), NPQ levels became very similar between all lines at 5 min after transition from dark to high light ( Figure 3, B [rid=kiab135-F3] ). The quantum efficiency of PSII was increased in after 2–3 min in high light and reduced in and after the transition from high to low light ( Supplemental Figure S5, A [this file] ). 
ECS recovery in the dark was slowest in ( of recovery at ∼3.5 s, with WT, 2xKEA3.2 and 0.5xKEA3.3 at ∼2.5 s) and fastest in ( at ∼1.4 s; Supplemental Figure S5, B [this file] ). The membrane conductivity for protons ( ) was unchanged between genotypes in high light ( Figure 3, F [rid=kiab135-F3] ), as were the acceptor availability of PSII expressed as qL, levels of oxidized cytochrome- (Cyt ), and PSI donor and acceptor side limitations ( Figure 3, G–I [rid=kiab135-F3] and Supplemental Figure S5, C [this file] ). 
All plants expressing KEA3-GFP fusions had a faster recovery of the ECS signal than WT and ( Supplemental Figure S5, D [this file] ). The donor side limitation of PSI was significantly lower in when compared with ( Figure 3, O [rid=kiab135-F3] ), while PSI acceptor side limitation remained unchanged between genotypes ( Supplemental Figure S5, E [this file] ). 
The fastest recovery was observed for and the slowest for ( Supplemental Figure S5, B and D [this file] ), which suggests that deregulation and levels of KEA3 have an additive effect on the ECS recovery in the dark after low light. 
There was no significant difference in the electron transport rate through PSII between genotypes ( Supplemental Figure S5, F [this file] ). showed increased NPQ and qL in low and medium light when compared with WT ( Supplemental Figure S5, G and H [this file] ). showed strong differences to WT mostly during high light with decreased NPQ and PSI donor site limitation and enhanced PSI acceptor side limitation at very high, non-physiological light intensities ( Supplemental Figure S5, G–I [this file] ). 
As expected from the spectroscopic analyses ( Supplemental Figure S4, B–G [this file] ), no significant differences in thylakoid complex composition or stoichiometry were apparent between the different lines ( Figure 5, A [rid=kiab135-F5] ). 
We then searched for potential protein interaction partners of KEA3 by analyzing the co-immunoprecipitation (Co-IP) results obtained from the and lines ( Supplemental Figure S1 and Supplemental File S1 [this file] ). The strongest candidates for interactions were selected based on their presence in at least 4 (of 7) Co-IP eluates of and or 2 (of 4) of and absence in the Col-0 controls ( Supplementary File S1 [this file] ). The Co-IP results showed that PsbS and FtsH subunits bind to the GFP trap, because they are found in the pellet of Col-0, which does not express a KEA3-GFP fusion, and thus can likely be considered contaminations ( Supplemental Figure S6, A [this file] ). Additionally, gel slices that contained KEA3 high molecular weight complexes were excised from the BN-PAGE ( Figure 5, A and B [rid=kiab135-F5] and Supplemental Figure S6, B [this file] ) and analyzed for their protein composition by MS. The MS analysis of BN-gel slices mainly reproduced the protein blot results, with KEA3 being differentially accumulated depending on size and isoform and lacking from slices of the mutant ( Supplemental Figure S6, B–D [this file] ). None of the other potential interaction candidates showed a similar pattern as KEA3 ( Supplemental Figure S6, E [this file] ). However, except for Alb3 and TLP18.3, all other proteins were present at much higher levels (more than four-fold) than KEA3 in the analyzed gel slices ( Supplemental Figure S6, E [this file] ). 
Thus, we generated recombinant KEA3 C-terminus ( Figure 5, C [rid=kiab135-F5] and Supplemental Figure S7 [this file] ), removed residual free Ni ions by adding EDTA to avoid interaction of the His -tags and performed size exclusion chromatography (SEC, Figure 5, D [rid=kiab135-F5] ). The identity of the band as the KEA3 C-terminus was confirmed by protein blot analysis using the specific KEA3 antibody ( Figure 5, E [rid=kiab135-F5] ) and MS analysis of the purified protein ( Supplementary File S1 [this file] ). The MS analysis revealed that the KEA3-terminus was the main component and contaminating proteins were 100-fold less abundant in the sample ( Supplementary File S1 [this file] ). 
The hypothesis that is strongly activated after a transition to low light is based on the finding (3) that mutants have a slow NPQ relaxation ( Supplemental Figure S3, B [this file] ), while NPQ decay is strongly accelerated in plants over-accumulating KEA3.2 as in in this work ( Figure 2, C [rid=kiab135-F2] ), and in overexpressors ( Armbruster et al., 2016 [rid=kiab135-B4] ). plants show no significant alterations of NPQ relaxation when compared with WT or ( Figure 2, D [rid=kiab135-F2] ). Given that this assumption is correct, our data suggest that KEA3.2 is also active directly after transition to dark ( Supplemental Figure S5, B–D [this file] ). 
Further evidence for this notion can be found in the light response curves, which reveal lower PSI donor side and increased acceptor side limitation at high light in when compared with the other lines ( Supplemental Figure S5, H–I [this file] ). 
Plants expressing either or from the promoter were generated as follows: and coding sequences were amplified from the constructs ( Armbruster et al., 2016 [rid=kiab135-B4] ) by using the primer sequences described in Supplemental Table S1 [this file] , and then assembled downstream of the (1,854 bp) and upstream of the (104 bp) into the 100 vector ( Earley et al., 2006 [rid=kiab135-B19] ) cut with the two restriction enzymes I and I by using Gibson assembly ( Gibson et al., 2009 [rid=kiab135-B26] ).

The cDNAs of selected proteins, total RNA of Hela cell was obtained by TRIzol™ Reagent (Ambion, cat. # 15596018) and reverse transcript with M-MuLV Reverse Transcriptase (NEB, cat. #M0253L) than amplified with PrimeSTAR HS Premix (Takara, cat. #R040A) using corresponding primers ( Supplementary Table S2 [this file] ). 
The FAM-labelled oligonucleotides (detailed in Supplementary Table S1 [this file] ) were heated at 95°C for 5 min in 20 mM Tris, pH 7.5 buffer with 150 mM KCl and annealing to 25°C at a rate of −1°C/min. 
The structural model of G4PID, as depicted in Figure 1A [rid=F1] and Supplementary Figure S1 [this file] , showcased its composition: RHAU23 positioned at the N-terminal, miniTurbo at the C-terminal, and an intermediary flexible linker bridging the two components. The nucleotide sequences used in EMSA were detailed in Supplementary Table S1 [this file] . Circular dichroism spectroscopy was utilized to confirm the G4 conformation of each sequence (Figure 1B [rid=F1] and Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). We also confirmed that G4PID binds to G4s exhibiting different conformations and showed negligible binding affinity to single-stand oligos and double-strands hairpins (Figure 1B [rid=F1] , C [rid=F1] and Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). 
As shown in Supplementary Figure S3 [this file] , G4PID predominantly localized within the nucleus, with a secondary presence in the cytoplasm, which is different from the homogeneous distribution of miniTurbo. As shown in Figure 2A [rid=F2] , a [rid=F2] remarkable 57.60% of G4PID-binding sites were found to contain PQS, while only 16.85% of random sequences observed contain PQS ( Supplementary Figure S4 [this file] ). We have compared G4PID eCLIP PQS with PQS data from rG4-seq and DMS-seq was analyzed and shown in Supplementary Figure S5 [this file] . 
The pull-down proteins were visualized by streptavidin–HRP blotting ( Supplementary Figure S6 [this file] ). Three independent biological replicates were performed, resulting in a coverage of 578 proteins with an 80% consistency rate, thus affirming the repeatability of our methodology (Figure 3B [rid=F3] , Supplementary Table S3 [this file] ). Ultimately, our approach yielded a total of 149 candidate G4-interacting proteins ( Supplementary Table S3 [this file] , Figure 3C [rid=F3] ). 
In aggregate, 31 out of the total 149 proteins (20.8%) had been previously reported in the previous literature ( Supplementary Table S3 [this file] ). 
To validate the G4 binding affinity of newly identified candidate proteins, we selected several of them and expressed recombinant proteins in Rosetta2 ( Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] ). 
Protein binding affinity with single stranded DNA and double stranded DNA hairpin were conducted as control ( Supplementary Figure S8 [this file] ). 
We further verified that SF3B4 binds specifically to the G4 structure formed by G4-INPPL1 and G4-PPP6R2, and not to their mutant sequences which possess similar nucleotide composition but cannot form G4 structure (Figure 6B [rid=F6] and Supplementary Figure S9 [this file] ).

context_description:
In addition, several subunits of the TFIIH complex (XPD/p80, XPB/p89, GTF2H1/p62, and CDK7) also associated with RNAPIIo after UV (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] ; Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). Similar results were obtained when using antibodies against Ser5-phosphorylated RNAPII (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). Although the CS proteins and TFIIH readily assembled with RNAPIIo after UV irradiation, downstream repair proteins such as XPA, ERCC1-XPF, and XRCC1 could not be detected (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). It should be noted that we could not detect UVSSA either after pull-down of RNAPIIo or in whole cell lysates due to a lack of specific antibodies (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). 
See Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] for each individual Co-IP. See Supplementary Fig. 2a, b [this file] for validation of knockouts by sequencing. 
The knockout of CSB, CSA, and UVSSA was confirmed by western blot analysis and/or DNA sequencing (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] ; Supplementary Fig. 2a, b [this file] ). As an additional control we also included XPC-KO cells, which are deficient in global genome repair (GGR; Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ). 
See Supplementary Figs. 3 [this file] and 4 [this file] for a full overview of all tested mutants. See Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] for additional alignments. 
To identify the CSA-interaction domain in CSB, we fused various truncated fragments of CSB to mCherry-LacR and examined their ability to recruit CSA-GFP to the LacO array (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Figs. 3 [this file] , 4 [this file] ). Conversely, tethering of a LacR-tagged CSB region spanning the C-terminus (C and ∆N) triggered robust recruitment of CSA-GFP (Fig. 2b–d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). However, a region just upstream of the UBD (1306–1399) is sufficient to mediate CSA recruitment to the LacO array (Fig. 2b–d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). Further deletion analysis showed that CSB lacking the region just upstream of the UBD (1353–1399) failed to recruit CSA-GFP, whereas CSB lacking the UBD (1400–1428) or amino acids 1306–1352 were fully proficient in interacting with CSA-GFP (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Moreover, while CSB and CSB were fully proficient in recruiting CSA-GFP to the LacO array, deleting amino acids 1385–1399 abolished the ability of CSB to interact with CSA-GFP (Fig. 2b–d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). These findings identify an evolutionary conserved CSA-interaction motif (CIM) in CSB that is located between amino acids 1385–1399 (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
These findings were confirmed by quantitative mass spectrometry (MS) after pull-down of GFP-tagged versions of either CSB or CSB (Supplementary Fig. 6a–c [this file] , see Supplementary Table 7 [this file] for link to interactive volcano plots). To determine whether the CIM can mediate a functional interaction between CSB and CSA, we mixed recombinant CSB or CSB with ubiquitin, E1, E2, and the E3 ubiquitin ligase CRL4 consisting of CSA, DDB1, CUL4A, and RBX1 (Supplementary Fig. 6d [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 6e [this file] for additional Co-IP data. See also Supplementary Fig. 6d [this file] . 
The knockout of CSB and CSA was verified by western blot analysis, DNA sequencing (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] ; Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ), and Illudin S clonogenic survival assays (Fig. 4b [rid=Fig4] ). 
Interestingly, TFIIH also failed to associate with RNAPIIo in CSB-KO cells complemented with GFP-CSB (Supplementary Fig. 6e [this file] ), consistent with our findings that this mutant is not capable of recruiting CSA (Fig. 3c, g [rid=Fig3] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] for additional XR-seq data. 
Additionally, among the most prominent UV-specific interactions were the TFIIH subunits XPB/p89 and XPD/p80 (Fig. 5b [rid=Fig5] ; see Supplementary Table 7 [this file] for link to interactive volcano plots). 
In addition, we included XPA-KO cells (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ) as a positive control since XPA recruitment, at least during GGR, occurs downstream of TFIIH . 
We generated nucleotide-resolution maps of UV-induced CPDs repair in U2OS WT cells (Fig. 5f [rid=Fig5] ; Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ; Supplementary Table 8 [this file] ), which revealed that CPD repair under these conditions is enriched on the transcribed strands within gene bodies consistent with TCR-mediated repair . Importantly, the bias in CPD repair observed in transcribed strands was completely lost in both CSA-KO (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ) and UVSSA-KO cells (Fig. 5f [rid=Fig5] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 7b, c [this file] for additional Co-IP data. 
These interactors were virtually absent after pull-down of GFP-UVSSA (Fig. 6e [rid=Fig6] ; Supplementary Fig. 7b, c [this file] ). Pull-down of GFP-UVSSA resulted in a strong UV-induced interaction with RNAPIIo, CSB, and CSA, while its interaction with TFIIH was completely abolished (Fig. 6e [rid=Fig6] ; Supplementary Fig. 7b, c [this file] ). Interestingly, this approach also identified several proteins that interacted with UVSSA , but not with the UVSSA mutants (Supplementary Fig. 8a–e [this file] ; see Supplementary Table 7 [this file] for link to interactive volcano plots). 
In line with this, genome-wide XR-seq revealed that the stable expression of GFP-UVSSA and GFP-UVSSA in UVSSA-KO cells failed to restore the repair of CPDs in the transcribed strand, which was fully restored by GFP-UVSSA (Fig. 7b [rid=Fig7] ; Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] Supplementary Table 8 [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] for additional XR-seq data. 
Interestingly, the CIM region in CSB is evolutionary conserved in species that also contain the gene, including mammals, amphibians and fish (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). However, the CIM is absent in species without CSA, including yeast, nematodes, but also holometabolous insects, which have lost the gene during the course of evolution (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
Cell lines (listed in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) were cultured at 37 °C in an atmosphere of 5% CO in DMEM (Thermo Fisher Scientific) supplemented with penicillin/streptomycin (Sigma) and 10% Fetal bovine serum (FBS; Bodinco BV). 
To generate stable knockouts, U2OS Flp-In/T-REx cells were co-transfected with pLV-U6g-PPB encoding a guide RNA from the LUMC/Sigma-Aldrich sgRNA library (see Supplementary Table 2 [this file] for plasmids, Supplementary Table 3 [this file] for sgRNA sequences) together with an expression vector encoding Cas9-2A-GFP (pX458; Addgene #48138) using lipofectamine 2000 (Invitrogen). 
Fragments of ~1 kb, containing the sgRNA sequence, were amplified by PCR (sequencing primers are listed in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) followed by Sanger sequencing using either the forward or the reverse primer. 
Selected knockout clones of CSB, CSA, and UVSSA (see Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) were subsequently used to stably express GFP-CSB , GFP-CSB , CSA -GFP, GFP-UVSSA , GFP-UVSSA , and GFP-UVSSA by co-transfection of pCDNA5/FRT/TO-Puro plasmid encoding these CSB, CSA, and UVSSA variants (2 µg), together with pOG44 plasmid encoding the Flp recombinase (0.5 µg). 
CSB , CSA , and UVSSA were amplified by PCR (see Supplementary Table 5 [this file] for primers) and inserted into pcDNA5/FRT/TO-Puro-GFP-N1 or pcDNA5/FRT/TO-Puro-GFP-C1 and in mCherry-LacR-NLS-C1/C3. 
For interactors of the CSB and UVSSA mutant proteins (Supplementary Figs. 6a [this file] –c and 8a–e [this file] ), mass spectrometry analysis was performed as previously described . 
Links to the interactive volcano plots are listed in Supplementary Table 7 [this file] and in the relevant figure legends. 
The membrane was then probed with antibodies (listed in Supplementary Table 6 [this file] ) as indicated. 
CPDs were detected using anti-CPD mouse monoclonal antibody followed by incubation with an anti-mouse HRP conjugated antibody (Supplementary Table 6 [this file] ). 
All open reading frames were cloned into pAceBac1 (pAB1) or pIDC vectors containing the indicated affinity tags (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
Mass spectrometry proteomics data are presented in main Fig. 5b [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Figs. 6a–c [this file] and 8a–e [this file] , and have been deposited to the ProteomeXchange Consortium via the PRIDE partner repository ( https://www.ebi.ac.uk/pride/ (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/pride/) ) with the dataset identifiers PXD013572 (http://proteomecentral.proteomexchange.org/cgi/GetDataset?ID=PXD013572) and PXD017329 (http://proteomecentral.proteomexchange.org/cgi/GetDataset?ID=PXD017329) . S7a [this file] , S9a [this file] . The source data underlying Figs. 1b, d–h [rid=Fig1] , 2b, d–h [rid=Fig2] , 3b–g [rid=Fig3] , 4a–d [rid=Fig4] , 5a, c–e [rid=Fig5] , 6c–f [rid=Fig6] , and 7a [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Figs. 1a–c [this file] , 2c [this file] , 3c [this file] , 4c [this file] , 6d–e [this file] , and 7b–c [this file] are provided as a Source Data [rid=MOESM4] file.

To conditionally express Flag-tagged, murine in mammary epithelia, MMTV-driven mice were bred with mice bearing a floxed ß-Geo-Stop- flag cassette transgene. , hereafter referred to as , were viable, fertile, and over-produced TRIM24 in mammary epithelia (Supplementary Fig. S1a–d [this file] ). The Flag-tagged mTrim24 transposon integrated as a single copy, into the q-arm of chromosome 1 without disrupting any known genes or regulatory elements, as determined by whole-genome sequencing and PCR (Supplementary Fig. S1e [this file] and Supplementary Data 3 [this file] ). transcript expression in the whole mammary gland was increased ~2.5–3-fold in mice, as compared to controls (Supplementary Fig. S1c [this file] ). TRIM24 and exogenous Flag-TRIM24 protein levels in the mammary epithelium were confirmed by western blot analysis (Supplementary Fig. S1d [this file] ). Necropsy revealed no other primary tumor sites and two mice with metastases: one to the lung and the other to the liver (Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ). , lacking MMTV-Cre-expression, lacked any palpable tumor formation within 600 days and MMTV-Cre-only mice ( = 27) had occasional hyperplasia and spontaneous mammary tumor development (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] ). tumors overexpressed TRIM24 compared to controls, as determined by IHC (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] ). tumors exhibited overexpression of FLAG and TRIM24 proteins and lacked detectable expression of p53 (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] ), compared to Cre-only control mammary glands. 
Pathologic examination of mammary tumors formed in mice revealed three tumor types, including adenoma (8%), carcinoma (25%), and carcinosarcoma (67%) (Fig. 2a [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ). Assessment of carcinosarcoma tumors by IHC revealed gain of vimentin, loss of E-cadherin, estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), and no over-expression of receptor tyrosine kinase erbB-2 (ERBB2) (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
Expression of TRIM24 was additionally assessed by IHC of a tumor array with 46 MpBC patient biopsies and quantified according to previously published convention (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ) . High nuclear TRIM24 levels were found in 27% spindle and 45% matrix producing subtyped MpBC patients, similar to the cohort distribution of subtypes (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ). 
Using a false discovery rate (FDR) of 5%, we found 2006 genes, 529 up-regulated and 1477 down-regulated, had at least 5-fold change (Supplementary Data 6 [this file] ). 
To validate the expression of genes within the top 1% (based on FDR) of DEGs in our RNA-Seq analysis, we used qRT-PCR analysis of RNA isolated from tumors (carcinoma, = 3: tumor number 2735, 3956, and 89; metaplastic carcinosarcoma, = 3: tumor number 567, 64, and 897) and controls (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). As predicted by RNA-seq, qRT-PCR shows that , gelactin-1 ( ), macrophage migration inhibitory factor ( ), cyclin-dependent kinase Inhibitor 2 A ( ), vimentin ( ), and fibronectin 1 ( ) were highly expressed in TRIM24-driven tumors compared to Cre-only mammary glands (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). In comparison, p53 ( , aldehyde dehydrogenase 1 family member A1 ( ), V-set domain-containing T-cell activation inhibitor 1 ( ), synuclein gamma ( ), leukocyte receptor tyrosine kinase ( ), E-cadehrin ( ), and synaptotagmin 9 ( ) were down-regulated in TRIM24-driven tumors compared to Cre-controls (Supplementary Fig. 3a, b [this file] ). 
Interestingly, the EMT scores of TRIM24-driven and non-TRIM24-driven carcinomas were not significantly different (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). 
We compared the gene expression analysis of Weiget et al. by means of the calculated TRIM24 metaplastic score and found that this cohort of human MpBC tumors has a significantly higher TRIM24 metaplastic score than TRIM24-driven carcinomas, as did TRIM24-driven metaplastic carcinosarcomas (Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ), predicting that TRIM24 is activated in human metaplastic tumors. Comparison of our calculated TRIM24 metaplastic score to microarray expression analysis of MMTV-Met-driven and MMTV-Met;Trp53 tumors revealed that the TRIM24 signature is significantly higher in the two MET-driven metaplastic models, but not the non-metaplastic p53/MET model (Supplementary Fig. 3e [this file] ). This assessment revealed significant alignment between carcinosarcoma DEGs and human metaplastic gene signature data (NES = 1.615 and FDR 0.002) (Supplementary Fig. 3f [this file] ). 
Normalized protein loading and transformed linear values were used to determine fold change and later log 2 transformed fold change values (Supplementary Data 7 [this file] ). 
Further, using a tet-inducible system, we showed that knock-down of leads to a parallel decrease in mRNA expression of (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). 
PHA-665752 treatment and targeting of MET significantly reduced cell viability in a dose-dependent and metaplastic carcinosarcoma-specific manner (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). 
PI3K pathway components exhibited high protein levels in RPPA and CyTOF analysis of metaplastic carcinosarcoma tumors (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] ), likely activated by post-transcriptional regulation (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). We found that metaplastic carcinosarcoma cell lines showed a marked reduction in cell viability with low doses of Dactolisib, which was not recapitulated in the 4T1 TNBC-like cell line (Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] ). 
We used RNA-Seq analysis of MpBC patient tumor biopsies, acquired at the time of enrollment in the clinical trial, to generate a human TRIM24 metaplastic breast cancer signature using the SIGNATURE system, as previously described , and developed a heatmap representation of the TRIM24 metaplastic signature expressed by murine metaplastic carcinosarcoma (M) versus carcinoma tumors (C) (Fig. 6a [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Data 8 [this file] ). 
Further, TRIM24-signature-high-scoring MpBC tumors (red dots) also showed a higher percentage of vimentin IHC staining, indicative of EMT, compared to non-metaplastic TNBC tumors (Fig. 6d [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Data 9 [this file] ). RCB-II and RCB-III tumors had higher TRIM24 scores, but did not achieve statistical significance due to low numbers of chemosensitive tumors (Fig. 6e [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Data 9 [this file] ), indicating little to no response to primary chemotherapy. In the subtypes of TNBCs, described by Lehman et al. , we found that MpBC tumors with significant TRIM24 metaplastic scores were classified mainly as immunomodulatory (IM) and mesenchymal (M*) subtypes (Fig. 6f [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Data 9 [this file] ). 
Non-MpBC and MpBC subtyped patient biopsies were further classified by Vanderbilt-Based subtyping (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). Human mitochondrial protein IHC for nonglycosylated components of mitochondria distinguishes human tissue in the mouse mammary environment of PDX models (Supplementary Fig. 5b, d [this file] ). MpBC PDXs have high levels of TRIM24 expression in both nuclear and cytoplasmic compartments, while non-MpBC TNBC PDXs have more variable TRIM24 expression (Fig. 7a [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). 
However, IACS9571 bromodomain inhibitor was further developed as a VHL-ligand-based proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC), which proved to be an effective TRIM24 protein degrader (dTRIM24) in cellulo ( and Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] ). The dTRIM24 drug successfully degraded TRIM24 compared to eTRIM24 and DMSO (Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] ). To ascertain potential relevance of TRIM24 targeting in human TNBC, we compared the ability of dTRIM24 and eTRIM24 to impact viability of TNBC PDX tumorspheres, both MpBC and non-MpBC (Fig. 7a [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ), using a high-throughput drug screening platform (Fig. 7b [rid=Fig7] ). 
Comparison of RNA expression changes in MMTV-driven tumors, as well as to publicly available human MpBC ( GSE57544 (GSE57544) ), revealed significant concurrence with our derived TRIM24 Metaplastic signature score (Supplementary Fig. 3d, e [this file] ). 
A transposon vector was constructed bearing a human promoter-driven cassette 5′ of a FLAG-tagged cDNA ( ) (Supplementary Fig. S1a [this file] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) . Transgenic ( ) founder mice were identified by PCR of tail genomic DNA (Fig S1b), using primers listed in Supplementary Data 1 [this file] . mice were bred with the Tg(MMTV-cre)4Mam (The Jackson laboratory, stock 003553) recombinase mouse line D ( ) for Cre-mediated excision of the floxed stop cassette to drive expression of transgenic in mammary epithelial cells. 
The discordant reads of these samples are included in Supplementary Data 3 [this file] . 
Immunoblotting was performed using standard techniques for antibodies listed in Supplementary Data 1 [this file] . Total RNA was isolated with TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen) and qRT-PCR was performed as described previously using primers listed in Supplementary Data 2 [this file] . 
This resulted in a list of 2006 genes (Supplementary Data 6 [this file] ). 
Samples were probed with 244 antibodies listed in Supplementary Data 7 [this file] . 
We then compared the scores between the metaplastic tumors (defined by a pathologist) and the non-metaplastic ones using a two-tailed T-test via GraphPad Prism (Supplementary Data 8 [this file] ).

title: Neurons reveal diversity in identities. Related to
caption: ( A ) Velocity field projected in the UMAP plot; arrows indicate average velocity at a local level and predict the future cell state. The analysis of RNA velocities predicts the direction of lineage differentiation from the less differentiated NBs to the more differentiated neurons. ( B ) Top differentially expressed markers between each neuronal cluster and all remaining clusters; ion channels (blue) and genes integrating the immunoglobulin and cadherin super families (green) are highlighted. Outlines identify clusters 5 and 35, predicted to be the oldest/more mature neurons in the dataset. ( C ) Number of neurons expressing neurotransmitter-associated genes ( VGlut ,  VAChT Gad1 ,  Vmat ) independently or simultaneously (counts >0); the respective percentages within the total neuronal population are indicated in bold. Each portrayed gene is associated with a different neurotransmitter: glutamatergic ( VGlut ), cholinergic ( VAChT ), GABAergic ( Gad1 ), or monoaminergic ( Vmat ). The data underlying this figure are contained within GEO database (Accession number:  GSE179763 ).  Gad1 ,  glutamic acid decarboxylase 1 ; NB, neuroblast; UMAP, uniform manifold approximation and projection;  VAChT ,  Vesicular acetylcholine transporter ;  VGlut ,  vesicular glutamate transporter ;  Vmat ,  Vesicular monoamine transporter .

title: VGlut, ChAT, and Gad1 transcript and protein dynamics. Related to Figs
caption: (A, B) 18-h clone induced at 87 h ALH and analysed at 105 h ALH (wL3). Oldest neurons in clone are approximately 12.5 h. (A) Schematic representation of temporal strategy used to induce clones in neural lineages. (B) smFISH against Gad1. Individual mRNA molecules are displayed as magenta dots; clone cells are labeled with nuclear GFP (green). Dashed line delimitates a neural lineage clone; pink arrowhead indicates the closest cell to the neuroblast where mRNA is visible; yellow asterisk identifies a neuroblast. Z-projection from 11 slices with 0.25-μm interval; scale bar, 5 μm. (C) Schematic representation of the smFISH spot classification regarding distance to the neuroblast. All spots detected within a specific lineage were classified according to their distance towards the NB (yellow) as: (1) spots in cells that are touching the NBs (green); and (2) all spots located in cells that are more than 1-cell distance away from the NB (magenta). (D) Quantification of the number of smFISH spots detected for VGlut (4 lineages; 2 brains), ChAT (12 lineages; 4 brains), and Gad1 (10 lineages; 4 brains). Data shown as mean ± SEM; statistical analysis was done using unpaired two-tailed  t  test; ** P  value < 0.01, *** P  value < 0.001. The data underlying this figure are contained within  S1 Data . (E) Temporal expression of Gad1-GFP under endogenous regulation. Expression was assessed at wL3 (dashed line delimitates the OL) and at 24 h APF (Z-projection from 4 slices with 1-μm interval; Gad1 expression is indicated with an arrow); scale bar, 50 μm. (F) Single-cell transcript expression pattern of  ChAT ,  VGlut , and  Gad1  in OL neurons at indicated times in the X axis (times in hours APF). Two types of neurons are shown for each of the represented neurotransmitter families: L5 and Mi1 (cholinergic), L1 and Mi1 (glutamatergic), Dm10 and Mi4 (GABAergic). Expression patterns shown for these genes range from 0 h APF to 96 h APF, with a 12-h interval; levels of expression are represented in normalized values; the red dashed line indicates 24 h APF, the approximate onset of protein detection in the OL. The data underlying this figure were obtained using the dataset generated by [ 18 ] and is contained within  S2 Data . (G) Quantification of VGlut and ChAT fluorescence intensity in wL3 OL regions when the indicated subunits of the proteosome are knocked down in optic lobe neurons.  elav -Gal4 was used to drive the expression of UAS-Pomp RNAi, UAS-Prosβ2 RNAi, and UAS-Rpt5 RNAi. Mean fluorescence intensity of VGlut and ChAT was measured in medulla neurons (W1118,  n =  8 brains; Pomp RNAi,  n  = 5 brains; Prosβ2 RNAi,  n  = 5; Rpt5 RNAi,  n  = 5). Data shown as mean ± SEM; statistical analysis was done using 1-way ANOVA, with a Bonferroni’s multiple comparison test;  p -values < 0.05 were considered statistically significant; ns, not significant. The data underlying this figure are contained within  S4 Data . ALH, after larval hatching; APF, after puparium formation; ChAT, choline acetyltransferase; Gad1, glutamic acid decarboxylase 1; NB, neuroblast; OL, optic lobe; smFISH, single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization; VGlut, vesicular glutamate transporter; wL3, wandering third instar larvae.
description: S4  Fig  VGlut,  ChAT,  and  Gad1  transcript  and  protein  dynamics.  Related  to  Figs  3  and  4  .  (A,  B)  18-h  clone  induced  at  87  h  ALH  and  analysed  at  105  h  ALH  (wL3).  Oldest  neurons  in  clone  are  approximately  12.5  h.  (A)  Schematic  representation  of  temporal  strategy  used  to  induce  clones  in  neural  lineages.  (B)  smFISH  against  Gad1.  Individual  mRNA  molecules  are  displayed  as  magenta  dots;  clone  cells  are  labeled  with  nuclear  GFP  (green).  Dashed  line  delimitates  a  neural  lineage  clone;  pink  arrowhead  indicates  the  closest  cell  to  the  neuroblast  where  mRNA  is  visible;  yellow  asterisk  identifies  a  neuroblast.  Z-projection  from  11  slices  with  0.25-μm  interval;  scale  bar,  5  μm.  (C)  Schematic  representation  of  the  smFISH  spot  classification  regarding  distance  to  the  neuroblast.  All  spots  detected  within  a  specific  lineage  were  classified  according  to  their  distance  towards  the  NB  (yellow)  as:  (1)  spots  in  cells  that  are  touching  the  NBs  (green);  and  (2)  all  spots  located  in  cells  that  are  more  than  1-cell  distance  away  from  the  NB  (magenta).  (D)  Quantification  of  the  number  of  smFISH  spots  detected  for  VGlut  (4  lineages;  2  brains),  ChAT  (12  lineages;  4  brains),  and  Gad1  (10  lineages;  4  brains).  Data  shown  as  mean  ±  SEM;  statistical  analysis  was  done  using  unpaired  two-tailed  t  test;  **  P  value  <  0.01,  ***  P  value  <  0.001.  The  data  underlying  this  figure  are  contained  within  S1  Data  .  (E)  Temporal  expression  of  Gad1-GFP  under  endogenous  regulation.  Expression  was  assessed  at  wL3  (dashed  line  delimitates  the  OL)  and  at  24  h  APF  (Z-projection  from  4  slices  with  1-μm  interval;  Gad1  expression  is  indicated  with  an  arrow);  scale  bar,  50  μm.  (F)  Single-cell  transcript  expression  pattern  of  ChAT  ,  VGlut  ,  and  Gad1  in  OL  neurons  at  indicated  times  in  the  X  axis  (times  in  hours  APF).  Two  types  of  neurons  are  shown  for  each  of  the  represented  neurotransmitter  families:  L5  and  Mi1  (cholinergic),  L1  and  Mi1  (glutamatergic),  Dm10  and  Mi4  (GABAergic).  Expression  patterns  shown  for  these  genes  range  from  0  h  APF  to  96  h  APF,  with  a  12-h  interval;  levels  of  expression  are  represented  in  normalized  values;  the  red  dashed  line  indicates  24  h  APF,  the  approximate  onset  of  protein  detection  in  the  OL.  The  data  underlying  this  figure  were  obtained  using  the  dataset  generated  by  [  18  ]  and  is  contained  within  S2  Data  .  (G)  Quantification  of  VGlut  and  ChAT  fluorescence  intensity  in  wL3  OL  regions  when  the  indicated  subunits  of  the  proteosome  are  knocked  down  in  optic  lobe  neurons.  elav  -Gal4  was  used  to  drive  the  expression  of  UAS-Pomp  RNAi,  UAS-Prosβ2  RNAi,  and  UAS-Rpt5  RNAi.  Mean  fluorescence  intensity  of  VGlut  and  ChAT  was  measured  in  medulla  neurons  (W1118,  n  =  8  brains;  Pomp  RNAi,  n  =  5  brains;  Prosβ2  RNAi,  n  =  5;  Rpt5  RNAi,  n  =  5).  Data  shown  as  mean  ±  SEM;  statistical  analysis  was  done  using  1-way  ANOVA,  with  a  Bonferroni’s  multiple  comparison  test;  p  -values  <  0.05  were  considered  statistically  significant;  ns,  not  significant.  The  data  underlying  this  figure  are  contained  within  S4  Data  .  ALH,  after  larval  hatching;  APF,  after  puparium  formation;  ChAT,  choline  acetyltransferase;  Gad1,  glutamic  acid  decarboxylase  1;  NB,  neuroblast;  OL,  optic  lobe;  smFISH,  single-molecule  fluorescence  in  situ  hybridization;  VGlut,  vesicular  glutamate  transporter;  wL3,  wandering  third  instar  larvae. title: Ecdysone is not necessary to inhibit VGlut translation in larval stages. Related to
caption: ( A, B ) Immunofluorescence images for VGlut antibody staining (magenta); VT201094-Gal4;tubGal80ts was used to permanently label with GFP NB-derived lineages using G-TRACE; outlines indicate examples of GFP-positive lineage clones. Scale bar, 20 μm. ( A ) 18-h clones induced at 87 h ALH and analysed at 105 h ALH; oldest neurons in clones are approximately 12.5 h. ( A ) G-TRACE (Control) and ( A’ ) EcRDN;G-TRACE. ( B ) 72-h clones induced at 87 h and analysed at 159 h ALH (approximately 48 h APF); oldest neurons in clone are approximately 66.5 h. ( B ) G-TRACE (Control) and (B’) EcRDN;G-TRACE. ( C - E )  elav -Gal4;tubGal80ts was used to drive EcR-DN expression in neurons from 87 h ALH for 18 h (analysis at 105 h ALH) or for 72 h (analysis at 48 h APF). VGlut antibody staining (white) ( C ,  D ) G-TRACE (Control); ( C’ ,  D’ ) EcR-DN;G-TRACE. Outlines indicate examples of areas where VGlut is expressed. Scale bar in  C ,  C’  = 20 μm. Scale bar in  D ,  D’  = 50 μm. ( E ) Quantification of the volume of VGlut expression per lobe at approximately 48 h APF in control brains ( n  = 8) and EcRDN;G-TRACE ( n  = 10). Data shown as mean ± SEM. ( F ,  G ) Evaluation of VGlut expression at 48 h APF after prothoracic gland ablation at 0 h APF. ( F ) Control brains; ( F’ ) Brains with prothoracic gland ablated, PGX. Outlines indicate examples of areas where VGlut is expressed. Scale bar, 50 μm. ( G ) Quantification of the volume of VGlut expression per lobe at 48 h APF in control brains ( n  = 5) and PGX ( n  = 7); indicated values refer to mean ± SEM. Statistical analysis was done using unpaired two-tailed  t  test. The data underlying this figure are contained within  S5 Data . ALH, after larval hatching; APF, after puparium formation; NB, neuroblast; VGlut, vesicular glutamate transporter.
description: S5  Fig  Ecdysone  is  not  necessary  to  inhibit  VGlut  translation  in  larval  stages.  Related  to  Fig  4  . title: NIHMS1605462-supplement-Figure_S1.pdf
context_description:
To evaluate the effect of MBR on multiple MS/MS experiments, we first looked to establish a baseline identification rate by assessing the number of unique peptides and proteins identified, by species, in each of the 40 MS/MS analyses ( Figure 1B [href=#F1] , Table 1 [href=#T1] , Supporting Figure S1 [href=this file] ). Without MBR, only 57% and 56% of all observed human peptides were detected in each MS/MS analysis of Sample H and HY, respectively ( Supporting Figure S1 [href=this file] ).
For example, yeast peptide IIDDDVPTILQGAK contained no signal in Sample H while peptide FGPIVSASLEK contained several peaks within the identified retention time window ( Supporting Figure S2 [href=this file] and S3 [href=this file] ).
Figure S1 [href=this file] : Analysis of MBR false transfers as a percentage of peptide identifications; Figure S2 [href=this file] : Extracted ion chromatograms for peptide IIDDDVPTILQGAK across 40 runs; Figure S3 [href=this file] : Extracted ion chromatograms for yeast peptide FGPIVSASLEK across 40 runs ( PDF [href=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.jproteome.9b00492/suppl_file/pr9b00492_si_002.pdf] )
pub_title: Evaluating False Transfer Rates from the Match-between-Runs Algorithm with a Two-Proteome Model - PMC

Downregulation of KRAB zinc finger proteins in 5-fluorouracil resistant colorectal cancer cells

title: No Title
caption: Additional file 1.
context_description:
All the experimental conditions were described in Fig. S 2 [rid=MOESM3] and Table S 1 [this file] . 
Each TMTsixplex label reagent (#90066) was equilibrated at room temperature, dissolved in 41 μl anhydrous acetonitrile and added in a 50 μg-peptide sample (more details in Table S 1 [this file] ). 
All those different conditions were then mixed differentially in order to allow comparison between the different cell lines and the different treatments, resulting in different 6-plex TMT mixes (Table S 1 [this file] ). Significantly upregulated and downregulated proteins are presented as light and dark share of the circle, as well as the comparison between the sensitive and resistant cell lines (|z-score (ratio) ≥ 1.96|) (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] B, Tables S 2 [this file] .1–15, Tables S 3 [this file] .1–9). 
The readings were aligned to the human transcriptome constructed from the annotations from ENSEMBL (Homo sapiens version 98) (Table S 4 [this file] ). Gene quantification analysis revealed that the annotation contained 59,369 genes, with 23,313 detected in at least one sample (using a minimal quantification of 1 TPM) (Table S 5 [this file] ). The differential expression of transcripts and genes was obtained by comparing the specific data for each cell line compared to the control condition (Tables S 6 [this file] .1–15, Tables S 7 [this file] .1–9). 
We then looked in more detail at the effect of 5-FU on the proteo-transcriptome of the three sensitive CRC cell lines (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] , Tables S 2 [this file] and S 3 [this file] ). No statistically significant biological process was observed (Tables S 3 [this file] .1, S 7 [this file] .1). Regarding the HCT-116 cell line, after 5-FU treatment, there was a decrease in proteins involved in (GO:0000018) represented by H1FX, KPNA2, RIF1, HIST1H1C and RPA2 (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] D, in orange) and from (GO:0044391) included RPS29, MRPS28, RPLP1 and RPL37A (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] D, in purple) (Tables S 3 [this file] .4). There was also an increase in proteins involved in (KEGG:04115) [ 75 [rid=CR75] ] with SFN, BAX, SERPINB5, CDKN1A, RRM2B and TP53I3 (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] E, in blue) and from mitochondria (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] E, in yellow) including TYMS, the main enzyme targeted by 5-FU (Table S 3 [this file] .4). At the transcriptomic level, in response to 5-FU, we noted the strong downregulation of transcripts corresponding to proteins involved in the (GO:1903047) (Table S 7 [this file] .4, Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] F, in blue). Finally, for the HT-29 cell line, no statistically significant biological process was observed at the proteomic level (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] G, H, Tables S 3 [this file] .7) but some upregulated proteins from (GO:0030667) can be observed (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] H, in green). 
The major observation is that the induction of chemoresistance to 5-FU largely affects the proteins involved in RNA metabolism (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] A, B; Tables S 3 [this file] .3, S3.6, S3.9). 
At the transcriptome level, there are few transcripts common to the three cell lines after induction of resistance to 5-FU (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] C, D) and therefore no significant common biological processes were identified (Tables S 7 [this file] .3, S7.6, S7.9).
pub_title: Downregulation of KRAB zinc finger proteins in 5-fluorouracil resistant colorectal cancer cells

title: No Title
caption: Additional file 2.
context_description:
Genetic profiles CIN, MSI and CIMP are indicated (+) as well as the CMS and proteomic subtypes [ 2 [rid=CR2] , 57 [rid=CR57] , 58 [rid=CR58] ], the associated mutations [ 59 [rid=CR59] – 63 [rid=CR63] ] and the LD50 and IC previously measured (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] , Fig. S 1 [this file] ). tumor, nodes, metastasis, chromosomal instability, microsatellite instability, CpG island methylator phenotype, consensus molecular subtype, V-Ki-ras2 Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, v-Raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homolog B1, phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate 3-kinase catalytic subunit alpha isoform, cellular tumor antigen p53 
In order to determine the sensitivity to ionizing radiations, these cell lines were exposed to 2, 4, 6 and 8 Gy at D + 1 post-seeding and colony forming units (CFU) were counted after an 8-day or 12-day incubation (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] A; Fig. S 1 [this file] A). These results showed that these CRC cell lines had different intrinsic radio-sensitivities (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] B; Fig. S 1 [this file] B). These cell lines were subjected to increasing doses of 5-FU from 0.1 to 100 μM administered for 24 h at D + 1 post-seeding and CFU were counted after an 8-day or 12-day incubation (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] C; Fig. S 1 [this file] C). These results showed that these CRC cell lines also had different intrinsic chemo-sensitivities (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] D; Fig. S 1 [this file] D).

Transcriptome-(phospho)proteome characterization of brain of a germline model of cytoplasmic-predominant Pten expression with autism-like phenotypes
Transcriptome-(phospho)proteome characterization of brain of a germline model of cytoplasmic-predominant Pten expression with autism-like phenotypes
Transcriptome-(phospho)proteome characterization of brain of a germline model of cytoplasmic-predominant Pten expression with autism-like phenotypes

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
At P14, a total of 3207 unique proteins, with an average of 2345 unique proteins per sample, were identified (Supplementary Data 1: Table 1 [this file] ), whereas at P40, a total of 6635 unique proteins, with an average of 5381 unique proteins per sample, were identified (Supplementary Data 1: Table 2 [this file] ). Principal component analysis (PCA) based on the LFQ/NSAF abundance values for a given protein, at both time points revealed completely separate clusters representing homozygous mutant and wild-type samples (Supplementary Information: Fig. 1A, B [this file] ). At P14, a total of 4080 unique peptides were identified, 97% of which contained phosphorylated residues in the phospho-serine/threonine scan, an average of 2239 unique phosphopeptides per sample (Supplementary Data 1: Table 3 [this file] ). At P40, a total of 8468 unique peptides were identified, 90% of which contained phosphorylated residues, with an average of 5783 unique phosphopeptides per sample (Supplementary Data 1: Table 4 [this file] ). PCA, based on the LFQ abundance values for a given phosphopeptide, at both time points revealed non-overlapping clusters of homozygous mutant and wild-type samples (Supplementary Information: Fig. 1C, D [this file] ). 
Surprisingly, we found no intersection between the P14 and P40 proteome (0% overlap; Fig. 2A [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Information: Table 1 [this file] ). For the phospho-serine/threonine scan, we found 21 molecules of all input molecules shared between time points (13% overlap; Fig.2B [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Information: Table 1 [this file] ). For the phospho-tyrosine scan, we found 25 molecules of all input molecules shared between time points (48% overlap; Fig. 2C [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Information: Table 1 [this file] ). Furthermore, 49 molecules were shared between the P14 and P40 transcriptome datasets (7% overlap; Fig. 2D [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Information: Table 1 [this file] ). 
Surprisingly, we found minimal intersection across these datasets; 8% overlap for P14 datasets and 3% overlap for P40 datasets (Fig. 2E [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Information: Table 1 [this file] ). We proceeded to assess the overlap between the transcriptome and proteome within each time point and found 1 (i.e., 2% overlap) and 30 (i.e., 4% overlap) intersecting molecules at P14 and P40, respectively (Fig. 2F [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Information: Table 1 [this file] ). 
In the proteome, the top implicated canonical pathways broadly involve phosphoinositide metabolism (i.e., 3′-phosphoinositide Biosynthesis) or neurological pathways, such as GABA Receptor Signaling and Glutamate Receptor Signaling (Fig. 3A [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Data 2: Tables S1 [this file] , S2 [this file] ). In the phosphoproteome, the top canonical pathways generally involve neurological and cancer processes or major cellular signaling cascades: Molecular Mechanisms of Cancer, Synaptic Long Term Potentiation, Neuregulin Signaling and cAMP-mediated Signaling (Fig. 3B [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Data 2: Tables 3 [this file] , 4 [this file] ). Overall, a broad qualitative appraisal of these enriched pathways and functional networks consistently implicate PTEN signaling, overgrowth or proliferative processes, and neurological process, especially those related to synaptic transmission or neuroinflammation (Supplemental Data 4 [this file] ). 
We extracted the largest STRING networks from each –omic dataset at each time points and analyzed the network statistics using Cytoscape (Supplementary Information: Fig. 2 [this file] ).
pub_title: Transcriptome-(phospho)proteome characterization of brain of a germline model of cytoplasmic-predominant Pten expression with autism-like phenotypes

title: Custom RPMI medium for culture and ATP analysis.
caption: Composition of custom RPMI medium for culture (upper) and ATP analysis (lower). “-“ means 0 mg/L.
description: Supplementary  file  1.  Custom  RPMI  medium  for  culture  and  ATP  analysis.  Composition  of  custom  RPMI  medium  for  culture  (upper)  and  ATP  analysis  (lower).  “-“  means  0  mg/L.
context_description:
Furthermore, compared to HSCs cultured under the quiescence-maintaining conditions of HSC achieved by hypoxia, abundant fatty acids, and low cytokines as we previously reported ( Kobayashi et al., 2019 [rid=bib45] ), HSCs cultured under cytokine-rich proliferative conditions were more resistant to the inhibition of OXPHOS by oligomycin ( Figure 1—figure supplement 1N [rid=fig1s1] ; Supplementary file 1 [this file] ). 
Cells were resuspended in 0.5–2 mL of PBS +2% FCS+0.1% propidium iodide (PI) (Invitrogen, Cat# P3566) (for C57BL/6 mice) or PBS +0.1% BSA (for GO-ATeam2 mice) and sorted using the FACSAria IIIu Cell Sorter (BD Biosciences) into RPMI1640 (without glucose) (Nacalai Tesque, Cat# 09892–15) containing 4% w/v BSA or GO-ATeam2 basal medium (Ba-M, Supplementary file 1 [this file] with 4% w/v BSA) (custom made by Gmep Inc). 
Surface-marker-stained BMMNCs from GO-ATeam2 mice were dispensed into a basal medium (Ba-M) containing minimal salts, vitamins, and buffers (HEPES and sodium bicarbonate), but no glucose or mitochondrial substrates ( Supplementary file 1 [this file] ), or into a medium containing mitochondrial substrates, pyruvate, lactate, fatty acids, and amino acids, but no glucose (PLFA medium).
pub_title: Context-dependent modification of PFKFB3 in hematopoietic stem cells promotes anaerobic glycolysis and ensures stress hematopoiesis

title: In vitro tracer analysis for 5-FU-treated HSCs.
caption: Results of tracer analysis using U- 13 C 6 -glucose with HSCs from mice treated with PBS or 5-FU. Each section contains raw data from the glycolytic system, TCA cycle, and  P ~NAS from top to bottom. Data from three individual experiments are described for each. All values represent average metabolite levels in single HSCs obtained by dividing the metabolite levels detected in HSCs (compared to internal standards) by the number of HSCs used in the analysis.
description: Supplementary  file  2.  In  vitro  tracer  analysis  for  5-FU-treated  HSCs. context_description: Therefore, we examined the metabolic flux of glucose by performing in vitro IC-MS tracer analysis with uniformly carbon-labeled (U- C ) glucose to determine the pathways driving changes in ATP in 5-FU-treated HSCs ( Figure 1A [rid=fig1] ; Supplementary file 2 [this file] ).

title: In vitro tracer analysis for oligomycin-treated HSCs.

caption: Metabolic flux values of each enzyme obtained from 100 trials of  13 C quantitative metabolic flux analysis for PBS-treated (left), 5-FU-treated (middle), and OXPHOS-inhibited HSCs (right).
description: Supplementary  file  4.  13  C  quantitative  metabolic  flux  analysis.  Metabolic  flux  values  of  each  enzyme  obtained  from  100  trials  of  13  C  quantitative  metabolic  flux  analysis  for  PBS-treated  (left),  5-FU-treated  (middle),  and  OXPHOS-inhibited  HSCs  (right).
context_description:
Unlike PBS-treated HSCs, those treated with 5-FU or oligomycin exhibited preferential glycolytic activation rather than TCA- or PPP-based metabolic strategies; the first half of the glycolytic system appeared to be the site of metabolic activation ( Figure 3A–J [rid=fig3] ; Figure 3—figure supplement 1D–U [rid=fig3s1] , Supplementary file 4 [this file] ). 
Data is obtained from 100 simulations in OpenMebius, and flux data for each enzyme is displayed ( Supplementary file 4 [this file] ). ( ) Ratio of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate (F1,6BP) to fructose-6-phosphate (F6P) calculated from tracer experiments shown in Figure 1B [rid=fig1] and Figure 2B [rid=fig2] .

title: In vivo tracer analysis for 5-FU treated mice.
caption: Results of tracer analysis during continuous in vivo administration of U- 13 C 6 -glucose to mice treated with 5-FU or PBS. A sheet is prepared for each metabolite and each contains two tables. The A.U. table (left) shows the metabolite levels detected in the four biological replicates in the 5-FU and PBS groups, obtained by dividing the metabolite levels detected in HSCs (compared to internal standards) by the number of HSCs used in the analysis. The ratio table (right) shows the calculated percentage of labeled metabolites among detected metabolites, where 12 C indicates unlabeled metabolites and 13Cn indicates n-carbon labeled metabolites by U- 13 C 6 -glucose.
description: Supplementary  file  5.  In  vivo  tracer  analysis  for  5-FU  treated  mice.  Results  of  tracer  analysis  during  continuous  in  vivo  administration  of  U-  13  C  6  -glucose  to  mice  treated  with  5-FU  or  PBS.  A  sheet  is  prepared  for  each  metabolite  and  each  contains  two  tables.  The  A.U.  table  (left)  shows  the  metabolite  levels  detected  in  the  four  biological  replicates  in  the  5-FU  and  PBS  groups,  obtained  by  dividing  the  metabolite  levels  detected  in  HSCs  (compared  to  internal  standards)  by  the  number  of  HSCs  used  in  the  analysis.  The  ratio  table  (right)  shows  the  calculated  percentage  of  labeled  metabolites  among  detected  metabolites,  where  12  C  indicates  unlabeled  metabolites  and  13Cn  indicates  n-carbon  labeled  metabolites  by  U-  13  C  6  -glucose.
context_description: In HSCs from 5-FU-treated mice, we observed increased labeling of glycolytic metabolites such as dihydroxyacetone phosphate, glycerol-3-phosphate, and phosphoenolpyruvate, as well as NAS metabolites such as inosine monophosphate and ATP, and those derived from TCA cycle such as aspartic acid and glutamate, compared to HSCs from PBS-treated mice ( Figure 3—figure supplement 2B–I [rid=fig3s2] , Supplementary file 5 [this file] ).
pub_title: Context-dependent modification of PFKFB3 in hematopoietic stem cells promotes anaerobic glycolysis and ensures stress hematopoiesis

title: No Title
caption: Supporting information
context_description:
The plasmid pWH1266 (Fig. S1 [this file] , 8.89 kb, ATCC 77092) was selected as the free plasmid DNA. 
The and genes were detected with both short and long amplicon PCR (Bio-Rad C1000 Touch, USA) (the primers are listed in Supporting Information Table S1 [this file] ). 
The temperature profile included one cycle at 95 °C for 2 min, then 40 cycles of the steps that included 95 °C for 10 s, an annealing temperature (Table S1 [this file] ) for 20 s, and finally 72 °C for either 60 s (long amplicons) or 20 s (short amplicons). 
In addition, an extremely high concentration (30 mg/L) was also applied in this study to test the high chlorine resistance of in terms of MIC analyses (Table S2 [this file] ). The frequency of eARGs transformation was ~1.5 × 10 after 6 h (Fig. S2 [this file] ), and was maximized when the plasmid concentration was greater than 0.8 ng/μL (Fig. S3 [this file] ). 
Both chloramine and free chlorine could significantly increase the number of transformants and the transformation frequency of plasmid-encoded eARGs in System 1 (Fig. 2a, b [rid=Fig2] , and Fig. S4 [this file] ). For instance, concentrations of chlorine residuals decreased to 2.7 or 1.4 mg/L after 6 h of treatment when initial levels of 30 mg/L of chloramine or free chlorine were applied respectively (Fig. S5 [this file] ). 
All the transformants exhibited increased resistance against the two antibiotics (Table S2 [this file] ), indicating the expression of the Amp and Tet resistance genes after uptake of the pWH1266 plasmid. In contrast, the wild-type was susceptible to antibiotics Amp and Tet (Table S2 [this file] ). 
However, this overestimation can be ruled out, since the total number of recipients did not increase during the 6-h period (Fig. S4 [this file] and Table S3 [this file] ), this indicating that the increased frequency was facilitated by transformation, rather than VGT. 
As expected, after exposure to chloramine or free chlorine the bacterial ROS levels decreased significantly in comparison with those detected under aerobic conditions (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] , Fig. S6 [this file] , = 4.1 × 10 –1.5 × 10 ) to the levels of the non-disinfectant controls. 
Under aerobic conditions, both chloramine and free chlorine (30 mg/L) could generate the ClO• radical with strong intensity (Fig. S7 [this file] ). 
We further employed transcriptional analysis to provide molecular evidence that the exposure to the chlorine-based disinfectants at 10 mg/L triggered oxidative stress in the recipient strains (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] , Table S4 [this file] ). Furthermore, the expression of core genes related to DNA integration and repair showed increased transcript levels under the exposure of chloramine or free chlorine (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] , Table S5 [this file] ). 
In particular, SodA and Ahp family proteins (AhpC and AphF) are antioxidant enzymes that play a role in the protection from ROS attack [ 39 [rid=CR39] ], were upregulated (Table S6 [this file] ). 
Damage of the cell membrane caused by the disinfectants was further assessed by analysis of protein and gene expression in the recipient (Tables S7 [this file] , S8 [this file] ). 
The transcription levels of stress-related genes ( ) and competence-related genes ( ) were upregulated under the exposure of 10 mg/L disinfectants (Table S9 [this file] ). In addition, when exposing to chloramine or free chlorine under anaerobic conditions, no significant variations of live/dead cell percentages were seen compared with the non-disinfectant control (Fig. S8 [this file] ). 
Although the intracellular ROS generation dramatically decreased after removing the remaining disinfectants (Fig. S9 [this file] ), the increased cell membrane permeabilization remained. 
For example, the highest fold change was only 2.8-fold under anaerobic conditions (as shown in Fig. S10 [this file] ), while it could reach 40-fold aerobically (Fig. 4a, b [rid=Fig4] ). However, it should also be noted that compared with the non-disinfectant control, a significant enhancement of membrane permeability was shown under the exposure of free chlorine anaerobically (Fig. S10 [this file] ).
pub_title: Chlorine disinfection facilitates natural transformation through ROS-mediated oxidative stress

title: No Title
caption: Additional file 1.
context_description:
All selected cell lines met our set criteria of having pediatric origins, similar to the patient samples we studies (See Supplementary Methods [this file] ). 
Additional information on patient assessment and sample collection is detailed in Supplementary Methods [this file] . 
See Supplementary Methods [this file] for more description of sample cohort. 
See Supplementary Methods [this file] for more description of the criteria for determining overt leukemia, and selection of PDX for analysis. 
Amplicon-based sequencing and variant determination was performed as described elsewhere [ 24 [rid=CR24] ], and is detailed in Supplementary Methods [this file] . 
Cell lines, patient and PDX samples were prepared for mass spectrometry-based analysis as detailed in Supplementary Methods [this file] . 
The methods for high pH fractionation and LC-MSMS are detailed in Supplementary Data [this file] . 
DIA data were analyzed with Spectronaut Pulsar X (version 12.0.20491.3.15243, Jocelyn from Biognosys, Schlieren, Switzerland), as detailed in Supplementary Methods [this file] . All PDX samples had less than 5% of murine proteins detected (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] A). 
Spectronaut output for 6397 identified proteins and related sample descriptions are provided in Additional files 1 [this file2] and 2 [this file3] . A similar data for the N terminome experiment (6352 modified sequences) is in Additional files 3 [this file4] and 4 [this file5] . Proteins, peptides, and N termini (acetylated and dimethylated sequences only), identified per sample in unfiltered Spectronaut output files are depicted in Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] B, C, and D respectively. Data for each experiment was further processed for additional statistical analysis as described in Supplementary Methods [this file] . 
Precursor information from DIA analysis on phophopeptides were exported from Spectronaut and processed with the Peptide Collapse PlugIn (version v1.4.1) [ 25 [rid=CR25] ] in Perseus (version 1.6.2.2) [ 26 [rid=CR26] ] using settings described in Supplementary Methods [this file] . The number of phosphorylated sequences identified in each sample based on unfiltered Spectronaut output file is shown in Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] E. Following analysis with Peptide Collapse PlugIn, the resulting quantified data for 3531 phosphosites (Additional files 5 [this file6] and 6 [this file7] ) were used for further analysis. 
Quantified datasets were processed as explained in Supplementary Methods [this file] , and used for statistical analysis. 
Equivalence tests were performed as detailed in Supplementary Methods [this file] . 
Additional methods to characterize N-terminal peptides and to perform biological process and pathway enrichment are described in Supplementary Methods [this file] . 
Protein-level and N termini average CV were below 6 and 21% respectively (Supplementary Fig. S 1 [this file] F and G). 
An overlap of proteins represented in non-leukemic and diseased categories (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] A and B) revealed a large protein subset common to patients and PDX was not detected in non-leukemic samples. 
The average Spearman’s correlation scores for protein abundance in T-ALL patient and corresponding xenograft mice was 0.83 (SD=0.06) (Supplementary Fig. S 3 [this file] A), with lower correlations (average=0.67, SD=0.06) observed between primary leukemias with lower disease burden and their matched PDXs. B-cell leukemia samples had average correlation score of 0.88 (SD=0.02) (Supplementary Fig. S 3 [this file] B). Proteins involved in known signaling pathways affected in pediatric leukemia also correlated strongly between primary and PDX leukemias (Supplementary Fig. S 3 [this file] A and B). 
Although matched patient and PDX did not co-cluster, a positive correlation (B-ALL average=0.62, SD=0.06; T-ALL average=0.60, SD=0.03) was retained between individual patients and their corresponding xenografts (Supplementary Fig. S 4 [this file] ). S 4 [this file] B and D). 
We first compared biological processes and pathways enriched in proteins that were uniquely identified in patients or in PDXs (Supplementary Fig. S 6 [this file] A and B). S 6 [this file] C and S 7 [this file] A). In PDXs, processes linked to cell division and regulation of cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase activity were enhanced (Supplementary Fig. S 7 [this file] B). 
Similar to PDXs, B- and T-ALL cell lines lacked or minimally expressed proteins including serpins and S100 proteins, that regulate immune and inflammatory response systems in patients (Supplementary Fig. S 8 [this file] A). Leukemia in 380 CDX localized to the liver (93% human cells) and not spleen (16% human cells), and CDX liver best reflected the proteome of B-ALL 380 in comparison to xenograft spleen (Supplementary Fig. S 8 [this file] B). When compared with 380 cell lines, 380 CDX spleen and liver had higher amounts of MCM2 proliferation marker, while PCNA showed an increased but not significant trend (Supplementary Fig. S 8 [this file] C). 
Additionally, RB1 protein levels were similar in the multiple xenograft samples from patients B-02, B-06, and B-07, which were not analyzed by targeted NGS (Supplementary Fig. S 9 [this file] A). 
This was also the case for patients with more than one expanded xenograft mice (Supplementary Fig. S 9 [this file] B). The absolute fold change for quantified proteins between paired patients and PDX is shown in Supplementary Fig. S 10 [this file] A. We identified 389 and quantified 302 (Supplementary Table S 7 [rid=MOESM8] ), with proteins CLUH and RNF138 showing the strongest abundance changes between patient and PDX. (Supplementary Fig. S 10 [this file] B). The total number of and targets showing protein abundance change greater than 2-fold in each patient/PDX pair is depicted in Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] C. 
We found that total protein (r =0.94) and phosphopeptide (r =0.90) intensities correlated better ( -value< 0.0001) between the patient and xenograft groups while N termini abundance correlated moderately (r =0.73, p-value< 0.0001) (Supplementary Fig. S 11 [this file] A – F). The unique cleavage pattern of MCM5 in ALL patients and corresponding PDXs further substantiated the existence of proteolytic fingerprints that are indistinguishable at the protein level (Supplementary Fig. S 11 [this file] G). 
Neo N termini profiles showed a loss in caspase 1 (CASP1) proteolytic activities in blast cells after transplantation, and a gain in elastase (ELNE) activities in xenografts (Supplementary Fig. S 11 [this file] H and Supplementary Table S 8 [rid=MOESM9] ). 
In our smaller cohort of two T-ALL patients (blast count> 80%) and corresponding PDXs, 194 neo N termini were dysregulated (189 upregulated, and 9 downregulated) between patients and PDXs (Supplementary Table S 10 [this file1] , Supplementary Figs. S 12 [this file] A and B). Enrichment analysis showed similar processes and complexes associated with protein processing and maturation (Supplementary Fig. S 12 [this file] C), comparable sequence motifs and a similar protease map (Supplementary Fig. S 12 [this file] D-F), as was detected for B-ALL patients. 
A similar protease network was associated with neo N termini alterations in B-ALL (Supplementary Fig. S 13 [this file] A). 
While the majority of these proteins were stable between PDX and patients, five proteins critical for cytokine signalling were markedly deficient or missing in B- and T- cell xenograft leukemias, as well as in 380 cell line-derived xenograft (Supplementary Fig. S 13 [this file] ).
pub_title: PDX models reflect the proteome landscape of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia but divert in select pathways
