Depletion of abundant plasma proteins for extracellular vesicle proteome characterization: benefits and pitfalls
Depletion of abundant plasma proteins for extracellular vesicle proteome characterization: benefits and pitfalls

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary file1 (PDF 440 KB)
context_description:
We examined the top 20 most abundant proteins in both depleted and non-depleted plasma samples (see Electronic Supplementary Material (EMS) 1, Fig. S1 [this file] ). 
For both EV samples, the elution profile showed peaks in particle concentrations in fractions 6–8, suggesting that these fractions contained the EVs (EMS1, Fig. S2 [this file] ). 
Afterwards, protein and particle concentration of pooled SEC fractions (F1–F5, F6–F8, and two-by-two for F9 to F15) were analyzed to determine which fractions had the highest number of particles and the least amount of protein (EMS1, Fig. S3 [this file] ). 
In addition, both EV samples statistically contained an increased number of identified proteins in comparison to plasma samples, in which 224 proteins were identified (EMS1, Fig. S4 [this file] ). 
To observe how depletion impacted the highly abundant plasma proteins in EVs, we looked at the top 20 quantified proteins in N and D EVs (EMS1, Fig. S5 [this file] ). 
First, we compared the proteins identified in N and D EVs to EV-associated proteins and non-EV co-isolated components, reported in the Minimal Information for Studies of EVs (MISEV2018) [ 21 [rid=CR21] ] (EMS1, Fig. S6 [this file] ).

context_description:
Following raw data processing, a total of 3,581 transcripts, 1,340 proteins, 99 lipids, and 37 extracellular metabolites were identified and quantified ( Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] – 4 [this file] ). 
We first aimed at identifying the feature variations that were the most associated with time using Longitudinal Gaussian Processes (LGPR; Timonen et al., 2021 [rid=ref71] ; Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] – 4 [this file] ). 
Next, clusters with similar profiles were merged and regrouped in larger clusters named A–D for both transcriptomic and proteomic data ( Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] , 2 [this file] ). 
Moreover, between 12 h and 18 h 45 min, 1,790 genes (177 up- and 309 down-regulated, |log FC| > 1) and 399 proteins (17 up-, including five ON proteins, and 17 down-regulated, including eight OFF proteins, |log FC | > 1) are differentially expressed (adj -value < 0.05; Supplementary Tables 5 [this file] , 6 [this file] ). 
To functionally characterize clusters, pathway enrichment analyses ( Huang et al., 2009 [rid=ref28] ) were next performed with the groups of transcripts/proteins that constitute each cluster using the KEGG and GO databases ( Supplementary Tables 7 [this file] – 10 [this file] ). 
The expression of these genes remained stable between 4 and 12 h, increased from 12 h to 18 h 45 min, and then decreased from 18 h 45 min to 26 h of culture ( Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes, 2022 [rid=ref36] ; Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
This is consistent with the sudden decrease of the gene (cluster A) expression (Log FC = −4.7) and of the PutA protein (cluster A) synthesis (Log FC = −1) between 12 and 22 h ( Supplementary Tables 5 [this file] , 6 [this file] ). 
Similarly, while the expression of , encoding a putative glutamate transporter ( Keidel et al., 2018 [rid=ref34] ) decreased between 12 h and 18 h 45 min (Log2FC = −1.8), a marked expression increase of this gene was also observed between 18 h 45 min and 22 h (Log2FC = +2.0), ( Supplementary Tables 5 [this file] , 6 [this file] ). 
In the present study, the expression of most TCA cycle genes and the synthesis of corresponding proteins increased at 18 h 45 min of culture (cluster D; Figure 6B [rid=fig6] ; Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] , 2 [this file] ). 
Transcriptomic and proteomic analyses were used to monitor transcripts and proteins involved in aP vaccine antigen production throughout culture ( Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] , 2 [this file] , 5 [this file] , 6 [this file] ). 
For this purpose, a list of 207 (log FC < −2) (log FC > 2; Supplementary Tables 11 [this file] , 12 [this file] ) was selected from the literature ( Moon et al., 2017 [rid=ref45] ; Coutte et al., 2020 [rid=ref10] ). 
In our study, to discover new virulence regulation mechanisms in . , the longitudinal gene expression profiles of these 20 putative regulators were compared to the profile of 16 recently described without BvgA-binding sites ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ; Coutte et al., 2020 [rid=ref10] ). 
A differential gene expression analysis, between 4 and 8 h of culture, revealed 19 downregulated (log FC < −1, -value < 0.05) and 62 upregulated genes (log FC > 1, -value < 0.05; Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, this starvation was concomitant with the starvation of ascorbic acid in the extracellular medium ( Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ; Supplementary Figure 5 [rid=SM5] ).

context_description:
Homozygous and heterozygous loss of were detected in 1.5% and 54.5% of The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) breast cancer cases, respectively ( Figure S1A [this file] ). There was a significant association between copy number and breast cancer subtypes (Kruskal-Wallis test; p = 0.007), with luminal tumors displaying a higher proportion of loss than the other subtypes ( Figure S1B [this file] ). Indeed, copy numbers were significantly lower in luminal tumors or ERα-positive tumors than tumors of the other subtypes or ERα-negative tumors ( Figure S1C [this file] ). The copy number of correlates with its mRNA levels (r = 0.69, p < 0.0001; Figure S1D [this file] ), suggesting a possible causal relationship. 
Intriguingly, low mRNA levels were associated with poor survival in patients with ERα-positive breast cancer in the KM plotter dataset (patients divided at lower tertile: hazard ratio [HR] = 1.27, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.04–1.54, p = 0.017; not significant for patients divided at median or quartile) and in METABRIC dataset (divided at median: HR = 1.15, 95% CI = 1.01–1.32, p = 0.037; or lower tertile: HR = 1.16, 95% CI = 1.01–1.35, p = 0.036; Figures 1B [rid=F1] and S2A [this file] ; Table S1 [this file] ). No association was observed in patients who were ERα-negative or that were stratified based on the status of progesterone receptor or HER2 in both datasets ( Figures 1B [rid=F1] and S2A [this file] ; Table S1 [this file] ). When patients in these two datasets were stratified into the intrinsic molecular subtypes, a significant association between low mRNA levels and poor survival was observed in patients with luminal B (KM plotter samples divided at lower tertile: HR = 1.47, 95% CI = 1.08–2.00, p = 0.016; METABRIC samples divided at median: HR = 1.48, 95% CI = 1.20–1.88, p = 0.0005; Figures S2B [this file] and S2C [this file] ), suggesting that the shorter survival in patients who were ERα-positive might be mainly attributed to the luminal B subpopulation. Further, analysis of TCGA breast cancer data identified that gene copy loss was associated with a trend (although not statistically significant) toward shorter progression-free survival in patients with luminal A or luminal B ( Figure S2D [this file] ) and a significantly shorter survival in patients with luminal B in METABRIC cohort (HR = 1.27, 95% CI = 1.01–1.60, p = 0.043; Figure S2E [this file] ). No trend was noted in patients of basal, HER2-enriched, or normal-like subtype ( Figures S2D [this file] and S2E [this file] ). 
The efficiency of the siRNA was presented in Figures S3A [this file] – S3C [this file] . Depletion of enhanced viability consistently in 5 ERα-positive breast cancer cell lines, MCF7, MDA-MB-361, MDA-MB-175, BT474, and T47D ( Figures 1C [rid=F1] and S3D [this file] ). In addition, cell migration and invasion capabilities were enhanced upon loss in MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 ( Figure 1D [rid=F1] ) but not in HER2-enriched or basal cells ( Figures 1D [rid=F1] and S3E [this file] ). 
The functional impacts of loss were further examined in MCF7 cells with stable knockdown ( Figure S4A [this file] ). Consistently, increases in viability, long-term clonogenic growth, migration, and invasion could be observed in these cells compared with empty-vector-expressing or parental cells ( Figures S4B [this file] – S4D [this file] ). The weight and volume of the depleted tumors were both higher than that of the vector tumors ( Figures 1E [rid=F1] and S4E [this file] ). 
Binding between AKTIP and AKT was not detected by immunoprecipitation experiments, in which we included a positive control HOOK1, which has been reported to bind AKTIP ( Figure S5A [this file] ). Moreover, the lack of effect of AKTIP on AKT signaling was observed in HER2-overexpressing SKBR3 cells ( Figure S5B [this file] ). 
Real-time PCR revealed no significant difference in ESR1 mRNA levels upon knockdown in MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 cells ( Figure S5C [this file] ), demonstrating that transcriptional regulation unlikely contributes to the increased ERα protein level. Increased protein stability of ERα was further supported by a decrease in ERα poly-ubiquitination after knockdown in MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 cells ( Figures 3B [rid=F3] and S5D [this file] ). 
Depletion of cullin-associated and neddylation-dissociated protein 1 (CAND1), which was validated to bind AKTIP ( Figure S5E [this file] ), led to a reduction of ERα protein levels in -depleted cells ( Figure 3D [rid=F3] ). Our data showed that the Hook proteins were not involved in ERα stabilization by AKTIP ( Figure S5F [this file] ). Consistently, siRNA reduced ERα protein levels in MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 cells ( Figures 3E [rid=F3] and S5G [this file] ), with an increase in ERα ubiquitination ( Figure 3F [rid=F3] ). siRNA of and , which have been previously shown to regulate ERα, had no significant effect on loss-induced ERα levels ( Figure S5H [this file] ). 
Binding between ERα and CAND1 could not be detected, whereas binding between ERα and a known protein binding partner HSP70 was observed in the same experiment ( Figure S5I [this file] ). 
Remarkably, 89% of the 91 DEGs identified in MCF7 were defined as estrogen-responsive genes based on the transcriptomic data in the Signaling Pathways Project ( Figure 4E [rid=F4] ; Table S2 [this file] ). We validated 12 DEGs with high or low fold change and documented functional roles in cancers by real-time PCR ( Figure S6A [this file] ). Notably, the expression levels of classical ERα targets ( , , ) were increased in MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 cells but not in SKBR3 after knockdown ( Figures 4G [rid=F4] and S6A [this file] ). The mRNA levels of in MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 cells were not altered upon β-estradiol stimulation, suggesting that is not a transcriptional target of ERα and that there is no feedback from ERα to AKTIP ( Figure S6B [this file] ). 
Similarly, loss of increased the protein levels of SGK3 and its phosphorylation at T320 in both MCF7 and MDA-MB-361 cells ( Figure 4I [rid=F4] ), whereas inhibition of ERα by fulvestrant or tamoxifen (4-OH-Tam) abrogated the increases ( Figure S6C [this file] ). We next examined whether the upregulation of SGK3 plays a role in sustaining ERα activation. siRNA-mediated knockdown of did not alter the extent of ERα upregulation upon loss ( Figure S6D [this file] ). 
We investigated the drug responses of -depleted cells toward ERα or JAK2/STAT3 inhibition. -depleted MCF7 or MDA-MB-361 cells were more resistant to fulvestrant or 4-OH-Tam compared with vector control cells ( Figures 6A [rid=F6] and S7A [this file] ). Interestingly, among the group of patients with ERα-positive breast cancer who received adjuvant tamoxifen therapy, patients with low mRNA levels had a higher risk of developing recurrence, further supporting that -low tumors may be endocrine resistant ( Figure 6B [rid=F6] ). -depleted MCF7 or MDA-MB-361 cells also displayed resistance toward JAK2 inhibition when cells were treated with AZD1480 alone ( Figures 6C [rid=F6] and S7A [this file] ). 
Remarkably, the addition of a fixed concentration of JAK2 inhibitor AZD1480 increased the sensitivity of -depleted MCF7 or MDA-MB-361 cells to fulvestrant or 4-OH-Tam ( Figures 6D [rid=F6] and S7B [this file] ), demonstrating that JAK2/STAT3 inhibition can resensitize -depleted cells to ERα inhibition. AZD1480 had no effect on the dose-response curve of fulvestrant or 4-OH-Tam in vector control or mock-transfected cells ( Figures 6D [rid=F6] and S7B [this file] ). Similar observations were obtained when cells were treated with STAT3 inhibitor C188–9 ( Figures 6E [rid=F6] and S7C [this file] ). 
The siRNA sequences are listed in Table S3 [this file] .

Sequences of the primers used are shown in Table S5 [this file] .

All strains utilized in this study are detailed in the appendix in Supplementary Table S1 [this file] . Detailed information on bacterial strains and their construction is listed in Appendix Supplementary Table S2 [this file] . 
Plasmids and DNA oligonucleotides are listed in Appendix Supplementary Table S2 [this file] and S3 [this file] , respectively. 
Fold enrichment in the -tagged samples compared to untagged control samples was calculated using the CLC ‘Differential Expression for RNA-Seq’ tool ( Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
The oligonucleotides used for probing are listed in Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . The oligonucleotides used for qRT-PCR are listed in Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . 
Oligos used for depletion are indicated in Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . 
Primers used are listed in Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . synthesized mRNA was mixed with or without the sRNA in a 10 μl reaction volume following the manufacturer’s instructions. 
The Minora algorithm of PD2.2 was applied for relative protein abundance quantification ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). 
Analogous to the genomes of and , the gene of is located between the (encoding a protease) and (encoding a methionine-(R)-sulfoxide reductase) genes and its transcription is driven by single promoter located 50 bps upstream of the translation start site ( Supplementary Figure S1A [this file] ; ( 62 [rid=B62] )). We detected nearly constant ProQ production under all tested conditions with a mild increase in protein expression under stationary phase growth conditions ( Supplementary Figure S1B [this file] ) and similar results were obtained when we probed mRNA levels using qRT-PCR ( Supplementary Figure S1C [this file] ). We found that growth of this mutant was comparable to wild-type cells and plasmid-borne overexpression of did not affect growth either ( Supplementary Figure S1D [this file] ). 
We discovered 496 mRNA and 60 sRNA ligands at low cell density (OD of 0.2) and 463 mRNA and 75 sRNA ligands at high cell density (OD of 2.0) ( Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). In line with a previous report ( 23 [rid=B23] ), we discovered that 3′-UTRs of mRNAs were preferentially bound by ProQ ( Supplementary Figure S1E [this file] ). We further classified the sRNAs based on their genomic location, determining whether they were transcribed from intergenic regions (IGRs) or encoded within mRNA 5′-UTRs or 3′-UTRs ( Supplementary Figure S1F [this file] ). Analogous to ProQ, mutation or overexpression of did not affect growth of in rich media ( Supplementary Figure S1G [this file] ). 
The gene is located in the 3′-UTR of (encoding a major flagellin) in (Figure 2A [rid=F2] and Supplementary Figure S2A [this file] ) and was reported to accumulate as a ∼150 nt transcript ( 14 [rid=B14] ). Indeed, we discovered that Δ cells displayed reduced FlaX stability, whereas elevated ProQ levels increased its stability (Figure 2C [rid=F2] and Supplementary Figure S2B [this file] ). 
One representative gel is shown in Supplementary Figure S2B [this file] . 
Transcription of and is driven by a single promoter located upstream of the gene (Figure 2A [rid=F2] and ( 62 [rid=B62] )) and mutation of this promoter strongly reduced FlaX expression ( Supplementary Figure S2C [this file] ). In accordance, with these results we discovered that mutation of the RNase E recognition motif ( 49 [rid=B49] , 65 [rid=B65] ) at the 5′ end of inhibited accumulation of the full-length FlaX transcript ( Supplementary Figure S2D [this file] ). 
Again, we performed these experiments at low and high cell density (OD of 0.2 and 2.0, respectively), which revealed dozens of differentially expressed genes at both cell densities in Δ and FlaX overexpressing cells (Figure 3D [rid=F3] and Supplementary Figure S3A [this file] ). Indeed, we discovered that FlaX overexpression reduced the stability of the mRNA, when compared to a control sample ( Supplementary Figure S3B [this file] ). 
Analogous to the RIP-Seq experiments outlined above, we performed these analyses at low and high cell densities (OD of 0.2 and 2.0) allowing us to recover 299 484 and 117 561 ProQ-associated interactions, respectively (Figure 4A [rid=F4] and B [rid=F4] and Supplementary Figure S4A [this file] ). We quantified the respective interactions according to their genomic origin, i.e. mRNAs or sRNAs, which revealed that the majority (89%) of ProQ-associated interactions involved mRNAs, whereas only 3% of all interactions included sRNAs (8% of the interactions involved IGRs, Supplementary Figure S4B [this file] ). 
Quantification of data from two biological replicates is provided in Supplementary Figure S4C [this file] . 
Five of the nine reporters showed significant regulation by FlaX: , , and were repressed, whereas was induced (Figure 4D [rid=F4] and Supplementary Figure S4D–G [this file] ). Indeed, we discovered that FlaB levels were strongly increased under all growth conditions in the mutant and that protein abundance was largely restored when FlaX was expressed from a plasmid (Figure 4E [rid=F4] and Supplementary Figure S4C [this file] ). 
We also performed the reverse experiments using radio-labeled FlaX and increasing concentrations of synthesized 5′-UTR to determine the base-sequences in the sRNA ( Supplementary Figure S5A [this file] ). Of note, all base-pairing sites in ( Supplementary Figure S5B [this file] ) and FlaX ( Supplementary Figure S2A [this file] ) are highly conserved and analysis of the RIL-seq dataset using the ChimericFragments algorithm ( 48 [rid=B48] ) predicted RNA duplex formation of FlaX with three separate binding sites in the 5′-UTR, which we named BS1-3 (Figure 5C [rid=F5] – E [rid=F5] ). Importantly, expression of FlaX variants carrying compensatory mutations for each of the sites restored regulation (Figure 5F [rid=F5] and Supplementary Figure S5C [this file] ). 
In line with our previous data (Figure 5F [rid=F5] – H [rid=F5] ), we found that all five mutated variants were still repressed by FlaX, albeit to different levels ( Supplementary Figure S6A [this file] ). 
Western blot analysis showed that FlaB:GFP protein was readily detectable after 10 min of incubation and gradually increased with time (Figure 6C [rid=F6] and Supplementary Figure S6B [this file] and C [this file] ). Whereas none of the mutations impaired basal FlaB::GFP synthesis ( Supplementary Figure S6C [this file] ), we found that mutations 2 and 3 both reduced the effect of FlaX on translation, whereas mutation of base-pairing site 1 had no significant impact (Figure 6C [rid=F6] ). 
Consistent with the experiments using the reporter (Figure 5F [rid=F5] – H [rid=F5] ) and the translation assays (Figure 6C [rid=F6] and D [rid=F6] ), we discovered that mutation of binding site 2 in ( Supplementary Figure S6D [this file] ) or FlaX ( Supplementary Figure S6E [this file] ) had the strongest impact on toeprint intensity, followed by binding site 3 and binding site 1. 
As expected, addition of L-arabinose to Δ or Δ / cells carrying a control plasmid did not affect flaggelin mRNA expression (Figure 7A [rid=F7] and B [rid=F7] and Supplementary Figure S7A–D [this file] ). Plasmid-borne production of FlrA in Δ cells resulted in rapid activation of mRNA reaching maximal expression already 15 min post induction (Figure 7A [rid=F7] ) and a similar pattern was observed for FlaX ( Supplementary Figure S7A [this file] ). In comparison, expression of was delayed displaying highest levels 30 min ( , ) or 60 min after ( , ) after addition of the inducer (Figure 7B [rid=F7] and Supplementary Figure S7B–D [this file] ). 
Indeed, using scanning electron microscopy, we discovered that Δ mutants display elevated numbers of unflagellated cells, when compared to isogenic wild-type cells ( Supplementary Figure S7E [this file] ). 
The gene is conserved in many ( Supplementary Figure S2A [this file] ), suggesting that similar regulatory mechanisms for flagella synthesis could be relevant here as well. The homolog of FlaB in and is FlaA and indeed the FlaX binding sites in the 5′-UTRs of their corresponding mRNAs are highly conserved ( Supplementary Figure S5B [this file] ). 
Our list of ProQ-associated sRNAs contains a large fraction of 3′-UTR-derived sRNAs (Figure 1D [rid=F1] and Supplementary Figure S1E [this file] ), including Vcr077 and Vcr078 (Figure 1C [rid=F1] ), which are located in the 3′-UTRs of the and flagellin genes, respectively. Both sRNAs share sequence similarity with FlaX ( Supplementary Figure S7F [this file] ) and are produced by ribonucleolytic cleavage ( 62 [rid=B62] ). Indeed, we discovered that Vcr077 and Vcr078 both inhibited FlaE::GFP expression and Vcr077 also inhibited FlaA::GFP, whereas Vcr078 negatively affected FlaC::GFP levels ( Supplementary Figure S7G [this file] ). 
In accordance, we found that repression of FlaB::GFP by FlaX in a mutant was only mildly reduced (∼2.5-fold) and a similar effect was detected for cells lacking the genes encoding both major RNA chaperones ProQ and Hfq ( Supplementary Figure S7H [this file] ). Second, when comparing the fraction of recovered RNA duplexes according to their genomic origin, i.e., mRNAs and sRNAs, in our ProQ (Figure 4A [rid=F4] and B [rid=F4] ) and Hfq ( 46 [rid=B46] ) RIL-Seq datasets, we discovered that the vast majority (91%) of ProQ-associated interactions involved base-pairing between two mRNAs, whereas only 9% of all interactions included sRNAs ( Supplementary Figure S7I [this file] ).

Rhein, a novel Histone Deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor with antifibrotic potency in human myocardial fibrosis
Rhein, a novel Histone Deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor with antifibrotic potency in human myocardial fibrosis

title: No Title
caption: Dataset 2.
context_description:
To study the potential effect of Rhein on phenotype and secretome modulation, cells were exposed for 4d to normoxic or hypoxic conditions (Fig. 1A [rid=Fig1] ) in the absence or presence of a non-toxic concentration of 35 µM Rhein (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). Furthermore, Rhein treatment showed an overall reduction in the expression of exemplary pro-fibrotic response targets (Supplementary Fig. 2A [this file] ; ) and increased expression pointing towards a higher MMP:TIMP ratio. 
The expression status of known positive and negative regulators of the G2/M phase derived from the overall gene expression analyses pointed towards an impact of cell cycle progression in Rhein-mediated phenotype modulation (Supplementary Fig. 2B [this file] ). 
While was induced and differentially regulated on transcriptional level following Rhein treatment (Supplementary Fig. 2A [this file] ), intriguingly, TP53 was not differentially regulated, indicating a posttranslational mechanism leading to increased p53 abundance. In accordance, nodal cell cycle stages of G1/S and G2/M transition were differentially regulated in the comparisons (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). Surprisingly, HDAC expression levels derived from holistic gene expression analyses throughout all members of the HDAC family was unchanged (Supplementary Fig. 2C [this file] ). Rhein then is a more efficient HDAC enzymatic activity inhibitor than the commonly used inhibitors in a direct mode that even additive specifically in HDAC class I (Supplement Fig. 4 [this file] ), or SIRT (HDAC class III) (Supplement Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
Dose-response analyses revealed a concentration-dependent effect of Rhein on selected cardiac fibrosis-relevant proteins and mRNAs (Supplementary Fig. 6A–C [this file] ). Consistent with the dose-dependent reduction of TGFβ1-promoted induction of (Supplementary Fig. 6D [this file] ) Rhein also decreased the protein abundance of αSMA (Fig. 6C [rid=Fig6] ; 15 µM: 113%, p < 0.05; 35 µM: 49%, p < 0.0001). However, TGFβ1 target SMAD3 were not affected by Rhein on protein or mRNA level (Supplementary Fig. 7A–D [this file] ). HCF-v pre-treated with Rhein for 24 h prior to 30 min incubation with TGFβ1, demonstrated decreased abundance and expression of TGFβ receptor I (Supplementary Fig. 6E,F [this file] ) along with significantly decreased phosphorylation of SMAD2 at Ser465/467 by 50% (p < 0.05) (Fig. 6B [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Fig. 7E [this file] ). In line, SMAD-specific E3 ubiquitin ligase SMURF2 but not SMURF1 protein stability increased in parallel (Supplementary Fig. 8A–D [this file] ).
pub_title: Rhein, a novel Histone Deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor with antifibrotic potency in human myocardial fibrosis

title: NIHMS921965-supplement-1.pdf
context_description:
Using this approach, we found that active loci in MF progenitors are significantly associated with signaling pathways linked to the TNF/NF-κB/inflammatory signaling and hypoxia/HIF1 pathways ( Figures 1D, 1E [href=#F1] , S1A [href=this file] , and Table S1 [href=#SD2] ), suggesting that a NF-κB-dependent regulatory network sustains the inflammatory state observed in MF mice. Analysis of the chromatin landscape of JAK2V617F-positive MEPs, but not LSK or GMPs (data not shown), showed similar enrichment of the TNF/NF-κB signaling pathway at both TSS and enhancers compared to control cells ( Figures 1F [href=#F1] and S1B [href=this file] ), further highlighting an important role of an NF-κB-dependent regulatory network in MPN pathogenesis.
See also Figure S1 [href=this file] and Table S1 [href=#SD2] .
Detailed information about the creation of sub-networks and a list of gene sets can be found in , Figure S2 [href=this file] and Table S1 [href=#SD2] . See also , Figure S2 [href=this file] , and Tables S2 [href=#SD3] and S3 [href=#SD4] .
We next assessed for pathway enrichment by performing GSEA and subsequently identified key optimal sub-networks ( Figures S2A and B [href=this file] ) ( Bader and Hogue, 2003 [href=#R6] ). Consistent with the finding of dysregulated TNF/NF-κB pathway signaling in MF progenitors by gene expression and chromatin state analysis, integrated analysis of gene expression and H3K27ac occupancy data revealed a significant association between epigenetic and gene transcription data ( Figures 2E, 2F [href=#F2] , and S2C [href=this file] ), suggesting integrated epigenetic and transcriptional networks that regulate inflammatory signaling in MF progenitors. We therefore assessed for the presence of STAT3 and NF-κB binding sites ( Figure S2D [href=this file] ) in the regulatory regions of DEGs in MPLW515L-positive and JAK2V617F-positive MPN cells ( Table S2 [href=#SD3] ). Notably, we found a strong co-occurrence and enrichment for canonical p65/NF-κB and STAT3 DNA bindings sites in DEGs in both models ( Figures 2G [href=#F2] and S2E [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S3 [href=this file] .
Interestingly, while both mice receiving JQ1 and ruxolitinib alone showed a reduction in NF-κB pathway activation, the effect was significantly more potent when both drugs were administered as combination therapy ( Figures 3E [href=#F3] and S3 [href=this file] ).
Furthermore, JQ1 therapy resulted in lower spleen weights, decreased EMH in liver and spleen, a reduction in reticulin fibrosis, and a decrease of the proportion of GFP-positive mutant cells in the peripheral blood (PB) ( Figures 4B–D [href=#F4] , and S4 [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S4 [href=this file] .
Clusters 3–5 are presented in Figure S5 [href=this file] . See also Figure S5 [href=this file] and Table S4 [href=#SD4] .
We identified five distinct clusters with each cluster associated with a specific therapeutic regimen ( Figures 5B [href=#F5] and S5A [href=this file] ). Notably, integration of ChIP-sequencing and RNA-sequencing data comparing wild-type and mutant MEPs revealed that genes in cluster 1 are significantly enriched for the top 1000 differential H3K27ac peaks (ranked based on DESeq2 statistics), the top 1000 differential H3K4me1 peaks, and genes which were up-regulated in mutant MEPs compared to wild-type MEPs (***p value <1e-6) ( Figures 5B [href=#F5] and S5A [href=this file] ). Genes in cluster 1 were significantly enriched for the JAK2/STAT signaling pathway (p value=1.8e-4), while genes in cluster 2 were significantly enriched for the NF-κB signaling pathway (p value =0.02) ( Figure S5B [href=this file] ).
Combined JAK/BET inhibition reduced WBC and spleen weights to a degree not observed by either therapy alone ( Figures 5C, D [href=#F5] and S5C [href=this file] ). Similar to our findings in MF mice, combined JAK/BET inhibition showed increased therapeutic efficacy in JAK2V617F-diseased mice compared to JQ1 and/or ruxolitinib monotherapy ( Figures 5G, 5H [href=#F5] , and S5D–F [href=this file] ). In addition, combined JAK/BET inhibition substantively decreased the number of erythroid progenitors in the bone marrow of primary JAK2V617F mice and led to a significant reduction of red cell blood parameters in JAK2V617F-mutant mice ( Figure S5D–F [href=this file] ).
Strikingly, combined JAK/BET inhibitor therapy completely eliminated fibrosis in MF mice ( Figures 6A, 6B [href=#F6] and S6A [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S6 [href=this file] , Tables S5 and S6 [href=#SD4] .
JQ1 prevented the development of JAK inhibitor persistence and JAK inhibitor persistent SET-2 cells remained sensitive to BET inhibition ( Figures 6D, 6E [href=#F6] , and S6B [href=this file] ).
Of note a subset of patient samples (3 out of 5) which required higher concentrations of ruxolitinib to block colony formation retained sensitivity to BET inhibition ( Figure S6C [href=this file] ). Genomic analysis of colonies from patients with multiple mutations, including high-risk MPN disease alleles ( ), showed that combined ruxolitinib/JQ1 therapy showed efficacy against all MPN clones including clones with multiple disease alleles ( Tables S5, S6 [href=#SD4] and Figure S6D [href=this file] ).
We found the raw p values of the GSEA analysis are found to be highly inflated ( Figure S2B [href=this file] ).
Mice were randomized based on HCT and PLT counts and treatment was performed for 28 days as indicated above with the exception that BET inhibitor JQ1 was administered on 7 days per week at 50 mg/kg ( Figure S5D–F [href=this file] ).
The data set contains the ChIP-sequencing data shown in Figures 1A–G [href=#F1] , S1A [href=this file] (MEP, MigR1 versus MPLW515L n=12), and S1B [href=this file] (JAK2fl/WT Cre-negative versus Cre-positive, n=6), Creand RNA-sequencing data shown in Figures 2 [href=#F2] , (MEP, MigR1 versus MPLW515L, n=6), (SET-2 cell line, n=12), (GFP-positive MEP, MPLW515L model, n=9), and S2E [href=this file] (JAK2fl/WT Cre-negative versus Cre-positive, n=6).
pub_title: Dual Targeting of Oncogenic Activation and Inflammatory Signaling Increases Therapeutic Efficacy in Myeloproliferative Neoplasms - PMC

See also Figure S1 [href=#SD1] and Table S1 [href=this file] .
Detailed information about the creation of sub-networks and a list of gene sets can be found in , Figure S2 [href=#SD1] and Table S1 [href=this file] .

title: NIHMS921965-supplement-3.xlsx
description: Related to Figure 2. Differentially expressed genes. Provided as an Excel file.
context_description:
To elucidate MPLW515L-dependent gene expression changes, we applied DESeq2 to identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs) (adjusted p value <0.01 and absolute value of log2-fold change > 1) of which 850 genes were upregulated and 499 genes were downregulated in MPLW515L-expressing MEPs compared to empty vector control cells ( Table S2 [href=this file] ).
See also , Figure S2 [href=#SD1] , and Tables S2 [href=this file] and S3 [href=#SD4] .
The HALLMARK_TNFA_SIGNALING_VIA_NFKB gene set represented the core expression signature of the TNF/NF-κB expression cluster and Tnf itself was found to be highly upregulated in MF progenitors compared to control cells (2.8-fold, q value <0.001, Figures 2C–E [href=#F2] , Table S2 [href=this file] ). We therefore assessed for the presence of STAT3 and NF-κB binding sites ( Figure S2D [href=#SD1] ) in the regulatory regions of DEGs in MPLW515L-positive and JAK2V617F-positive MPN cells ( Table S2 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Dual Targeting of Oncogenic Activation and Inflammatory Signaling Increases Therapeutic Efficacy in Myeloproliferative Neoplasms - PMC

title: NIHMS921965-supplement-4.xlsx
description: Related to Figure 2. KEGG Pathway enrichment analysis
context_description:
KEGG pathway enrichment analysis of DEGs showed enrichment of 28 (p value <0.01) gene ontology terms, including hematopoietic cell lineage, cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction, JAK/STAT signaling pathway, and chemokine signaling pathway, consistent with the known role of JAK2 in cytokine signaling and hematopoietic lineage decision ( Figure 2B [href=#F2] and Table S3 [href=this file] ).
See also , Figure S2 [href=#SD1] , and Tables S2 [href=#SD3] and S3 [href=this file] .
With the exception of the genes in cluster 2, gene ontology annotations indicated that down-regulated genes were associated with NF-κB signaling ( Table S4 [href=this file] ), in agreement with our data showing reduction of NF-κB activity in response to JQ1 and ruxolitinib therapy which is augmented by combination therapy.
List of select enriched biological process Gene Ontology (GO) terms for each cluster can be found in Table S4 [href=this file] . See also Figure S5 [href=#SD1] and Table S4 [href=this file] .
See also Figure S6 [href=#SD1] , Tables S5 and S6 [href=this file] .
Genomic analysis of colonies from patients with multiple mutations, including high-risk MPN disease alleles ( ), showed that combined ruxolitinib/JQ1 therapy showed efficacy against all MPN clones including clones with multiple disease alleles ( Tables S5, S6 [href=this file] and Figure S6D [href=#SD1] ).
Information about the age and gender of each patient is listed in Table S5 [href=this file] .
All experiments were performed in duplicate using ten different patient samples ( Tables S5 and S6 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Dual Targeting of Oncogenic Activation and Inflammatory Signaling Increases Therapeutic Efficacy in Myeloproliferative Neoplasms - PMC

title: Click here for additional data file.
context_description:
RNA-seq analyses of all senescence models are in Supplementary Tables S1–S9 [href=this file] ( GSE130727 [href=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE130727] ).
Forward and reverse primers used to validate the RNA-seq results are listed in Supplementary Table S10 [href=this file] .
RNA-seq performed using an Illumina should be HiSeq 4000 instrument at a depth of 75 million unidirectional reads for a total of 150 million paired-end reads per sample; after completion, bioinformatic analyses were performed ( Supplementary Tables S1–S9 and Figures S1 and S2 [href=this file] ).
A heat map representation of these 68 RNAs (50+18) is shown in Supplementary Figure S3 [href=this file] . Ingenuity pathway analysis (IPA) revealed several metabolic and inflammatory pathways such as granzyme A signaling, cysteine biosynthesis and interferon signaling ( Supplementary Figure S4A [href=this file] ). Network analysis found that several of the encoded proteins were part of shared regulatory networks in the nucleus and cytoplasm ( Supplementary Figure S4B [href=this file] ).
The changes in shared downregulated and upregulated transcripts (Figures 3 [href=#F3] and 4 [href=#F4] ) were validated by using RT-qPCR analysis employing gene-specific primer pairs ( Supplementary Table S10 [href=this file] ). Among the many RNAs shared across all senescence models, we validated 16 reduced and 12 increased transcripts (Figure 5A [href=#F5] and B) in replicative, IR-induced, Dox-induced and oncogene-induced senescence in WI-38 cells, as well as in replicative and IR-induced senescence in IMR-90 cells and IR-induced senescence in HUVEC and HAEC; additional validation in biological replicates is shown in Supplementary Figure S5 [href=this file] .
Using leave-one-out (LOO) cross-validation to evaluate performance, we were able to decrease the number of transcripts to 5 at an optimal value of (penalty coefficient), while still observing a low misclassification error rate ( Supplementary Figure S6 [href=this file] ).
The transcripts listed in CellAge ( 23 [href=#B23] ) were largely (>90%) shared with the aggregate of all differentially expressed mRNAs in at least one cell type and a given senescence trigger ( Supplementary Tables S1–S9 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Transcriptome signature of cellular senescence - PMC
Off-target based drug repurposing opportunities for tivantinib in acute myeloid leukemia
Off-target based drug repurposing opportunities for tivantinib in acute myeloid leukemia

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Supporting this report, analysis of publically available expression levels of GSK3α and GSK3β using the BloodSpot database (which contains more than 2000 AML and normal samples assembled from six independent studies on AML) revealed that GSK3α is overexpressed across multiple AML subtypes as compared to normal hematopoietic lineages (Fig. S1a [this file] ). Interestingly, GSK3β expression in AML differs little from normal hematopoiesis (Fig. S1b [this file] ). Consistent with GSK3α being overexpressed in AML, this analysis suggested that AML cell lines are significantly more sensitive (low RSA Sensitivity score) to GSK3α silencing as compared to GSK3β gene silencing (Fig. S1c [this file] ). Furthermore, AML cell lines constitute the most sensitive population of hematopoietic cell lines with regard to GSK3α gene silencing (Fig. S1d [this file] ). 
Our model had good accordance between predicted and experimental values (r = 0.71, AUC = 0.83) which is comparable to similar models (Figs 1a [rid=Fig1] , S2a [this file] ) . Interestingly, many of the gene features selected through regularization are known to associate with GSK3 signaling (STRING) , such as the TCF7 cofactor MLLT11, which had the most highly weighted coefficient (Fig. S2b [this file] ) . 
Interestingly, whereas tivantinib was only weakly correlated with paclitaxel, it was highly correlated with ML320 suggesting the GSK3 inhibition is the primary mechanism in which tivantinib elicits activity in these cells (Fig. S2c [this file] ). 
Pulldowns were of high quality with good reproducibility between biological replicates (Fig. S3a [this file] ). We prioritized targets with a SAINTScore ≥ 0.95, a CRAPomePCT ≥ 0.95 and an –ln(NSAF) ≥ −7 (Fig. S3b [this file] ). 
Detailed flow cytometry analysis showed a strong accumulation of cells in G2/M phase upon tivantinib treatment (Figs 3c [rid=Fig3] , S4 [this file] ). Similar increases in early apoptosis were observed over time between tivantinib and LiCl; however, a much larger late apoptotic population was observed with tivantinib treatment (Figs 3d [rid=Fig3] , S5 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, while tivantinib treatment for 96 hours resulted in a significant increase of cell differentiation, LiCl caused a much stronger effect (Figs 3e [rid=Fig3] , S6 [this file] ), which is consistent with previous studies . 
Using several different primary AML patient samples, tivantinib displayed a strong ability to inhibit colony formation at the clinically relevant concentration of 5 μM across all patients with only a few colonies remaining (Figs 5a [rid=Fig5] , S7 [this file] ). Single drug ABT-199 treatment showed slight variations in efficacy, but on average reduced colony formation to approximately 30–40 percent consistent with previous reports (Figs 5a [rid=Fig5] , S7 [this file] ) . The combination of tivantinib and ABT-199 exerted synergy in 4 of 7 patients with moderate (patients 1 and 2) to strong synergy (patients 3 and 4) values (Figure S7 [this file] ). Consistent with GSK3α being overexpressed across all major AML karyotypes (Figure S1a [this file] ), tivantinib efficacy did not show any obvious relationship with mutational status or karyotypes (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] ; Table S2 [rid=MOESM3] ) although the number of patient samples was low.
pub_title: Off-target based drug repurposing opportunities for tivantinib in acute myeloid leukemia

title: NIHMS906627-supplement-Supp_Figs.pdf
description: Supp Figure 1. pyalba4− clonal populations were generated by double homologous crossover recombination and confirmed by genotyping PCR. A) The entire PyALBA4 ORF was deleted by introducing linear plasmid DNA containing two homology repair sequences flanking a GFP cassette and HsDHFR cassette. B) The successful disruption of the PyALBA4 ORF was confirmed by genotyping PCR, and two clonal parasite lines were isolated by limited dilution cloning. Primer sequences are provided in Supplemental Table 20.
context_description:
Replacement of the PyALBA4 open reading frame with both a drug resistance cassette (HsDHFR) and GFP expression cassette (GFPmut2) enabled rapid selection and isolation by limited dilution cloning, which was confirmed by genotyping PCR ( Supp Figure 1 [href=this file] ). In contrast to previous reports of ALBA proteins (including PbALBA4), no significant growth defect was observed in asexual blood stage ( 37 [href=#R37] , 50 [href=#R50] ) when compared to a wild-type line with a GFPmut2 expression cassette integrated in the dispensable locus (WT-GFP) ( Supp Figure 2 [href=this file] ).
As rodent-infectious species produce gametocytes that are sexual dimorphic for much of their development, we assigned parasites into three categories as has been done for previously: sexual dimorphic (immature), mature males, and mature females (scoring key provided in Supp Figure 3 [href=this file] ) ( 51 [href=#R51] ).
While we observed no significant differences in the prevalence of mosquito infection, oocyst numbers, nor in the total number of sporozoites per infected mosquito (the sum of midgut and salivary gland sporozoites) ( Supp Table 2 [href=#SD2] , Supp Fig 4, Supp Fig 5 [href=this file] ), we observed a significant effect upon the semi-synchronous egress of sporozoites from oocysts in the midgut and their arrival in the salivary gland ( Fig 1B [href=#F1] ).
This genetic modification was confirmed by genotyping PCR ( Supp Fig 6 [href=this file] ), as well as by live fluorescence and immunofluorescence assays ( Fig 2 [href=#F2] , Supp Fig 7, Supp Fig 8 [href=this file] ).
In mosquito stages, PyALBA4 is first expressed diffusely throughout early oocysts (Day 3) but then much of it is directed to puncta within developing sporozoites ( Supp Fig 7 [href=this file] ), with the remainder persisting within sporoblasts/cytoplasmic islands. Finally, PyALBA4 follows a similar pattern in liver stage parasites, shifting from a largely diffuse expression pattern in mid-liver stage (24 hours) to increasingly smaller puncta during late (48 hours) and very late (52 hours) liver stage ( Supp Fig 8 [href=this file] , Supp Table 4 [href=#SD2] ).
This is further supported when these datasets are compared to transcripts found to associate with DOZI/CITH by RIP-chip, with 108 of 226 transcripts overlapping ( Supp Fig 9A [href=this file] , Supp Table 7 [href=#SD2] ) ( 23 [href=#R23] ).
These effects are consistent with changes observed when another ALBA family member, PfALBA1, was overexpressed in asexual blood stages and may reflect invasion-related roles for ALBA family proteins ( Supp Figure 9B [href=this file] ) ( 37 [href=#R37] ).
Immunoprecipitations were confirmed by western blotting prior to mass spectroscopic analyses ( Supp Figures 10 and 11 [href=this file] ), and the resulting mass spectra (nano LC/MS/MS) were analyzed using the Trans-Proteomic Pipeline (TPP, Institute for Systems Biology) to identify peptides and to infer protein identities with a stringent <1% false discovery rate (FDR).
Finally, we also note that ALBA4 undergoes proteolysis, which may be biologically relevant or an artifact of sample preparation despite how rapidly they can be processed ( Figure S11 [href=this file] ).
Smears were viewed under 100X oil objective and the numbers of mature female, mature male, and immature gametocytes were counted per ~10,000 red blood cells (see Supp Fig 3 [href=this file] for a key for these gametocyte populations).
pub_title: ALBA4 modulates its stage-specific interactions and specific mRNA fates during Plasmodium growth and transmission - PMC

title: NIHMS906627-supplement-Supp_Tables.xlsx
description: Table S1: Gametocyte comparison between parasite lines.
context_description:
Based upon this, we did not observe differences in total gametocytemia, sex ratio, or mature-immature ratio ( Supp Table 1 [href=this file] ), and therefore conclude the PyALBA4 contributes more directly to the activation program of male gametocytes into gametes.
While we observed no significant differences in the prevalence of mosquito infection, oocyst numbers, nor in the total number of sporozoites per infected mosquito (the sum of midgut and salivary gland sporozoites) ( Supp Table 2 [href=this file] , Supp Fig 4, Supp Fig 5 [href=#SD1] ), we observed a significant effect upon the semi-synchronous egress of sporozoites from oocysts in the midgut and their arrival in the salivary gland ( Fig 1B [href=#F1] ). Instead, parasites continue to egress from the oocysts over time and are capable of invading the salivary gland and are highly infectious to mice ( Supp Table 3 [href=this file] ).
Finally, PyALBA4 follows a similar pattern in liver stage parasites, shifting from a largely diffuse expression pattern in mid-liver stage (24 hours) to increasingly smaller puncta during late (48 hours) and very late (52 hours) liver stage ( Supp Fig 8 [href=#SD1] , Supp Table 4 [href=this file] ).
Those that remain with greater than a 2-fold change in abundance (36 increase, Supp Table 5 [href=this file] ; 190 decrease, Supp Table 6 [href=this file] ) include many transcripts that encode for functions important to the gametocyte (calcium-dependent activities; inner membrane complex proteins: GAPM2, MAP45, IMC1b-IMC1k, GAP50) or to early mosquito stage infections (LCCL-domain containing proteins: CCp1, CCp2, CCp4, LAP5; CPW-WPC protein family members; WARP; PSOP proteins 6, 13, and 20). This is further supported when these datasets are compared to transcripts found to associate with DOZI/CITH by RIP-chip, with 108 of 226 transcripts overlapping ( Supp Fig 9A [href=#SD1] , Supp Table 7 [href=this file] ) ( 23 [href=#R23] ).
Here, loss of contributes to a mixed effect but upon twice as many mRNAs (1131 transcripts with > 2-fold change in abundance), with some notable increases and decreases in transcript abundances compared to the WT-GFP control line that are distinct from other parasite stages ( Figure 3CD [href=#F3] , Supp Table 8 [href=this file] ). In sporozoites, two gene ontology (GO) terms were significantly attributed to transcripts that increased in abundance: RNA-binding proteins and translation factor activity ( Supp Table 9 [href=this file] ). Of those genes that experienced a decrease in transcript abundance in sporozoites were those associated with heat shock protein binding ( Supp Table 10 [href=this file] ).
In contrast to its roles in gametocyte and sporozoite stages, PyALBA4 exerts a pronounced effect in asexual blood stage schizonts to decrease the abundance of specific transcripts that are largely distinct from the transcripts affected in other stages ( Supp Table 11 [href=this file] , in parasites where ALBA4 is missing, only four transcripts decrease in abundance >2-fold while 251 increase in abundance >2-fold). Transcripts that were affected included those that encode functions related to microtubule motor activity and binding ( Supp Table 12 [href=this file] ), including several dynein heavy and light chain proteins, actin-related proteins, and kinesins.
This is also evident from how little overlap there is between the differentially affected transcripts in gametocytes, sporozoites, and asexual blood stage schizonts, with only six transcripts being affected across all three stages ( Figure 3D [href=#F3] , Supp Table 13 [href=this file] ).
First, using gametocytes enriched by sulfadiazine selection and Accudenz purification, we confirmed that PyALBA4 indeed associates with members of the DOZI and CITH complexes ( Table 1 [href=#T1] , complete list provided in Supp Table 14 [href=this file] ) ( 26 [href=#R26] ). Additionally, factors that associate with RNA and shuttle between the nucleus and cytosol were also identified, including RNA-binding proteins (Bruno/CELF2, CELF4 and Mushashi), stress granule components (GBP2), and splicing factors (SR1, PREBP) ( Supp Table 15 [href=this file] ) ( 36 [href=#R36] , 53 [href=#R53] , 54 [href=#R54] ).
Complete datasets for all three stages with both thresholds noted are provided ( Supp Table 14, Supp Table 16, and Supp Table 17 [href=this file] ).
Upon expanding this threshold (0.35), many additional members of the DOZI/CITH/ALBA complex from blood stages are then included, such as ALBA2, Bruno/CELF2, GBP2, Aldolase, UAP56, and ribosomal proteins from both small and large subunits ( Table 2 [href=#T2] , Supp Table 16 [href=this file] ).
Consistent with this, we observe substantial overlap in interactions between asexual blood stage schizonts and purified gametocytes, much of which is attributable to the DOZI/CITH/ALBA complex ( Figure 4 [href=#F4] , Supp Table 17 [href=this file] ). Comparison of the PyALBA4 and CK2-beta interactomes revealed significant overlap ( Supp Table 18 [href=this file] ), whereas those proteins from the PyALBA4 dataset that did not overlap largely have functions consistent with stress granule functions. Moreover, we also searched our proteomic data for clear evidence of phosphorylation of members of the PyALBA4 complex in schizonts and gametocytes, and detected modification of PyALBA4, ALBA3, Bruno/CELF2, GBP2, EF1g, and eIF3A even without enrichment of phosphorylated proteins ( Supp Table 19 [href=this file] ). This is further supported by the presence of other translation factors, including elongation factors (EF1a, EF1b, EF1g, EF2), eukaryotic initiation factors (eIF2g, eIF3D, eIF3E, eIF3G, eIF5a), and PABP-Interacting Protein 1 (PAIP1) which stimulates eIF3 subunits during active translation ( Table 2 [href=#T2] , Supp Table 17 [href=this file] ).
Taken together, these proteomic datasets indicate that many of these interacting partners are conserved across all three stages and likely form a core complex: Musashi, Bruno, GBP2, SR1, GAPDH, Aldolase, PABP, a thioredoxin peroxidase, EF1alpha, ribosomal proteins and ALBA1, 2, 3, and 4 ( Figure 4 [href=#F4] ; Supp Table 14, Supp Table 16, and Supp Table 17 [href=this file] ).
Oligonucleotides used in their construction are provided in Supp Table 20 [href=this file] .
pub_title: ALBA4 modulates its stage-specific interactions and specific mRNA fates during Plasmodium growth and transmission - PMC

context_description:
To explore interactions between cancer cells and tumour microenvironment, we established an automated image analysis method with pixel classification based on machine learning (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). The minimal distance distribution between α-SMA-positive vessels and metastatic lesions was unimodal, whereas that between VEGFR3-positive vessels and metastatic lesions was bimodal (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). The density plots showed that 91% of the metastases localized within 100 μm from α-SMA-positive vessels (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). Although 43% of the metastases localized within 75 µm from VEGFR3-positive vessels, 53% of the metastases were within 75–400 µm of VEGFR3-positive vessels (Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] ). 
For IL6 and PDGFB, we observed an increase in expression after 4 h of TGF-β stimulation (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
Some of these genes, such as and , were upregulated immediately after TGF-β stimulation (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
Antibodies used in immunostaining and sampling days after cancer cell injections are listed in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
Primer sequences are shown in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] .

Based on these considerations, we designed and synthesised a -propargyl adenosine phosphoramidate pronucleotide ( , Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). A maximum concentration is reached 8 h after addition and it is maintained for at least 24 h (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). Comparing labelling (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] ) with parent -propargyl adenosine ( , Fig. 1f [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ) yielded a larger number of significantly enriched proteins with the pronucleotide. Immunoprecipitation of the two selected proteins PFKP and PPME1 from the probe treated HeLa cells followed by click reaction with rhodamine-azide tag confirmed incorporation of the probe into these proteins (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
For both PARP inhibitors, no influence on labelling intensity was observed based on in-gel fluorescence analysis (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). Second, only two of our identified AMPylated proteins in HeLa cells (HIST1H2AH, RPS10) matched known ADP-ribosylated proteins (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ) . 
We were able to directly analyse AMPylated peptides on three different cysteine cathepsin proteases CTSB (S104 and S107), CTSC (S254) and CTSL (S137) in HeLa cells (Supplementary Figs. 4 [this file] and 5 [this file] ). To determine whether FICD is the AMPylator of these cathepsins, we used an in vitro peptidase activity assay and found that cathepsin B is indeed inhibited upon FICD (wild-type (wt) or E234A mutant) treatment and did not observe any inhibition without the addition of ATP (Fig. 2d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Here, previous trials in cell lysates using an active recombinant FICD E234G mutant yielded a complementary set of proteins likely due to an increased degree of modification (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] and Supplementary Data 5 [rid=MOESM8] ) . 
Exemplary MS/MS spectrum (MaxQuant) for the CTSB AMPylation site identification on S107 (see Supplementary Figs. 4 [this file] and 5 [this file] ). 
We performed chemical-proteomic profiling in three different cancer cell lines, HeLa, A549 and SH-SY5Y, which revealed a total of 58 significantly enriched proteins, of which 38 were contributed solely from the latter neuroblastoma cells (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
To directly dissect the descent of AMPylated proteins from FICD, we compared the AMPylation levels of proteins in probe treated HeLa cells comprising FICD knockdown, wt FICD overexpression (OX) and activated FICD E234G OX (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] and Supplementary Data 6 [rid=MOESM9] ). Of note, FICD E234G revealed a more pronounced interaction with HSPA5, confirming our OX studies (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] and Supplementary Data 7 [this file0] ). 
Thus, normalisation of total AMPylation to the expression of HSPA5 results in an overall reduction of its AMPylation, which is in line with previously published results (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ) . Despite the moderate impact of ER stress on AMPylation in these cells, we found 145 dysregulated proteins in SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
To study AMPylation in a model system of developing neurons, neural progenitor cells (NPCs) and neurons were generated from human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs, Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ) . Successively, iPSCs, NPCs and neurons were each treated with and the enriched proteins were analysed via LFQ LC-MS/MS (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] and 12 [this file] and Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM4] and 8 [this file1] ). This is of particular interest as the cytoskeletal remodelling, which is required for neuronal polarisation, migration, and proper axon guidance, is a highly dynamic processes precisely regulated by several PTMs on tubulin and microtubules - and AMPylation may indeed be an additional one (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] ) . AMPylation remodelling could be involved in the process of cell type specification and differentiation from iPSCs through NPCs to neurons, with cellular proteins undergoing substantial de- and re-AMPylation following an hourglass-like model (Fig. 4b [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ) . Further, parallel chemical-proteomics studies of AMPylation under ER stress induced by Tg in iPSCs, NPCs and neurons showed distinct responses ranging from a strong change of AMPylation of several proteins in iPSCs over mild alterations in NPCs to an obvious upregulation on two proteins (HSPA5 and SQSTM1) in neurons (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
To specify if the observed AMPylation in neurons is common for differentiated postmitotic cells we performed chemical profiling in fibroblasts (Fig. 4c [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 14 [this file] ). 
The chemical-proteomic results were corroborated by fluorescence imaging of probe-treated HeLa, iPSCs, NPCs and neurons (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Fig. 15 [this file] and Supplementary Data 9 [this file2] ). Indeed, we observed only a slight decrease in overall cell staining by rather than disappearance of the bright AMPylation spots, while we observed a strong decrease in 5-EU labelling (Supplementary Fig. 16 [this file] ). 
In cerebral organoids, FICD (green) is enriched in the DCX+ neuronal layer (white), which is in line with qPCR data from 2D in vitro generated NPCs and neurons (Supplementary Fig. 19 [this file] ). See also Supplementary Fig. 15 [this file] . 
Given that the cellular localisation of FICD and AMPylated proteins might play an important functional role, we combined click chemistry with rhodamine-azide for intracellular probe visualisation with immunohistochemistry (IHC) for FICD and various cellular markers: PDI for rough endoplasmic reticulum, GM130 for Golgi complex, TUBB3 for total neuronal microtubule cytoskeleton, MAP2 for neuronal dendrites, phospho-TAU for neuronal axons, and DAPI to visualise nuclei (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Fig. 15 [this file] ). This observation was further corroborated by overexpression of FICD with a C-terminal FLAG tag (Supplementary Figure 17 [this file] ) and by analysis of the FICD’s glycosylation using endoglycosidase H assay (Supplementary Fig. 17 [this file] ). Finally, fibroblasts showed another specific localisation pattern with AMPylation accumulated around the nucleus and its’ complete absence inside (Supplementary Figure 15 [this file] ). 
COs contain areas which closely resemble the structure and organisation of the germinal zones of developing human neocortex (Supplementary Figure 18 [this file] ) . Treatment of COs with and subsequent analysis via LFQ LC-MS/MS confirmed the AMPylation of PFKP, found in all cell types, and CTSB, another prevalent target in other studied cell lines (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Figs. 5 [this file] and 12 [this file] ). Analysis of the significantly enriched proteins using a STRING database revealed that several proteins are located in extracellular space (Supplementary Fig. 13 [this file] ). Interestingly, visualisation of the probe-treated COs via click-chemistry with rhodamine-azide revealed strongest fluorescence in the neuronal layer (Fig. 5i, j [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 15 [this file] ), which is in line with the highest number of AMPylated proteins identified in neurons (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] ). 
To examine the function of AMPylation in neurogenesis and neuronal differentiation in more detail, we first characterised the expression of FICD in NPCs, neurons, neuroblastoma cells and COs and found a clear enrichment of FICD in the neurites of neurons, SH-SY5Y and in the neuronal layer of COs compared to the progenitor zone (Fig. 5d, h [rid=Fig5] ; Supplementary Fig. 15 [this file] ). Results of imaging were paralleled by qPCR studies demonstrating higher baseline expression levels of FICD in neurons compared to iPSCs and NPCs (Supplementary Fig. 19 [this file] ). We knocked down FICD levels (Supplementary Fig. 20 [this file] ) in NPCs differentiating to neurons (Fig. 6a, b [rid=Fig6] ) and found a significant increase in transfected cells that remain in cell cycle (KI67+) (Fig. 6a [rid=Fig6] ). To asses if FICD-mediated activity has a function in neurogenesis during development, COs were analysed 7 (Figs. 6 [rid=Fig6] and 7 [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] ) and 14 days post-electroporation (dpe) (Supplementary Fig. 22 [this file] ). Cortical-like germinal zones were defined by immunohistochemical (IHC) analysis using PAX6 as a marker for dorsal aRGs (Figs. 6d [rid=Fig6] , and 7b [rid=Fig7] ) with mitotic cells labelled for PH3 (Fig. 6e [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] ). The position and number of neurons was analysed by IHC using two different markers for mature neurons: MAP2, a microtubule-associated protein which is enriched in neuronal dendrites (Fig. 7c [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] ) and the nuclear marker NEUN (Figs. 6g [rid=Fig6] and 7d [rid=Fig7] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] for analysis of PH3+ progenitors upon FICD wt/E234G/H363A OX in COs and for scoring of MAP2+ progenitor cells intruding the VZ upon FICD KD or FICD wt/E234G/H363A OX in COs and Supplementary Fig. 22 [this file] for the analysis of 2 weeks after electroporation of COs with FICD wt/E234G OX constructs. 
Conversely, when electroporating vectors carrying wt FICD, activated FICD E234G mutant or catalytically inactive FICD H363A mutant into ventricles of 50 days old COs, those transfected with FICD wt or E234G showed an increase and redistribution in fluorescent signal upon treatment indicating a remodelling of AMPylation upon FICD overexpression (Fig. 7a [rid=Fig7] ), while there were no changes in distribution or intensity of the signal upon OX of FICD H363A used as a control (Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] and similarly in neuroblastoma cells Supplementary Fig. 23 [this file] ). At the same time, MAP2+ neurites increasingly invaded these progenitor zones 7 dpe (Fig. 7c [rid=Fig7] , blue arrowheads; Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] ) and 14 dpe (Supplementary Fig. 22 [this file] ), which was not the case upon control or FICD H363A electroporation (Fig. 7c [rid=Fig7] ), nor upon FICD KD (Supplementary Fig. 21 [this file] ). Interestingly, both the E234G mutant and wt FICD-transfected aRGs gave rise to a significantly higher number of neurons compared to H363A inactive mutant or control already at 7 dpe (Fig. 7e, f [rid=Fig7] ), which was consistent also at 14 dpe (Supplementary Fig. 22 [this file] ). Additionally, we have excluded other cellular processes to be involved in the observed effect by whole proteome analysis of FICD transfected neuroblastoma cells (Supplementary Fig. 24 [this file] , Supplementary Data 10 [this file3] ), which showed only minimal changes in overall protein expression. Furthermore, pull-down of the AMPylated proteins from neuroblastoma cells under FICD E234G OX conditions revealed a general increase in AMPylation including proteins such as CTSB, TPP1, CAPZB, and NSFL1C, which were found AMPylated in COs (Supplementary Fig. 25 [this file] , Supplementary Data 11 [this file4] ). 
Synthesis of the phosphoramidate probe is described in the Supplementary Information [this file] . 
Subsequent cell lysis, click chemistry, avidin beads enrichment and MS sample preparation were performed as described in Supplementary Information [this file] and literature . For details see Supplementary Information [this file] . 
For details of MS measurement and data analysis see Supplementary Information [this file] and Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM4] , 4 [rid=MOESM7] and 8 [this file1] . 
Induced pluripotent stem cells reprogrammed from fibroblasts (for reprogramming see Supplementary Information [this file] ) were cultured at 37 °C, 5% CO and ambient oxygen level on Geltrex coated plates (Thermo Fisher Scientific) in mTeSR1 medium (StemCell Technologies) with daily medium change. 
The resulting miRNA expression plasmids were sequenced, the knockdown efficiency was validated in Hela cells via qPCR and Westernblot and the most efficient construct was used for NPC transfection and for electroporation of COs (Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Fig. 19 [this file] ). 
The primary antibody (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] in Supplementary Information [this file] ) in blocking solution was then incubated overnight at 4 °C.

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S9 and Tables S1 and S2
caption: No description
description: Document  S1.  Figures  S1–S9  and  Tables  S1  and  S2
context_description:
In addition, 21.9% (7 of 32) of patients from the CHIK-deaths group developed neurologic signs and symptoms (e.g., confusion, syncope, adynamia, and sensory loss) ( Figures S1 [this file] A and S1B). The CHIK-deaths group was composed predominantly of males (male-to-female ratio = 1.46), and the median age was 52 years (interquartile, 36–73 years old), but no significant difference regarding age and sex were observed among the three groups ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] C and S1 [this file] C). The comorbidity most often reported in the CHIKV-deaths group was hypertension (21.9%, 7 of 32) ( Figure S1 [this file] D). 
CHIKV RNA was detected in CSF samples from all fatal cases ( Figure S1 [this file] E). CHIKV RNA was also detected in the spleen (52%, 13 of 25), lung (44%, 11 of 25), liver (28%, 7 of 25), kidney (20%, 5 of 25), heart (20%, 5 of 25), and brain (13%, 3 of 23) of CHIK-death patients from available specimens ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] F and S1 [this file] E). Moreover, histopathological findings of CHIK-death cases revealed extensive damage in the brain (e.g., anoxic depolarization, perivascular mononuclear infiltration, necrosis, and hemorrhage), and hemodynamic abnormalities (e.g., vascular congestion and edema) in the brain, lung, spleen, and kidney ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] G and S2 [this file] ). 
Moreover, IFN-λ3 (IL-28B) was 1.4-fold higher in the CHIK-deaths group compared with the CHIK-survivors group (p = 0.0005) ( Figure 3 [rid=fig3] A; Table S1 [this file] ). 
Based on an analysis of 82 metabolites, we found 56 that were differentially expressed in the sera of the CHIK-deaths group compared with patients who survived CHIK ( Figures S3 [this file] and S4 [this file] ). 
We identified and quantified 580 proteins ( Figure S5 [this file] ), including 338 proteins (188 downregulated and 150 upregulated) that were differentially expressed in the CHIK-deaths group compared with the healthy group. Also, we found 525 proteins (268 downregulated and 257 upregulated) differentially expressed in the CHIK-survivors group compared with the healthy group ( Figure S5 [this file] ). 
To better understand the impact of CHIKV on specific biological processes, we conducted a pathway enrichment analysis using significantly dysregulated proteins and the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) and Reactome databases. [xref] [rid=bib29] [xref] [rid=bib30] We found that enriched pathways associated with CHIK-deaths and CHIK-survivor groups but not with the healthy group were related to hemostasis (i.e., platelet degranulation, complement and coagulation cascades, common pathway of fibrin clot formation, clotting cascade, platelet activation and aggregation, binding and uptake of ligands by scavenger receptors, and metabolism), and the immune system (innate immune system, neutrophil degranulation, biosynthesis of amino acids, glycolysis/gluconeogenesis, and post-translational protein phosphorylation) ( Figures S6 [this file] and S7 [this file] ). 
To contextualize our data, we also included 10 novel CHIKV genome sequences obtained from patients in São Paulo, Maranhão, and Alagoas States in Brazil ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
Because of this, we conducted molecular dynamic simulations of CHIKV with the matrix remodeling associated 8 (MXRA8), a receptor for multiple arthritogenic alphaviruses, including CHIKV. [xref] [rid=bib31] [xref] [rid=bib32] [xref] [rid=bib33] We observed that the CHIKV-ECSA lineage with H242 resulted in reduced E2 surface area and increased the buried surface area interacting with the human MXRA8 receptor, compared with the ancestral E2-R242, due to physical proximity of the E3 protein toward the D2 domain of the MXRA8 receptor ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] D, 5E, and S8 [this file] ). Also, the CHIKV-H242 variant resulted in lower root mean square fluctuation compared with CHIKV-R242 in the contact region of E2 protein with MXRA8 ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] F and S8 [this file] ). Alanine-scanning mutagenesis analysis also indicates that E2-H242 may be relevant to the MXRA8 interaction with CHIKV glycoprotein based on free-energy differences compared with CHIKV strains harboring R242 ( Figure S9 [this file] ). 
The lengths of the simulations were sufficient to ensure stabilization of the Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) for both native and R242H mutants ( Figures S8 [this file] and S9 [this file] ).

As shown in Figure S2A [this file] , and consistent with the results shown in Figure 1 [rid=F1] , an increase in fungal growth was observed in all N-conditions as disease progressed, with larger quantities in infected plants grown under N-limiting conditions. 
The severity of the disease symptoms (Figures 2B,C [rid=F2] ) and the accumulation of fungal biomass (Figures S2B,C [this file] ) in infected MG and RR fruits from plants grown under N-limiting conditions were larger than those obtained from a N-sufficient regime.

context_description:
As shown in Figure S3 [rid=SM3] , our analysis suggests a significant interaction between the plant N-status and infection (Two-way ANOVA, < 0.01), where 2110 genes showed significant Nitrogen/ (N/B) interaction, representing approximately 4.7% of the analyzed tomato transcriptome (Table S1 [this file] ). 
For ANOVA analysis, we used a model with expression Y of a given gene i calculated as Y = β + β B + β N + β N/B + ε, where β is the global mean, and where β , β , and β are the effects of the infection, the N-condition and the interaction between these two factors (N/B), respectively (Table S1 [this file] ). 
Genes possessing a significant Nitrogen/ (N/B) interaction factor were selected to carry out a gene network construction (Table S1 [this file] ).

title: NIHMS1634043-supplement-supporting_information_I.pdf
context_description:
Details of materials and reagents are listed in Supporting Information I [href=this file] .
The details of SDS-PAGE and CZE-MS/MS analysis are described in Supporting Information I [href=this file] .
We further analyzed the proteins prepared by the SP3 method with the three different bead amounts using SDS-PAGE, Figure S1 [href=this file] in Supporting Information I [href=this file] . We also noted that the SP3 method-based sample cleanup introduced an obvious bias against large proteins (higher than 50 kDa) compared to the sample before cleanup, Figure S1 [href=this file] . The bias was also observed in the HepG2 human cell lysate processed by the SP3 method, Figure S2 [href=this file] .
We obtained a higher protein recovery for the human cell lysate than the cell lysate (86% vs 60%) using the MU method, presumably due to the fact that proteins tend to be smaller than human proteins in the length range of 1–250 amino acids based on the data in Swiss-Prot database, Figure S3 [href=this file] , resulting in a higher chance for protein to flow through the membrane (30 kDa MWCO) for the sample.
The whole workflow shows good reproducibility regarding the CZE separation profile, base peak intensity ( Table S1 [href=this file] ), and identifications.
We also identified one proteoform of 60S ribosomal protein L32 with one disulfide bond, Figure S4 [href=this file] , which is not reported in the literature according to the UniProt Knowledgebase. Our data revealed one phosphorylation site (mass shift of 79.97 Da) in the underlined region (S85 or T87) in Figure S5A [href=this file] , which is not reported previously. We also compared the relative abundance of the identified phosphorylated proteoform of PTMA and the corresponding unphosphorylated proteoform based on the extracted base peak electropherogram, Figure S5B [href=this file] . Figure S5C [href=this file] , D [href=this file] shows mass spectra of the unphosphorylated and phosphorylated proteoforms, indicating a difference between them regarding charge distribution.

context_description:

In two independent experiments, the most abundant peptide hit for tagged GPR35 mapped to Na/K-ATPase subunit α (Uniprot P05023 [href=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/protein/P05023] isoform 4; encoded by ), and was not present in HEK293T cells transfected with tag only, or in mock-transfected cells ( table S1 [href=this file] ).
Indeed a 75% knock-down ( fig S2a [href=this file] ) of mRNA expression by siRNA in Caco2 cells resulted in a 15% reduction in Rb uptake compared to cells transfected with control siRNA ( Fig. 2B [href=#F2] ).
The increase in resting Ca to maximum levels appeared to be specific for deletion, because siRNA-mediated knock-down ( fig S2b [href=this file] ) of mRNAs encoding other, unrelated GPCRs such as (which encodes the β -adrenoreceptor), cannabinoid receptor 2 ( ), and LPA receptor 2 ( ) in BMDMs did not affect, or minimally lowered resting intracellular Ca ( Fig. 2F [href=#F2] ).
S3 [href=this file] ) as expected ( 47 [href=#R47] ).
We therefore designed a series of palmitoylated peptides that targeted the i1, i2, or i3 loop and initially screened them in wild-type compared to BMDMs for their effect on Ca and chemotactic responses ( fig S4, A and B [href=this file] ). g35-i2 and g35-i3, which target the i2 and i3 loop, respectively, were characterized further ( Fig. 7A [href=#F7] ). g35-i2 triggered a transient increase in IP in wild-type BMDMs, which was absent in BMDMs ( Fig. 7B [href=#F7] ).
All other data needed to evaluate the conclusions in the paper are present in the paper or the Supplementary Materials [href=this file] .
