title: NIHMS1859868-supplement-Supplementary_information.docx
context_description:
RiboTag approaches to isolate actively translated mRNAs were used with AAVs employing or promoters that target striatal astrocytes and neurons, respectively ( Figure S1A [href=this file] – G [href=this file] ).
A-ZFP and A-Delta were expressed in ~80% of striatal astrocytes, but in negligible neurons ( Figure S2A [href=this file] – C [href=this file] ). tdTomato was also expressed in 80% of astrocytes and was not found in neurons ( Figure S2A [href=this file] – C [href=this file] ).
N-Delta and N-ZFP were expressed in ~98% of neurons, but negligibly in astrocytes ( Figure S2D [href=this file] – F [href=this file] ). Furthermore, tdTomato was expressed in ~82% of neurons and was not found in astrocytes ( Figure S2D [href=this file] – F [href=this file] ). The degree of mHTT lowering in neurons and astrocytes was similar when assessed with IHC whether ZFP and Delta-ZFP expression was assessed by virtue of the HA tag or by expression of the tdTomato ( Figure 1E [href=#F1] , H [href=#F1] ; Figure S3 [href=this file] ).
Astrocyte-specific RNA-seq data were enriched with 200 striatal astrocyte enriched genes , whereas neuronal RNA-seq data were enriched with 200 MSN genes ( Figure S4A [href=this file] , B [href=this file] ).
We found little evidence for uniquely A1 astrocytes in HD and no evidence of A-ZFP or N-ZFP affecting A1 marker genes in R6/2 mice ( Figure S4C [href=this file] ). We did find evidence of A-ZFP and N-ZFP reversing changes of astrocyte DEGs identified previously in mouse models and post mortem human tissue ( Figure S4D [href=this file] ), although at this stage the relationship of those genes to pathogenesis is unknown. We found significant rescue of HD DEGs in comparisons for R6/2 and human snRNA-seq data; effects of neuronal mHTT lowering were much greater than astrocytic mHTT lowering ( Figure S5A [href=this file] – L [href=this file] ).
Consistent with Figure 3C [href=#F3] , we found that disruption of cholesterol metabolism was a core feature of astrocytes in mouse models and in human data when DEGs were assessed with RNA-seq ( Figure S6 [href=this file] ). However, the agreement was weaker in relation to studies in zQ175 mice and for astrocytes derived from human embryonic stem cells that used fluorescence activated cell sorting and microarrays ( Figure S6 [href=this file] ).
We assessed 46 genes known to carry CAG repeats or to be downstream of genes that carry CAG repeats in our A-ZFP and N-ZFP data for astrocytic and neuronal RNA-seq ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ). Most were not detected with criteria for astrocyte and neuron enrichment ( Figure 2D(ii) [href=#F2] ), but of those that were, we found suppression of , , and only in neurons following N-ZFP, and suppression of in astrocytes following N-ZFP or A-ZFP ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ). This was expected as , , and are comparatively depleted in astrocytes relative to input, whereas is neither depleted nor enriched in astrocytes relative to the IP fraction ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ). Overall, the analyses of cell type markers ( Figure 1D [href=#F1] , F [href=#F1] , Figures S1 [href=this file] – 3 [href=this file] ), MDS ( Figure 2C [href=#F2] ), and known off target genes repressed by ZFPs ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ) suggests that our approach and analyses detected mainly astrocyte and neuronal gene expression and their alterations following ZFPs.
We found that N-ZFP significantly, but subtly, improved excitability as measured by input-output curves ( Figure S8A [href=this file] , B [href=this file] ). N-ZFP also significantly restored the resting membrane potential, cell capacitance, membrane resistance, and Rheobase ( Figure S8A [href=this file] – F [href=this file] ). Furthermore, N-ZFP rescued the loss of spontaneous excitatory post synaptic currents (sEPSCs) associated with HD in R6/2 mice, with no effect on sEPSC amplitude ( Figure S8G [href=this file] – I [href=this file] ). In contrast, astrocytic ZFPs did not improve these MSN electrophysiological properties ( Figures S8J [href=this file] – R [href=this file] ).
AAVs containing N-ZFP or N-Delta were microinjected intrastriatally at 6 months of age and neuron-specific and bulk RNA-seq was performed at 12 months ( Figure S9A [href=this file] ). The N-ZFPs reduced mHTT levels in Darpp32 positive neurons at 12 months by ~55% ( Figure S10A [href=this file] , B [href=this file] ). Our evaluations in 12 month old zQ175 mice showed that N-ZFPs were effective at reducing HD-associated DEGs and pathways in neuronal RNA-seq data ( Figure S9B [href=this file] , C [href=this file] , S9H [href=this file] – J [href=this file] ), that known astrocytic DEGs from zQ175 mice were also significantly rescued by N-ZFPs within bulk RNA-seq ( Figure S9D [href=this file] – G [href=this file] ), and that HD-associated changes in glia identified in human data and overlapping with zQ175 bulk RNA-seq data were also partially rescued ( Figure S10C [href=this file] – L [href=this file] ).
We packaged A-ZFP and N-ZFP into BBB-penetrant PHP.eBs to deliver them or the Delta controls throughout the brain ( Figure 4A [href=#F4] – C [href=#F4] ) of R6/2 and NCAR mice positive for the Ly6a receptor gene required for these AAVs to cross the BBB ( Figure S11A [href=this file] ). HA-tagged A-Delta, N-Delta, A-ZFP, and N-ZFPs were detected throughout the brain and their expression studied relative to mHTT ( Figure 4D [href=#F4] – G [href=#F4] ; Figure S11B [href=this file] – I [href=this file] ). mHTT aggregate intensity for brain areas such as the cortex, striatum, and hippocampus suggested that A-ZFP and N-ZFP lowered mHTT levels relative to the Delta controls ( Figure S11B [href=this file] – I [href=this file] ), allowing detailed astrocyte and neuron specific evaluations for the striatum ( Figure 4H [href=#F4] – K [href=#F4] ).
We summarized the behavioral data for each evaluation for A-ZFP and N-ZFP ( Figure S12A [href=this file] , B [href=this file] ) and found that A-ZFP produced modest 26% improvement of the overall aggregate z-score, but that N-ZFP improved HD mouse behavioral phenotypes by ~89% ( Figure 5 [href=#F5] , Figure S12A [href=this file] – B [href=this file] ). However, relative to the Delta group, R6/2 mice receiving N-ZFPs gained less weight as they aged ( Figure S12C [href=this file] – F [href=this file] ).
We detected ~2800 proteins in each case for the Delta groups, A-ZFP, and N-ZFP ( Figure S13A [href=this file] – B [href=this file] ). A greater effect of N-ZFP on HD-associated DEPs was also observed when the Delta groups were combined between astrocytic and neuronal studies ( Figure S13G [href=this file] ). The top 50 up- and down-regulated DEPs rescued by A-ZFP or N-ZFP are shown in Figure 6G [href=#F6] – J [href=#F6] ; the top IPA pathways for the HD DEPs are shown in Figure S13C [href=this file] – F [href=this file] .
The finding that early interventions were more effective than later N-ZFP administration ( Figure 7A [href=#F7] , B [href=#F7] ) most likely reflects greater mHTT lowering by early N-ZFP (~80%; Figure 4K [href=#F4] ) later N-ZFP administration (~20%; Figure S14A [href=this file] – C [href=this file] ). mHTT aggregates are already formed by 7 weeks of age in R6/2 mice, implying that ZFP-mediated mHTT lowering is most effective before aggregate formation.
Incidentally, cell loss does not occur in the R6/2 model and consistent with this, we found no evidence that either A-ZFP or N-ZFP increased the numbers of astrocytes or neurons relative to controls, respectively in R6/2 mice ( Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Neuronal and astrocytic contributions to Huntington’s disease dissected with zinc finger protein transcriptional repressors - PMC

Spine Patterning Is Guided by Segmentation of the Notochord Sheath

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
Similar to the downregulation of the reporter, segmented expression of proceeded in an anteroposterior direction starting at about 4 days post-fertilization (dpf), or approximately 3.5 mm SL ( Figures 2A [rid=F2] and S1 [this file] ). 
Principal-component and differential expression analyses confirmed that each population had unique enrichment signatures ( Figures 3B [rid=F3] and S2A [this file] ). The transitional ( / double-positive) domain was enriched for Notch target genes known to function in somite segmentation, such as , , and ( Figures 3C, 3D [rid=F3] , and S2B [this file] ), and also expressed low levels of . 
In contrast, during notochord segmentation, expression was clearly detected in newly formed and mature segments at similar levels ( Figure S3 [this file] ), suggesting that its expression does not oscillate in the notochord, as it does during PSM segmentation. 
This experimental approach also allowed us to avoid somitogenesis defects ( Figures S4A and S4B [this file] ). Expression of GFP, or the system components QF2 or QUAS alone, did not lead to defects in either notochord or vertebral segmentation ( Figures 5A [rid=F5] and S4C [this file] ). At later stages, these early defects resolved into wedge, short, and pebble vertebrae, as visualized by staining with alizarin red ( Figures 5B [rid=F5] and S5A [this file] ). This manipulation generated gaps in the domain that were filled later by more but smaller and fused segments at the posterior end of the notochord and spine ( Figures 5C [rid=F5] and S5B [this file] ). 
To bypass the early developmental defects, we injected QS ( Potter et al., 2010 [rid=R37] ) mRNA at the one-cell stage to inhibit QF2 during early development ( Figure S6 [this file] ). On average, centra were longer and their number was decreased in fish expressing compared with controls ( Figures S5B and S5C [this file] ). 
Second, expression does not seem to oscillate in the notochord, as it does in the PSM ( Figure S3 [this file] ). 
Our data also suggest that notochord and spine segment size and number are linked (e.g., misexpression of produces less segments that are also larger; Figures S5B and S5C [this file] ). 
Further details and an outline of resources used in this work can be found in Supplemental Experimental Procedures [this file] . 
SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION [this file] 
Supplemental Information [this file] includes Supplemental Experimental Procedures [this file] , six figures, and two tables and can be found with this article online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2018.01.084 (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2018.01.084) . 
See also Figure S1 [this file] . 
See also Figures S2 and S3 [this file] and Tables S1 [rid=SD2] and S2 [rid=SD3] . 
See also Figures S4–S6 [this file] .
pub_title: Spine Patterning Is Guided by Segmentation of the Notochord Sheath

SMARCA5 interacts with NUP98-NSD1 oncofusion protein and sustains hematopoietic cells transformation
SMARCA5 interacts with NUP98-NSD1 oncofusion protein and sustains hematopoietic cells transformation
SMARCA5 interacts with NUP98-NSD1 oncofusion protein and sustains hematopoietic cells transformation
SMARCA5 interacts with NUP98-NSD1 oncofusion protein and sustains hematopoietic cells transformation
SMARCA5 interacts with NUP98-NSD1 oncofusion protein and sustains hematopoietic cells transformation

title: No Title
caption: Additional file 1.
context_description:
Protein label-free quantification (LFQ) values from two replicate samples were analyzed using two-samples t-test statistics (Benjamini-Hochberg correction with FDR = 0.05) leading to the quantification of 502 proteins out of which 182 were statistically significant potential NUP98-NSD1 interactors (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). Finally, a separate analysis of the interactomes of WT NSD1 and the NUP98 N-terminus uncovered that SMARCA5 was the only protein among the 20 most enriched interactors, to be bound independently by WT-NSD1 and N-terminal NUP98, which suggests a deeply rooted molecular connection with the fusion protein (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] & Tables 2 [this file] and 3 [this file] ). 
We achieved almost equilibrated expression and immunoprecipitation of the mutated constructs (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] D, Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). Strikingly, principal component analysis (PCA) separated the interactomes acquired for the FG-repeat motif deleted fusions and control on the one side, and full-length and PHD1-4 and PHD5-C5HCH deleted fusions on the other side, suggesting a prominent role of the disordered domains in the interactome organization (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] B-D, Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). To assess the impact of the mutated domains on the core interactome, we analyzed the LFQ values of the top 20 NUP98-NSD1 interactors and observed significant perturbations in this core interactome upon deletions of single or both FG repeat domains, whereas deletions of the PHD domains barely affected these interactions (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] C, Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] , Supplementary Tables 4-6 [this file] ). As expected, the interaction with RAE1, mediated by the GLEBS domain of NUP98 moiety, was not affected by FG repeat deletions (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] C, Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] B), indicating that our analysis identified specific, FG-repeat mediated interactions. 
Importantly, the fusion protein kept the nuclear puncta localization pattern, which was dependent on the presence of FG repeats (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). After expansion under antibiotic selection and enrichment by GFP sorting (Supplementary Fig. 5 A [this file] ), we confirmed the presence of NUP98-NSD1 nuclear puncta by immunofluorescence staining (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] A). Giemsa-Wright staining revealed a blast-like morphology of NUP98-NSD1/FLT3-ITD cells (Supplementary Fig. 5 B [this file] ). 
To further examine SMARCA5 function in transformed cells, we performed treatment with an allosteric inhibitor (ED2-AD101) targeting the ATPase activity of the ISWI family of chromatin remodelers (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ) [ 25 [rid=CR25] , 26 [rid=CR26] ], which consistently prevented colony formation in methylcellulose (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). To further address the clinical relevance of ED2-AD101, we treated NUP98-NSD1 patient cells using 10 μM concentration (following the previously calculated IC in transformed murine hematopoietic cells, Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ) and found some increase in expression of the CD11b and CD14 surface markers of myeloid differentiation (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] A). However, due to high cell death (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] B) upon inhibitor treatment we could not characterize the exact effect of the inhibitor, probably caused by the low specificity of the compound.
pub_title: SMARCA5 interacts with NUP98-NSD1 oncofusion protein and sustains hematopoietic cells transformation

PICH Supports Embryonic Hematopoiesis by Suppressing a cGAS‐STING‐Mediated Interferon Response

title: No Title
caption: Supporting Information
description: Supporting  Information  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
There was a clear difference in appearance and weight of the WT and ‐KO embryos (Figure 1D,E [rid=advs3449-fig-0001] ), as well as in the size and cell content of the FL (Figure 1F,G [rid=advs3449-fig-0001] and Figure S1A [this file] , Supporting Information). 
No obvious difference was found in the quantity of LT‐HSC (CD150+ CD48− LSK) (Figure 1H,I [rid=advs3449-fig-0001] and Figure S1B [this file] , Supporting Information). Increased CLP populations and decreased CMP populations were detected in ‐KO FLs (Figure S1C [this file] , Supporting Information). The cell death level of CMP, GMP, and CLP were also elevated in ‐KO FLs (Figure S1D [this file] , Supporting Information). 
Moreover, IFN‐ content was significantly elevated in LSK cells rather than lineage positive cells or LK cells inFLs (Figure S2A [this file] , Supporting Information). We also detected increased IRF7expression both in cytoplasm and nuclear in Pich LSK cells (Figure S2B [this file] , Supporting Information). 
Type I IFNs exert their proproliferation effect on dormant HSCs via the IFN‐ / receptor (IFNAR).[rid=advs3449-bib-0032] ,[rid=advs3449-bib-0033] ,[rid=advs3449-bib-0034] ,[rid=advs3449-bib-0035]To further validate the proproliferation action of PICH deficiency‐induced IFN production in HSCs, we generated and double knock‐out (DKO) embryos via crossing ‐het (heterozygous) mice with ‐KO mice (Figure S3 [this file] A,B, Supporting Information). 
Moreover, we observed that cGAS, STING, IFIT1, and IRF7 protein expression were elevated following deletion (Figure 5B,C [rid=advs3449-fig-0005] ), and that depletion of cGAS suppressed the production of type I interferons (Figure 5B–D [rid=advs3449-fig-0005] and Figure S4A [this file] , Supporting Information). Consistently, we found elevated DNA damage level in LSK cells in our model (Figure S4 [this file] B,C, Supporting Information). 
Finally, the impaired progenitor cell compartments and embryonic anemia seen inmice were rescued by the additional deletion of (Figure 6F,G [rid=advs3449-fig-0006] and Figure S5 [this file] A,B, Supporting Information). 
However, the additional two copies of gene failed to reverse the HSC dysfunctions in ‐KO FLs (Figure S6 [this file] A,B, Supporting Information). 
After being washed twice with staining buffer (PBS containing 1% bovine serum albumin and 0.05% sodium azide), the FL cells were stained with a mixture of metal‐tagged antibodies (see Table S1 [this file] , Supporting Information, for the complete antibodies list).
pub_title: PICH Supports Embryonic Hematopoiesis by Suppressing a cGAS‐STING‐Mediated Interferon Response

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Using the same assay, another 22 chemicals were tested (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
Nevertheless, all three reacted to acid and alkali in the same way as wild-type cells (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ) so we did not proceed with additional analyses. 
Notably, the PDEB1 null mutant differs from both early procyclic forms, which react to acid and alkali, and late procyclic forms, which form projections in response to alkali but do not respond to acid (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
Total numbers are derived from two replicates per cell line (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
We were able to obtain knockouts of CARP3 and 4, however (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). CARP4 null mutants did not show any difference to the parental line when they were subjected to a standard SoMo assay (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ) and were not analysed further. Deletion of CARP3, while not affecting growth in liquid culture (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ) or on plates (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] , d [this file] ), or expression of the early marker GPEET (Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ) resulted in a major SoMo defect (Fig. 6b [rid=Fig6] , upper panel) reminiscent of the PDEB1 null mutant. The CARP3 knockout did not display a motility defect in liquid culture (Supplementary Fig. 4a, b [this file] ) and still reacted to alkali, but did not react to acid on plates (Fig. 6b [rid=Fig6] , lower panel and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
In addition, we engineered an addback ectopically expressing an untagged version of CARP3 (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). In addition, whereas 55–60% of flies heavily infected with the wild type, and 100% heavily infected with the addback, had trypanosomes in the proventriculus, the knockout gave no heavy midgut infections nor did it colonise the proventriculus (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
CARP3 is present in both the cytoplasm and the flagellum (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ; www.tryptag.org (http://www.tryptag.org) ). We obtained null mutants of ACP2 and ACP6, but it was only possible to generate single knockouts of ACP1 and ACP5 (Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] , 7a [this file] ) implying that they are essential at this stage of the life cycle. The full knockout of ACP6 and the semi-knockout of ACP1 both exhibited hyper-SoMo phenotypes, while the full knockout of ACP2 showed no phenotype (Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). In terms of their pH response, ACP5 single knockouts resembled CARP3 double knockouts - they were able to form projections migrating towards an alkaline source, but were refractory to acid (Fig. 6e [rid=Fig6] , lower panel and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). Further experiments showed that >80% of these cells were GPEET-positive and that the phenotype of the ACP5 mutants was not due to defects in growth or motility (Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] – g [this file] ). 
Down-regulation or deletion of ACP6 ( and Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ) or deletion of one copy of ACP1 cause hyper-SoMo, while ACP2 is not required for SoMo or pH taxis.
pub_title: Cyclic AMP signalling and glucose metabolism mediate pH taxis by African trypanosomes

The up-regulation of high-affinity glucose transporters (THT2 and 2A), glycolytic enzymes and components of the glycosome (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] , middle and Supplementary Data 1a [this file] ) is suggestive of higher glucose metabolism by the tip than the root. 
RNA-seq was also performed on the tips of communities exposed to acid or alkali (Fig. 4b [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Data 1b [this file] ).

context_description:
This led to the identification of adenylate cyclases ACP3 and ACP5 in two biological replicates (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). These interactions were confirmed by in situ tagging and co-immunoprecipitation of myc-tagged versions of ACP3 and ACP5 in the CARP3-HA addback line (Fig. 6d [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). The reciprocal co-immunoprecipitations with anti-myc antibody confirmed the interaction for both ACP3 and ACP5 (Fig. 6d [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). 
It is also worth noting that CARP3 interacts with other adenylate cyclases, although ACP3 and ACP5 were the top hits (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ), and that it was recently identified by proximity labelling as interacting with ACP1 .

caption: Figure S2.  In vitro stimulation of BMDM with IFNγ+LPS or IL4 resulted in differentiation into classically activated and alternatively activated macrophage phenotypes, respectively. Cross-polarization, with each stimulus delivered sequentially, resulted in intermediate phenotypes, demonstrating macrophage plasticity. Representative dot plots of cultured BMDM from (a) an  Ifngr1 −/−  mouse (red) compared to a C57BL/6J mouse (black) under M(IFNγ+LPS) stimulation condition and from (b) an Il4ra −/−  mouse (blue) compared to a BALB/cJ mouse (black) under M(IL4) stimulation condition with an inset histogram of the same data.Nos2 and Arg1 expression of WT strains confirm polarization to M(IFNγ+LPS) and M(IL4). (c) Median fluorescent intensity (MFI) of BMDM macrophages in the CD11b + CD16/32+ macrophage gate when exposed to 5 stimulation conditions. CD16/32 was more robustly stimulated by M(IL4) than M(IFNγ+LPS) ( p  < 0.0001). However,  Ifngr1 −/−  BMDM showed the most dramatic increase in CD16/32 MFI, suggesting that IFNγ signaling may modulate the effect of LPS on CD16/32 expression. CD11b showed no clear pattern of response to stimulation, with minimal differences between strains. BALB/cJ and  Il4ra −/−  were analyzed separately, and Tukey groups are indicated by letters/numbers. Groups with the same letter or number are not significantly different. Significance was determined by linear mixed effect model with Tukey post-hoc comparison within stimulation. Significance was set as  p  < 0.05.  n  = 5 mice/strain. nd, no significant difference. (JPG 33 kb)

This revealed that the acral model developed a significantly higher proportion of fin tumours than the cutaneous model (53% versus 30%, < 0.0001) ( Fig. 1e [href=#F1] , Extended Data Fig. 2h [href=#F7] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ).
Whereas in the mosaic acral fish 53% of tumours (110 out of 206) arose on the fins, 84.2% (96 out of 114) of tumours from the acral stable line were fin tumours ( Extended Data Fig. 4c [href=#F9] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ). By contrast, only 39.7% (77 out of 194) of tumours arose on the fins in the cutaneous stable line ( Extended Data Fig. 4c [href=#F9] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ).
To determine which of the acral driver genes were sufficient for fin positioning, we expressed each one individually ( Fig. 2a [href=#F2] ). was the only genetic driver sufficient to form tumours without any additional genetic alterations ( Fig. 2b [href=#F2] , c [href=#F2] ), with 62% -alone tumours occurring in the fins ( Fig. 2d [href=#F2] , e [href=#F2] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ), indicating that fin melanocytes were more efficiently transformed by CRKL compared with other locations. Withdrawal of , or loss from the acral model still demonstrated fin specificity ( Fig. 2h [href=#F2] , i [href=#F2] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ). Whereas 62% (37 out of 60) of tumours arose on the fins in the mosaic fish, we found that 75.8% (25 out of 33) of tumours from -only stable transgenic fish were fin tumours ( Extended Data Fig. 4b [href=#F9] , c [href=#F9] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ).
Numbers of fish and tumours across all replicates and experimental conditions are shown in Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] .
Fish and tumour numbers are shown in Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] .
This modestly slowed tumour initiation ( Extended Data Fig. 10e [href=#F15] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ) and notably led to a robust loss of fin specificity in the acral melanoma model ( Fig. 5k [href=#F5] , l [href=#F5] , Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ).
For gel source data, see Supplementary Fig. 3 [href=this file] . (c) qPCR to validate RNA expression of transgenes. See Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] showing the exact number of fish and corresponding percentages for each replicate.
See Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] for a full list of fish and tumor numbers across all replicates and experimental conditions. (d) Adult WT melanocyte and acral melanoma models were dissected to isolate body skin and fins and then analyzed via flow cytometry.
pub_title: Anatomic position determines oncogenic specificity in melanoma - PMC

We performed pathway analysis comparing fin and body melanocytes, which found that 11 out of 30 of the top pathways in fin melanocytes were related to limb development or anatomic position ( Fig. 3c [href=#F3] , Extended Data Fig. 5e [href=#F10] , f [href=#F10] , Supplementary Table 4 [href=this file] ).
The zebrafish fin versus body bulk RNA-seq experiment is available via the NCBI Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository under identifier code GSE158538 [href=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE158538] , with bulk RNA-seq counts and differential expression tables in Supplementary Table 4 [href=this file] .

A full list of pathways can be found in Supplementary Table 4 [href=this file] . (g) GSEA barcode plot comparing acral model fin vs body melanocytes showing enrichment of genes in the GO: Regulation of Multicellular Organisms Growth pathway, generated weighted WKS testing.

title: NIHMS1816756-supplement-Supplementary_Table_8.xlsx
context_description:
CRKL bound multiple subunits of PI3K, including PIK3CB, PIK3CD and PIK3R2, which are the major downstream mediators of IGF–IGF1R signalling ( Extended Data Fig. 9d [href=#F14] – f [href=#F14] , Supplementary Table 8 [href=this file] ). In addition, we also pulled down many GTPase-activating proteins (GAPs) of RAC and RHO GTPases, such as ARAP1 , ASAP1 and ARHGAP32, and guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) of RAC and RHO, such as C3G, DOCK1 , DOCK5 and the DOCK co-activators ELMO1 and ELMO2 ( Extended Data Fig. 9d [href=#F14] – f [href=#F14] , Supplementary Table 8 [href=this file] ). In contrast to this heavily enriched PI3K-centred mechanism, we found relatively few members of the MAPK pathway (SOS1 and SOS2) ( Extended Data Fig. 9d [href=#F14] – f [href=#F14] , Supplementary Table 8 [href=this file] ).
CRKL immunoprecipitation–mass spectrometry data are available at ProteomeXchange with identifier PXD027968 and in Supplementary Table 8 [href=this file] .
Raw data can be found in Supplementary Table 8 [href=this file] . (f) Volcano plot showing log2 fold enrichment of CRKL-V5 IP vs. control IP (CRKL with no V5 tag). * p-value < 0.05, ** p-value < 0.01, *** p-value < 0.001, **** p-value < 0.0001.

Disease-associated KBTBD4 mutations in medulloblastoma elicit neomorphic ubiquitylation activity to promote CoREST degradation
Disease-associated KBTBD4 mutations in medulloblastoma elicit neomorphic ubiquitylation activity to promote CoREST degradation
Disease-associated KBTBD4 mutations in medulloblastoma elicit neomorphic ubiquitylation activity to promote CoREST degradation

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Figures and legends
context_description:
KBTBD4 mutations recur around the same conserved residues (G308 to R313) in the Kelch domain (Fig. 1A [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. S1 [this file] ). 
A Venn diagram comparing differential interacting partners of KBTBD4 , KBTBD4 and KBTBD4 identified in LC-MS/MS is presented in Supplementary Fig. S2A [this file] . 
Interaction of exogenously expressed CoREST was also observed with KBTBD4 and KBTBD4 but not KBTBD4 after immunoprecipitation of CoREST (Supplementary Fig. S2B [this file] ). 
We also observed that CoREST ubiquitylation was prevented by MLN4924 (Supplementary Fig. S2C [this file] ) as predicted from the results of immunoprecipitation analysis (Fig. 1D [rid=Fig1] ). 
In DAOY medulloblastoma cell lines, we could detect interaction of endogenous CoREST with KBTBD4 , but not with KBTBD4 as in HEK293T (Supplementary Fig. S3A [this file] ). Expression of mutant KBTBD4 or KBTBD4 , but not KBTBD4 , promoted a drastic reduction in CoREST levels, which could be restored by treating cells with the proteasome inhibitor MG132 (Supplementary Fig. S3B [this file] ), showing that CoREST is targeted for proteasomal degradation by KBTBD4 mutants, but not KBTBD4 , in accordance with the interaction data. MLN4924 similarly prevented the degradation of CoREST in DAOY cell lines expressing KBTBD4 or KBTBD4 , demonstrating a role for CRL activity in controlling the levels of CoREST (Supplementary Fig. S3C [this file] ). 
All lines showed detectable CoREST and LSD1 proteins (Supplementary Fig. S3D [this file] ). Cells expressing mutant KBTBD4 showed a reduction in CoREST protein level, whereas these levels were unchanged by expression of KBTBD4 (Supplementary Fig. S3E [this file] ), consistent with data from other medulloblastoma cell lines. 
Minimal induction of KBTBD4 with the lowest doxycycline dose still promoted CoREST degradation (Supplementary Fig. S3F [this file] ). By contrast, the highest expression of KBTBD4 did not alter CoREST levels (Supplementary Fig. S3F [this file] ). In addition to CoREST, LSD1 was also degraded, although at a seemingly reduced level compared to CoREST (Supplementary Fig. S3F [this file] ). 
The increase in the epigenetic mark H3K4me2 was also confirmed by Western blotting in D283Med and DAOY cell lines (Supplementary Fig. S3G, H [this file] ). 
To identify the transcriptional programmes promoted by mutant KBTBD4, we compared total RNA-seq samples in quadruplicates from D283Med cells where expression of KBTBD4 , KBTBD4 or KBTBD4 was promoted by doxycycline untreated controls (Supplementary Fig. S4A, B [this file] ). Although we detected a significant induction of KBTBD4 , a volcano plot and heatmap of differentially expressed genes revealed that KBTBD4 did not promote significant transcriptional changes (Fig. 3A [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. S4B [this file] ). 
To confirm that the transcriptional alterations detected are consistent in different models we also used the D425Med cell line, where expression of KBTBD4 or KBTBD4 faithfully leads to CoREST degradation (Supplementary Fig. S2E [this file] ). Using quantitative PCR (qPCR) in cells expressing KBTBD4 or KBTBD4 we could detect the upregulation of multiple CoREST targets (Supplementary Fig. S4C [this file] ), confirming the role of mutant KBTBD4 in different model cell lines. 
Interestingly, the changes observed in gene expression after induction of KBTBD4 mutants could be in part recapitulated by siRNA mediated depletion of CoREST, reinforcing the idea that KBTBD4 mutants are mainly acting through CoREST depletion (Supplementary Fig. S3D [this file] ). 
Surprisingly, we did not detect a significant difference in the proliferation of cells (Supplementary Fig. S5A [this file] ), indicating that other features enable KBTBD4 mutants to promote tumorigenesis. In addition, Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) showed that epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT), a fundamental pathway for vertebrate embryonic development and often linked to cell migration and metastatic potential of cancer cells [ 21 [rid=CR21] ], was significantly enriched in cell lines expressing either KBTBD4 mutant (Supplementary Fig. S5B [this file] ). In adherent medulloblastoma cells, we also could detect an increased migration of cells expressing KBTBD4 (Supplementary Fig. S5C [this file] ), supporting our GSEA analysis. 
Note that the increased tumorsphere formation can’t be ascribed to increased cell proliferation as this remains unchanged (Supplementary Fig. S5A [this file] ). 
In a second assay to measure stemness, we observed that KBTBD4 and KBTBD4 expression more than doubled the percentage of D283Med cells presenting with high ALDH activity compared to cells expressing KBTBD4 (Supplementary Fig. S5D [this file] ). More importantly, chemical inhibition of LSD1 (LSD1i) was found to mimic this phenotype and the combination of KBTBD4 mutant plus LSD1i did not show an additive effect (Fig. 4D [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. S5C [this file] ), showing that the increased stemness caused by KBTBD4 and KBTBD4 is exerted via modulation of CoREST complex activity. 
While GFI1 and GFI1B overexpressing tumours show high LSD1 activity that could be blocked using specific chemical inhibitors [ 30 [rid=CR30] ], our findings show that inhibition of LSD1 increases stemness (Fig. 4D [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. S5D [this file] ), raising caution over the use of LSD1 inhibitors in the treatment of specific subtypes of medulloblastoma. Our data also indicate that KBTBD4 mutation leads cells into an intermediate state of differentiation, keeping ES-like and EMT gene signatures (Fig. 4A, B [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. S5A [this file] ) while expressing differentiated features of several synaptic pathways (Fig. 3D, E [rid=Fig3] ).
pub_title: Disease-associated KBTBD4 mutations in medulloblastoma elicit neomorphic ubiquitylation activity to promote CoREST degradation

context_description:
We identified a total of 487 unique pTyr sites assigned to 310 unique phosphoproteins ( table S1 [href=this file] ). Our analysis found that phosphorylation of STAT3 (pTyr , −3.76-fold), FRS2 (pTyr , −7.58-fold), MAPK1 (pTyr , −2.65-fold), and PTPN6 (pTyr , 2.34-fold) are reduced by crizotinib in H3122 cells ( table S1 [href=this file] ), indicating that these proteins are common components of EML4-ALK signaling.
Our quantitative phosphoproteomics analysis found that crizotinib decreased phosphorylation of FRS2 ( table S1 [href=this file] ).
We found that inhibition of ALK increased the phosphorylation of CC2D1A at pTyr ( table S1 [href=this file] ).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
The three homologues, which we named NOT4A, -B and -C (AT5G60170, AT3G45630 and AT2G28540, respectively), possess 38–39% identity with NOT4 (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ), and crucially share high identity across the unique combination of RING, RRM and C3H1 domains. We isolated homozygous T-DNA insertion lines for from publicly available collections (GABI-KAT, SALK and SAIL) and confirmed T-DNA inserts and full-length mRNA knockout (Supplementary Fig. 2A, B [this file] ). 
For full sequence alignments see Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] . , Representative rosette images of 4-week-old col-0, mutants, and two independent complementation lines ( and ) grown under long day (LD) conditions. 
Two independent transgenic lines expressing the full-length NOT4A protein (N4A-G1 and N4A-G3, Supplementary Fig. 2C [this file] ), displayed wild-type greenness and normal development (Fig. 1c–e [rid=Fig1] ), and NOT4A expression, determined by GUS staining, was localized to the first true leaves of seedlings where the pale mutant phenotype first presents (Fig. 1g [rid=Fig1] ). 
This revealed a large number of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in the mutant relative to WT (>2300 genes, < 0.05), with GO-analysis showing that a large proportion of these are chloroplast-related and implicated across all structures of this organelle (Fig. 2a, b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] and Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM4] ). Carbon assimilation in stroma is undertaken by an array of higher order enzymatic complexes present within the internal membrane system of chloroplasts (thylakoids), which includes many nuclear-encoded components that were mis-regulated in the transcriptome (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] and Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ) . This revealed in a severe decrease in the accumulation of protein bands corresponding to the photosystem II monomer and cytochrome b f complex (PSII m/ Cyt b f), as well as the photosystem I - NAD(P)H dehydrogenase megacomplex (PSI-NDH), when equal protein was loaded (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 4A [this file] ). Individual subunits were then resolved by a second denaturing dimension, which confirmed lower abundance of the PetA, -B, -C and -D cytochrome b f complex subunits (Fig. 2d [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 4B [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Fig. 4A [this file] . 
Analysis of the chloroplast-specific proteins in these datasets (619 in WT, 689 in Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] ) confirmed reduced levels of all detected subunits making up the cytochrome b f and NDH complexes, but also revealed that components of many other plastid enzyme complexes were mis-regulated (either increased or decreased in abundance) (Supplementary Fig. 4C [this file] and Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ). 
Values are quantified from Tapestation data shown in Supplementary Fig. 5, [this file] following normalisation to cytosolic 18 s rRNA. 
We also observed a significant reduction of chloroplast 30 S-associated 16 S rRNA in relative to WT, while levels of the 50 S-associated 23 S and 23 Sb rRNAs were similar or slightly increased (Fig. 3e [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
In contrast, no obvious differences in the sensitivity to the cytosolic ribosome inhibitor cycloheximide were observed (Supplementary Fig. 6A [this file] ). 
These mutations were based on conserved homologies to yeast NOT4 where the activities of both domains were successfully knocked out previously (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ) . 
Mutations in black are those introduced to the gene, which correspond to equivalent conserved residues in NOT4 (shown in grey), additionally highlighted in Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] sequence alignments. anti-GUS western blot of steady state levels of -GUS variants expressed in . 
Amongst these genes were 34 chloroplast-targeted PPR proteins, which collectively may be upregulated to compensate for compromised chloroplast translation in the mutant (Supplementary Fig. 6B [this file] , Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ) . Interestingly, we found that mRNA encoding one of these chloroplast-targeted PPR proteins, PROTON GRADIENT REGULATION 3 (PGR3) (AT4G31850), was downregulated to undetectable levels in , but restored to WT levels in the N4A-G3 complementation line (Fig. 6b [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 6B [this file] ). As such, mutants have reduced levels of cytochrome b f and NDH, similar to (Fig. 2c–e [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 4A, B, D [this file] ) . 
Values are quantified from Tapestation data shown in Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] , following normalisation to cytosolic 18 s rRNA. 
Reduced transcripts of and , but not , and , were detected in both and relative to their respective wildtypes, consistent with the requirement for PGR3 in stabilising these two RNAs (Fig. 6f [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 6C, D [this file] ). In contrast, steady state protein levels of the Rubisco subunit RBCL, PSII subunits D1 and PsbP, and the PSI-associated protein LHCA4 were not significantly altered relative to WT in either mutant under nonstressed conditions (Supplementary Fig. 4E [this file] ). Furthermore, there is a significant reduction in the 30 S associated 16 S rRNA in both mutants (Fig. 6g [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
We observed enhanced levels of SVR7 protein in relative to WT (Supplementary Fig. 6B [this file] ), perhaps compensating for loss of , and explaining why 50 S subunits are not affected in the mutant. The upregulation of PPR proteins SOT1, EMB2654, PPR4 and PPR2 (which all promote chloroplast rRNA maturation), and GUN1 (implicated in the production of chloroplast ribosomal subunits RPS1 and RPL11) present further evidence of compensatory responses to reduced ribosome abundance and protein synthesis within chloroplasts (Supplementary Fig. 6B [this file] ) . 
We therefore investigated the effect of ectopic xpression on phenotypes by transforming and Col-0 with a functional construct capable of complementing (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). PGR3-YFP protein levels were comparable across the Col-0 and lines, while transcripts were elevated between 2- and 6-fold above WT levels in all transgenics, with specific qPCR corroborating the proportional pattern of expression between lines (Fig. 7a, b [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 7B [this file] ). 
Experiment was replicated at least 3 times (see Supplementary Fig. 7D [this file] for further repeats). 10-day-old Col-0, and PGR3-YFP transgenic seedlings grown on vertical plates ±10 µM lincomycin. 
PGR3-YFP localized as expected within chloroplasts in both backgrounds (Fig. 7c [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 7D [this file] ). This is further supported by an inability to detect ubiquitin modification of immunoprecipitated PGR3-YFP (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ) and an absence of a protein-protein interaction between NOT4A and PGR3 when assayed by yeast two-hybrid (Fig. 7g [rid=Fig7] ). 
Remarkably however, introduction of the transgene was able to complement the pale-yellow and lincomycin-sensitive phenotypes of , despite the lack of expression (Fig. 7d, e [rid=Fig7] and Supplementary Fig. 7C [this file] ). 
Homozygous T-DNA insertions were identified by PCR with primers designed by T-DNA express and null expression confirmed by RT-PCR (Supplementary Fig. 2A, B [this file] ).

context_description:
This revealed a large number of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in the mutant relative to WT (>2300 genes, < 0.05), with GO-analysis showing that a large proportion of these are chloroplast-related and implicated across all structures of this organelle (Fig. 2a, b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [rid=MOESM1] and Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
To identify potential causal agents of the phenotypic defects in we analysed the DEGs annotated with chloroplast functions (GO:0009507) in the RNA-seq dataset (Fig. 6a [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Data 2
context_description:
Carbon assimilation in stroma is undertaken by an array of higher order enzymatic complexes present within the internal membrane system of chloroplasts (thylakoids), which includes many nuclear-encoded components that were mis-regulated in the transcriptome (Supplementary Fig. 3 [rid=MOESM1] and Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ) . 
To complement our RNA-seq analysis and investigate differences in protein abundance in vs WT in more detail, we carried out a quantitative proteomics analysis of total protein extracts from 30-day-old whole plants as previously described (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). Analysis of the chloroplast-specific proteins in these datasets (619 in WT, 689 in Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] ) confirmed reduced levels of all detected subunits making up the cytochrome b f and NDH complexes, but also revealed that components of many other plastid enzyme complexes were mis-regulated (either increased or decreased in abundance) (Supplementary Fig. 4C [rid=MOESM1] and Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). 
See also Supplementary Data 2 [this file] . 
In addition to a reduction of photosynthetic proteins, we also observed a significant downregulation or absence of plastid ribosome proteins in (Fig. 3b, f [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). The reduction of 30 S subunits was only apparent at the protein level, as transcripts of the nuclear-encoded subunits were in fact elevated in the RNA-seq data (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). 
Amongst these genes were 34 chloroplast-targeted PPR proteins, which collectively may be upregulated to compensate for compromised chloroplast translation in the mutant (Supplementary Fig. 6B [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ) .
pub_title: RETRACTED ARTICLE:The Arabidopsis NOT4A E3 ligase promotes PGR3 expression and regulates chloroplast translation

Arabidopsis lines were transformed with the genomic sequences of (AT5G60170) and (AT4G31850) plus ~2KB of the upstream promoters cloned into Invitrogen pENTR™/D-TOPO™ (ThermoFisher- K240020) (For primer sequences see Supplementary Data 3 [this file] ) and sequenced before ligations into pGWB533 and pGWB540 constructs respectively , using the (GV3101 pMP90) floral dip method .

caption: Appendix
description: Appendix  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
Patient 2 showed developmental delay (Appendix Table S1 [this file] ). 
S1P could still be detected after elimination of the mitochondrial outer membrane, which indicated that S1P resides in the mitochondrial matrix space (Appendix Fig S1 [this file] ). 
To explore the molecular mechanism underlying the inflammatory symptoms, we screened S1P interactors by Co‐IP and liquid chromatography‐tandem mass spectrometry (LC–MS/MS) and identified 29 potential candidates (Hosp , 2015 [rid=emmm202114904-bib-0022] ) (Fig 3A [rid=emmm202114904-fig-0003] , Appendix Table S2 [this file] ). We demonstrated a stable association between S1P and the ETFA/ETFB complex in HaCaT cells through a Co‐IP assay (Fig 3C [rid=emmm202114904-fig-0003] , Appendix Fig S2A [this file] ). Correspondingly, IVD, LYRM5, SARDH, and ACADS, known interactors with ETF, were immunoprecipitated from HaCaT cells with anti‐ETFB antibodies (Kim & Miura, 2004 [rid=emmm202114904-bib-0023] ; Floyd , 2016 [rid=emmm202114904-bib-0014] ) (Appendix Fig S2B [this file] ). S1P associated with SARDH (a known ETF substrate) in HaCaT cells (Appendix Fig S2C [this file] ). 
In addition, S1P reduced the association between ETFB and LYRM5 (a deflavinase of ETF) (Floyd , 2016 [rid=emmm202114904-bib-0014] ) but increased the association between ETFB and ACADS (a known ETF substrate) (Kim & Miura, 2004 [rid=emmm202114904-bib-0023] ) (Appendix Fig S2D [this file] ). 
No significant change in the concentration of succinate was observed (Fig 5B [rid=emmm202114904-fig-0005] , panel 3), and moderate accumulation of metabolic intermediates in the TCA cycle, such as succinyl‐CoA (by 147.8%) (Fig 5B [rid=emmm202114904-fig-0005] , panel 4), citrate (by 56.2%), oxaloacetate (by 55.8%), and α‐ketoglutarate (KG) (by 100.1%), was observed in HaCaT cells (Appendix Fig S3A [this file] ). 
Furthermore, we observed a compensatory increase in glycolytic metabolites, such as pyruvate (by 205.3%), ‐lactate (by 41.7%) (Fig 5B [rid=emmm202114904-fig-0005] , panels 5–6), D‐fructose 1,6‐bisphosphate (FDP) (by 50.7%), dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) (by 2160.4%), and phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) (by 578.3%) (Appendix Fig S3B [this file] ), in KO HaCaT cells compared with the control. 
Given that S1P maintains the stability of ETF, we measured palmitoyl‐CoA‐induced enzymatic activity in ‐KO HaCaT cells and controls. ‐KO HaCaT cells exhibited impaired FAO activity compared with control cells (Appendix Fig S3C [this file] ). 
All antibodies and dilutions used for immunoblotting, immunohistochemistry, immunofluorescence, and immunoprecipitation were described in the Appendix Table S3 [this file] .

context_description:
These in vitro findings are in line with ZNF750 studies of normal human skin sections, showing weak staining of nuclei in the suprabasal spinous layer as compared with strong staining in granular layer nuclei [15] [rid=pone.0042628-Sen1] and the sebaceous glands ( Figure S1 [this file] ). 
Furthermore, ZNF750 acts in terminal KC differentiation: ZNF750 is expressed in suprabasal layers, and its expression is dramatically increased in the granular layer ( Figure S1 [this file] ), [15] [rid=pone.0042628-Sen1] .

context_description:
Genome mapping indicated that like KRAS-induced PCGs, there is no specific chromosomal preference of the KRAS-induced lncRNAs ( Figure S1A [href=this file] ).
The qRT-PCR results verified that and the six lncRNAs were significantly induced by KRAS expression in a time-dependent manner, whereas the expression of was significantly decreased ( Figure S1B [href=this file] ). EGF or IGF-1 stimulation did not significantly increase Orilnc1 expression in MCF10 cells which expressed wild-type RAS and RAF ( Figure S1C [href=this file] ) suggesting that the up-regulation of might be an oncogenic growth promoting effect. There was no significant growth inhibition in MCF10A cells ( Figure S1D [href=this file] ).

description: Fig.  S1  .  (A)  Illustration  of  CD24  isoform  expression  in  GCT  and  testis  tissues  as  well  as  other  cancer  entities  and  corresponding  tissues  of  origin  based  on  the  TCGA  and  GTEX  cohorts.  Location  of  ‘primers’  used  in  this  study  for  qRT‐PCR  analysis  of  various  isoforms  are  indicated  by  purple  arrow  heads.  (B)  RNA  sequencing  data  of  CD24  expression  throughout  various  cancer  types  based  on  data  extracted  from  TCGA.  Data  has  been  illustrated  using  ‘Firebrowse’. (F)  Immunohistochemical  staining  of  CD24  in  normal  testis  tissue.  (G)  Mutational  burden  of  CD24  in  GCT  tissues  based  on  the  TCGA  ‘testicular  germ  cell  tumor’  cohort.  Data  has  been  illustrated  using  ‘cBioPortal’.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
The gene coding for is located on chromosome 6q21 and encodes for eight transcript variants (Fig. S1 [this file] A). The isoform , which lacks exons 1, 3, and 4, is predominately found in GCTs, while the isoforms . (lacking parts of exons 1 and 5, and exons 2, 3, and 4) can be found very rarely (Fig. S1 [this file] A). In other CD24 cancer entities (origin: bladder, prostate, kidney, skin, lung, liver, brain, and ovary), we found a similar expression profile with predominant expression of and very weak expression of (Fig. S1 [this file] A). 
We compared expression of is a broad range of human malignancies by screening the ‘The Cancer Genome Atlas’ (TCGA) database. is expressed in the majority of analyzed cancers (Fig. S1 [this file] B). Expression intensity of the isoform was negligibly low in all GCT cell lines and control cells (Fig. 1B [rid=mol213066-fig-0001] , Fig. S1 [this file] A). Additionally, in EC cells, the CD24 band patterning suggested different levels of post‐translational modifications, that is, glycosylation (Fig. S1 [this file] C). Next, we stained GCNIS ( = 46), seminoma ( = 74), EC ( = 27), YST ( = 15), and CC ( = 3) tissues for CD24 by IHC (Fig. 1C [rid=mol213066-fig-0001] ; Fig. S1 [this file] D). GCNIS was completely CD24 (Fig. 1C [rid=mol213066-fig-0001] ; Fig. S1 [this file] D). 93% of ECs were CD24 , while only 15% of seminoma cell components in mixed GCT setting and 18% of pure seminomas were CD24 (Fig. 1C [rid=mol213066-fig-0001] ; Fig. S1 [this file] D). Nevertheless, CD24 stained considerably weaker in YST (FOXA2 [ 38 [rid=mol213066-bib-0038] ]) and CC tissues compared with EC cells (OCT3/4 ) (Fig. 1C [rid=mol213066-fig-0001] ; Fig. S1 [this file] E). Of note, germ cells of different developmental stages (spermatogonia to sperm) were negative for CD24, which is in contrast to earlier findings in mice, which found a CD24 spermatogonial population (Fig. S1 [this file] F) [ 63 [rid=mol213066-bib-0063] ]. 
Next, we screened the TCGA GCT cohort for mutations in the gene locus (Fig. S1 [this file] G). The vast majority of analyzed samples was extracted from testes, harbored the 12p gain, a high aneuploidy score, and was in the typical GCT age of 14–44 years at time point of diagnosis (Fig. S1 [this file] G).
pub_title: The signal transducer CD24 suppresses the germ cell program and promotes an ectodermal rather than mesodermal cell fate in embryonal carcinomas

Location of oligonucleotides used for sodium bisulfite sequencing analysis are indicated by purple arrow heads. Start of exon 1 is labeled by green arrow head. (B) Sodium bisulfite sequencing results of ten CpG dinucleotides in the  CD24  CpG island in GCT cell lines. Each cell line has been analyzed in sextuplicate. White circle: unmethylated CpG dinucleotide; black circle: methylated CpG dinucleotide. (C) Validation of CpG methylation data by methylation‐specific PCR of the region analyzed in (B) and the alternative promotor of the  CD24  main isoform (see Fig. 2 E, gray box). (D) Immunohistochemical staining of GCT tissues for CD24 (SWA11 antibody). The same samples as used for  CD24  CpG island DNA methylation analyses were stained. Location  of  oligonucleotides  used  for  sodium  bisulfite  sequencing  analysis  are  indicated  by  purple  arrow  heads.  Start  of  exon  1  is  labeled  by  green  arrow  head.  (B)  Sodium  bisulfite  sequencing  results  of  ten  CpG  dinucleotides  in  the  CD24  CpG  island  in  GCT  cell  lines.  Each  cell  line  has  been  analyzed  in  sextuplicate.  White  circle:  unmethylated  CpG  dinucleotide;  black  circle:  methylated  CpG  dinucleotide. (D)  Immunohistochemical  staining  of  GCT  tissues  for  CD24  (SWA11  antibody).  The  same  samples  as  used  for  CD24  CpG  island  DNA  methylation  analyses  were  stained.  (E)  Sodium  bisulfite  sequencing  results  (n  =  6)  of  the  CD24  CpG  island  in  JAR  cells  96  h  after  application  of  20  and  50  nM  Decitabine.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
Thus, we performed sodium bisulfite sequencing of a region upstream the transcription start site containing ten CpG dinucleotides and classified as a CpG island in GCT cell lines and tissues (Fig. S2 [this file] A). InCC cell lines, methylation varied between 1.7% (JEG3), 50% (BeWo), and 100% (JAR), while all other cell lines analyzed harbored a strongly hypomethylated CpG island (TCam‐2: 10%; 2102EP: 1.7%; NCCIT: 0%; NT2/D1: 0%; 1411H: 0%; GCT72: 0%; and MPAF fibroblasts: 0%) (Fig. 2B [rid=mol213066-fig-0002] ; Fig. S2 [this file] B). Microdissected cells from seminoma, EC, YST, and CC tissues ( = 3) showed a sample‐dependent hypo‐ or hypermethylation (Fig. 2B [rid=mol213066-fig-0002] , Fig. S2 [this file] B). We validated these data in JAR, JEG3, and BeWo by performing PCR using a methylation‐specific (MS) primer and found a similar DNA methylation profile (Fig. S2 [this file] C). Additionally, we analyzed CpG methylation around the alternative promoter region of the main isoform (Fig. 2E [rid=mol213066-fig-0002] , gray box) by MS‐PCR (Fig. S2 [this file] B). Here, we also found the same DNA methylation profile as before, suggesting that the DNA methylation profile is comparable across the analyzed CpG island (Fig. S2 [this file] B). 
To correlate sample‐specific DNA methylation to CD24 protein levels, we performed IHC of related GCT samples and found that DNA methylation levels did not correlate to CD24 protein levels (Fig. 2B [rid=mol213066-fig-0002] , Fig. S2 [this file] D). Within each sample, we found the CpG island either fully methylated or completely demethylated, mimicking an imprinting‐like DNA methylation pattern (Fig. S2 [this file] B). 
By sodium bisulfite sequencing, we demonstrated that upregulation of expression coincided with demethylation of the CpG island in JAR cells 96 h after 20 (to 33%) and 50 n (to 10%) decitabine treatment (Fig. S2 [this file] E). 
Again, we found upregulation of in JEG3, BeWo, TCam‐2, GCT72, and JAR, but not in 2102EP, after 16 h of treatment (Fig. S2 [this file] D). How do other epidrugs, such as inhibitors against histone demethylases (HDMi; JIB‐04), histone methyltransferases (HMTi; GSK343), E3 ubiquitin ligases (E3‐ULi; PRT4165), and bromodomain‐containing proteins (BRDi, MZ‐1, and LP99), affect expression in GCT cell lines (for IC concentrations, see Fig. S2 [this file] E)?

context_description:
Thus, we treated TCam‐2, 2102EP, GCT72, and JAR for 16 h with individual IC concentrations (Fig. S3 [this file] A) of the histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDACi) quisinostat, resulting in histone H3 hyperacetylation (Fig. S3 [this file] B) and upregulation of in all cell lines showing negligible mRNA/CD24 protein levels (TCam‐2, GCT27, and JAR) (Fig. 2D [rid=mol213066-fig-0002] ). In CD24 2102EP cells, HDAC inhibition had no effect on expression (Fig. 2D [rid=mol213066-fig-0002] ), which we confirmed on protein level by western blotting (Fig. S3 [this file] C). Additionally, we confirmed upregulation of CD24 upon quisinostat treatment (16 h, 5 n ) in JAR cells by western blotting (Fig. S3 [this file] C). 
Therefore, we treated GDF3 /CD24 TCam‐2 and JAR cells with recombinant GDF3 (50, 100 n ; 48–72 h) (Fig. S3 [this file] E). 
To be able to sort the different cell populations after co‐cultivation by flow cytometry, we generated GFP GCT and mCherry /DeepRed microenvironmental cells (Fig. S3 [this file] F). Purity of isolated cell populations was demonstrated by qRT‐PCR analysis of (fibroblast marker), (M2 macrophage marker), (T‐lymphocyte marker), and / (endothelial cell marker) expression; , and expression was only detectable in HVHF2, THP‐1‐M2, JURKAT, or HUVEC cell populations, respectively (Fig. S3 [this file] G).

context_description:
To decipher the molecular function of CD24 in more detail, we generated ‐deficient NCCIT and 2102EP EC cell lines ( = 5) by the CRISPR/Cas9 method (Fig. S4 [this file] A,B). In ‐deficient clones (−Δ ), /CD24 was strongly reduced compared with parental cells (−) as demonstrated by qRT‐PCR, flow cytometric, and western blot analyses (Fig. 3A,B [rid=mol213066-fig-0003] ; Fig. S4 [this file] C). 
Only RNA samples with a RNA quality value of > 9 were used (Fig. S4 [this file] D). Additionally, we performed a short‐time siRNA‐mediated knockdown of expression in NCCIT cells, resulting in a considerable decrease in the CD24 protein level 48 h after transfection (Fig. S4 [this file] E). By qRT‐PCR analysis, we validated downregulation of , and LIN28, upregulation of , and and unchanged expression of and as found by the RNA‐seq analysis (Fig. S4 [this file] E; Table S4 [rid=mol213066-sup-0009] A). 
We confirmed this increase in 5mC levels by DNA dot blotting using a 5mC antibody (Fig. S4 [this file] F). 
In our RNA‐seq analysis and related qRT‐PCR validation, was upregulated 3.7‐fold in NCCIT‐Δ cells compared with the parental clones (Table S4 [rid=mol213066-sup-0009] A; Fig. S4 [this file] D).

description: Table  S4  .  RNA  seq,  850k  DNA  methylation  array  and  MSA  data.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
We performed RNA‐seq of NCCIT‐Δ ( = 5) and parental cells ( = 2) to screen for differences in the transcriptome caused by deficiency (Table S4 [this file] A). On mRNA level, we detected 287 genes upregulated (representing genes negatively regulated by CD24) and 465 genes downregulated (representing genes positively regulated by CD24) in NCCIT‐Δ cells versus parental cells (fold change (FC) > log 3) (Fig. 4B [rid=mol213066-fig-0004] ; Table S4 [this file] B). was among the set of genes strongly downregulated in NCCIT‐Δ cells (FC: ‐ log 5.3) (Fig. 4B [rid=mol213066-fig-0004] ). By the STRING and DAVID algorithm, we predicted interaction and biological processes/functions of deregulated genes, respectively (Fig. 4C,D [rid=mol213066-fig-0004] ; Table S4 [this file] B). Regarding differentiation, in detail genes associated with germ cell/spermatogenesis ( , / , , / , , / , ), limb (mesoderm; , / , ), heart (mesoderm; , , , , ), uterus (mesoderm; / , ), and skeletal (mesoderm; , / , , ) development were upregulated (Table S4 [this file] B). By qRT‐PCR analysis, we validated downregulation of , and LIN28, upregulation of , and and unchanged expression of and as found by the RNA‐seq analysis (Fig. S4 [rid=mol213066-sup-0004] E; Table S4 [this file] A). Furthermore, by using liquid chromatography paired with mass spectrometry (LC‐MS), we took a proteome snapshot of NCCIT‐Δ ( = 5) and parental cells ( = 3) (Table S4 [this file] C). A PCA demonstrated that NCCIT‐Δ cells clearly clustered apart from parental cells (Fig. S5 [rid=mol213066-sup-0005] A). 163 proteins were significantly enriched in the proteome of NCCIT‐Δ compared with NCCIT‐CD24 cells, and 99 were depleted (> FC 2) (Fig. S5 [rid=mol213066-sup-0005] B; Table S4 [this file] D). By utilizing the STRING and DAVID algorithm again, we demonstrated that these proteins are involved in similar processes as found when analyzing the RNA‐seq data (Fig. S5 [rid=mol213066-sup-0005] C,D; Table S4 [this file] D). Additionally, in the sets of enriched and depleted proteins, we found proteins associated with chromatin and protein modifications, such as acetylation, methylation, ubiquitination, and citrullination (Fig. S5 [rid=mol213066-sup-0005] C,D, Table S4 [this file] D). 
Therefore, we analyzed changes in DNA methylation (5mC) in ‐deficient NCCIT and 2102EP cells compared with parental controls by Infinium MethylationEPIC bead arrays (Fig. 5 [rid=mol213066-fig-0005] , Table S4 [this file] E). We identified 3157 differentially methylated CpG dinucleotides (2227 5mC up; 930 5mC down; ΔM‐value: 1.5) in NCCIT (Δ vs. control) and 5300 in 2102EP (3429 5mC up; 1871 5mC down) (Fig. 5C [rid=mol213066-fig-0005] ; Table S4 [this file] E). Changes in DNA methylation of these differentially methylated CpGs occurred mainly in CpG island context and around transcription start sites (TSS220, TSS1500) (Fig. 5D [rid=mol213066-fig-0005] ). 163 CpG dinucleotides were commonly altered in ‐deficient NCCIT and 2102EP cells (104 5mC up; 59 5mC down) (Table S4 [this file] C). In NCCIT cells, we correlated changes in 5mC to changes in gene expression (GEX) found by the RNA‐seq analysis (Fig. 5E,F [rid=mol213066-fig-0005] ; Table S4 [this file] F). For subsequent analysis, we only considered genes linked to a known ‘gene symbol’ and with significant alterations in DNA methylation (difference in ‐values > 1.5) in at least three CpG dinucleotides in all three ‐deficient samples and with a significant difference in gene expression of FC > log 1.5 (Table S4 [this file] F). Additionally, we identified genes upregulated in expression and showing an increase in DNA methylation (Group 3), but found no gene showing downregulation in expression and a decrease in DNA methylation (Fig. 5F [rid=mol213066-fig-0005] , Table S4 [this file] F). 
In our RNA‐seq analysis and related qRT‐PCR validation, was upregulated 3.7‐fold in NCCIT‐Δ cells compared with the parental clones (Table S4 [this file] A; Fig. S4 [rid=mol213066-sup-0004] D).

Gene-specific primers pairs were designed with the Primer 3 software (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). First and second strand cDNA synthesis were performed using the ™ kit (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) with RT/Platinum® (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) and using primers specific for the genes of interest (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
As a first step to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying the seasonal reorganization in the cambial zone, we examined the transcriptional pattern of 26 genes (Figure 1 [rid=F1] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) related to specific pathways of plant primary metabolism: glycolysis, ethanolic fermentation, TCA cycle and carbon fixation.

title: NIHMS957484-supplement-Supplementary_Figures_1-18.pdf
context_description:
We generated WGBS DNA methylome profiles for four stages of zebrafish, and mouse embryogenesis corresponding to the blastula (1,000-cell stage , st. 9, E3.5 inner cell mass (ICM) ), gastrula (80% epiboly, st. 12.5, E7.5 ( ref. 8 [href=#R8] )), pharyngula (24 h.p.f., st. 30, E9.5) and tailbud/fetus (48 h.p.f., st. 43, E14.5) stages (for details on non-conversion rates and sequencing metrics, see Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ).
To identify genomic regions displaying developmental changes in 5mC levels, we searched the DNA methylome profiles for differentially methylated regions (DMRs; false discovery rate (FDR) = 0.05, minimum change in the fraction of methylated CpG sites (ΔmCG) = 0.2), identifying thousands of localized changes in methylation state that occur during embryonic development in each species ( Fig. 1b [href=#F1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a,b and Supplementary Tables 2–20 [href=this file] ). The identified DMRs displayed a median ΔmCG of 0.33–0.53 (zebrafish), 0.29–0.44 ( ) and 0.27–0.53 (mouse) ( Supplementary igs. 2–4 [href=this file] ). In zebrafish embryos, whereas the transition from the 1,000-cell stage (blastula) to the stage with 80% epiboly (gastrula) was characterized by both developmental hyper- and hypomethylation ( Fig. 1b [href=#F1] and Supplementary Fig. 2a,b [href=this file] ), the transitions associated with the phylotypic stage were overwhelmingly characterized by developmental hypomethylation (median ΔmCG = 0.33–0.44; Fig. 1b [href=#F1] and Supplementary Fig. 2 [href=this file] ). A similar trend could be observed in embryos, where almost no DMRs were identified between the blastula and gastrula stages ( Supplementary Fig. 1a [href=this file] ) and 5mC remodeling was mostly limited to demethylation (ΔmCG = 0.29–0.44) surrounding the phylotypic stage ( Fig. 1b [href=#F1] and Supplementary Fig. 3a,b [href=this file] ). Similarly, the majority of mouse DMRs found between the late gastrula (E7.5) and tailbud (E14.5) stages were being developmentally demethylated (ΔmCG = 0.38–0.43; Fig. 1b [href=#F1] and Supplementary Fig. 4 [href=this file] ).
We identified 63 conserved (shared by all species) and significantly enriched (FDR ≤ 0.01) terms for early phylotypic DMRs (late gastrula–phylotypic stage demethylation) and 70 such terms for late phylotypic DMRs (phylotypic stage–tailbud/fetus demethylation) ( Fig. 1c [href=#F1] and Supplementary Tables 21 and 22 [href=this file] ). Early mouse DMRs that became hypomethylated between E3.5 and E7.5 as well as later-stage DMRs that became hypermethylated between E9.5 and E14.5 were enriched in GO categories associated with embryonic development; however, these stages yielded far fewer significant categories than the ones associated with the phylotypic transitions ( Supplementary Figs. 5 [href=this file] and 6).
Furthermore, the extent of hypomethylation in phylo(−)DMRs was similar in 10 cells and 24 h.p.f. embryos for both early and late phylo(−)DMRs ( Supplementary Fig. 7a [href=this file] ). To explore whether these intermediate 5mC levels observed in 10 cells and 24 h.p.f. embryos are a result of different cell populations with either fully methylated or fully unmethylated sequences or of a uniform, partially methylated population, we plotted average mCG levels in individual sequencing reads for phylo(−)DMRs ( Supplementary Figs. 7b–d and 8 [href=this file] ). In mouse, however, a substantial proportion of the reads were found in a partially methylated state ( Supplementary Fig. 7b [href=this file] ), a finding that could be attributed either to demethylation intermediates or the formation of low-methylated regions displaying intermediate 5mC levels, as previously described in mammalian cell lines .
Notably, the other zebrafish DMR groups did not display such a strong enrichment in enhancer chromatin ( Supplementary Fig. 9a [href=this file] ). However, some of the identified DMRs that became developmentally hypermethylated (DMRs hypomethylated in the 1,000-cell stage and hypermethylated in the epiboly stage and DMRs hypomethylated in the epiboly stage and hypermethylated at 24 h.p.f.) overlapped the promoter regions of genes such as and , some of which were previously identified as differentially methylated between early embryos and differentiated tissues ( Supplementary Fig. 9b [href=this file] ). Whereas the CpG densities of phylo(−)DMRs in zebrafish and mouse were similar to that of CpG islands identified through pulldown of unmethylated DNA , phylo(−)DMRs, and in particular the early phylo(−)DMRs, displayed considerably lower CpG density than these CpG islands ( Fig. 2c [href=#F2] and Supplementary Fig. 10a [href=this file] ).
To provide further evidence that phylo(−)DMRs act as developmental enhancers, we intersected the mouse phylo(−)DMR genomic positions with the positions of previously validated enhancers from the VISTA enhancer browser database and obtained 13 intersections corresponding to active enhancers ( Supplementary Table 23 [href=this file] ). These regions displayed a mild degree of developmental demethylation; however, none of them overlapped with statistically significant mouse DMRs ( Supplementary Fig. 10b,c and Supplementary Table 23 [href=this file] ).
To investigate this hypothesis, we identified orthologous genes that were linked to phylo(-)DMRs in all the species examined ( Supplementary Table 24 [href=this file] ) and subjected them to pathway enrichment analyses . These analyses showed that orthologous phylo(−)DMR-linked genes were enriched in pathways such as Wnt, Notch and transforming growth factor (TGF)-β, implicated in body plan and organ formation ( Supplementary Fig. 11 [href=this file] ).
Proteins displaying differential binding to unmethylated and methylated DNA oligonucleotides were identified by an adapted test on label-free quantification (LFQ) intensities ( Supplementary Figs. 12 and 13, and Supplementary Tables 25 and 26 [href=this file] ). We also performed absolute quantification of the nuclear extract proteomes ( Supplementary Fig. 12 [href=this file] ) to directly assess the effects of stage-specific protein abundance on binding enrichments. Of the 45 readers quantified, the differential binding of only 19 could be explained by different protein abundance ( Supplementary Fig. 13 [href=this file] ), thereby demonstrating the dynamics of the 5mC interactome during early vertebrate embryogenesis.
Forty-five of these 96 proteins showed conserved binding (47% < 1.1 × 10 , hypergeometric test) ( Fig. 3a,b [href=#F3] and Supplementary Fig. 6 [href=this file] ). Readers for cytosine, 5mC and 5hmC in mouse NPCs and 24 h.p.f. zebrafish embryos also displayed substantial overlap: 99 of 249 proteins (40% < 5 × 10 , hypergeometric test) for which orthologs are annotated in both species displayed conserved binding ( Fig. 3a,b [href=#F3] and Supplementary Fig. 14 [href=this file] ).
To assess whether phylo(−)DMRs become demethylated through an active mechanism that involves the 5hmC intermediate, we generated base-resolution maps of 5hmC in zebrafish (24 h.p.f.), (st. 30) and mouse (E9.5) embryos by Tet-assisted bisulfite sequencing (TAB-seq) (for details on non-conversion and TAB-seq metrics, see Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ). Accordingly, the 5hmC signal in zebrafish and coincided with developmental demethylation taking place in both early and late phylo(−) DMRs ( Fig. 4d [href=#F4] and Supplementary Fig. 15 [href=this file] ). A similar pattern was observed for mouse late phylo(−) DMRs ( Fig. 4d [href=#F4] and Supplementary Fig. 15 [href=this file] ), whereas mouse early phylo(−)DMRs were already demethylated by E9.5 ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [href=this file] ) and therefore did not show any localized 5hmC enrichment ( Fig. 4d [href=#F4] ). When superimposed over mouse early and late phylo(−)DMRs, both Tet1 and 5hmC displayed a strong enrichment over these regions in mouse ESCs ( Supplementary Fig. 16 [href=this file] ). Furthermore, a positive correlation between the quantity of 5hmC and Tet1 signal, as well as between Tet1 signals from different antibodies, was evident for both early and late phylo(−)DMRs ( Supplementary Fig. 16b [href=this file] ), thereby supporting the notion of Tet-dependent 5mC-5hmC conversion in phylo(−)DMRs during mammalian embryogenesis.
Embryos injected with tet3 morpholino showed only minor defects, with 23% of the morphants displaying varying degrees of microphthalmia ( Supplementary Fig. 17a [href=this file] ), as previously reported in a morpholino study performed in embryos . The triple morphants were severely affected, with the majority displaying embryonic lethality, while the embryos that survived gastrulation (23%) displayed short and blended axes, impaired head structures, small eyes and reduced pigmentation ( Supplementary Fig. 17a [href=this file] ), comparable to the defects recently described in a - - zebrafish knockout . We next performed WGBS (for details, see Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ) on morphant embryos ( = 50) and compared the 5mC profiles to their counterparts in wildtype embryos. No differences in 5mC increase were observed between early and late phylo(−)DMRs, and no other DMR population displaying developmental demethylation was affected by this perturbation ( Supplementary Fig. 17b,c [href=this file] ). Also, there was an increase in mCG levels in a subpopulation of CpG islands that corresponded to phylo(−)DMRs and, thus, with sites of aberrant demethylation in the morphants ( Fig. 5a [href=#F5] and Supplementary Fig. 17d,e [href=this file] ).
We therefore performed ATAC-seq on two pools of morphant embryos and their wild-type counterparts (for ATAC-seq metrics, see Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ). Of note, unsupervised clustering of the zebrafish embryonic transcriptomes identified a cluster encompassing the morphant samples, their wild-type controls and other zebrafish phylotypic-stage samples , indicative of morpholino phenotype specificity rather than a developmental delay caused by knockdown ( Supplementary Fig. 18 [href=this file] ). Differential gene expression analyses showed bidirectional changes in gene transcript abundance in morphants ( = 718 upregulated genes and = 780 downregulated genes in the morphant) ( Fig. 5e [href=#F5] and Supplementary Table 27 [href=this file] ). GO analyses of downregulated genes showed an over-representation of functions associated with transcriptional regulation, similar to those described to be enriched among zebrafish phylo(−)DMR-associated genes ( Fig. 5f [href=#F5] and Supplementary Fig. 5 [href=this file] ), whereas no statistically significant gene ontology enrichments were associated with the upregulated group of genes.
Single-read MethylC-seq libraries (for details, see Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ) were sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq 1500 platform. To estimate the bisulfite non-conversion frequency the frequency of all cytosine base calls at reference cytosine positions in the lambda phage genome (unmethylated spike-in control) was normalized by the total number of base calls at reference cytosine positions in the lambda phage genome ( Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ).
Single-read TAB-seq libraries (for details, see Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ) were sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq 1500 platform.
The output of the methylpy pipe-line is provided as Supplementary Tables 2–5 [href=this file] .
We also designed a specific splice-junction morpholino for the zebrafish Tet3 protein ( Supplementary Table 28 [href=this file] ).
The FDR and s0 significance threshold values used are depicted in these volcano plots ( Supplementary Fig. 3 [href=this file] ).
Note: Any Supplementary Information [href=this file] and Source Data files are available in the online version of the paper.

context_description:
Interestingly, only secreted proteins and vesicles from (ESP, EVs, and vesicle-depleted ESP) showed efficacy in preventing colitis signs and symptoms, whereas purified fractions from did not confer significant protection (Figure 3 [rid=F3] ; Figure S1 [this file] in Supplementary Material). 
Data for ( ) extracellular vesicles (EVs) were analyzed in a separate independent experiment (see Figure S1 [this file] in Supplementary Material) and included only for representation.

title: No Title
caption: Proteomic analysis of extracellular vesicles (EVs) secreted by  Nippostrongylus brasiliensis . Details of the identification of the proteins present in the EVs secreted by  N. brasiliensis  using X!Tandem, Tide, MS-GF+ and OMSSA. All proteins are shown, including contaminants.
description: Table  S1  Proteomic  analysis  of  extracellular  vesicles  (EVs)  secreted  by  Nippostrongylus  brasiliensis  .  Details  of  the  identification  of  the  proteins  present  in  the  EVs  secreted  by  N.  brasiliensis  using  X!Tandem,  Tide,  MS-GF+  and  OMSSA.  All  proteins  are  shown,  including  contaminants.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
In 12 ODG fractions from concentrated and purified ESP, we purified vesicles in a size range of 60–160 nm (mean 95 ± 37.3 nm), which were most abundant in fractions 7–10 (density of 1.06–1.11 g/ml) as detected by qNano TRPS (Figure 1 [rid=F1] ). -EVs were verified by proteomic analysis, revealing several proteins which are frequently present in mammalian exosomes (“EV-markers”), including tetraspanin (NBR_0001199101), enolase (NBR_0001176401), 14-3-3 protein (NBR_0000671101), heat shock protein 70 (HSP70; NBR_0000494801), histones, and structural/cytoskeletal proteins (Table S1 [this file] in Supplementary Material). 
Purified -EVs were digested with trypsin and analyzed by LC-MS/MS, resulting in a list of 81 proteins for -EVs (Table S1 [this file] in Supplementary Material). In 53 (65.4%) of the 81 proteins, a signal peptide was absent (Table S1 [this file] in Supplementary Material), which is characteristic for EV proteins as a class of non-classically secreted particles.
pub_title: Hookworm Secreted Extracellular Vesicles Interact With Host Cells and Prevent Inducible Colitis in Mice

title: Additional file 1
caption: The effect of fenofibrate on less sensitive breast cancer cells and human breast epithelial cells. (A)  Fenofibrate induced apoptosis of BT549 cells.
