description: Additional  file  1  The  effect  of  fenofibrate  on  less  sensitive  breast  cancer  cells  and  human  breast  epithelial  cells.  (A)  Fenofibrate  induced  apoptosis  of  BT549  cells.  (B)  Fenofibrate  barely  induced  apoptosis  of  MCF-10A  cells,  which  were  human  breast  epithelial  cells.  (C)  Fenofibrate  arrested  cell  cycle  of  MDA-MB-468  cells  at  G0/G1  phase.  The  experiments  were  repeated  three  times  and  the  representative  ones  of  those  results  were  shown.  Click  here  for  file
context_description:
Besides MDA-MB-231 cells, fenofibrate induced apoptosis of BT549 cells and had little effect on MCF-10A cells (see Additional file 1 [this file] A and B). 
The similar cell cycle arrest was found in MDA-MB-468 cells (see Additional file 1 [this file] C). 
Fenofibrate had the least effects on human breast epithelial cells (Figure 1 [rid=F1] A and Additional file 1 [this file] B) and the data from the xenograft mouse model provided the evidence that such doses of fenofibrate were safe and had little side effects on hematologic, hepatic and renal functions.

description: Additional  file  1:  Figure  S1-S5  and  Table  S1.  Figure  S1.  Comparison  of  biological  replicates;  additional  examples  of  AS-NMD  transcript  coverage.  Figure  S2.  Comparison  of  EJC  and  RNA-Seq  libraries  coverage  across  additional  transcript  biotypes.  Figure  S3.  Representation  of  bioinformatics  pipeline  to  classify  annotated  and  unannotated  exon  junctions.  Figure  S4. Additional  example  of  an  unannotated  AS-NMD  cassette  exon.  Figure  S6.  Analysis  of  previously  published  RNA-Seq  libraries  made  from  HeLa  cells  treated  with  cycloheximide  for  0  min,  15  min,  or  24  h  [  45  ,  46  ].  Table  S1. context_description:
Paired-end deep sequencing of these EJC RIPiT-Seq libraries resulted in 19–25 million mate pairs each (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1). 
These strict mapping parameters resulted in 6–10 million and 60–76 million aligned pairs for the EJC RIPiT-Seq and RNA-Seq libraries, respectively (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1). Examination of per-transcript abundance revealed high concordance (≥ 0.93 to 0.99) among biological replicates (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S1A). 
Similar trends were observed for other known AS-NMD targets (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S1B-D), including hnRNPA1 where the AS-NMD isoform results from 3′ UTR splicing as a consequence of alternative polyadenylation (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] d). 
EJC library enrichment was also readily discernible for NMD, NSD, retained intron, and processed transcript isoforms (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] c and Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2A), with median enrichments falling between 1.8 and 2.6-fold (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2B). 
The position of an exon junction in an individual read can be found by examining the “N operation” in the CIGAR string, which indicates the locations and lengths of gaps inserted during alignment to genomic DNA (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S3). We further required that any candidate junction (1) occurs within an annotated gene; (2) has reads with ≥ 15 nt aligning on both sides of the junction (≥ 90% exact sequence match on each side); (3) be detectable in all replicates of a particular library type; and (4) has a mean read count ≥ 2 per library type (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S3). 
The majority (76%) of previously annotated exon junctions meeting our detection criteria in protein-coding genes (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S3) were present in all three library types (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] c, left). 
Plotting MaxENT versus conservation revealed markedly different distributions between annotated splice sites and random GT- and AG-containing sequences (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] b and Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S4A-B), with annotated sites being notably skewed toward higher values for both measures. In contrast, whereas unannotated splice sites were similarly distributed as annotated splice sites with regard to MaxENT, the majority exhibited conservation scores more similar to random than annotated splice sites (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] c and Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S4C). The majority of these occurred within annotated protein-coding exons, so their conservation is likely driven by amino acid conservation and not as a requirement for recognition by the splicing machinery (see Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5A for an example). In contrast, examination of unannotated 3′ splice sites occurring within introns uncovered a conserved alternative splicing event in the HECTD4 (HECT domain E3 ubiquitin protein ligase 4) gene that adds 9 amino acids into the middle of the protein (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5B); this spliced isoform is currently annotated in mouse RefSeq and GENCODE, but not in humans. 
Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S4A shows the same plot for all observed annotated splice sites. also contains 2268 random GT-containing (left) and 2693 random AG-containing (right) sites; identical plots for four additional sets of randomized locations are shown in Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S4B. Genes for which genome browser tracks are shown in panels and and in Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5A and B are indicated. 
Other high-abundance examples were a 103 nt exon in intron 3 of the 29-intron DNA Polymerase Theta (POLQ) gene (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S5C) and a 69 nt exon in intron 37 of the 39-intron pleckstrin homology domain interacting protein (PHIP) gene (Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] d). 
Similar results were observed for other RNA-binding protein genes known to maintain protein homeostasis by AS-NMD (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S1). 
However, the harringtonine (+) and (−) RNA-Seq data in this study clearly show that this treatment had no discernible effect on either protein-coding or AS-NMD isoform abundance in actively dividing HEK293 cells (Figs. 1 [rid=Fig1] and 2 [rid=Fig2] and Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S1–2). While the 15-min exposure had almost no effect on protein-coding isoform abundance, the 24-h exposure did [ 45 [rid=CR45] , 46 [rid=CR46] ] (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S6A). Our analysis of those data revealed that the 15-min cycloheximide treatment was sufficient to increase AS-NMD isoform abundance, with this increase being even more apparent at 24 h (Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S6B). 
Read counts for unprocessed libraries and for the individual processing steps detailed below are provided in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1. 
Transcript biotypes (i.e., “protein-coding,” “nonsense-mediated decay”) and intron counts used to categorize transcripts throughout Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] , Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S2 and S6A are based on the transcriptome annotation from Ensembl (GRCh38.p12) [ 3 [rid=CR3] ]. 
The custom bioinformatics pipeline designed for our annotated and unannotated junction analysis (Figs. 3 [rid=Fig3] , 4 [rid=Fig4] , 5 [rid=Fig5] , and 6 [rid=Fig6] ) is shown in detail in Additional file 1 [this file] : Figure S3A.
pub_title: Deep sequencing of pre-translational mRNPs reveals hidden flux through evolutionarily conserved alternative splicing nonsense-mediated decay pathways

context_description:
To identify all annotated exon junctions, we integrated the RefSeq (hg38) [ 23 [rid=CR23] ], Ensembl (GRCh38.p12) [ 3 [rid=CR3] ], GENCODE (v29) [ 24 [rid=CR24] ], and Comprehensive Human Expressed SequenceS (CHESS) transcriptome annotations to create a comprehensive reference file containing 575,837 known introns (Additional file 2 [this file] : Table S2). While Ensembl and GENCODE are largely identical [ 25 [rid=CR25] ], our analysis revealed 240 junctions in Ensembl GRCh38.p12 that were not in GENCODE v29, and 4554 junctions in GENCODE v29 that were not in Ensembl GRCh38.p12 (Additional file 2 [this file] : Table S2). 
Transcriptome annotation files from RefSeq (hg38) [ 23 [rid=CR23] ], Ensembl (GRCh38.p12) [ 3 [rid=CR3] ], GENCODE (v29) [ 24 [rid=CR24] ], and CHESS (v2.1) [ 26 [rid=CR26] ] were combined to create a comprehensive reference file of all annotated introns (Additional file 2 [this file] : Table S2).

caption: Additional file 3: Table S3.  Locations and characteristics of highly conserved unannotated exon junctions identified in this study.
description: Additional  file  3:  Table  S3.  Locations  and  characteristics  of  highly  conserved  unannotated  exon  junctions  identified  in  this  study.
context_description:
To limit our analysis to events most likely representing real splicing events (as opposed to mapping artifacts), we subsequently only considered the 5075 previously unannotated junctions where the putative intron began and ended with dinucleotides GT-AG or AT-AC to include excision events mediated by both the major and minor spliceosomes (Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S3). 
Using these values as cutoffs to filter out the majority of events likely due to splicing noise (although this may be unnecessarily conservative for 3′ splice sites due to the high degree of overlap between the annotated and random conservation scores) left us with 453 (23%) and 651 (28%) evolutionarily conserved unannotated 5′ and 3′ splice sites, respectively (Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S3). 
Combining these exon conservation scores (white to dark blue in Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] b) with the previously calculated 5′ and 3′ splice site conservation scores (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] b) revealed a set of 20 previously unannotated cassette exons exhibiting both high internal (phyloP score ≥ 1) and high splice site (≥ 1 for both splice sites) conservation (Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] b, right; Additional file 3 [this file] : Table S3).
pub_title: Deep sequencing of pre-translational mRNPs reveals hidden flux through evolutionarily conserved alternative splicing nonsense-mediated decay pathways

context_description:
In the mouse spinal cord, NEK1 was found in the NeuN+ neurons in the ventral and lateral horns (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). A large fraction of ChAT+ motor neurons in the ventral horn of wild type (WT) spinal cords were NEK1 (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). In addition, NEK1 was detected in CD31 endothelial cells and IBA1 microglia in WT mouse brains (Supplementary Fig. 1c-d [this file] ). 
Inhibition of RIPK1, however, did not affect the polycystic kidney development, dwarfism, or facial deformity in this mutant line (Supplementary Fig. 1e-g [this file] ). Inhibition of RIPK1 did not rescue the reduced body weight in mice at 2 weeks of age (Supplementary Fig. 1h [this file] ). While inhibition of RIPK1 rescued the lethality of mice to allow their survival, the body weight of mice at 5 months of age was still lower than that of WT or mice (Supplementary Fig. 1i [this file] ). 
Inhibition of RIPK1 blocked the immunostaining signals of p-S166 RIPK1, p-S345 MLKL, and cleaved caspase-3 in the brains of mice at 3 weeks of age (Fig. 1c–f [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1j [this file] ). 
Treatment of MEFs, but not MEFs, with TNF induced cell death, which was prevented by RIPK1 inhibitor Nec-1s (R-7-Cl-O-Nec-1) (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). MEFs were also sensitized to RDA induced by a combination of TNF and TAK1 inhibitor, 5z7 (5z-7-Oxozeaenol) and necroptosis induced by TNF/5z7/zVAD (Supplementary Fig. 2b, c [this file] ). Knockdown of using shRNA also sensitized RGC5 cells and L929 cells to RDA and necroptosis, which was protected by RIPK1 inhibition with Nec-1s (Supplementary Fig. 2d-f [this file] ). 
Furthermore, we found that the levels of total A20 protein were much lower in cells relative to WT, but A20 mRNA levels were not affected by deficiency (Fig. 2a [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Fig. 2g [this file] ). Consistent with A20 deficiency , the phosphorylation and degradation of IκBα in MEFs stimulated by TNF was increased compared to that of WT (Supplementary Fig. 2h [this file] ). 
We stained brain slices from , , and WT littermates with thioflavin S, which marks misfolded protein aggregates (Fig. 3a, b [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). Strikingly, we found that the levels of α-synuclein were elevated in the hippocampal and cortical neurons of mice compared to that of WT littermates (Fig. 3c–e [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). 
Increased mRNA levels of ﻿, , , , , and were observed in primary microglia compared to primary microglia WT littermates (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). 
In contrast, the expression of Cst7 in primary microglia isolated from mice was increased by 1.48x (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). is highly induced in the CNS in microglia from the ALS mouse model , human Alzheimer’s disease brains (AD), the APP/PS1 mouse model of AD , aging microglia, during demyelination , and in a prion disease model . 
Consistent with the induction of DAM, the expression of all other known DAM signature genes including , (6.14x), (4.26x), , , , , (77.17x), (44.81x), , and (10.79x), except , were also highly elevated in the brains of Nek1 mice, which were suppressed by the inhibition of RIPK1 in mice (Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ). In contrast, the markers of homeostatic microglia, such as , , , , and , were not elevated, or minimally induced, such as (1.85x), (3.61x) and (3.04x), in the brains of mice, which were also suppressed by the inhibition of RIPK1 in the brains of mice (Supplementary Fig. 3e [this file] ). 
We found that NEK1 bound to VPS26B and VPS35 (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ) and furthermore, knockdown of VPS26B and VPS29 sensitized cells to necroptosis (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). Furthermore, we found that knockdown of VPS26B sensitized WT, but not MEFs, to RDA and necroptosis; while knockdown of VPS29 or VPS26A sensitized both WT and MEFs to RDA and necroptosis, which was inhibited by treatment with RIPK1 inhibitor Nec-1s (Fig. 4a, b [rid=Fig4] ; Supplementary Fig. 4c-f [this file] ). 
In our mass spectrometry analysis of cell surface proteins, the plasma membrane levels of SNX27 were much higher in MEFs compared to WT MEFs, while the plasma membrane levels of another sorting nexin protein SNX2, a retromer binding protein that regulates the retrieval of proteins from endosome to Golgi apparatus , was much lower in compared to WT MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 4g [this file] ). 
Using mass spectrometry analysis, we identified that NEK1 could phosphorylate Ser302 and Ser304 of VPS26B (Supplementary Fig. 4h [this file] ). 
We found that the C-terminus of VPS26B is important for binding between VPS26B and SNX27 as a truncation of VPS26B that lacks the C-terminal 298-336 residues bound poorly with endogenous SNX27 (Supplementary Fig. 4i [this file] ). Addback of VPS26B and VPS26B , but not VPS26B , rescued VPS26B knockdown cells from the sensitization to cell death stimuli (Supplementary Fig. 4j, k [this file] ). 
In contrast, the levels of SNX2 in the cell surface membrane were decreased in VPS26B knockdown MEFs expressing VPS26B and increased in VPS26B knockdown MEFs expressing VPS26B (Supplementary Fig. 4l [this file] ). 
Reduced plasma membrane presence of GLUT1 was not affected by treatment of Nec-1s (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ), which is consistent with the model that activation of RIPK1 is downstream of retromer defects in Nek1 deficient cells. 
The reduced plasma membrane levels of GLUT1 in MEFs were restored by the expression of WT NEK1 but not NEK1 , a kinase dead mutant of NEK1, suggesting the importance of NEK1 kinase activity in regulating the trafficking of GLUT1 (Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] ). 
Longer term C-labelling experiment also demonstrated the reduction in the levels of pyruvate in MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). With reduced precursor metabolites such as pyruvate from glycolysis, the TCA activity of MEFs was also compromised, which were evidenced by the reduced oxygen consumption rate in seahorse analysis (Supplementary Fig. 5d [this file] ), reduced levels of acetyl-coA (Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] ) and reduced levels of ATP (Supplementary Fig. 5f [this file] ). Consistent with reduced glucose uptake and the activation of starvation response, MEFs showed higher levels of p-S79 ACC, a substrate of AMPK, than that of WT (Supplementary Fig. 5g [this file] ). The levels of p-S79 ACC in and WT MEFs were elevated to the same levels when treated with metformin, which is known to activate AMPK (Supplementary Fig. 5g [this file] ). Treatment with Nec-1s had no effect on the levels of p-ACC (Supplementary Fig. 5h [this file] ). 
Consistence with the expression of VPS26B and VPS26B promoted the localization of GLUT1 to the plasma membrane (Fig. 5d, e [rid=Fig5] ), addback of VPS26B and VPS26B significantly rescued the decreased glucose uptake and acetyl-CoA levels in VPS26B knockdown cells, while the addback of VPS26B showed no significant effect on glucose uptake and acetyl-CoA levels in VPS26B knockdown cells (Supplementary Fig. 5i, j [this file] ). 
We found that ALCAR pretreatment reduced the sensitivity of MEFs to RDA and necroptosis, while effects on WT MEFs were minimal (Fig. 6a [rid=Fig6] ; Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ). 
The protein levels of LAMP1 were also increased in MEFs compared to that of WT MEFs (Fig. 6f [rid=Fig6] ). deficiency resulted in dramatically decreased lysosomal activity as determined by the cathepsin B activity assay using the Magic Red probe and increased protein levels of p62, which were not affected by the treatment with Nec-1s (Fig. 6f [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). Consistent with increased levels of α-synuclein in the brains of mice, MEFs transfected with an expression vector of α-synuclein showed increased accumulation compared to WT MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] ). ALCAR pretreatment showed no obvious effect on the cathepsin B activity assay using the Magic Red probe, protein levels of p62 and LAMP1, nor did it have any significant effect on the enlarged LAMP1 lysosome size in MEFs (Supplementary Fig. 6d–f [this file] ). 
Addback of VPS26B and VPS26B , but not VPS26B , reduced the enlarged lysosomes and mitochondria fragmentation in VPS26B knockdown cells (Supplementary Fig. 6g, h [this file] ). 
Consistent with inadequate glucose uptake in cells, we found the acetyl-CoA levels were also lower in cells (Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] ). Consistent with the decreased acetyl-CoA levels, the acetylation of A20 protein was much lower in cells (Supplementary Fig. 6i [this file] ). We found that treatment with ALCAR or sodium octanoate substantially rescued the A20 protein levels in MEFs (Fig. 6i [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Fig. 6j [this file] ). Treatment with Nec-1s has no effects on the enlarged lysosomes, decreased glucose uptake into cells, decreased acetyl-CoA levels and mitochondrial fragmentation in cells (Supplementary Fig. 6k–n [this file] ). 
In contrast to substantial amount of extravasated Evans blue in the brains of mice on control diet, newborns from mothers who had been on ketogenic diet since pregnancy showed no extravasated Evans blue (Fig. 7b [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). Ketogenic diet also inhibited necroptosis and RDA of cerebrovascular endothelial cells in the brains of mice; no obvious phosphorylation of MLKL or cleaved caspase-3 were observed in the brains of mice on ketogenic diet (Supplementary Fig. 7b, c [this file] ). The ketogenic diet showed no significant effects on body weight of WT and mice compared to the control diet (Supplementary Fig. 7d, e [this file] ). Taken together, we conclude that the the preweaning lethality of mice can be reduced by inhibition of RIPK1 as well as by ketogenic diet which can rescue metabolic defects to inhibit RIPK1 mediated cell death and inflammation (Supplementary Fig. 7f [this file] ).

context_description:
Of note, an initial (i) aliquot of culture medium was collected after ZIKV inoculation or mock inoculation, and then a final (f) aliquot of medium was collected at the culture endpoint to assess viral replication by plaque assay (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] A). 
Neither ZIKV protein was detectable in inoculated EVT samples (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ), supporting the minimal increase of infectious virus seen in plaque assays. Full Western Blots and isotype control immunofluorescence images are shown in Supplementary Figs. 2 [this file] and 3 [this file] , respectively. 
Full heatmaps presented in Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] show a similar clustering pattern when genes that were only detected in as few as one sample were included. 
Cell type comparisons can be found in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] . ( ) Normalized CPMs by DESeq2 for candidate ZIKV receptors. ( , ) Top 10 canonical pathways identified by IPA in the TSC and ST3D datasets [− log (p-value)]. 
The expression of seven of the genes involved in the antiviral response pathway ( and ) and two genes involved in the anti-apoptosis pathway ( and ) were validated with qRT-PCR (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] E; primer sequences Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). The trends in expression observed with qRT-PCR agreed with those identified by poly(A)-seq analysis (Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ). A trend in decreased expression of and was confirmed in TSC-Z samples by qRT-PCR, supporting the RNAseq data. p-values are listed in Supplementary Table 5 [this file] . There was no significant difference in PPAR14 expression with ZIKV exposure, but there was a difference between cell types (Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ). 
A significant difference was not detected in CG or progesterone secretion with ZIKV exposure, although there were significant cell type-dependent changes in CG secretion (TS vs ST3D, p < 0.001; TS vs EVT, p < 0.001; Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
Cytokines and growth factors associated with infection and the inflammatory response were quantified by Luminex assay (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] B,C). ( ) was significantly upregulated in infected ST3Ds compared to control (a similar trend was observed in mRNA expression, Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] B), and was more highly expressed in infected ST3Ds compared to infected TSCs. Regardless of infection status, there were significant differences in the secretion of several cytokines and growth factors between trophoblast cell types (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] B). Conversely, significant differences were not detected across cell type or infection status (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] C). p-values for hormones and analytes are listed in Supplementary Table 5 [this file] . 
The ZIKV E protein was readily detected in the TSC-Z and ST3D-Z EV samples with none detected in the EVT-Z EV samples or any controls (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] C; Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] D). 
Three peptides aligned with the capsid and membrane ZIKV structural proteins (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
Full heatmaps, of all significantly differentially detected proteins, are present in Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] . 
For the top 1000 genes identified in the eight EV poly(A)-seq samples, DAVID enrichment analysis showed that the most enriched cellular component was extracellular exosome (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] A). When comparison was restricted to transcripts detected in a majority of samples regardless of cell type origin (3/5 control or 2/3 ZIKV-exposed; Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] B), 832 and 601 transcripts were detected only in control or ZIKV EVs, respectively. Pathways enriched by transcripts identified in the majority of ZIKV or control EVs (602 and 871 for ZIKV and control, respectively) are shown in Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] C. IPA analysis identified several pathways to be significantly increased (cholecystokinin/Gastrin-mediated, protein kinase A, senescence, and Rho family GTPase signaling) and decreased (RHOA, ILK, and PFKFB4 signaling; Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] C) by ZIKV exposure. 
TSCs were differentiated into either EVTs or ST3D aggregates (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] A). TSCs were grown in 13 ml media, EVTs in 15 ml media, and ST3Ds in 10 ml media (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] B). 
The number of ST3D “cells” (at this point they are aggregates) present was based on the number of TSCs added to the flask three days prior (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] B). 
At the end of the culture period, TSCs were lifted, EVTs were scraped off the flasks, and ST3Ds were pelleted prior to aliquoting cells for RNA, DNA, and protein isolation (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] A). 
For antibody details please see Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
For this assay, additional cells were inoculated at the same MOI and length of duration as previously stated and shown in Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] A. 
Beta-actin mRNA was amplified in parallel to serve as the reference gene and the primer sequences are listed in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . cDNA was diluted 1:10 and reactions were run in triplicate. 
To detect ZIKV, the E and nonstructural protein 2B (NS2B) antibodies were used; see Supplementary Table 1 [this file] for antibody information. 
Blots were incubated in primary antibody (at the concentrations specified in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) for 1 h on a rocker in 5% milk at 37 °C.

context_description:
The elution profiles calculated by Specter agree extremely well with expert annotation in terms of both total ion intensities and the retention times at which they are identified ( Figure 2(a) [rid=F2] and Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
The identifications can therefore be retained as is or filtered to a lower false discovery rate by means of linear discriminant analysis ( Figure 3(b) [rid=F3] , Methods §4.5, and Supplementary Note 1.3 [this file] ), though this comes at the cost of decreasing the number of on-target identifications. 
We tested the robustness of Specter in such situations and found that its output is largely unaffected when precursors are removed individually or en masse from a spectral library ( Supplementary Figures 2 and 3 [this file] ). 
We used three families of synthetic peptides, each consisting of precursors whose spectra are highly similar and whose / ratios (in charge state +2) fall into the same isolation windows for DIA ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
This is also an example of a situation in which the use of library retention time information would improve the results of Specter, as a two-minute window for identification around the elution times for LPVLAVNGQIR and LPVLANGVQIR would have made these false peaks impossible (though this still would not necessarily result in a positive identification of LPVLANVGQIR, as per Supplementary Figure 3 [this file] ). 
We found that DIA with analysis by Specter is more reproducible than DDA, due to large numbers of precursors which are identified in one replicate DDA run but not another, or which exhibit high variability in their quantifications between runs ( Supplementary Figure 4(a) [this file] ). Fig. 4(b) [this file] ; average across DDA replicates = 0.72, average across DIA replicates = 0.98). 
We calculated the accuracy of quantification by Specter following the LFQ Bench study methods and compared to the other tools ( Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) . 
The maximum similarities (normalized dot products) between the unique Specter identifications and all other library spectra are, in a statistically significant fashion, higher overall than these values for the unique Spectronaut identifications ( Supplementary Figure 5 [this file] ), with a mean of 0.74 as opposed to 0.64 for Spectronaut ( -value of one-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov test = 5.24 x 10 ). 
For each MS2 scan , the / coordinates of the peaks of the library spectra are then binned with the / coordinates of the peaks of to obtain a vector of intensities whose length equals the number of peaks of ( Supplementary Note 1.1 [this file] ). 
In order to account for peaks of library spectra not matching peaks in , as described above, we append a zero to the end of this vector so that it has length This extra zero serves to penalize the linear contributions of library spectra that have peaks with significant intensities that aren’t present in Let be the corresponding matrix of normalized reference spectra constructed above (see also Supplementary Note 1.1 [this file] ). Some peaks of may not be close to any of the peaks of the reference spectra, as determined using the mass accuracy δ, and these may be discarded from the analysis as they don’t affect the determination of the optimal linear combination ( Supplementary Note 1.2 [this file] ), i.e. we project the spectrum to the linear span of the library spectra prior to analysis. 
With these unnecessary peaks removed, the optimal linear combination of the reference spectra is determined as the solution of the corresponding nonnegative least squares problem, which finds the vector of length (where is the number of spectral library members), all of whose entries are nonnegative, such that the matrix product of with is as close as possible to in the Euclidean norm among all such nonnegative vectors ( Supplementary Note 1.2 [this file] ). 
Equations for these scores are given in Supplementary Note 1.3 [this file] . 
The HEK293T digest was resuspended using 0.1%TFA and a mixture containing ninety-six synthetic peptides at known individual concentrations ( Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ) was spiked into it to generate a five-point calibration curve. 
For spike-in experiments, synthetic peptide mixtures were constructed according to Supplementary Table 5 [this file] . 20 injections worth of peptide mixtures for each of the zero, single, or double drop out samples were created. 
The window centers can be found in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
Drug treatments and concentrations are shown in Supplementary Table 6 [this file] . Ten randomly chosen phosphoenriched samples of PC3 cells treated with the perturbations highlighted in bold in Supplementary Table 6 [this file] were measured by DDA (acquired with the same settings as the DDA runs described in §4.9).

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S6 and Tables S1–S3

description: Document  S1.  Figures  S1–S6  and  Tables  S1–S3
context_description:
The rodent and human structure of the gene is complex, consisting of multiple 5′ exons, each containing its own promoter and 5′ untranslated region (5′UTR), that are alternatively spliced to a universal coding exon [xref] [rid=bib16] [xref] [rid=bib17] [xref] [rid=bib18] ( Figure S1 [this file] A). 
The expression of isoforms was analyzed by quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR) with a reverse primer complementary to universal exon IX and forward primers matching each 5′UTR ( Figure S1 [this file] A). 
See also Figure S1 [this file] . 
In the nucleus, the genome is arranged into self-interacting TADs in which DNA sequences contact each other more frequently. [xref] [rid=bib42] [xref] [rid=bib43] Strengthening of intra-TAD and depletion of inter-TAD contacts have been observed during neuronal development, and new TAD boundaries form near developmentally regulated genes as they become transcriptionally active. [xref] [rid=bib44] To study the TAD boundaries that regulate gene interactions, we analyzed high-resolution HiC data of mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) differentiated into NPCs and cortical neurons. [xref] [rid=bib44] We discovered a sub-TAD encompassing the gene and a downstream, gene-free region adjacent to the closest gene ( Figure S1 [this file] B). The sub-TAD falls at the 3′ end of a larger TAD and, despite the dramatic difference in expression, its contact frequencies appeared similar in NPCs and cortical neurons ( Figure S1 [this file] B). 
CTCF (CCCTC-binding factor) and cohesin are key regulators of TAD boundaries, [xref] [rid=bib45] [xref] [rid=bib46] and are known to bind to the locus at promoter IV and intron 7 in mouse neurons. [xref] [rid=bib47] Loss of either CTCF or cohesin compromises transcription from promoter IV, increasing repressive histone modifications. [xref] [rid=bib47] Analysis of published CTCF Chromatin Immunoprecipitation with sequencing (ChIP-seq) data [xref] [rid=bib44] identified peaks in the and genes in both NPCs and cortical neurons at sites coinciding with the sub-TAD boundaries ( Figure S1 [this file] B). CTCF binding site 1 spans exon II, but the highest enrichment of CTCF was observed at binding site 2, located on the downstream part of exon VII and extending into the intron ( Figures S1 [this file] B and S1C). ChIP-qPCR for the cohesin subunit Rad21 confirmed cohesin binding to CTCF site 2 in primary NPCs and PMNs ( Figure S1 [this file] C). In PMNs, low levels of Rad21 enrichment were seen at site 1 and at the site, which were significantly above the IgG control ( Figure S1 [this file] C). 
The profile appeared the same irrespective of the expression levels in the cell type ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] A), consistent with the HiC analysis ( Figure S1 [this file] B). 
See also Figure S2 [this file] . 
The use of a reciprocal combination of probe labels further supported this conclusion ( Figure S2 [this file] ). 
Sensitivity to DNase I is a feature of active chromatin regions including promoters and enhancers. [xref] [rid=bib53] ENCODE DNase I hypersensitivity data showed peaks atin brain ( Figure 3 [rid=fig3] A), but not in other tissues, which was similar to the pattern of DNase I hypersensitivity observed at promoters ( Figure S3 [this file] A). 
See also Figure S3 [this file] and Table S1 [this file] . 
We then investigated other enhancer hallmarks atusing ChIP-seq datasets generated by our and other laboratories ( Table S1 [this file] [xref] [rid=bib55] [xref] [rid=bib56] [xref] [rid=bib57] ). CBP and the MED23 Mediator subunit were also found to bind toin cortical neurons ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] A and S3 [this file] B), together with the transcription factors MEF2, CREB and TBR1 ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] A and S3 [this file] B). 
Primary cortical neurons were depolarized with KCl, and eRNA levels were assessed with qRT-PCR.eRNA increased concomitant with mRNA ( Figure S4 [this file] A). The activity-dependent Activator Protein-1 (AP-1) transcription factors JUN and FOS were recruited toin response to neuronal depolarization ( Figure S4 [this file] B), which is consistent with transcription factors encoded by early response genes, like and , controlling the expression of late response genes, such as . [xref] [rid=bib72] 
After 5 DIV, the media was supplemented with puromycin to select lentiviral-transduced cells, and then cells were depolarized with KCl at DIV 7 for 3h before harvesting ( Figure S4 [this file] C). Expression ofeRNA after neuronal activation was significantly decreased in the presence of enhancer-targeted guide RNAs ( Figure S4 [this file] D). Although we did not detect a significant reduction of total mRNA afterinhibition ( Figure S4 [this file] E), analysis of different isoforms indicated thatinhibition resulted in lower expression of variants as a group ( Figure S4 [this file] F), confirming its role as an enhancer. Significant effects ofinhibition were seen on variants containing exon II and V ( Figure S4 [this file] F). We did not see a reduction in mRNA or antisense promoter transcription at −2.0 kb ( Figure S4 [this file] G), confirming that the CRISRPi inhibitory effect at the enhancer does not spread into the adjacent promoter. 
See also Figures S4 [this file] and S5 [this file] . 
Depolarization of cortical neurons in the presence of EV increased neuritic arborization, which was reduced byinhibition ( Figure S5 [this file] ). Co-transfection of pBdnf rescued the branching defects close to the soma, although it did not fully reinstate the branching in distal dendrites ( Figure S5 [this file] ). 
Initial experiments performed on NPCs in culture indicated that inhibition ofaffected PMN cluster formation, quantified by measuring nuclei-nuclei distance ( Figures S6 [this file] A and S6B). PMN dispersion was reversed by co-infection with a lentiviral vector encoding ( Figure S6 [this file] C), indicating that Bdnf is necessary for neuron-neuron interaction, cell migration, or adhesion properties . 
See also Figure S6 [this file] . 
Its inhibition significantly regulates the expression of at least five 5′ isoforms during differentiation ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] D), and at least two in response to depolarization ( Figure S4 [this file] F).bears most known enhancer hallmarks, including binding of CBP and Mediator, chromatin accessibility, specific histone modifications, and transcription ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] and S3 [this file] ). Analysis of genome topology revealed that gene and enhancer are located within a sub-TAD which is bounded by CTCF and cohesin ( Figures S1 [this file] B and S1C). activation correlates with increasing frequency of enhancer-promoter co-localization ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] C and S2 [this file] ) and movement of the genomic region away from the nuclear periphery ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] D).inhibition altered neuronal clustering ( Figure S6 [this file] ), dendritic branching ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] B and S5 [this file] ), and cortical development ( Figure 6 [rid=fig6] ), demonstrating its key role in regulating Bdnf functions and . 
We explored the 3D genome architecture of the genomic region using HiC and 4C-seq and described, for the first time, a sub-TAD of increased interaction frequency that includes the gene and the downstream region includingand the neuronal gene , with CTCF and cohesin-positive boundaries within the and genes ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] A, 2B, S1 [this file] B, and S1C). Neither the sub-TAD boundaries nor the enhancer-promoter loop sites changed during neuronal differentiation ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] A and S1 [this file] B), suggesting that the boundaries are pre-wired in NPCs. Topological structure has been shown to precede gene activation in many model systems, [xref] [rid=bib84] [xref] [rid=bib85] [xref] [rid=bib86] [xref] [rid=bib87] [xref] [rid=bib88] and preconfigured loops prime genes for transcriptional activation. [xref] [rid=bib89] Single cell imaging showed an increase in co-localization ofwith the promoter during the activation of the gene ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] C and S2 [this file] ), suggesting that the sub-TAD organization may facilitate enhancer-promoter interaction and transcription. 
During differentiation,inhibition markedly affected isoforms containing exon IV, V, VI, VIII, and IXa ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] ), whereas in response to depolarization, the strongest effect ofinhibition was on exon V and exon II- expressing isoforms ( Figure S4 [this file] F). 
In addition to promoting the formation of neuronal clusters ( Figure S6 [this file] ) and dendritogenesis ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] and S5 [this file] ),is necessary for mouse cortical neuron development ( Figure 6 [rid=fig6] ). The effect on neuronal migration could be linked to the neurite extension phenotype seen ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] and S5 [this file] ) because neuronal polarity and morphology are tightly interlinked with migration. [xref] [rid=bib79] Moreover,inhibition caused a loss of bipolar morphology in neurons that reached the cortical plate, which was restored by co-electroporation with a vector expressing Bdnf ( Figures 6 [rid=fig6] D and 6E). 
Primers for 4C-seq; see Table S2 [this file] 
Primers for qPCR, ChIP; see Table S3 [this file] 
These include: pLV-hU6-Enh -hUbC-dCas9-KRAB-T2a-puro ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B–4E and S4D–S4G [this file] ), pLV-hU6-Enh -hUbC-dCas9-KRAB-T2a-puro ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B–4E and S4D–S4G [this file] ), pLV-hU6-Enh -hUbC-dCas9-VP64-T2a-puro ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] F–4I), BPK1520-Enh ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] and S5 [this file] ), BPK1520-Enh ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] and S5 [this file] ), pCAG-Bdnf ( Figure 6 [rid=fig6] and Figure S5 [this file] ), pLV-hU6-Enh -hUbC-dCas9-KRAB-T2a-GFP ( Figure S6 [this file] ), pLV-hU6-Enh -hUbC-dCas9-KRAB-T2a-GFP ( Figure S6 [this file] ). 
RNA was treated with the TURBO DNA-free kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific) before being reversed-transcribed in a 20 μL reaction volume containing random hexamers, RiboLock RNAse inhibitor and RevertAid (Thermo Fisher Scientific). qRT-PCR reactions (20 μL) contained 10 μL SYBR Select Master Mix (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and 0.25 μM primers (sequences shown in Table S3 [this file] ) and were performed on a BioRad CFX qPCR machine. 
Primer sequences are shown in Table S3 [this file] . 
4C-seq libraries were generated using Expand Long Template polymerase (Roche) and primers designed using the 4C-seq primer database [xref] [rid=bib50] ( Table S3 [this file] ). 
Assays were carried out as described previously. [xref] [rid=bib95] Briefly, 2–3h after plating in 24-well plates, mouse cortical neurons were transfected using Optimem containing 375 ng dCas9-KRAB-MECP2 DNA, 125 ng BPK1520 (Non-targeting, or containing guides targeting), a GFP expression vector (200 ng pBIRD ( Figure 5 [rid=fig5] ) or 500 ng pCIG vector (EV or pBdnf); Figure S5 [this file] ) and 0.8–1.5 μL Lipofectamine 2000 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). 
W.V. analyzed HiC and CTCF ChIP-seq data ( Figure S1 [this file] B).

title: No Title
caption:
Additional file 1: 
 Figure S1A.  Non-comprehensive overview of major growth signaling functions of PP2A complexes. A key mechanism by which PP2A exerts its tumor suppressive role resides in controlling several components downstream of RAS signaling, including PI3K/AKT, MEK/ERK and JAK/STAT, thereby preventing anomalous cell survival, growth and migration. PP2A is also more directly involved in preventing activation of diverse proto-oncogenes, including β-catenin and c-MYC, as well as in promoting activation of major tumor suppressors, such as p53 and pRb. Other established roles of PP2A occur in regulation of apoptosis, autophagy, cell division and protein synthesis.  Figure S1B.  Structural diversity of PP2A complexes, and their regulation by cellular inhibitors and activators. Functional PP2A complexes consist of one C and one A subunit (each encoded by two different human genes), or one C, one A and one B-type subunit (encoded by 15 different human genes, some of which give rise to multiple isoforms). Additional regulation of phosphatase activity or holoenzyme assembly occurs by endogenous cellular PP2A inhibitory proteins, such as SET, ANP32A, TIPRL, CIP2A, PME-1/PPME-1 and ARPP19, and cellular PP2A activators, such as IGBP1 and PTPA/PPP2R4.  Table S1.  Genes and search terms that were used to investigate the expression datasets: PP2A-search terms, PDAssign and IPA-EMT.  Table S2.  Spearman correlation and differentially gene expression for GSE15471, GSE16515, GSE101448 and calculated means. Legend:  Table S2A.  For dataset GSE15471, GSE16515 and GSE101448, the Spearman correlation (SP) and corresponding p was computed for the PP2A-genes. The mean Spearman correlation (SPmean: tumor = 1 vs non-tumor = 0) and the median for p-value was computed and expressed as  10 log.  Table S2B.  Differential gene expression (DELTA) was also computed (tumor vs non-tumor as  2 log values) and the mean was calculated (meanDELTA). A t-test was computed for the individual gens in each dataset followed by calculation of median p-value ( 10 log).  Table S2C.  Spearman correlation for EMT-genes.  Table S2D.  Differential gene expression for EMT genes. The in this paper used GSE datasets are publicly accessible through the NCBI website ( https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ ).  Table S3.  RNA expression in clone OA7G vs control Panc-1 cells. The  2 log fold change for PP2A and EMT genes was calculated for resistant clone OA7G vs untreated Panc-1 cells (FDR = false discovery rate, ns = not significant, nd = not determined).  Table S4.  Differential protein expression in Panc-1 cells exposed to Okadaic acid and clones. Protein composition of Panc-1 cells (Contr), cells exposed to OA for 24 h (OA-24) and the resistant clones OA7A and OA7G was determined. The 2log fold change (with corresponding FDR) for PP2A (A) and EMT genes (B) was calculated relative to untreated Panc-1 cells in the first block of 6 columns. In the second block, differences between the clones or between the clones and OA-24 were calculated. An FDR smaller than 0.05 is indicated in green, when FDR is between 0.05 and 0.20 this is indicated in yellow. (FDR = false discovery rate, ns = not significant, FDR > 0.20). Supplementary Material and Methods: RNA sequencing procedure.

context_description:
This is a group of closely related enzymes that are central to several cellular processes especially control of cell survival and proliferation (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. S1A) [ 17 [rid=CR17] – 19 [rid=CR19] ]. Structurally, PP2A phosphatases are composed of at least two subunits, one of which is the catalytic C subunit, and one is the structural A subunit (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. S1B) [ 21 [rid=CR21] ]. In human cells, these three subunit classes are encoded by 19 different genes (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. S1B). PP2A activity is further regulated by several endogenous inhibitors (e.g., KIAA1524/CIP2A, SET), the expression of which is often increased in cancer cells [ 22 [rid=CR22] , 23 [rid=CR23] ], and by cellular activators (e.g., PTPA), the expression of which is often decreased in tumors [ 24 [rid=CR24] , 25 [rid=CR25] ] (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. S1B). 
They identified a set of 62 genes that could classify the PDAC into subclasses (PDAssign, Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1) [ 5 [rid=CR5] ]. 
This web-based software is backed by the Ingenuity Knowledge Base of highly structured, detail-rich biological and chemical findings obtained through datamining in literature and other databases, and is constantly updated (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1). 
Protein phosphatase 2 (PP2A): We selected a list of 59 search terms (gene symbols and synonyms) based on literature (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1). 
In short, the poly-A containing mRNA molecules were purified, converted into cDNA and sequence-libraries of each sample were equimolarly pooled and sequenced on Illumina NovaSeq 6000 (100 bp, Single Reads, v1.5) (for full methods: see Additional file 1 [this file] ). 
To demonstrate an association in patients between PP2A and EMT, we performed hierarchical clustering in dataset GSE15471 (GSE15471) now using a PP2A gene list (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1). 
A full list of results for PP2A and EMT-genes in the different datasets is given in the Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S2. 
Tumor samples were clustered based on PDAssign, EMT or PP2A gene sets (see Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1), each classifier resulted in two clusters. 
In addition, twenty-four-hour culture with OA had a stronger effect on gene expression (6300 of 12,400 genes showed altered expression with a log >+ 1 or < − 1) than long-term culture (only 2749 and 2863 genes for clones 7A and 7G respectively showed altered expression—see also Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] A vs Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S3), suggesting adaptation over time. 
Notably, e.g., expression of and changed in opposite directions in short-term vs. long-term treated cells, whereas e.g. and , responded in the same way (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S3, Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] A). 
In addition, as observed for the EMT genes, some PP2A genes were oppositely affected in short- versus long-term treated conditions (e.g., and many of the endogenous PP2A inhibitor genes) (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] B) (detailed numbers shown for OA7G in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S3). 
Of these, the proteins present in the EMT list and those from the PP2A list were selected and subsequently analyzed by hierarchical clustering (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] C, D—statistical overview in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4). 
At the protein level, we found limited effects on PP2A expression in the cells treated for 24 h (OA-SH), while a shift becomes more pronounced in clone OA7G, and clone OA7A showed an intermediate change in PP2A protein expression pattern (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] D and Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4A). For the EMT markers, each of the conditions has its own protein expression pattern (Fig. 7 [rid=Fig7] C and Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4B). Differential expression evaluation versus untreated cells confirmed the clustering, while, between the clones, no statistical difference was identified (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4).
pub_title: Human pancreatic cancer patients with Epithelial-to-Mesenchymal Transition and an aggressive phenotype show a disturbed balance in Protein Phosphatase Type 2A expression and functionality

Using the same approach, we also obtained the prey specificity scores for proteins identified in chromatin ( Supplementary Fig S2B [this file] ) and soluble fractions ( Supplementary Fig S2C [this file] ). These analyses allowed us to easily rule out the generic preys (HSPs) and other non-specific binding proteins (actin, tubulin, RPLs), which appear as tails at the lower right corner of each atlas, while the proteins with high specificity and abundance appear in the upper right regions ( Supplementary Fig S2 [this file] ).

We have obtained eight potential positive regulators and six potential negative regulators of MAX, and six potential positive regulators of FOXO3 ( Supplementary Fig S3C [this file] and E [this file] ). Overexpression of FOXK1 translocated FOXO3 to the nucleus, while knocking down FOXK1 reduced the FOXO3 nuclear translocation upon treatment with PI3K inhibitor LY294002 ( Supplementary Fig S3F [this file] ).

context_description: On the basis of our proteomics studies, we proposed that we could use this location-specific (i.e. chromatin-associated and soluble) interactomes to predict how TFs function or are regulated in the cell (Figs 4 [rid=fig04] – 6 [rid=fig06] and Supplementary Fig S4 [this file] ). For example, RBPJ/CBF1, a TF that plays a central role in Notch signalling (Tanigaki & Honjo, 2010 [rid=b70] ), is functionally annotated to be linked with the Notch signalling pathway ( Supplementary Fig S4A [this file] ). These results agree well with the known diverse functions of FOXO3 in these processes ( Supplementary Fig S4B [this file] ). Moreover, both RBPJ and FOXO3 proteins could be functionally annotated to novel function or regulations based on our PPI studies: RBPJ might be regulated by DNA methylation-mediated transcriptional repression ( Supplementary Fig S4A [this file] ), and FOXO3 is potentially involved in BRCA1 signalling in DNA damage response ( Supplementary Fig S4B [this file] ).

context_description:
We identified a total of 29,919 interacting proteins from 120 TF and 70 control TAP/MS, which represents 3,751 unique preys ( Supplementary Tables S3 [rid=sd7] and S4 [this file] ). 
Our TAP/MS and corresponding reciprocal TAP/MS analysis showed that CREB1 and NFATC1/2 bind to each other only in the chromatin fraction, which is also the case for ATF1/2/3/7 and NFATC1 (Table 2 [rid=tbl2] , Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). However, CREB1 and ATFs always bind to each other, regardless of whether they are on or off chromatin (Table 2 [rid=tbl2] , Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
For instance, we compared the GO annotation results of RBPJ ( Supplementary Fig S4A [this file] ) and FOXO3 ( Supplementary Fig S4B [this file] ) based on their non-self-interact HCIPs (TF-HCIP) or with the known functions in the literature (TF literature). We have not only identified previously reported functions such as Notch signalling (Tanigaki & Honjo, 2010 [rid=b70] ) and PI3K/AKT signalling (Brunet , 1999 [rid=b11] ; Tzivion , 2011 [rid=b73] ), oestrogen receptor signalling (Guo & Sonenshein, 2004 [rid=b27] ; Xia , 2006 [rid=b79] ), but also novel function or regulations, such as RBPJ might be regulated by DNA methylation-mediated transcriptional repression ( Supplementary Fig S4A [this file] ), and FOXO3 is potentially involved in checkpoint signalling in the DNA damage response ( Supplementary Fig S4B [this file] ). 
Supplementary Tables S3 [rid=sd7] and S4 [this file] contain the lists of both the peptides identified and the proteins identified during these analyses.

For example, proteins SIN3A, SAP130, ARID4B, MORC2, FOXK1 and FOXK2 from MAX purification have been confirmed by the CCI database ( Supplementary Table S6 [this file] “CCI-Confirmed” column). In total, 389 interactions of the total 2,156 HCIPs (∽18%) were reported previously (Fig 2D [rid=fig02] and Supplementary Table S6 [this file] ). To experimentally verify our proteomics data set ( Supplementary Table S6 [this file] ), we performed reciprocal purifications using prey proteins and hoped to identify the corresponding bait proteins. 
We listed the protein families of these HCIPs ( Supplementary Table S6 [this file] ) and summarized them in two different fractions (Fig 4B [rid=fig04] ).

THP-1, an accepted human leukemia monocytic cell line , showed similar expression levels of compared to monocytes isolated from blood after FACS sorting (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). RNA-seq revealed that was induced after iPSC-differentiation to monocytes (d15), but lost again in macrophages (d21) (Fig. 1c, d [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM3] - 3 [rid=MOESM5] ), and that isoform NR_164153.1 (NR_164153.1) was predominantly expressed in monocytes (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). was one of the top altered lncRNAs expressed in monocytes compared to iPSC or macrophages (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] ). 
The successful knockout was validated by PCR with primers against the deleted genomic region and Sanger sequencing (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] , Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ), with RT-qPCR on cDNA level (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] ) and did not affect Anxa4 protein levels or splicing of (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). An additional RNA-seq and Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin (ATAC-seq) of knockout and non-targeting control (NTC) THP-1 cells revealed loss of expression accompanied by a loss of accessible chromatin of the deleted region (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
RNA immunoprecipitation in THP-1 and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) with antibodies against RUNX1 demonstrated that interacted with RUNX1, but not with the IgG negative control or in HEK293T cells (Fig. 2g [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
This strategy led to a knockout of RUNX1 on protein level, while the knockout itself had no effect (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 5a, b [this file] ). To determine the differential gene expression profile of and RUNX1 knockout THP-1 cells, RNA-seq was performed (Fig. 3c–f [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 7 [rid=MOESM9] , Supplementary Data 8 [this file0] ). 
CUT&RUN followed by high-resolution mapping of DNA binding sites affected by knockout showed that more than the majority of RUNX1-binding sites was decreased: 653 unaffected RUNX1-binding sites between control and knockout were found, but 801 RUNX1-binding sites decreased in knockout cells (Fig. 3i [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 9 [this file1] ). The -dependent alteration in RUNX1-DNA binding sites identified 66 genes in total that also exhibited differential expression in our RNA-seq analysis (Fig. 3l [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 7 [rid=MOESM9] , Supplementary Data 9 [this file1] ). The motif results for the common and downregulated RUNX1 peaks showed that the RUNX motif was the top hit in each of the peaksets, although there is a difference in the percentage of peaks with the motif between the common and downregulated groups (common >60% of the peaks have the motif, and downregulated >30%) (Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ). 
Interestingly, overexpression of the Alu-element of in knockout THP-1 cells rescued the expression of and (Fig. 4h, i [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] ). 
Therefore, or RUNX1 knockout THP-1 were differentiated into osteoclast-like cells under the constant stimulation of RANKL and M-CSF (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ), which was followed by RNA-seq (Supplementary Data 10 [this file2] , Supplementary Data 11 [this file3] ). Before sequencing, osteoclast markers , , and were tested with RT-qPCR and were significantly increased in osteoclast-like cells compared to basal THP-1 (Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] ). Expression levels of many ossification marker genes were increased in knockout compared to control and RUNX1 knockout (Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] ). However, the overlap of differentially expressed genes in and RUNX1 knockout THP-1-differentiated osteoclasts was limited (Supplementary Fig. 7d–g [this file] , Supplementary Data 10 [this file2] , Supplementary Data 11 [this file3] ).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
As shown in Supplementary Fig. 1a, b [this file] , we unexpectedly found that regardless of a high or low inocula, fungal loads in kidney, spleen and brain were maintained at a constantly high level over the first 7-day experimental period, which normally represents a time window for induction of innate immunity . Notably, infection with pathogenic SC5314 yeast cells (5 × 10 CFUs) continuously yielded high tissue fungal burdens during the course of experiments (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ), evidence on disease causality. Moreover, histopathologic examination of Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) and hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained sections from -infected mice confirmed abundant tissue colonization of aggregate yeast cells with no pseudohyphae and filaments, however, showed less severe inflammation and tissue damage and had much smaller multifocal areas of abscess formation than did -infected mice (Supplementary Fig. 1d–f [this file] ). 
Longer incubation periods ( ., 24 h) were not considered in this study, since we observed robust cell death in BMDMs 24 h after co-incubation (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). When yeast-form cells of or were inactivated by 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA-killed) and treated with BMDMs, we also found that was able to stimulate higher levels of cytokine/chemokine gene expression (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ), minimizing a possible effect of hyphal induction during co-culture. 
Principal component analysis (PCA) performed on accurately normalized data showed that mapped RNA-seq reads of both PBS and were clustered together, with minor variations between the biological replicates, whereas reads of exhibited major variance, as a clear separation from PBS and was observed (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ), suggesting that the host response of was very similar to that of PBS but significantly separated from that of . By contrast, treating BMDMs with C. significantly increased the number of DEGs, with 201 and 884 genes at the 3 and 6 h time points, respectively (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). KEGG pathway enrichment analysis of DEGs (Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM6] and 4 [rid=MOESM7] ) showed that the host response specific for stimulation includes genes related to chemokine, Th17, Toll-like receptor, JAK-STAT, NF-κB, and MAPK signaling pathways, whereas it is not the case for the response to (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). This tendency became even more obvious when we compared changes in the expression of selected innate immune-related genes during the interaction of BMDMs with PBS, or s (Fig. 1f [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] ). 
Interestingly, we observed peak levels of phosphorylated ERK, JNK, and p38 MAPKs in BMDMs after co-culture with live cells for 15 min (Fig. 1g [rid=Fig1] ), and at this time, the cells were still uniformly yeast-form (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ), downplaying the influence of hyphal formation on host MAPK activation. 
Interestingly, no statistically significant difference was observed in adhesion between skin-derived HaCat and gut-derived Caco-2 (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ), and an in vitro infection model using the commercial three-dimensional reconstructed epidermis-EpiSkin also verified the weak adherence ability of (Supplementary Fig. 5b, c [this file] ). However, in vivo model of murine skin, topical exposure revealed that established persistent colonization on the skin surface (Supplementary Fig. 5d, e [this file] ). Moreover, we found that unlike , failed to be endocytosed by Caco-2 cells (Supplementary Fig. 5f, g [this file] , Supplementary Movies 1 [rid=MOESM9] , 2 [this file0] ) and some other epithelial or endothelial cells (Supplementary Movies 3 [this file1] – 10 [this file8] ). Second, we investigated host-pathogen interactions by examining the abilities of different immune cells, including macrophages and neutrophils from humans and mice, to phagocytose and kill yeast cells in vitro. or cells were co-cultured over time with mouse BMDMs and primary human monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs), respectively, and initial recognition by macrophages was investigated by live video microscopy (Supplementary Movies 11 [this file9] – 14 [rid=MOESM22] ). In both human and mouse macrophages, showed reduced rates of uptake compared to (Fig. 2f, g [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ) and the phagocytic index of was also less than that of after 30 and 60 min of co-culture (Fig. 2f, h [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 6a, c [this file] ). Similar results were observed for PFA-killed yeast-form cells of both strains (Supplementary Fig. 6d–f [this file] ). Compared to , appeared to be taken up and internalized by neutrophils at lower rates (Fig. 2i–k [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 6g–i [this file] ). Importantly, the weaker interaction between and innate immune cells correlated with stronger resistance to intracellular killing by phagocytic cells (Fig. 2l, m [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 6j, k [this file] ). Indeed, further analysis using fluorescent microscopy proved that compared to , caused a small, but significant fall in the percentage of uptake (Supplementary Fig. 6l [this file] ) and phagocytic index (Supplementary Fig. 6m [this file] ), as well as less damage to the phagocytes like BMDMs (Fig. 2n [rid=Fig2] ). 
We further evaluated innate immune responses using the mouse model described above (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). It has to be noted that different inoculum doses of (5 × 10 CFU/mice) and (1 × 10 CFU/mice) were used, largely because of the fact that mice inoculated with at 1 × 10 CFU experience a clinical illness manifested by ruffled fur, reduced activity and weight loss, and rapidly reach the humane endpoints (within 5 days) (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). It has to be noted that all mice infected with cells survived and appeared to be clinically normal, although we did observe abnormal symptoms, including slight weight loss, head bobbing and body spinning, in mice receiving a high inoculum (2 × 10 CFU/mice) (Supplementary Fig. 7b, c [this file] ). Consistent with the results in Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] , we observed in Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] that following inoculation, the fungal burden was fairly constant and high on day 2 and 5 post-inoculations, regardless of inoculum size. 
Consistently, we found that the distribution of innate immune cells (e.g., leukocytes, CD11b cells, macrophages, monocytes, and NK cells) mirrored the patterns described for neutrophils, is particularly present in significantly higher numbers in -infected tissues versus -infected tissues (Fig. 3d, e [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 8b, c [this file] ). In terms of tissue fungal burden, there was no significant difference between and (Supplementary Fig. 8d [this file] ). However, we noticed that serum levels of cytokines/chemokines were significantly higher in -infected mice than in -inoculated mice (Supplementary Fig. 8e [this file] ) (the data on day 5 were unavailable because most mice reach the humane endpoint and have to be sacrificed before that time), minimizing the possible effect of inoculum size on innate immune activation. 
Our in vitro assays using different mammalian cells showed that all three cell types of displayed no differences in cell adherence (Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] ) and macrophage cytotoxicity (Supplementary Fig. 9b [this file] ). Moreover, all three cell types of also failed to induce p38 MAPK activation (Supplementary Fig. 9c [this file] ) and cytokine production (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 9d [this file] ). Consistently, when mice were challenged with either Y or FC form of in two different inoculum sizes, we observed that neither low (10 CFU/mice; L) nor high (2 × 10 CFU/mice; H) dose inoculum shows significant differences in fungal loads (Supplementary Fig. 9e, f [this file] ), innate immune cell populations (Fig. 4b, c [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 9g, h [this file] ) and cytokine production (Fig. 4d [rid=Fig4] ), highly suggesting that innate immune evasion of appears to be morphology-independent. 
Among them, 14 strains were isolated in different geographical areas, including 4 from China (Cau-C #1–2, Clade I; Cau-C#3–4, Clade III), 2 from Japan (Cau-J #1–2, Clade II), 6 from India (Cau-I #1–4, Clade I; Cau-I #5-6, Clade III), 1 from Korea (Cau-K, Clade II), 1 from South America (Cau-S, Clade IV), and 2 strains were independently isolated following repeated serial passage of the parental strain BJCA001 in fluconazole-containing medium (BJCA001-R #1–2) (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). Fluconazole resistance in each strain was assessed by a checkerboard assay according to the respective minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the drug (Supplementary Fig. 10a [this file] ). Similar to BJCA001, the rest of strains also failed to elicit meaningful proinflammatory response in BMDMs (MOI = 5; 3 or 6 h), as evidenced by unaltered p38 MAPK phosphorylation (Supplementary Fig. 10b [this file] ) and decreased expression and secretion of cytokines/chemokines (Fig. 4e, f [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 10c, d [this file] ). Similar results were obtained in experiments with lower doses of inoculum (MOI = 0.1) and longer time in stimulation (24 h) (Fig. 4g [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 10e [this file] ). 
The results are summarized in Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] . 
Notably, the HPLC elution profiles of the two strains were identical (Supplementary Fig. 12 [this file] ) and no additional distinct peaks were present between the two HPLC chromatograms, suggesting that should have no alternative PAMPs which may differ considerably from . The changes in cell wall polysaccharide fractions in and were further confirmed by both fluorescent staining and flow cytometry (Fig. 5f [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Fig. 13a [this file] ). A similar exposure pattern was observed during host-pathogen interaction (Supplementary Fig. 13b [this file] ). As shown in Supplementary Fig. 13c [this file] , same patterns of β-glucan exposure were shown in both staining methods. Confirmation of acid-labile mannan (phosphomannan) deficiency was observed by the reduced Alcian blue staining (Supplementary Fig. 13d [this file] ). 
Consistent with previous findings , the Δ/Δ mutant strain had a complete loss of phosphomannan (Supplementary Fig. 13e [this file] ) and displayed a significant reduction in macrophage uptake (Supplementary Fig. 13f [this file] ). Surprisingly, this mutant was still able to induce at least the same or even higher cytokine production when compared to the wild-type (Supplementary Fig. 13g [this file] ). Furthermore, we also found that deletion had no effect on pathogenicity because the Δ/Δ mutant was equally virulent in mice compared to its wild-type counterpart (Supplementary Fig. 13h [this file] ) . 
To further validate the essential role of the outer mannan layer of cell wall in protection against innate immune responses, we focused on various mannan-binding receptors in host, including the mannose receptor (MR), Mincle, DC-SIGN, TLR4, and TLR2. stimulation induced higher expression levels of these receptor-encoding genes in BMDMs than did (Supplementary Fig. 14a [this file] ). Moreover, blockade of Mincle or DC-SIGN in BMDMs, by using specific antibodies, resulted in unexpected cytokine responses seen either increasing or decreasing expression of cytokines in response to depending on the type of cytokine and blocking antibody tested (Supplementary Fig. 14b, c [this file] ). 
In , glycosylation of cell wall mannoproteins involves activities of a number of enzymes, for example, the families of fungal-specific mannosyltransferases (Supplementary Fig. 15a [this file] ). Searching the genome database for the number of genes encoding mannosyltransferases identified 51 in and 49 in , respectively (Supplementary Fig. 15b [this file] , Supplementary Data 5 [rid=MOESM8] ). Further RT-qPCR analyses indicated that the transcript levels of genes encoding the major protein - and - mannosyltransferases were significantly increased in when compared to their levels in (Supplementary Fig. 15c [this file] ), which may explain the observed phenotype that has an extensive outer mannan layer. 
Searching the released genome sequence of identified a gene orthologue encoding the protein product that shares 76.6% sequence similarity with Pmr1 of (Supplementary Fig. 16a [this file] ). In vitro analysis showed that Δ mutant of displayed significant vegetative growth defects, formed large aggregates and maintained yeast forms (Supplementary Fig. 16b–e [this file] ). Furthermore, similar to its counterpart in , the deletion mutant of also exhibited a weakened cell wall, exemplified by increased sensitivity to cell wall- and cell membrane-damaging agents such as Calcofluor White (CFW), Congo Red and SDS (Supplementary Fig. 16f [this file] ), and activation of the cell wall integrity pathway (Supplementary Fig. 16g [this file] ), suggesting that this gene is the functional ortholog of . 
belongs to one of the family members encoding a protein -mannosyltransferase catalyzing the initial step of protein -glycosylation (Supplementary Fig. 15a [this file] ) . Pmt1 shares a 55.2% sequence similarity with its orthologue Pmt1 (Supplementary Fig. 17a [this file] ). In vitro assays revealed that Δ mutant of had similar growth phenotypes as Δ mutant (Supplementary Fig. 17b–d [this file] ). Similar to Δ/Δ mutant of , Δ mutant of did exhibit growth and morphology defects in cell wall- and cell membrane-damaging agents (Supplementary Fig. 17e [this file] ), as well as activation of the cell wall integrity pathway (Supplementary Fig. 17f [this file] ). 
In yeast fungi like , -mannan outer chain synthesis is initiated by the α-(1,6)-mannosyltransferase encoded by whose protein product shares 76.6% sequence similarity with Och1 of (Supplementary Fig. 18a [this file] ). We, therefore, generated a Tetoff- mutant in which the endogenous promoter in BJCA001 was replaced with the tetracycline-regulatable promoter (Supplementary Fig. 18b, c [this file] ). When mutant cells were cultured with doxycycline, growth was unaffected on standard YPD medium (Supplementary Fig. 18d [this file] ) but the mannan content at the cell surface was remarkably decreased, based on fluorescent staining and flow cytometry (Supplementary Fig. 18e [this file] ), reconfirming the conserved function of Och1 in the elaboration of the outer mannan chains. More importantly, growth in 5 μg/ml doxycycline, which is sufficient to significantly reduce the expression of (Supplementary Fig. 18c [this file] ), significantly stimulated the production of cytokines (TNFα) by BMDMs (Supplementary Fig. 18f [this file] ), suggesting that protein glycosylation in the outer layer of cell wall also plays a key role in suppressing the innate immune response. 
All reagents and antibodies used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
All strains used in the experiments are listed in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . strain BJCA001, the first clinical isolate of in China , and wild-type reference strain SC5314 , were utilized for all in vitro and in vivo studies. 
A detailed list of specific antibodies is provided in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
A clinical score was determined to evaluate the disease severity of each animal, using parameters that were described previously and mainly include body weight, fur, lethargy, and motility (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
Construction of mutants was performed using protocols developed for use in , with minor modifications (Supplementary Figs. 16 [this file] b and 18b [this file] ) . The primers used for PCR amplification are listed in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] and plasmids used for gene deletion are listed in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
All primers listed in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] . 
A total of 1 × 10 live cells were blocked with CD16/CD32 and stained with antibodies listed in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . A detailed description of gating strategy is provided in Supplementary Fig. 19 [this file] .
