title: No Title
caption: Transcriptional analysis does not reveal significant differences of hyalocytes from macular pucker and macular hole eyes.  (A)  13 patients undergoing vitrectomy for macular pucker (right-hand side panel) or macular hole (left-hand side panel) were included in this study.  (B)  Heatmap depicting the transcriptional profile of the 13 samples. The color bars on the top of the heatmap reveal diagnosis of study subjects (pink for macular pucker, lilac for macular hole), sex (grass-green for male, orange for female), and age (age bar on the right side). Color coding according to the  z -score (deviation from a gene’s mean expression in standard deviation units). The transcripts are sorted according to the normalized counts (log2-scaled).  (C)  Volcano plot illustrating the genes differentially expressed between hyalocytes in macula pucker and macular hole patients [log2FC < -2 and > 2 (positive log2FC referring to macular hole samples),  p -value < 0.05]. The darker colored genes are filtered for StdErr ≤ 1.  (D)  Graphical presentation of the percentiles of normalized counts to illustrate the similarity between the transcriptomes of maclar pucker (MP) and macular hole (MH) eyes. The expression of each gene in each cell population was calculated as a percentile (the gene with the highest mean of normalized counts getting the percentile 100, the one with the lowest – the percentile 0). Colors code for the similarity defined as 1 min Δ percentile. The Pearson coefficient  R 2  quantifies the deviation from the diagonal with the incline 1.
description: FIGURE  S1  Transcriptional  analysis  does  not  reveal  significant  differences  of  hyalocytes  from  macular  pucker  and  macular  hole  eyes.  (A)  13  patients  undergoing  vitrectomy  for  macular  pucker  (right-hand  side  panel)  or  macular  hole  (left-hand  side  panel)  were  included  in  this  study.  (B)  Heatmap  depicting  the  transcriptional  profile  of  the  13  samples.  The  color  bars  on  the  top  of  the  heatmap  reveal  diagnosis  of  study  subjects  (pink  for  macular  pucker,  lilac  for  macular  hole),  sex  (grass-green  for  male,  orange  for  female),  and  age  (age  bar  on  the  right  side).  Color  coding  according  to  the  z  -score  (deviation  from  a  gene’s  mean  expression  in  standard  deviation  units).  The  transcripts  are  sorted  according  to  the  normalized  counts  (log2-scaled).  (C)  Volcano  plot  illustrating  the  genes  differentially  expressed  between  hyalocytes  in  macula  pucker  and  macular  hole  patients  [log2FC  <  -2  and  >  2  (positive  log2FC  referring  to  macular  hole  samples),  p  -value  <  0.05].  The  darker  colored  genes  are  filtered  for  StdErr  ≤  1.  (D)  Graphical  presentation  of  the  percentiles  of  normalized  counts  to  illustrate  the  similarity  between  the  transcriptomes  of  maclar  pucker  (MP)  and  macular  hole  (MH)  eyes.  The  expression  of  each  gene  in  each  cell  population  was  calculated  as  a  percentile  (the  gene  with  the  highest  mean  of  normalized  counts  getting  the  percentile  100,  the  one  with  the  lowest  –  the  percentile  0).  Colors  code  for  the  similarity  defined  as  1  min  Δ  percentile.  The  Pearson  coefficient  R  2  quantifies  the  deviation  from  the  diagonal  with  the  incline  1.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
Hierarchical clustering of expressed genes from all hyalocytes revealed no strong patterns that were related to diagnosis, sex or age ( Supplementary Figures S1A,B [this file] ). The expression profile of vitreal hyalocytes in patients with macular pucker or macular hole ( Supplementary Figure S1A [this file] ) was very similar ( Supplementary Figure S1B [this file] ) and only a negligible number of transcripts were differentially expressed between these two groups ( Supplementary Figures S1C,D [this file] ). The comparable transcriptional profile of hyalocytes derived from eyes with macular pucker and macular hole ( Supplementary Figures S1B–D [this file] ) implies no or at least a similar affection of hyalocytes due to the underlying vitreoretinal interface pathology. 
However, no obvious difference was found in the expression profiles of hyalocytes in patients with macular pucker and macular hole ( Figures 3A,B [rid=F3] and Supplementary Figure S1 [this file] ).
pub_title: Transcriptional Profiling Uncovers Human Hyalocytes as a Unique Innate Immune Cell Population

title: No Title
caption: Hyalocytes express numerous leucocyte-associated transcripts. Box plots, illustrating the normalized reads count  PTPRC  (CD45),  ITGAL  (CD11a),  CX3CR1 ,  HLA-DRA ,  SALL1 ,  ITGB2  (CD18),  HEXB ,  CD14 ,  CD68 ,  FCGR1A  (CD64), and  ITGAM  (CD11b) in hyalocytes (Hy), macrophages (Mac), brain microglia (BrMG), and monocytes (Mono).
description: FIGURE  S2  Hyalocytes  express  numerous  leucocyte-associated  transcripts.  Box  plots,  illustrating  the  normalized  reads  count  PTPRC  (CD45),  ITGAL  (CD11a),  CX3CR1  ,  HLA-DRA  ,  SALL1  ,  ITGB2  (CD18),  HEXB  ,  CD14  ,  CD68  ,  FCGR1A  (CD64),  and  ITGAM  (CD11b)  in  hyalocytes  (Hy),  macrophages  (Mac),  brain  microglia  (BrMG),  and  monocytes  (Mono).  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
Furthermore, human hyalocytes express numerous common leukocyte-associated genes, such as (CD45), (CD11a), and (CD18), or preferentially in myeloid cells, e.g., (CD11b), CD14, and (CD64) supporting the notion of a myeloid-cell derived origin ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). 
Immunohistochemical studies ( 29 [rid=B29] ) and our sequencing data ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ) indicate that vitreal hyalocytes belong to the myeloid cell lineage. While or (CD64) were highly and similarly expressed in hyalocytes and brain microglia, they were barely detectable in macrophages and monocytes ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). Expression of (MHCII) molecules and , in contrast, was remarkably increased in hyalocytes compared to a low expression in microglia, macrophages or monocytes ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). On the other hand, expression was significantly reduced in hyalocytes compared to microglia, macrophages or monocytes ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). Interestingly, expression was, as expected, high in microglia but almost not detectable in hyalocytes, macrophages, or monocytes ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ).
pub_title: Transcriptional Profiling Uncovers Human Hyalocytes as a Unique Innate Immune Cell Population

Heatmap  depicting  the  expression  of  genes  coding  for  extracellular  matrix  proteins  in  hyalocytes  (Hy)  and  microglia  (BrMG). Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description: Relative expression values for the 30 most strongly represented transcripts common to all samples demonstrated that human hyalocytes express high levels of numerous genes associated with antigen presentation, including , , and , regulation of myeloid cell migration and chemotaxis, such as , , , and humoral immune response, e.g., , , and ( Figures 2A–C [rid=F2] and Supplementary Figure S3A [this file] ). In addition, a plethora of factors involved in vitreous metabolism were found to be strongly expressed in hyalocytes in our analysis ( Supplementary Figure S3 [this file] ).
pub_title: Transcriptional Profiling Uncovers Human Hyalocytes as a Unique Innate Immune Cell Population

caption: Biological processes and molecular functions of human hyalocytes. All top expressed genes enriched in the 5 most disease-relevant GO biological processes (BP,  A ) and molecular functions (MF,  B ) terms are illustrated in cnetplots.
description: FIGURE  S4  Biological  processes  and  molecular  functions  of  human  hyalocytes.  All  top  expressed  genes  enriched  in  the  5  most  disease-relevant  GO  biological  processes  (BP,  A  )  and  molecular  functions  (MF,  B  )  terms  are  illustrated  in  cnetplots.  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description: GO enrichment analysis of BP showed that hyalocytes express genes that are involved in “humoral immune response” (GO:0006959), “leukocyte chemotaxis and migration” (GO:0030595 and GO:0050900), “myeloid leukocyte migration” (GO:0097529), and “antigen processing and presentation of peptide antigen” (GO:0048002; adjusted < 0.00, Figure 2B [rid=F2] , and Supplementary Figure S4A [this file] ). was the most highly expressed factor in two of the most enriched clusters ( Figure 2C [rid=F2] ). When sorted according to the lowest adjusted value, the GO enrichment analysis revealed MF such as “amide and peptide binding” (GO:0033218 and GO:0042277), “amyloid-beta binding” (GO:0001540), “MHC class II protein complex binding” (GO:0023026), and “MHC protein complex binding” (GO:0023023) to be the most enriched in hyalocytes ( Supplementary Figure S4B [this file] and Supplementary Table S3 [rid=DS3] ). All top expressed genes enriched in the 5 most relevant GO BP and MF terms are illustrated in the cnetplots in Supplementary Figure S4 [this file] and summarized in Supplementary Tables S2 [rid=DS2] , S3 [rid=DS3] .
pub_title: Transcriptional Profiling Uncovers Human Hyalocytes as a Unique Innate Immune Cell Population

More hyalocytes positive for CD74 are shown in Supplementary Figure S6A [this file] . 
Immunohistochemical staining for HLA-DRA and IBA1 (ionized calcium-binding adapter molecule 1) revealed that hyalocytes express HLA-DRA on the protein level, while microglia cells were at most slightly positive for HLA-DRA, but positive for IBA1 supporting our sequencing data ( Figure 3F [rid=F3] and Supplementary Figure S6B [this file] ).

A p38α-BLIMP1 signalling pathway is essential for plasma cell differentiation
A p38α-BLIMP1 signalling pathway is essential for plasma cell differentiation
A p38α-BLIMP1 signalling pathway is essential for plasma cell differentiation

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Development of B cell subsets in the spleen and bone marrow of 5–6 weeks old mice showed almost no difference between and mice (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). Although the percentage of small pre B cells in bone marrow from mice was less than that in WT mice, total cell number and frequency of peripheral B cells were not changed in mice (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). Similarly, no significant effect of deletion, starting at early hematopoiesis in mice, on the generation of B cell subsets was found (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). 
In the absence of immunization, the basal serum level of IgG1 was lower than, whereas the concentrations of IgM, IgG2a, IgG2b, and IgG3 in mice were similar to mice (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). Correlated with these data, we also observed a decrease in the number of PCs in non-immunized mice (Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] ). Meanwhile, NP-specific plasmablasts and NP-specific IgM, IgG2b, IgG3 ASCs were also significantly less in NP-LPS immunized mice in comparison with mice (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). On the other hand, immunization with NP-Ficoll, by which IgG3 is the dominant IgG form in antibody response, induced similar amounts of NP-specific IgG3 in and mice (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ), suggesting that p38α in B cells was not involved in type II T cell-independent immune response. Consistently, PC generation was significantly decreased by knockout in mice after NP-LPS immunization (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ) but was comparable in NP-Ficoll-immunized mice (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ). 
Naïve B cells isolated from mice, which had a better deletion efficiency in naive B cells than mice (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ) were used for the cellular experiments. To examine the involvement of other p38 family members in PCs generation, we cultured naïve B cells from , or mice in the iPC differentiation system, and found that iPCs generation from those mutant B cells was comparable to their WT counterparts (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] to 3d [this file] ). The genetic knockout of , or in naïve B cells was evidenced by sequencing of p38 isoforms in their corresponding mutation cells (Supplementary Fig. 3e [this file] ). 
The requirement of p38α in PC generation was also examined under several other in vitro culture conditions, including BAFF + CD40L + IL-4, BAFF + CD40L + IL-21, and anti-IgM+IL-4, and iPCs generation from B cells was severely impaired under all those conditions (Supplementary Fig. 3f [this file] ). We also examined the effect of deletion on B cell activation induced by various stimuli, including IL-4, anti-CD40, anti-IgM, and anti-IgM+IL-4, and found no difference (Supplementary Fig. 3g [this file] ). 
Pattern of CFSE dilution was similar in CD19 CD138 and CD19 CD138 cells (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ), and total B cell number at day 4 or day 8 showed no significant difference between and WT cells (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ), indicating that cellular proliferation during iPC differentiation was not altered by deletion. 
We next analyzed the stability of mRNA by treating cells with actinomycin D to block synthesis of new mRNA and found the half-life of mRNA was comparable in cultured and WT B cells (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). Treatment with proteasome inhibitor MG132 and protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide had no effects on BLIMP1 protein stability and translation, respectively, in and WT iPC culture (Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] and 4e [this file] ). 
Differentially expressed genes were classified into 8 groups by whether their expression in iPCs can be restored by ectopic expression of p38α and/or BLIMP1 (Fig. 4c [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). The Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis showed that the genes in Group 5 were mainly enriched in the processes of cell proliferation and activation (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). Since no significant difference in cell division or activation was observed in cultured B cells (Supplementary Fig. 3g [this file] , 4a [this file] and 4b [this file] ), we did not further evaluate this group of genes. 
Retroviruses encoding each sgRNA (BFP ) were produced individually and utilized to transduce B cells from mice (GFP ), followed by analysis of the percentage of iPCs among sgRNA-expressing cells (GFP BFP ) (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] ). was used as a positive control for this system, as shown in Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] , sgRNAs targeting dramatically decreased p38α expression and iPCs generation, consistent with results from mouse genetic studies (Fig. 2a [rid=Fig2] ). 
Moreover, ectopic expression of TCF3, TCF4 and IRF4 partially restored BLIMP1 expression (indicated by GFP expression) in B cells (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ) and IgG1 and IgE secretion in B cells (Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] ), suggesting that p38α controls BLIMP1 expression and antibody secretion via TCF3, TCF4, and IRF4. 
It needs to note that deletion did not affect the protein levels of TCF3 and TCF4 and slightly decreased the IRF4 protein level (Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] and 7d [this file] ). This notion is also supported by the observation of the decrease of IRF4 protein level in B cells in iPC culture (Supplementary Fig. 7e [this file] ). 
We showed that knockout by CRISPR/Cas9 in cultured B cells in iPC differentiation system had no markable effect on B cell number, different from knockout that significantly decreased B cell number (Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). Ectopic expression of MEF2C, or its phospho-mimetic mutants MEF2C-3E (T293E/T300E/S387E) or MEF2C-3D (T293D/T300D/S387D) in cultured B cells had no rescue effect on knockout caused defect in iPC differentiation (Supplementary Fig. 8b [this file] ). Moreover, CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of in both and WT iGCB cells decreased PC differentiation in the iPC differentiation system, suggesting additive effects of MEF2C and p38α in this process (Supplementary Fig. 8c [this file] ). 
However, ectopic expression of a E47 S140D or S140E phosphomimetic mutant in cultured B cells restored iPC differentiation to a degree similar to WT TCF3 (Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] ), suggesting that phosphorylation of Ser140 is dispensable for the function of E47 in iPC generation. 
These reporters could also signpost transactivation of TCF3/TCF4 and IRF4 in the in vitro iPC differentiation system (Supplementary Fig. 9b [this file] ). Co-expression of IRF4 with IRF4 reporter enhanced reporter gene expression and activation of p38α dramatically enhanced IRF4-dependent reporter expression (Supplementary Fig. 9c [this file] ). We mutated each of the potential phosphorylation sites in IRF4 (Supplementary Fig. 9d [this file] ) and expressed them in the co-expression assay. T267A, T268A and T269A mutation, but not the mutation on other sites rendered IRF4 no long response to p38α in increasing IRF4 reporter gene expression (Fig. 7b [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 9e [this file] ) and the triple T to A mutant (T267A/T268A/T269A) of IRF4 completely lost the transcription activity. 
As mentioned before, p38α was required for NP-LPS-induced PC generation in vivo (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ), we therefore investigated whether the p38α-BLIMP1 axis was also involved in this process. 
Here, we show that p38α controls PC differentiation by upregulating transcription via TCF3, TCF4, and IRF4. p38α can directly activate IRF4 by phosphorylating it on T267, T268, and T269 (Supplementary Fig. 9d [this file] ). 
However, S140D or S140E mutant had no difference from WT TCF3 (E47) in restoring iPC differentiation of cultured B cells (Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] ), indicating that the previously described regulation mechanism of TCF3 (E47) by p38α is not applicable to iPC differentiation. 
In agreement with the data of chimeric mice, our studies showed that deletion does not affect B cell development, activation and division (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] and 1b [this file] , Supplementary Figs. 3g [this file] , 4a [this file] and 4b [this file] ). We showed in this study that the effect of knockout on B cell survival was different from that of knockout (Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] ). MEF2C, or its phospho-mimetic mutants cannot rescue the defect in iPC differentiation caused by knockout (Supplementary Fig. 8b [this file] ). And the effect of knockout and knockout had additive effect in impairing iPC differentiation (Supplementary Fig. 8c [this file] ). 
We showed that deletion of and did not affect iPC differentiation (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] and 3d [this file] ). 
All statistical analyses were performed with GraphPad Prism (version: 8.0.2) and SPSS (version: 27.0), and -values were determined by two-tailed unpaired -tests in most experiments, except the -values were determined by one-side hypergeometric test in Gene Ontology enrichment analysis in Fig. 4d [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] .

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S14
caption: No description
context_description:
Over 18 months, we collected fresh BrM specimens and matched blood samples from 31 patients at Emory University Hospital who underwent surgical resection of at least one BrM ( Figure S1 [this file] A). Samples were obtained fresh at time of surgery and included a mixture of primary tumor types, the most abundant of which was lung carcinoma ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] A and S1 [this file] A), consistent with it being the primary cancer most likely to metastasize to the brain. [xref] [rid=bib43] [xref] [rid=bib44] All patients were naive to immunotherapy. 
See also Figure S1 [this file] . 
BrMs were variably infiltrated by immune cells, ranging from 2.9 × 10 to 2 × 10 CD45 lymphocytes per gram of tumor (median 7.6 × 10 ), with BrMs from breast cancer having the lowest infiltration density ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] B and S1 [this file] B). CD8 T cell infiltration was also variable (range of 3.4 × 10 to 1.5 × 10 , median of 2.0 × 10 CD8 T cells/gram of tumor), with breast-carcinoma histology again showing the lowest density of infiltration ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] C and S1 [this file] C). Just under 10% of tumor-infiltrating CD4 T cells expressed FOXP3 by flow cytometry across measured samples ( Figure S1 [this file] D). 
The response to PD-1 pathway blockade and other immunotherapies is primarily mediated by CD8 T cells, and proliferation of these cells is associated with positive clinical outcomes after ICB. [xref] [rid=bib10] [xref] [rid=bib45] To interrogate the phenotype of circulating and tumor-infiltrating CD8 T cells in patients with BrMs, we performed high-parameter flow cytometry on patient-matched tumor-infiltrating and circulating CD8 T cells ( Figure S2 [this file] A). 
CD127 and CD28 have been used as extracellular markers of TCF-1 progenitor CD8 T cells in chronic infections and cancer. [xref] [rid=bib18] [xref] [rid=bib27] [xref] [rid=bib35] In BrM-infiltrating CD8 T cells, CD28 and CD127 were both more frequent on PD-1 TCF-1 compared with PD-1 TCF-1 cells ( Figures S2 [this file] B and S2C), but their expression did not completely recapitulate that of TCF-1. CD127 was mostly absent from PD-1 TCF-1 cells but only expressed on half of PD-1 TCF-1 cells ( Figure S2 [this file] B). CD28 was a more sensitive marker of TCF-1 expression and was found on over 75% of TCF-1 cells but lacked specificity, with expression on over 50% of TCF-1 cells ( Figure S2 [this file] B). 
Most cells in cluster 5 also expressed TOX and were TCF-1 ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] E and S2 [this file] D). 
See also Figure S2 [this file] . 
To determine transcriptional profiles, interrogate differentiation pathways, and examine antigen specificity of these PD-1-expressing cells, we performed scRNA-seq with TCR sequencing on sorted PD-1 CD8 T cells isolated from three non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) BrMs and two melanoma BrMs immediately after surgical resection ( Figure S3 [this file] ). There was no difference in the percentage of cells in each metacluster between BrMs from lung cancer versus melanoma, suggesting that these two tissues of origin did not strongly influence the phenotype of BrM-infiltrating PD-1 CD8 T cells here ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] C and 3D), consistent with our flow-cytometry results ( Figure S2 [this file] E). 
See also Figures S3 [this file] and S4 [this file] . 
Tumor-infiltrating PD-1 CD8 T cells in the A and D metaclusters had a terminally differentiated phenotype similar to that of FlowSOM cluster 5 that was characterized by high expression of genes encoding co-inhibitory molecules such as , (CD39), (TIM-3), and , consistent with this population containing tumor-reactive cells ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] E, 3F, and S4 [this file] A). These cells expressed a unique repertoire of genes encoding cell-surface proteins that could be assessed for co-inhibitory or co-stimulatory potential ( Figure S4 [this file] D). Metaclusters B and C expressed the lowest levels of co-inhibitory markers ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] E, 3F, and S4 [this file] ). They were distinguished from each other by higher expression of tissue-residence genes, such as CD69, in metacluster C ( Figure S4 [this file] A). Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) revealed that the transitory transcriptional signature characterized in the murine lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) model of CD8 T cell exhaustion [xref] [rid=bib19] was enriched in the D metacluster, suggesting that these cells may be undergoing differentiation from stem-like to terminally differentiated PD-1 CD8 T cells ( Figure S4 [this file] B). Similar analysis showed that the LCMV terminally differentiated signature was enriched in metacluster A ( Figure S4 [this file] B). 
To determine the clonal relationship between circulating and BrM-infiltrating CD8 T cells, we performed TCR sequencing on non-naïve PD-1 and PD-1 CD8 T cells sorted from patient-matched peripheral blood ( Figure S3 [this file] ). 
(F and G) Four other patients are shown in Figure S6 [this file] . 
See also Figure S5 [this file] . 
However, these dividing and exhausted cells exhibited minimal TCR overlap with metaclusters B and C, which contained cells with a less- or non-exhausted phenotype ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] E and S5 [this file] ). Most CD8 T cell clones—and particularly the most abundant clones—within each patient’s tumor were mostly restricted to either an exhausted (metaclusters A/D) or progenitor-like (metaclusters B/C) phenotype ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] F, 4G, and S5 [this file] ), indicating that these populations have largely unshared antigen specificity. 
Previous studies have identified tumor-infiltrating bystander CD8 T cells, [xref] [rid=bib40] [xref] [rid=bib50] but little is known about bystander infiltration of BrMs. We queried the VDJdb, a database of TCRs with known specificity, [xref] [rid=bib51] for matches with TCRs from our scRNA-seq data and identified one CMV-specific TCR in each of two patients ( Figure S6 [this file] ). We stimulated these cells with a microbial peptide pool (CEFX), isolated interferon gamma (IFNγ) and IFNγ CD8 T cells by fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS), and performed TCR sequencing on each subset to identify TCRs that responded to CEFX stimulation with cytokine secretion and were thus microbe specific ( Figure 5 [rid=fig5] A and S7 [this file] A). 
See also Figures S6 [this file] and S7 [this file] . 
Phenotypically, CEFX-specific BrM-infiltrating PD-1 CD8 T cells were found within metaclusters B/C in all four patients, where they were significantly enriched ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] B–5D and S7 [this file] B). Importantly, some of these experimentally validated bystander cells had a transcriptional phenotype similar to tumor-specific progenitor PD-1 CD8 T cells characterized in other studies, [xref] [rid=bib35] marked by expression of (CD127), , and (TCF-1) ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] G and S7 [this file] C). 
To test this, we performed spatial transcriptomics, a method to measure gene expression , on six BrM tissue sections: one melanoma ( Figure 6 [rid=fig6] ), one renal cell carcinoma ( Figure S8 [this file] ), one breast carcinoma ( Figure S9 [this file] ), and three lung carcinomas ( Figures S10–S12 [this file] ). 
See also Figures S8–S14 [this file] . 
Tumor parenchyma—referring to regions of tumor cells—was readily differentiated by their gene expression profiles ( Figures 6 [rid=fig6] A, 6B, and S8–S12 [this file] ). For sections where tumor-normal boundaries were clearly demarcated, the number of differentially expressed genes between tumor parenchyma and surrounding stroma ranged from 3,914 to 7,480 ( Figures 6 [rid=fig6] F, S11 [this file] C, and S12 [this file] E). In the two samples where tumor parenchyma and stroma were intermixed, the numbers of differentially expressed genes between the two regions were 637 and 2,327 ( Figures S8 [this file] E and S9 [this file] E). One of the six tissue sections was composed entirely of tumor parenchyma, precluding this analysis ( Figures S10 [this file] A–S10C). 
In the renal cell carcinoma case, “small nests” of tumors showed a higher density of , , and expression than “large nests,” and these transcript levels were even higher in regions of desmoplasia surrounding vessels ( Figures S8 [this file] C and S8D). Additionally, in the two lung-carcinoma samples where tumor parenchyma and brain tissue were visible, transcript levels were highest at the tumor interface with brain ( Figures S11 [this file] D, S12 [this file] C, and S12D). 
See also Figure S10 [this file] . 
These findings were confirmed in the lung carcinoma BrM (patient 15), where the entire tissue section was tumor parenchyma and was inhabited only by TCRs expressed by metacluster A/D cells ( Figures S10 [this file] E–S10J). 
In the renal cell carcinoma sample (patient 24), gene expression varied with tumor architecture: 305 genes were differentially expressed between small and large nests of tumor ( Figures S8 [this file] F–S8H). Major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I expression was higher within small tumor nests compared with large tumor nests ( Figure S8 [this file] F), suggesting that CD8 T cells within the same tumor may receive different levels of TCR stimulation based on their location within the parenchyma. Conversely, in the breast carcinoma sample (patient 24), MHC class I was highly downregulated in capture spots containing tumor, potentially indicating limited tumor-associated antigen presentation to CD8 T cells in this patient ( Figure S9 [this file] G). 
Differences in cytokine and chemokine expression between bulk tumor parenchyma and surrounding tissue were also striking ( Figure S13 [this file] A). As examples, (encoding TGF-β) was enriched in the stroma in three samples, whereas its receptor was more highly expressed predominately in the parenchyma ( Figures S13 [this file] A and S13B). The IFNγ receptor subunit was elevated in the parenchyma of four of five tumors ( Figures S13 [this file] A and S13C). and were upregulated in the parenchyma all five tumors ( Figures S13 [this file] A and S13D). To catalog signaling networks between specific regions of the BrM microenvironment, we used CellPhoneDB [xref] [rid=bib52] to interrogate expression of receptor-ligand pairs between among spatial-transcriptomics clusters ( Figure S14 [this file] ). This analysis revealed several signaling molecules involved in multiple signaling pathways within the BrM microenvironment, including vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A), VEGF-B, TGF-β, galectin-9, epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), and others ( Figures S14 [this file] A–S14D). Confirming the observations above, CellphoneDB analysis showed that tumor-surrounding inflammatory stroma expressed and , with its corresponding receptors found in the tumor parenchyma of patient 16 ( Figure S14 [this file] E). In patient 24, where gene expression varied by tumor histology ( Figure S10 [this file] ), TGF-β signaling also varied within different tumor regions ( Figure S14 [this file] F). Certain galectin-9 signaling pathways also varied between tumor regions ( Figures S14 [this file] E and S14F). Additionally, the commonality of some of these signaling pathways across different patients ( Figures S14 [this file] A–S14D) within our cohort indicates the presence of targetable signaling pathways across BrMs of different primary histologies. 
The duration of dexamethasone therapy prior to surgery was not correlated with CD45 lymphocyte or CD8 T cell infiltration of brain metastases in our cohort ( Figures S1 [this file] E and S1F). 
Cells were then stained for viability, CD3, and CD8 and sorted on a BD FACS ARIA II in the Emory University School of Medicine Flow Cytometry Core ( Figure S7 [this file] A). 
For analyses of boundary and tumor gene expression ( Figure S13 [this file] ) the following clusters were used: sample 16, clusters 5 and 3/4 (boundary and tumor, respectively); sample 19, clusters 3 and 5; sample 24, clusters 4 and 1/2/3; sample 26, clusters 6 and 1/2/3; sample 27, clusters 7 and 2/3/4/5/6.

Immunopeptidomics-Guided Warehouse Design for Peptide-Based Immunotherapy in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
Immunopeptidomics-Guided Warehouse Design for Peptide-Based Immunotherapy in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

title: No Title
caption: Click here for additional data file.
description: Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
Patient characteristics of the immunopeptidome cohort (n = 61) are provided in[this file] . Sample characteristics of the immunogenicity cohort (n = 51) are provided in[this file] . 
The Proteome Discoverer (v1.3, Thermo Fisher) was used to integrate the search results of the SequestHT search engine (University of Washington) ( 30 [rid=B30] ) against the human proteome (Swiss-Prot database, 20 279 reviewed protein sequences, September 27th 2013) accompanied with recurrent somatic CLL-associated mutations in 61 different proteins ([this file] ) as described in the literature ( 31 [rid=B31] , 32 [rid=B32] ) and assigned in the COSMIC database ( ) ( 33 [rid=B33] ) without enzymatic restriction. 
In the first step of our workflow for the definition of an off-the-shelf peptide warehouse ([rid=f1] ), we comprehensively mapped the immunopeptidome of 61 primary CLL samples (n = 52 for HLA class I, n = 49 for HLA class II,[this file] ). The number of identified unique peptides per patient ranged from 527 to 9 530 (mean 3 035,[this file] ). For HLA class II, we identified 70 525 different peptides (range 575-10 392, mean 3 842 per sample,[this file] ) derived from 6 074 source proteins, achieving 85% of maximum attainable coverage ([this file] ). 
In comparison, 76% of patients included in a previous CLL peptide vaccination trial ( NCT02802943 (NCT02802943) ), 68% of the European population, and 61% of the world population carry one or more of these HLA allotypes ([this file] ). Allotype-specific immunopeptidome analysis revealed 8 575 unique HLA-A*02- (range 82-3 723, mean 1 121 per sample), 5 280 unique HLA-A*24- (range 134-1 926, mean 1 042 per sample), and 5 780 unique HLA-B*07-restricted (range 223-2 933, mean 1 140 per sample) peptides derived from 5 020, 3 813, and 3 886 source proteins, achieving 89%, 85%, and 86% of the estimated maximum attainable protein coverage, respectively ([this file] ). Overlap analysis of the total HLA class I immunopeptidome of the CLL cohort with the benign tissue cohort revealed 23 676 peptides to be exclusively presented on CLL samples and never on benign tissue samples ([this file] ). Allotype-specific overlap analysis with the entirety of benign tissue-derived immunopeptidomes revealed 2 774 HLA-A*02-, 1 440 HLA-A*24-, and 1 450 HLA-B*07-presented peptides detected exclusively on CLL samples ([rid=f1] and[this file] ). At a target-definition FDR of < 1%, a total of 393 HLA-A*02-, 168 HLA-A*24-, and 127 HLA-B*07-restricted ligands with allotype-specific representation frequencies up to 73%, 81%, and 60%, respectively, and 3 970 HLA class II-restricted peptides with frequencies up to 59% were identified ([rid=f1] and[this file] ). 
In addition to the identification of high-frequent non-mutated tumor-associated peptides, we screened our CLL cohort for naturally presented neoepitopes derived from common CLL-associated point and frameshift mutations (95 point and 3 frameshift mutations within 61 different genes representing 85 different mutation sites,[this file] ). 
For the setup of a broadly applicable peptide warehouse, we focused on the 532 non-mutated peptides presented by ≥ 20% of (HLA-matched) CLL samples comprising 82 HLA-A*02-, 105 HLA-A*24-, 127 HLA-B*07-, and 218 HLA class II-restricted peptides ([this file] ). 
Experimentally acquired spectra of the selected peptide identifications were validated by comparison of mass spectrometric fragment spectra using isotope-labeled synthetic peptides ([rid=f2] and[this file] ). 
Using aAPC-based priming of naive CD8 T cells of HLA-matched HVs, we confirmed induction of peptide-specific CD8 T cells for all 9 HLA class I peptides in at least 2/3 HVs ([rid=f3] ,[this file] and[rid=T1] ). Intracellular cytokine and degranulation marker staining revealed induction of multifunctional peptide-specific T cells for 7/9 (78%) peptides ([rid=f3] ,[this file] and[rid=T1] ). Moreover, IFN-γ ELISpot assays, using PBMCs from HLA-matched CLL patients, revealed preexisting peptide-specific memory T cells targeting 2/9 (22%) and 4/5 (80%) HLA class I- and HLA class II-restricted warehouse peptides in up to 29% and 50% of CLL patient samples, respectively ([rid=f3] ,[this file] and[rid=T1] ). 
The Supplementary Information contains the[this file] and the[this file] .
pub_title: Immunopeptidomics-Guided Warehouse Design for Peptide-Based Immunotherapy in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

context_description:
Fibroblast cell lines from 15 individuals comprising 3 biological replicates from each of five primate species (human, chimpanzee, gorilla, orangutan, and rhesus macaque) were obtained from Coriell ( supplementary table S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). DNase-seq libraries were generated from 50 million cells and sequenced on Illumina instruments ( supplementary table S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
Details on the number of reads in the input files and at each step are included in supplementary table S2 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online. 
Because some of the samples were from males and some were from females ( supplementary table S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online), we removed reads that mapped or lifted over to the human X or Y chromosomes to eliminate any sex-specific bias. Details on the number of reads lifted over and remaining after removal of sex chromosomes are included in supplementary table S2 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online. 
See supplementary table S3 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online for DHS site counts before and after each filtering step.

Five contrasts were used to identify changes in a single species, six for changes in two species, and four for changes in three species ( Supplementary files 2 [this file] , supplementary table S4 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
We have included Supplementary Material [this file] online that contain the input data for the R script ( Supplementary files 3 [this file] ), the results from the analyses discussed in this article ( Supplementary files 4 [this file] ), and the field information for the input and output files ( Supplementary files 5 [this file] ). The GitHub repository contains a document (also included as Supplementary files 6 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online) detailing the necessary modifications to that script.

We then tested for significant enrichment of positive selection in different classes of DHS sites ( supplementary table S5 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
We then tested whether the distributions of differed between classes of differential DHS sites ( supplementary table S6 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
We then asked whether the distribution of cell type specificity scores varied between different classes of DHS sites ( supplementary table S7 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online).

S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). Because we are drawing on the original data from Shibata et al. (2012) [rid=evz218-B51] for three species (human, chimpanzee and rhesus macaque) and new data generated several years later for two species (gorilla and orangutan) ( supplementary table S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online), we also investigated whether batch effects would overwhelm the species signal by comparing principal component analyses performed with and without three additional chimpanzee samples generated more recently and reported in Pizzollo et al. (2018) [rid=evz218-B38] ( supplementary table S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). As shown in supplementary figure S1 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online, the Pizzollo et al. chimpanzee samples cluster with the original Shibata et al. chimpanzee samples across the first four principal components (cumulative proportion of variance of 0.53), suggesting that biological signal is retained even when samples are prepared and sequenced years apart. 
S5 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). S6 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
Using the species-specific calls from Shibata et al., we detected a high degree of concordance ( supplementary table S8 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). Due to updates in the analysis pipeline, not all of the DHS sites that were previously characterized were also identified as DHS sites in this study ( supplementary table S9 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). For 342 DHS sites that Shibata et al. characterized as human-specific increased accessibility, 245 (72%) are still characterized as human-specific increased accessibility even after including gorilla and orangutan, whereas 91 (27%) are now characterized as increased accessibility in human and at least one other species ( supplementary table S8 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). For 148 DHS sites that Shibata et al. characterized as human-specific decreased accessibility, 21 (14%) are still characterized as human-specific decreased accessibility even after including orangutan and gorilla, whereas 107 (72%) are now characterized as decreased accessibility in human and at least one other species ( supplementary table S8 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). A similar trend was detected for previously identified chimpanzee-specific changes ( supplementary table S8 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). For 1,154 DHS sites that Shibata et al. (2012) [rid=evz218-B51] characterized as nondifferential between human, chimpanzee, and rhesus macaque, 5% (56) displayed changes in accessibility on the gorilla and/or orangutan branches that were not considered by Shibata et al., ( supplementary table S8 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
For DHS sites that are not differential between primate species, 22% (11,850) of these regions overlap proximal elements, 57% (30,371) overlap distal elements, and the remaining 20% (10,857) are unannotated ( fig. 5 [rid=evz218-F5] and supplementary table S10 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). All DHS sites with increased accessibility relative to rhesus macaque display a substantially depleted amount of proximal element overlap compared with the nondifferential DHS sites (human: 3%; chimpanzee: 4%; gorilla: 9%; orangutan: 10%; human–chimpanzee: 3%; human–chimpanzee–gorilla: 5%; fig. 5 [rid=evz218-F5] and supplementary table S10 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). Conversely, half of the classes of DHS sites with decreased accessibility relative to rhesus macaque overlap proximal elements to a similar degree as nondifferential DHS sites (human: 19%; chimpanzee: 22%; gorilla: 12%; orangutan: 21%; human–chimpanzee: 35%; human–chimpanzee–gorilla: 11%; fig. 5 [rid=evz218-F5] and supplementary table S10 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
DHS sites with increased accessibility in chimpanzee, gorilla, or orangutan all have much higher overlaps with unannotated regions, with orangutan increased accessibility showing the highest degree of overlap with unannotated regions ( fig. 5 [rid=evz218-F5] and supplementary table S10 [this file] , Supplementary Material [this file] online). 
Supplementary data [this file] are available at online.
pub_title: Evaluating Chromatin Accessibility Differences Across Multiple Primate Species Using a Joint Modeling Approach

Impact of WIN site inhibitor on the WDR5 interactome

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
Proteins that interact with WDR5 do so through either a hydrophobic cleft called the “WBM” site or an arginine-binding pocket called the “WIN” site ( Figure 1A [rid=F1] ; Figure S1A [this file] ), both of which engage motifs in partner proteins ( Guarnaccia and Tansey, 2018 [rid=R23] ). 
In C6-treated cells, however, WDR5 is absent from fractions above 670 kDa ( Figures 1B [rid=F1] and S1B [this file] ), with most material migrating below the 158-kDa marker. The impact of C6 on complex formation is an authentic consequence of WIN site blockade, because mutation of phenylalanine 133 within the WIN site (F133A) has a comparable impact on the distribution of WDR5 ( Figures S1C [this file] and S1D [this file] ). Supporting this point, an inactivating mutation in the WBM site (L240K), which disrupts interaction with both RBBP5 and KMT2A/B ( Figure 1C [rid=F1] ), has little effect on WDR5 mobility in these gradients ( Figures S1C [this file] and S1D [this file] ). 
We treated lysates from “heavy” and “light” HEK293 cells expressing FLAG-tagged WDR5, recovered proteins by FLAG immunoprecipitation (IP), and analyzed samples by MudPIT liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) ( Figure 2A [rid=F2] ; Figure S2A [this file] ). The experiment was performed in duplicate, with label swap, and a total of 747 proteins were quantified in the IP samples ( Figures S2B [this file] and S2C [this file] ; Table S1 [rid=SD2] ). 
As predicted from experiments in Figure 1 [rid=F1] , most canonical WDR5 interaction partners are recalcitrant to WIN site inhibition, including members of KMT2 and NSL complexes ( Figure 2D [rid=F2] ; Figure S2D [this file] ; Table S2 [this file] ). These same themes are reinforced by results of Reactome pathway and ontology analyses ( Figures S2E [this file] and S2F [this file] ). 
We confirmed that interaction of FLAG-tagged WDR5 with PDPK1, RICTR, SIN1, HELB, SYRC, SYIC, and MTMR1 is sensitive to C6 ( Figure 3E [rid=F3] ) and to mutation of the WIN site of WDR5 ( Figures S3A [this file] and S3B [this file] ). 
Now, WDR5 associates with all four mTORC2 components in a manner that is sensitive to C6 ( Figure 3F [rid=F3] ) and the F133A mutation ( Figure S3C [this file] ). 
Interestingly, we also observed that all three interact with WDR5 in a manner that is sensitive to mutation of the WBM site, and that two, CHD8 and UBR5, contain WBM motifs ( Figure S3D [this file] ). 
We confirmed by coIP that endogenous PDPK1 and WDR5 interact in multiple cell lines ( Figure 4A [rid=F4] ; Figure S4A [this file] ), and that the interaction in U2OS cells is sensitive to C6, as determined by proximity ligation assay ( Figure 4B [rid=F4] ; Figure S4B [this file] ). We demonstrated that the interaction is unaffected by treatment of cells with the PDPK1 kinase inhibitor GSK2334470 ( Najafov et al., 2011 [rid=R51] : Figure 4C [rid=F4] ) and, conversely, that its disruption by C6 has no obvious effect on growth factor signaling by PDPK1, including AKT and S6 kinase phosphorylation ( Figure S4C [this file] ). 
We inhibited CRM1-dependent nuclear export with leptomycin B (LMB) and quantified the distribution of wild-type (WT) and R3A EGFP-tagged PDPK1 variants in U2OS cells ( Figures S4D [this file] – S4F [this file] ). 
We confirmed that a PDPK1 N-terminal peptide lacking the initiator methionine binds to recombinant WDR5 ( Figure S5A [this file] ). We also purified endogenous PDPK1 from HEK293 cells ( Figure S5B [this file] ), analyzed AspN digestion products by MS/MS ( Figure S5C [this file] ), and saw that all spectra assigned to the N terminus of PDPK1 carry two modifications; they lack the initiator methionine and carry an amino-terminal acetyl moiety ( Figure 5A [rid=F5] ). 
Ectopic N-terminal acetylation has been shown to increase the affinity of H3 and KMT2A WIN motif peptides for WDR5 ( Avdic et al., 2011b [rid=R5] ; Karatas et al., 2010 [rid=R31] ), and we observe this phenomenon with H3 peptides in our TR-FRET (time-resolved fluorescence resonance energy transfer) assays ( Figure S5D [this file] ). 
Next, we determined the X-ray crystal structure of WDR5 in complex with an acetylated PDPK1 peptide ( Figures 5C [rid=F5] – 5F [rid=F5] ; Table S3 [this file] ). In general, the WDR5-PDPK1 WIN peptide interaction resembles other WDR5-WIN peptide structures ( Figure S5E [this file] ), with residues A2 and R3 of PDPK1 making contacts with WDR5 deep in the WIN site ( Figure S5F [this file] ), and the guanidinium side chain of R3 sandwiched by two aromatic rings from F133 and F263 of WDR5 ( Figure 5F [rid=F5] ). Like other WDR5-WIN peptide structures ( Zhang et al., 2012 [rid=R81] ), residues downstream of R3 lie along a crevice between blades three and four of the WDR5 b-propellor structure ( Figure 5C [rid=F5] ), and like other structures, the exact conformation of these residues is unique ( Figure S5E [this file] ). Distinct from other structures, the side chain of L8 of PDPK1 makes contact with side chains of F149 and Y191 of WDR5 ( Figure S5F [this file] ). 
Importantly, the acetyl group of the PDPK1 peptide forms an intramolecular interaction whereby the carbonyl of the acetyl group makes a hydrogen bond to the amide of T4 ( Figure S5G [this file] ). 
Interestingly, the human proteome contains 67 proteins with potential WIN motifs ( Figure S5H [this file] ; Table S4 [this file] ), including PDPK1, 19 histone H3 variants, and HELB, one of the proteins that is displaced from WDR5 with the WIN site inhibitor. Large-scale proteomic mapping of N-terminal acetylation ( Lange et al., 2014 [rid=R35] ; Yeom et al., 2017 [rid=R80] ) has not detected this modification in any of the proteins in Figure S5H [this file] , with exception of a small percentage of H3, perhaps because trypsin (which cleaves after arginine residues) generates WIN fragments that are too small for robust detection. 
We created U2OS cells in which endogenous PDPK1 or WDR5 are tagged with an FKBP12(F36V)-2xHA cassette ( Figures S6A [this file] and S6B [this file] ), permitting their degradation via the small molecule dTAG47 ( Huang et al., 2017 [rid=R29] ; Nabet et al., 2018 [rid=R50] : Figures S6C [this file] and S6D [this file] ). For both proteins, depletion is stable over 6 days, and cell growth over this time is slowed ( Figures S6E [this file] and S6F [this file] ). Importantly, neither tag disrupts the PDPK1-WDR5 interaction by coIP ( Figures S6G [this file] and S6H [this file] ). We performed RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) after 24 h of dTAG47 treatment and found that PDPK1 depletion results in changes in the expression of ~1,100 genes ( Figures 6A [rid=F6] and 6B [rid=F6] ; Figure S6I [this file] ). WDR5 depletion has more extensive effects, leading to changes in expression of ~7,400 genes ( Figures 6C [rid=F6] and 6D [rid=F6] ; Figure S6J [this file] ). The overlap of significant gene expression changes between the two is ~660 ( Figure S6K [this file] ). For PDPK1 and WDR5 depletion, Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis identified transcript changes consistent with the known functions of both proteins ( Figures 6E [rid=F6] and 6F [rid=F6] ; Figures S6L [this file] and S6M [this file] ). In general, changes in expression of these 246 genes are small ( Figures 6K [rid=F6] ; Figure S6N [this file] ) but significant ( Figures S6O [this file] and S6P [this file] ). 
To ask if any of these gene expression changes are due to disruption of the WDR5-PDPK1 interaction, we introduced the R3A mutation into endogenous loci in HEK293 cells ( Figures S7A [this file] and S7B [this file] ). Unfortunately, mutation of the N terminus of endogenous PDPK1 is accompanied by a decrease in PDPK1 expression ( Figure S7A [this file] ), preventing comparison of the R3A and WT parental cell lines. Compared with the WT PDPK1 reconstitution, we identified 429 significantly changed transcripts for vector cells and 136 significantly changed transcripts for R3A PDPK1 cells ( Figures S7C [this file] and S7D [this file] ), 110 of which overlap ( Figure 7B [rid=F7] ). 
Degradation of WDR5 and PDPK1 leads to changes in cell-cycle distribution that could produce changes in cell-cycle gene expression ( Figures S7E [this file] – S7G [this file] ). To separate cause from effect, we arrested cells in G1 with palbociclib ( Fry et al., 2004 [rid=R19] ) or G2 with RO-3306 ( Vassilev et al., 2006 [rid=R74] ; Figure S7H [this file] ) and examined the impact of WDR5 degradation on the expression of a set of G2/M-induced genes. Here, we observed that transcript levels from the G2/M genes are unaffected by WDR5 depletion in G1-arrested cells but are induced by WDR5 depletion in the G2 arrested state ( Figure S7I [this file] ). 
Ninety-two of these common genes ( Table S5 [this file] ) show reduced expression in response to PDPK1 depletion ( Figures S7J [this file] and S7K [this file] ), and 27 are also induced by the R3A mutation in PDPK1 ( Figure 7H [rid=F7] ). 
RNA was reverse transcribed with LunaScript RT SuperMix Kit (New England Biolabs) and analyzed by qPCR using gene-specific primers ( Table S6 [this file] ) and KAPA SYBR FAST qPCR 2x Master Mix. 
RNA was reverse transcribed with LunaScript RT SuperMix Kit (New England Biolabs), diluted 1:4 in water, and analyzed by qPCR. qPCR was performed using KAPA SYBR FAST qPCR 2x Master Mix and gene-specific primers designed for detection of early transcripts, i.e., primers spanning an intron-exon boundary to avoid contaminating total mRNA (see Table S6 [this file] for primer sequences).

pub_title: H4K20me0 recognition by BRCA1-BARD1 directs homologous recombination in sister chromatids

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
Intriguingly, BARD1 and SLF1 both contain ARDs with high similarity to the TONSL ARD that recognizes H4K20me0 6 [rid=R6] ( Fig. 1b [rid=F1] , Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ), and the reported structure of the BARD1 ARD 17 [rid=R17] revealed that the histone H4 binding interface 6 [rid=R6] is structurally conserved ( Fig. 1b [rid=F1] ). 
Indeed, we found progressive accumulation of the BRCA1-BARD1 complex on chromatin during S phase mirroring H4K20me0 incorporation 6 [rid=R6] ( Fig. 2a [rid=F2] ; Supplementary Fig. 2a, b [this file] ), and this was dependent on H4K20me0 recognition by the BARD1 ARD ( Fig. 2b [rid=F2] ; Supplementary Fig. 2c, d, e [this file] ). Depletion of SET8, responsible for methylation of H4K20 in G2 and mitosis, increased H4K20me0 levels and augmented BRCA1-BARD1 binding to chromatin in G2 and G1 in a manner dependent on H4K20me0 recognition by the BARD1 ARD ( Fig. 2d [rid=F2] ; Supplementary Fig. 2f, g, h [this file] ). 
Wild-type (WT) BARD1 recruitment to ionizing irradiation (IR)-induced DSBs increased during S phase and reached a maximum in late S before dropping in G2/M ( Fig. 3a [rid=F3] ), mirroring H4K20me0 occupancy 6 [rid=R6] ( Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ) and recruitment of other HR factors 11 [rid=R11] , 19 [rid=R19] . Of note, BARD1 WT and ARD mutants were expressed at similar levels across the cell cycle and were proficient for BRCA1 stabilization via the RING domain dimerization 3 [rid=R3] ( Supplementary Fig. 2c, e [this file] ). Further, we found that ARD recognition of H4K20me0 was as important as RNF8-dependent ubiquitination 14 [rid=R14] for BRCA1 accumulation at DSBs ( Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ), indicating that BRCA1-BARD1 recruitment requires multivalent interactions with chromatin at DSBs, similar to 53BP1 20 [rid=R20] . 
BRCA1 foci dominated in mid and late S phase in the presence of BARD1 WT as expected 11 [rid=R11] , but, remarkably, this pattern was reversed by the BARD1 ARD mutant ( Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). 
Consistent with a role of the H4K20me0 recognition in antagonizing 53BP1, depletion of 53BP1 partly restored HR in cells expressing the ARD mutant ( Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). Moreover, mutation of the H4K20me0 recognition site was as detrimental to HR as deletion of the full ARD or BRCT domain previously shown to be essential for HR 22 [rid=R22] ( Fig. 4b [rid=F4] , Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ), underscoring that the essential function of the ARD in HR is H4K20me0 recognition. In these experiments we included mouse BARD1 as a control and found that it rescued HR activity ( Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ) although N470, predicted to bind H4K20me0 ( Fig. 1b [rid=F1] ), is not conserved in mice. The best scoring structures predicted a repositioning of H4 R17, reducing the contacts between the H4 tail and BARD1 N470 as compared to N571 in TONSL ( Supplementary Fig. 4a, b [this file] ). All other interactions were highly similar between the two reader domains, in particular the contacts between BARD1 E467 and D500 with H4 H18 and the contacts between BARD1 E429, D458 and E467 with H4 K20 were conserved ( Supplementary Fig. 4a, b [this file] ). Consistent with this binding model, residues E467 and D500, but not N470, were critical for BARD1 chromatin binding and recruitment to IR-induced DSBs ( Supplementary Fig. 4c, d [this file] ). These key acidic residues diverge from the consensus ankyrin repeat 17 [rid=R17] , but are conserved across species in BARD1, TONSL and SLF1 ( Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ), explaining specialization of these ARDs for H4K20me0 recognition. 
The full proteomics list for H4K20me0/me2 nucleosome pull-downs is presented in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
The following antibodies were used for immunofluorescence: BARD1 (Bethyl A300-263A, 1:500), BRCA1 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology sc-6954, clone 9, 1:400), 53BP1 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology H-300, 1:500), H4K20me1 (Abcam ab9051, 1:250; validated in Supplementary Fig. 2g [this file] ), H4K20me2 (Diagenode C15200205, 1:250; validated in Supplementary Fig. 2g [this file] ), H4K20me0 (Abcam ab227804, 1:10000; validated in Supplementary Fig. 2g [this file] ), Phospho-H2A.X (S139) (Cell Signalling Technology 2577, 1:1000), HA (Roche 1 867 423, 1:200), HA (Bio Legend 901509, 1:100), BrdU (Eurobio ABC117-7513, 1:1000), and MCM2 (BD Biosciences 610701, 1:150). 
From om all cycles performed the best scoring pose was selected to represent the structure of BARD1 bound to the histone H4 tail shown in Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] . 
The mass spectrometry proteomics data have been deposited to the ProteomeXchange Consortium via the PRIDE partner repository with the dataset identifier PXD009281 and is presented in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . Unprocessed images of all gels and blots ( Fig. 1c, d [rid=F1] , Fig. 5a, c [rid=F5] ; Supplementary Fig. 2h [this file] ) are provided in Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] . Source data for all graphs are provided in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
Unprocessed blots for and are presented in Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] .

context_description:
Despite the heterogeneity, Mga-inactivated cells exhibited a striking increase in expression of several meiotic genes, such as , , and , previously reported to be directly regulated by MGA-PRC1.6 in ES and germline cells ( Figure 2A [rid=fig2] , Supplementary file 1a [this file] ; Suzuki et al., 2016 [rid=bib64] ). Consistent with our Ki67 data, levels were elevated in tumors compared to control ( Figure 2A [rid=fig2] , Supplementary file 1a [this file] ). 
Despite the differences in genetic background (Kras vs. KP), several ncPRC1.6 complex repressed germ cell related transcripts, including , were highly upregulated in KP cells lacking MGA ( Figure 2D [rid=fig2] , Supplementary file 1b [this file] ), similar to Kras-sgMga tumors. 
MGA, MAX, E2F6, and L3MBTL2 were seen to bind several thousand promoters in MGA-expressing KP tumor cells suggesting that the PRC1.6 complex plays a broad role in tumor cell gene expression ( Supplementary file 1c [this file] ). 
As for mouse KP lines, we observed a overall decrease in MGA and L3MBTL2 binding in inactivated cells (termed sgMGA), including at STAG3 and promoters ( Figure 5—figure supplement 1A [rid=fig5s1] ; Supplementary file 1d [this file] ). 
Importantly, we observed that four of the five genes ( , , , and ) identified from our analysis in lung cancer models were significantly upregulated upon loss of MGA ( Figure 8F [rid=fig8] , Supplementary file 1e [this file] ).

title: Document S1. Supplemental Experimental Procedures and Figures S1–S5
caption: No description
description: Document  S1.  Supplemental  Experimental  Procedures  and  Figures  S1–S5
context_description:
To that end, four TALEs were designed ( Figure S1 [this file] A) and tested by ChIP-qPCR to identify the most efficient TALEs ( Figure S1 [this file] B). Importantly, ESCs stably expressing either TALE showed unaltered expression ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] C and S1 [this file] C) and retained their pluripotency potential ( Figure S1 [this file] D). 
See also Figure S1 [this file] and Tables S1 [rid=mmc2] and S2 [rid=mmc3] . 
This revealed that TALE1 and TALE2 had 12 and 3 off-targets, respectively ( Figures S1 [this file] E and S1F; Table S1 [rid=mmc2] ), which is considerably less than what had been shown for comparable CRISPR-Cas9 approaches ( Liu et al., 2020 [rid=bib37] , 2017 [rid=bib38] ). Importantly, this analysis also confirmed that the only site co-bound by both TALEs is the promoter ( Figure S1 [this file] E). Notably, TINC did not simply result in the detection of highly abundant chromatin-associated proteins, but also in the specific enrichment of lowly abundant candidates, which further supports the validity and sensitivity of TINC ( Figure S1 [this file] G). 
See also Figure S2 [this file] and Table S3 [rid=mmc4] . 
The TINC proteins included 56 TFs and 101 epigenetic modifiers ( Figure S2 [this file] A; Table S1 [rid=mmc2] ). While the epigenetic modifiers were mainly associated with histone modifications ( Figure S2 [this file] B), the TFs showed enrichment for various processes related to transcriptional regulation and maintenance of pluripotency ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] D). Intersection of the TINC proteins with the previously defined pluripotency regulatory network ( Nefzger et al., 2017 [rid=bib47] ; Xu et al. 2013 [rid=bib68] , 2014 [rid=bib67] ) revealed that 69 key network components form part of the regulatory complex ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] E and S2 [this file] C). 
Interestingly, while we identified 381 of the authors' small interfering RNA targets at the promoter, knockdown (KD) of only 23 resulted in a significant decrease in expression, indicative of a role of these proteins in maintenance of pluripotency ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] F, S2 [this file] D, and S2E). Conversely, KD of 14 TINC proteins resulted in a significant increase in expression, suggesting that these proteins act as repressors of and might play a role in silencing of this gene during differentiation ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] F, S2 [this file] D, and S2E). 
See also Figure S3 [this file] . 
To determine whether these proteins directly control expression, we used small hairpin RNAs (shRNAs) for which we obtained approximately 75% target KD ( Figures S3 [this file] A and S3B). Depletion of several of these factors resulted in a change in ESC morphology, which was most pronounced for and ( Figure S3 [this file] C). As shown previously, KD of led to a considerable amount of cell death ( Chen et al.,2012 [rid=bib11] ), while loss of triggered the cells to grow in a monolayer instead of dome-shaped colonies ( Figure S3 [this file] C). 
Analysis of TINC protein expression during MEF reprogramming revealed that many are transiently or permanently upregulated and that these proteins are mainly associated with chromatin organization and transcriptional regulation ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] D, S3 [this file] D, and S3E). Furthermore, 73% of the TINC proteins, including the majority of our candidates, are upregulated at the end of reprogramming and are strongly correlated with expression ( Figures 3 [rid=fig3] E, 3F, and S3 [this file] D). 
Using a different reprogramming system (OKMS instead of OKSM) and two alternative shRNAs individually and combined, we observed the same trend ( Figures S3 [this file] F and S3G). Flow cytometric analysis during reprogramming revealed that the total number of cells en route to becoming iPSCs (SSEA1+) approximately doubled due to an overall increase in cell numbers rather than an increase in the percentage of SSEA1+ cells ( Figures S3 [this file] H–S3J). Conversely, overexpression of led to a decrease in iPSC formation, although non-significant, which indicates that RCOR2 may impair pluripotency acquisition ( Figure S3 [this file] K). 
To gain further insight into the targets and partners of RCOR2, we first performed ChIP-seq, which revealed extensive binding to intergenic and intronic regions in ESCs ( Figure S4 [this file] A; Table S4 [rid=mmc5] ). Approximately 13% of the binding sites of RCOR2 are located in promoter regions, including the promoters of , , and ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] A and S4 [this file] A). Indeed, the majority of RCOR2 target genes are expressed (e.g., 8,514) and associated with various cell division- and pluripotency-related functions, while low or unexpressed targets (e.g., 3,030) are mainly associated with neuronal processes ( Figure S4 [this file] B). Intersection of the genome-wide binding sites and target genes of RCOR2 revealed extensive co-occupancy of RCOR2 with NANOG, OCT4, or SOX2 targets ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B and S4 [this file] C; Table S4 [rid=mmc5] ). Notably, genes occupied by all four factors have the highest median expression, include many key pluripotency regulators, and are enriched for various developmental processes ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B, 4C, S4 [this file] D). In line with the observed binding of RCOR2 to neuronal genes ( Figure S4 [this file] B), we obtained motif enrichment for REST, a repressor associated with silencing of neuronal genes in non-neuronal cells ( Chong et al., 1995 [rid=bib13] ; Schoenherr and Anderson 1995 [rid=bib56] ). 
See also Figure S4 [this file] and Table S4 [rid=mmc5] . 
Among those were 79 transcriptional regulators predominantly associated with histone modifications, including LSD1, which had previously been found to interact with RCOR2 in pluripotent and neural cells ( Yang et al., 2011 [rid=bib69] ; Wang et al., 2016 [rid=bib64] ) ( Figure S4 [this file] E; Table S4 [rid=mmc5] ). Furthermore, integration of published ChIP-seq data confirmed extensive co-binding of RCOR2 and LSD1 within ESCs ( Figures S4 [this file] F and S4G; Table S4 [rid=mmc5] ). Interestingly, while some of these sites are also bound by REST and CoREST or, to a larger extent by NuRD complex components, many sites are exclusively targeted by LSD1 and RCOR2 ( Figures S4 [this file] F and S4G). Notably, ESC enhancers did not show major occupancy by CoREST or REST but extensive targeting by LSD1, RCOR2, and NuRD members ( Figure S4 [this file] H). Importantly, concomitant inhibition of LSD1 alleviated the inhibitory effect of RCOR2 overexpression, suggesting that RCOR2 exerts its function at least partly via LSD1 during reprogramming ( Figure S3 [this file] K) Together, our results revealed that RCOR2 binds extensively in ESCs and forms part of various regulatory complexes, including, LSD1, NuRD, and CoREST/REST complexes. 
To further investigate the role of RCOR2, we created a CRISPR-Cas9 knockout (KO) ESC line ( Figure 5 [rid=fig5] A). depletion was confirmed at the DNA, RNA, and protein levels ( Figures S5 [this file] A–S5C). Notably, KO resulted in similar morphological changes as observed upon shRNA-mediated KD ( Figures S3 [this file] C and 5 [rid=fig5] A). Interestingly, many RCOR2 targets, which showed transcriptional deregulation upon KO were related to cell cycle and cell division ( Figure S5 [this file] D). In agreement, growth rate analyses revealed a significant decrease in ESC and MEF doubling time upon depletion, suggesting that RCOR2 is a negative regulator of cell-cycle progression ( Figure S5 [this file] E). Furthermore, this analysis revealed that RCOR2 is involved in transcriptional regulation of various pluripotency network components, including repression of and ( Figures 5 [rid=fig5] C and S5 [this file] F). 
See also Figure S5 [this file] and Table S4 [rid=mmc5] and Video S1 [rid=mmc6] . 
In agreement with the EB assay, teratoma assays showed limited growth for KO ESCs Although KO ESCs were able to eventually form teratomas with cell types from all three germ layers, it took an additional 5 days to reach a palpable size ( Figures S5 [this file] G–S5H).

This revealed that TALE1 and TALE2 had 12 and 3 off-targets, respectively ( Figures S1 [rid=mmc1] E and S1F; Table S1 [this file] ), which is considerably less than what had been shown for comparable CRISPR-Cas9 approaches ( Liu et al., 2020 [rid=bib37] , 2017 [rid=bib38] ). Further comparative analyses of the proteins revealed that 241 were present in all three and an additional 214 in two of the three replicates ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] F; Table S1 [this file] ). Importantly, these 455 proteins, hereafter referred to as TINC proteins, contained 30 published binders ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] F; Tables S1 [this file] and S2 [rid=mmc3] ). In addition, ChIP-Atlas, which processes published ChIP sequencing (ChIP-seq) data via its own pipeline and can hence identify binding events not detected in the original publication ( Oki et al., 2018 [rid=bib48] ), confirmed promoter targeting by an additional 12 TINC proteins ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] G; Tables S1 [this file] and S2 [rid=mmc3] ). 
The TINC proteins included 56 TFs and 101 epigenetic modifiers ( Figure S2 [rid=mmc1] A; Table S1 [this file] ).

title: Table S4. RCOR2/OCT4/SOX2/NANOG/NuRD/REST/CoREST ChIP Analyses, RCOR2 CoIPs, and Rcor2 KO RNA Sequencing, Related to Figures 4 and 5
description: Table  S4.  RCOR2/OCT4/SOX2/NANOG/NuRD/REST/CoREST  ChIP  Analyses,  RCOR2  CoIPs,  and  Rcor2  KO  RNA  Sequencing,  Related  to  Figures  4  and  5  .
context_description:
To gain further insight into the targets and partners of RCOR2, we first performed ChIP-seq, which revealed extensive binding to intergenic and intronic regions in ESCs ( Figure S4 [rid=mmc1] A; Table S4 [this file] ). Intersection of the genome-wide binding sites and target genes of RCOR2 revealed extensive co-occupancy of RCOR2 with NANOG, OCT4, or SOX2 targets ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] B and S4 [rid=mmc1] C; Table S4 [this file] ). 
See also Figure S4 [rid=mmc1] and Table S4 [this file] . 
Next, to determine interactors of RCOR2, we conducted co-immunoprecipitations (CoIPs), which identified 368 proteins ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] E and 4F; Table S4 [this file] ). Among those were 79 transcriptional regulators predominantly associated with histone modifications, including LSD1, which had previously been found to interact with RCOR2 in pluripotent and neural cells ( Yang et al., 2011 [rid=bib69] ; Wang et al., 2016 [rid=bib64] ) ( Figure S4 [rid=mmc1] E; Table S4 [this file] ). Notably, while RCOR2 CoIP resulted in enrichment of various NuRD complex components, CoREST and REST were not detected ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] E; Table S4 [this file] ). Furthermore, integration of published ChIP-seq data confirmed extensive co-binding of RCOR2 and LSD1 within ESCs ( Figures S4 [rid=mmc1] F and S4G; Table S4 [this file] ). 
Subsequent RNA sequencing of the KO line revealed transcriptional deregulation of 1,977 genes, approximately 74% of which are RCOR2 targets ( Figure 5 [rid=fig5] B; Table S4 [this file] ). 
See also Figure S5 [rid=mmc1] and Table S4 [this file] and Video S1 [rid=mmc6] .

context_description:
The increased BAT activity was evident by the denser appearance of interscapular BAT (iBAT) in mice, along with significantly increased UCP1 protein level after 72 h of cold exposure (Fig. 1b, c [rid=Fig1] and Supplemental Figure S1a [this file] ). In addition, the phosphorylation of AKT, FOXO1 and GSK3β was markedly suppressed by cold exposure in liver, suggesting that cold exposure showed coordinated effects on BAT (elevated glucose uptake) and liver (increased gluconeogenesis) glucose metabolism (Fig. 1j [rid=Fig1] and Supplemental Figure S1b [this file] ). Meanwhile, decreased gluconeogenic gene expression levels (Fig. 1o [rid=Fig1] ), along with increased phosphorylation of AKT, FOXO1 and GSK3β was observed in the liver upon cold exposure (Fig. 1p [rid=Fig1] and Supplemental Figure S1c [this file] ). 
Although 72 h of cold exposure robustly activated the thermogenic activity of iBAT (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] ), its weight was not markedly changed yet (~100 mg, Supplementary Figure S2a [this file] ). As revealed by nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA), the collected BDEVs amount gradually increased within 24 h and reached a plateau in both the control (RT-BAT) and cold exposed (Cold-BAT) group, thus, a 24 h incubation period was chosen for further studies (Supplementary Figure S2b [this file] ). Of note, the Cold-BAT generally displayed more EV secretion than RT-BAT (4 × 10 RT-BDEV particles, ~80 μg RT-BDEV protein; while 1 × 10 Cold-BDEV particles, ~160 μg Cold-BDEV protein collected at 24 h, respectively) (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] c, d and Supplementary Figure S2c [this file] ). However, its detection in the same quantify of RT-BDEV samples was limited (Supplemental Figure S2e [this file] ). More importantly, the protein levels of EV markers, including CD9, CD63 and ALIX were markedly increased in cold-activated BDEVs compared with EVs isolated from the same amount of control BAT (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] and Supplemental Figure S2d [this file] ). As indicated by the red fluorescence staining of the hepatocytes, fluorescent signals could be detected in hepatocytes as early as 2 h post incubation, and gradually increased and reached a plateau phase after 6 h of incubation, which exhibited efficient uptake of BDEVs (Fig. 2g [rid=Fig2] and Supplemental Figure S2f [this file] ). Notably, the appearance of GFP signals in the liver suggested that cold exposure resulted in significantly increased BDEV uptake by the hepatocytes (CK18-positive, red) compared to RT (Fig. 2k [rid=Fig2] and Supplemental Figure S3a [this file] ). The GFP mRNA was not detected in the liver of mice infected with Palm-GFP lentivirus (Supplementary Figure S3b [this file] ). Moreover, neither the fluorescent signal nor mRNA expression was detected in the liver infected with Ctrl-EGFP, indicating that it is unlikely that the GFP signal detected in the liver was due to viral leakage (Supplementary Figure S2g [this file] - S2i [this file] ). Although the fluorescent GFP signals were highly expressed in the liver, the signals could also be detected in the kidney, heart, white adipose tissue and skeletal muscle but not the brain (arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus, hippocampus and cortex) (Supplementary Figure S3c [this file] ). 
Since cold exposure significantly increased BDEVs secretion, for 24 h incubation, 4 × 10 RT-BDEV particles (~ 80 μg RT-BDEV protein) and 1 × 10 Cold-BDEV particles (~ 160 μg Cold-BDEV protein) were isolated from the medium from 100 mg RT-BAT and Cold-BAT after 24 h of incubation, respectively (Fig. 2d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Figure S2c [this file] ). The BDEVs and hepatocytes were co-incubated for 48 h, followed by functional analysis (Supplementary Figure S4a [this file] ). Compared with the cells treated with 1.6 × 10 RT-BDEVs (~32 μg), the phosphorylation level of AKT was dramatically decreased in the hepatocytes administered 4 × 10 Cold-BDEVs (~64 μg), concurrent with markedly increased gluconeogenic genes ( , , ) (Supplementary Figure S4b [this file] - S4c [this file] ). To explore whether treatment with equal amounts of Cold-BDEV particles or protein would also have similar effects, hepatocytes were incubated with 1.6 × 10 Cold-BDEVs (equal particle numbers as RT-BDEVs, Supplementary Figure S4a [this file] - S4c [this file] ) or 32 μg Cold-BDEVs (equal amounts RT-BDEV proteins, Fig. 3a–d [rid=Fig3] ), respectively. Furthermore, for those mice treated with BDEVs secreted from the same amount (100 mg) of cultured RT-BAT (~4 × 10 RT-BDEVs) and Cold-BAT ( ~ 1 × 10 Cold-BDEVs), a more significantly enhancement of hepatic gluconeogenesis was observed in mice treated with Cold-BDEVs (Supplementary Figure S4d [this file] - S4f [this file] ). BAT local GW4869 treatment did not affect mouse food intake, insulin or glucagon levels (Supplementary Figure S5a [this file] - S5c [this file] ). As Cold-BDEVs fluorescent signals were also detected in WAT (Supplementary Figure S3c [this file] ), their influence on lipolysis were assessed. Compared with mice treated with RT-BDEVs, Cold-BDEV (80 μg each day) treatment resulted in elevated mRNA levels of fatty acid oxidation genes and , suggesting that Cold-BDEVs may also play a role in facilitating WAT lipolysis (Supplementary Figure S4g [this file] ). 
Notably, compared with the control group of mice, only miR-378a-3p was significantly upregulated in both BDEVs and serum EVs from cold-exposed mice, suggesting that miRNAs were selectively packaged in activated BDEVs and that the miRNAs may be selectively packaged in BDEVs under cold stress (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] f, g and Supplementary Figure S6a [this file] - S6c [this file] ). Cold exposure significantly increased the mRNA level in BAT, but decreased its expression in the liver, which was consistent with the transcription level of miR-378a-3p (Supplementary Figure S6d [this file] and Fig. 4i [rid=Fig4] ). Compared with the control group, the expression of was markedly repressed in the liver from cold-exposed mice (Supplementary Figure S6e [this file] ). Next, 80 μg RT-BDEVs (~0.49 fmol miR-378a /μg RT-BDEV) and Cold-BDEVs (~1.75 fmol miR-378a /μg Cold-BDEV) were intravenously administered to mice each day for 3 days (Supplementary Figure S6f [this file] ). In addition, local injection of GW4869 (inhibit EV release) in BAT led to significantly decreased miR-378a-3p level in the liver of cold exposed mice but not fasted mice (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] k, l, Supplementary Figure S6i [this file] - S6k [this file] ). The observed differences in cold-exposed and fasted mice were reasonable, as the increased miR-378a-3p expression was resulted from the elevated transcription of miR-378a in the liver from fasted mice (Supplementary Figure S6g [this file] - S6h [this file] ), whereas for cold-exposed mice, the increased miR-378a-3p was not from its own transcription activation in the liver (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] i, m). In addition, the expression of Dicer, which directly regulates miRNA maturation, was unchanged in the liver of cold-exposed mice (Supplementary Figure S6l [this file] - S6m [this file] ). Moreover, the uneven changes in several other miRNA expression levels in the cold-exposed liver, including miR-21, -192, and -223, suggested that the increased miR-378a-3p was unlikely due to the change of the miRNA processing proteins in the liver (Supplementary Figure S6n [this file] ). 
In control hepatocytes untreated with anti-miR-378a, Cold-BDEVs administration significantly reduced p110α protein level and markedly increased gluconeogenic gene expressions (~2-fold increase) (Supplementary Figure S7a [this file] - S7b [this file] ). While in those cells treated with anti-miR-378a (100 nM), comparable protein levels of p110α were detected in hepatocytes treated with or without Cold-BDEVs, suggesting that the function of miR-378a-3p that derived from Cold-BDEVs were completely abolished in hepatocytes (Supplementary Figure S7c [this file] ). Notably, only slight increases (~1.2-fold) expressions of gluconeogenic genes were observed (Supplementary Figure S7d [this file] ). 
The characterization of 378KO mice is shown in Supplementary Figure S8a [this file] - S8e [this file] . There were no overt differences in insulin and glucagon levels between the 378KO mice and the control animals (Supplementary Figure S8f [this file] - S8g [this file] ). 
Primers used for genotyping are shown in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
Primer sequences are shown in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
Other details of antibodies are described in Supplementary Table 3 [this file] .
