title: Document S1. Figures S1–S11 and Tables S1–S5
caption: No description
description: Document  S1.  Figures  S1–S11  and  Tables  S1–S5
context_description:
To limit chances of unspecific and weak binding, we set a threshold for the docking score of each compound corresponding to the docking score of the kinase pocket natural substrate, ATP ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
This yielded IC s in the low micromolar range ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] D and Table S3 [this file] ). 
Z4 blocked tunicamycin-induced degradation of mRNA compared to control treatment ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] F) while it had no effect in cells overexpressing a dominant-negative form of IRE1 ( Figure S1 [this file] A). 
Neither nor mRNA expression was significantly affected upon treatment with Z4 ( Figures S1 [this file] B–S1C). Moreover, eIF2α phosphorylation and ATF4 protein expression were not altered upon Z4 treatment ( Figure S1 [this file] D). 
Treatment of RADH87 cells with Z4 impacted on pathways such as immunity, circulatory system development, cell locomotion, and cell migration; all properties involved in tumor establishment ( angiogenesis) and tumor invasion ( metastasis) ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] G–1I and S2 [this file] ). We then compared the proteomes of Z4-treated cell lines to the same cell line overexpressing a truncated mutant form of IRE1 lacking an RNase domain known to blunt IRE1 activity [xref] [rid=bib26] ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] H and S2 [this file] ). We found that Z4 treatment systematically reduced cell migration ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] J, 1K, and S3 [this file] ). Interestingly, the primary lines RADH85 and RADH87 were the most impacted by Z4 ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] J, 1K, and S3 [this file] ). Cell viability at the point of maximal TMZ administration decreased by 1.5-fold in the presence of Z4 compared to control ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] L), an effect recapitulated in primary RADH87 cells ( Figure S4 [this file] ). 
The IC of these molecules was determined by a fluorescence-quenched IRE1 RNA substrate probe ( Figure S5 [this file] ) and the values are shown on Figure 2 [rid=fig2] C. 
The high TEER and low paracellular permeability of LY ( Table S4 [this file] ) shows that the barrier stability of the model was maintained during the incubation with the compounds, confirming the absence of significant toxic effect. 
Figures S6 [this file] and S7 [this file] show that both enantiomers inhibit IRE1 activity. Based on their IC values ( Figures S6 [this file] and S7 [this file] ) as well as MST data (not shown), we determined that both enantiomers are able to bind to IRE1 in a competitive manner. 
Figures 3 [rid=fig3] C, 3D and S8 [this file] show that IRE1 phosphorylation is reduced under Z4 compounds treatments. As shown by their respective kinome phylogenetic trees ( Figure S9 [this file] ) at a concentration of 10 μM, both compounds demonstrated to have very little effect on other kinases with no more than 20% inhibition across the panel ( Table S5 [this file] ). 
No toxicity was detected in wild-type (WT) mice in any of the concentrations tested ( Figure S10 [this file] A). 
While Z4P treatment alone had no effect on tumor growth or mouse survival, co-treatment with TMZ significantly increased survival and decreased tumor growth ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] F and S10 [this file] B). In contrast, no tumor relapse was observed in the group of animals treated with both TMZ and Z4P ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] G, yellow curve); full panel of samples are presented at D20 and D182 in Figure S11 [this file] . 
The global ability of Z4 compounds to sensitize GB cells to TMZ ( Figures 2 [rid=fig2] and S4 [this file] ) together with the ability of the Z4-family member, Z4P, to cross the BBB ( Table 1 [rid=tbl1] ) increased their clinical potential value, thus further justifying investigations in preclinical GB mouse models. , a clear attenuation of mRNA splicing in Z4P-treated tumors suggests the effective penetration of this drug in the brain. 
See Table S1 [this file] 
Primers sequences used were provided in Table S1 [this file] , and available upon request to the corresponding author. 
The primers used in the qPCR analyses are presented in Table S1 [this file] .

title: No Title
caption: Figure S1 : Supporting Information
description: Figure  S1  :  Supporting  Information  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
In the injected mice, GFP was expressed in astrocytes in the lumbar spinal cord, at day 65 and end stage (day 153–185) (Supplemental Figure S1 [this file] ). Another miR SOD1‐b sequence also targeting human SOD1 showed similar effects, which are therefore not specific to the miR sequence (Supplemental Figure S2 [this file] ). 
To assess if AAV‐miR SOD1 could prevent astrocytic and microglial activation in the spinal cord, we measured the area of GFAP immunoreactivity and the number of Iba1‐positive microglial cells on lumbar sections at day 65, 100 and 140 (Supplemental Figure S3 [this file] a–d). 
There was no difference between groups in the level of astrocytic markers (Supplemental Figure S4 [this file] a), indicating that the amount of contaminating astrocyte‐derived material was very similar across conditions. However, we found an upregulation of microglial transcripts in the AAV‐miR SOD1 treated mice as compared to the control groups (Supplemental Figure S4 [this file] b). 
Notably, subunit‐encoding genes of the ionotropic glutamate receptor family such as (glutamate ionotropic receptor 1, AMPA1) and (glutamate ionotropic receptor delta type subunit 2) were significantly downregulated (Supplemental Figure S5 [this file] a, b). Similarly, the levels of the transcripts encoding the gamma‐aminobutyric acid (GABA) A receptor subunits γ1 and γ2 were significantly reduced in the AAV‐miR SOD1 treated condition (Supplemental Figure S5 [this file] c, d). Genes implicated in cholinergic neurotransmission such as (choline acetyl transferase) and (high affinity choline transporter 1) were also downregulated (Supplemental Figure S5 [this file] e, f).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
To identify putative interactor(s) of hnRNP L that might contribute to the coupling of splicing and transcription, we decided to purify the RRM2-containing hnRNP L fragment, 162–321 (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] ). hnRNP L is predicted to have a nuclear localization signal (NLS) at its N-terminal region (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ) and is a nuclear protein. 
The IPA showed that the purified proteins were enriched in the RNA processing pathways which is consistent with the known role of the family of hnRNP proteins (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). 
Furthermore, the IPA of proteins co-purified with both the SETD2 fragments showed enrichment of pathways belonging to RNA processing much like what was observed for hnRNP L (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). 
Notably, the interaction with hnRNP L persisted without the Pol II interaction domain and in fact, increased upon RNase treatment (Fig. 2g [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 2b, c [this file] ). 
This fragment was nuclear, consistent with our previous characterization of the SETD2 NLS (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ) . 
MudPIT analysis of the purified complexes revealed that the fragment 1964–2263 interacts with hnRNP L (Fig. 3c [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). To accurately define the region of interaction between SETD2 and hnRNP L, additional Halo-tagged fragments and sub-fragments of SETD2 were made as depicted in Fig. 3c [rid=Fig3] and affinity-purified followed by MudPIT analysis (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] , Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM4] ). The mass spectrometry data was confirmed by performing Halo purification of several SETD2 fragments followed by western blotting (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). 
These findings were also confirmed by immunoblotting with an anti-hnRNP L antibody (Supplementary Fig. 3d [this file] ). 
Structural modeling of 2164–2213 stretch using Robetta and iTASSER did not reveal any striking sequence characteristic with most of the predicted structure consisting of coils (Supplementary Fig. 4a, b [this file] ). As anticipated, immunoblotting for RNA Pol II and anti-hnRNP L revealed that the SETD2-hnRNP L interaction was abolished without affecting the SETD2-Pol II interaction (Fig. 3h [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 4c, d [this file] ). 
The purification demonstrates that the RRM2 of hnRNP L alone is sufficient to interact with SETD2 (Supplementary Fig. 5a, b [this file] ). 
Hence, despite achieving a significant depletion of hnRNP L in cell extracts, a substantial amount of hnRNP L was still present in SETD2C purification (sihnRNP L) (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). Despite this, we found that not only did the binding of SETD2 with other splicing-related proteins persisted upon the depletion of hnRNP L, but strikingly, their binding increased relative to the purifications from extracts of scramble-siRNA (siScramble) treated cells (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] , Supplementary Data 6 [rid=MOESM4] ). 
The RNA-seq data revealed a global perturbation in terms of transcription and AS changes upon SETD2 and hnRNP L depletion (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
SETD2 depletion caused a significant (FDR < 0.05, fold change >1.5) upregulation of 57 genes out of which more than half showed a similar trend of increased expression upon hnRNP L depletion (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] , Supplementary Data 7 [rid=MOESM4] ). Also, out of the 146 genes that were significantly downregulated upon SETD2 depletion, more than a quarter of those showed a decreased expression upon hnRNP L knockdown (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). Notably, 95.24% of the differentially expressed genes that are co-regulated by SETD2 and hnRNP L showed a similar trend, whereas only 4.76% showed an opposite trend of expression (Fig. 6c, d [rid=Fig6] , and Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). 
Analysis of the AS events showed a similar trend where out of the 1221 differential AS events upon SETD2 knockdown compared to a scrambled siRNA treated cells, 16% of the events showed a similar trend on hnRNP L depletion, and only 1.47% of the events showed opposite regulation (Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] , Supplementary Data 8 [rid=MOESM4] ). 
Indeed, the rescue of 293T cells with SETD2 FL led to an increase in the ratio as compared to the vector control (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). No change in splicing was observed upon expression of SETD2 FLΔSHI relative to the control (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
Clear enrichment of H3K36me3 was found on genes the splicing of which were downregulated upon SETD2 depletion, suggesting that high H3K36me3 promotes splicing (Supplementary Fig. 9a, b [this file] ). Also, genes that showed a decrease in splicing upon SETD2 and hnRNP L depletion had higher H3K36me3 levels as compared to the genes that showed increased splicing or exhibited opposite trends (Supplementary Fig. 9c, d [this file] ). Such a correlation was not observed when hnRNP L-regulated AS genes were analyzed (Supplementary Fig. 9e, f [this file] ). 
Despite comparable expression levels of the constructs, a clear difference was observed in the H3K36me3 level between the cells rescued with WT SETD2 and the SETD2 mutants lacking the SRI and the SHI domains (Fig. 7c, d [rid=Fig7] , and Supplementary Fig. 10a [this file] ). 
Also, the decrease in H3K36me3 does not occur specifically from those genes the splicing of which is co-regulated by SETD2 and hnRNP L as H3K36me3 pattern was similar in SETD2 FLΔSHI expressing cells to that observed in SETD2 FL expressing and WT cells (Supplementary Fig. 10b [this file] ). 
Notably, the purification of SETD2 from extracts depleted of hnRNP L revealed enrichment of hnRNP A1 (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). On the other hand, the enrichment of U2AF2 was reduced (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
A sequence alignment of the four hnRNP L RRMs did not reveal any striking pattern that would explain the specificity of RRM2, and not the other RRMs, in engaging SETD2 and hnRNP L (Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). 
On the other hand, IPA of the co-purified proteins with the SETD2 N-terminus revealed enrichment of splicing-related pathways (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). Also, purification of SETD2 from cell extracts depleted of hnRNP L revealed enrichment of other proteins involved in pre-mRNA splicing (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
The sequence of oligos is in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
Also, the data for Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] have been deposited with the dataset identifier PXD022946 (http://proteomecentral.proteomexchange.org/cgi/GetDataset?ID=PXD022946) .

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Data 1-8
context_description:
The purified complexes were subjected to multidimensional protein identification technology (MudPIT) mass spectrometry (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
A total of 1236 proteins were significantly enriched over the mock (log fold change >1 and Z-statistic >2) including SETD2 (Fig. 1g [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
Proteomic analysis revealed a significant enrichment over mock (log fold change >1 and Z-statistic >2) of 116 proteins with the N + catalytic domains and 398 proteins with the C-terminal fragment (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). Strikingly, not only was hnRNP L co-purified with SETD2C, but it was also the most abundant protein identified in the purification after the bait (Fig. 2d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). 
To accurately define the region of interaction between SETD2 and hnRNP L, additional Halo-tagged fragments and sub-fragments of SETD2 were made as depicted in Fig. 3c [rid=Fig3] and affinity-purified followed by MudPIT analysis (Supplementary Fig. 3b [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 3 [this file] ). 
To test whether the 2164–2213 portion of SETD2 when added to ySet2 could result in interaction with hnRNP L, the stretch was added to ySet2, and ySet2ΔSRI followed by affinity purification and MudPIT (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ). 
To test this hypothesis, Halo-SETD2CΔSRI and Halo-SETD2CΔSHI, were affinity-purified and subjected to mass spectrometry (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ). 
Despite this, we found that not only did the binding of SETD2 with other splicing-related proteins persisted upon the depletion of hnRNP L, but strikingly, their binding increased relative to the purifications from extracts of scramble-siRNA (siScramble) treated cells (Supplementary Fig. 6 [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 6 [this file] ). 
SETD2 depletion caused a significant (FDR < 0.05, fold change >1.5) upregulation of 57 genes out of which more than half showed a similar trend of increased expression upon hnRNP L depletion (Supplementary Fig. 7a [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 7 [this file] ). 
Analysis of the AS events showed a similar trend where out of the 1221 differential AS events upon SETD2 knockdown compared to a scrambled siRNA treated cells, 16% of the events showed a similar trend on hnRNP L depletion, and only 1.47% of the events showed opposite regulation (Supplementary Fig. 7b [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 8 [this file] ). 
Notably, in SETD2C purifications, hnRNP A1 was the second most abundant protein after the bait, and U2AF2 was also identified in MudPIT (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Exposure to 30 μM Cd perturbs pneumococcal growth resulting in an extended lag time (0.11 vs. 0.19 h) and a reduction in the maximal growth rate (1.10 vs. 0.66 h ) (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). Validation of the RNA sequencing data were performed by qRT-PCR analysis using a subset of differentially expressed genes (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] , Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
The largest proportion of significantly (>2-fold) upregulated genes belonged to the Clusters of Orthologous Groups (COG) defined categories of carbohydrate metabolism (30.1%) and inorganic ion homeostasis (24.4%), while genes associated with lipid metabolism represented the largest downregulated group (29.7%) (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
In addition, other genes involved in inorganic ion homeostasis also showed altered expression (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
Concordant with Cd -treatment, the pneumococcal proteome revealed 395 individual peaks, indicative of protein-Cd interactions, and comparatively higher Cd abundance across the cytoplasmic proteome (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Comparison of the Cd peaks with the Zn proteome showed overlapping spatial distribution of the peaks, suggesting that Cd ions were interacting with some of the fractions previously associated with Zn ions (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
We propose that the resultant depletion of cellular Zn can be attributed to Cd -bound AdcR mimicking the Zn -bound state leading to repression of the regulon consistent with the downregulation of the Zn -recruiting genes , , and , (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
In addition, targeted metabolite analyses of Cd -treated cells revealed that cellular NADPH levels were approximately two-fold higher compared to untreated ( = 0.056), while ATP levels were significantly depleted (60%; < 0.0001) in these cells (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
We observed that grown in CDM-Gal had reduced growth by comparison with CDM-Glu (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
This occurred concomitantly with significant increases in the mixed acid fermentation end-products acetate (~15%, = 0.0002) and ethanol (~250%, = 0.0003) (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
Primer sequences are listed in Supplementary Table S2 [this file] .
pub_title: Cadmium stress dictates central carbon flux and alters membrane composition in

title: NIHMS2026890-supplement-Suppl_figures_and_legend.docx
context_description:
We confirmed disruption of the gene and the periostin expression in the dermis of the facial skin in FADS/ mice ( Figure S1 [href=this file] ). Periostin deficiency did not prevent the onset of facial eczema; it appeared around postnatal day 10 (P10) as it also did in the control mice ( Figures 3A [href=#F3] and S2 [href=this file] ).
(A) Macroscopic facial skin lesions of FADS/ mice and FADS/ mice at the indicated periods after birth (See also Figures S1 [href=this file] and S2 [href=this file] ).
We excluded the possibility that decreased scratch behavior was due to decreased motor activities because there was no difference in motor activities between FADS/ and FADS/ mice ( Figure S3 [href=this file] ).
(A) Scratching bouts in control/ mice (n = 6), control/ mice (n = 5), FADS/ mice (n = 12), and FADS/ mice (n = 12) at the indicated periods after birth. (B, C) Representative traces (left) and quantitative analysis (right) of spontaneous neuronal firing (B, See also Figure S4 [href=this file] ) and correlation between scratching bouts and neuronal firing (C) in 8-week-old FADS/ mice (n = 5) and FADS/ mice (n = 5).
We confirmed that recorded neurons were located in dorsal horn at comparable depths in FADS/ and FADS/ mice (FADS/ , 51.2 ± 3.2 μm; FADS/ 57.3 ± 2.8 μm, Figure S4 [href=this file] ).
We confirmed that the same treatment with CP4715 did not reduce motor activity ( Figure S5 [href=this file] ), excluding a possible sedative effect on the anti-itch actions of CP4715. Furthermore, neutralizing anti-periostin Ab (OC-20) significantly decreased scratching bouts in FADS/ mice as well ( Figure S6 [href=this file] ).
White arrows indicate epidermal cells with nuclear p65 expression (G). (I, J) Spontaneous firing of dorsal horn neurons (I) and scratching bouts (J) in 60 minutes after 10–14-week-old (I) (n = 5) or 4-week-old (vehicle, n = 8; CP4715, n = 10) (J) FADS/ mice were treated with single-shot administration of vehicle or CP4715 (30 mg/kg, see also Figures S5 [href=this file] and S6 [href=this file] ).
Moreover, as we previously showed, IL-31 expression was not increased in FADS mice and neither genetic disruption nor pharamacological inhibition of periostin changed IL-31 expression ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ). Since either genetic disruption or pharmacological inhibition of periostin downregulated recruiment of neutrophils, but not expression of CXCL10 ( Figure S7 [href=this file] ), it is unlikely in FADS mouse that the neutrophil-CXCL10-CXCR3 pathway is involved in promoting itching as previously suggested.
We in this study showed that genetic disruption of periostin did not prevent the onset, but the development, of skin inflammation ( Figures 3A [href=#F3] and S2 [href=this file] ), suggesting that genetic inhibition of periostin would be useful for ameliorating rather than preventing allergic skin inflammation.
pub_title: Periostin activates distinct modules of inflammation and itching downstream of the type 2 inflammation pathway - PMC

title: Download video file
description: Supplemental movie 1. Periostin deficiency reduces itch behaviors in 4-week-old FADS mice
context_description: Surprisingly, genetic disruption of periostin significantly decreased scratching behaviors during all of the observed periods from 4 to 12 weeks ( Figure 5A [href=#F5] and Supplemental movie 1 [href=this file] ), suggesting the importance of periostin in causing itching, although it was unclear whether in FADS mice, the roles of periostin in itching are direct or indirect.
pub_title: Periostin activates distinct modules of inflammation and itching downstream of the type 2 inflammation pathway - PMC

title: Download video file
description: Supplemental movie 2. Inhibitory effects of CP4715 on scratching bouts in 4-week-old FADS mice
context_description: Scratching bouts were immediately reduced after administration, with inhibitory effects continuing for about 40 minutes as well ( Figure 6J [href=#F6] and Supplemental movie 2 [href=this file] ), indicating that the effects of periostin on sensory neuron cells are probably direct.
pub_title: Periostin activates distinct modules of inflammation and itching downstream of the type 2 inflammation pathway - PMC

title: NIHMS2026890-supplement-Table_S1.xlsx
description: Table S1. Gene expression profiles in facial skins of 4-week-old FADS/Postn+/+ mice, control/Postn+/+ mice, and FADS/PostnlacZ/lacZ mice
context_description:
To understand the biological effects induced by genetic deficiency of Ikk2 in fibroblasts and the inhibitory effects by periostin disruption , we comprehensively identified the genes that are upregulated in facial skins of FADS mice and are downregulated by periostin disruption using the Cap Analysis of Gene Expression (CAGE) method ( Table S1 [href=this file] and Figure 4 [href=#F4] ).
(A) A gene plot of either the upregulated or downregulated genes in facial skins of 4-week-old FADS mice (vertical axis) and either the upregulated or downregulated genes by disruption in 4-week-old FADS mice (horizontal axis, See also Table S1 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Periostin activates distinct modules of inflammation and itching downstream of the type 2 inflammation pathway - PMC

title: NIHMS2026890-supplement-Table_S2.xlsx
description: Table S2. Genes that are upregulated in facial skins of 4-week-old FADS mice and are downregulated by periostin disruption
context_description:
We focused on 365 genes in the black square ( Table S2 [href=this file] ) in the upper left quadrant as the genes upregulated in FADS mice and downregulated by periostin disruption, applying these genes to pathway enrichment analysis to characterize them.
The 365 genes including representative genes ( , , , , , and ) are depicted in the black square (See also Table S2 [href=this file] ). (B, C) Gene Ontology (GO) pathway analysis (B, See also Table S3 [href=#SD6] ), and transcription factor enrichment analysis (C) of the 365 genes.
pub_title: Periostin activates distinct modules of inflammation and itching downstream of the type 2 inflammation pathway - PMC

title: NIHMS2026890-supplement-Table_S3.xlsx
context_description:
The 365 genes including representative genes ( , , , , , and ) are depicted in the black square (See also Table S2 [href=#SD5] ). (B, C) Gene Ontology (GO) pathway analysis (B, See also Table S3 [href=this file] ), and transcription factor enrichment analysis (C) of the 365 genes.
Gene ontology (GO) analysis showed that genes annotated with keratinization and neutrophil chemotaxis were significantly enriched in the 365 genes ( Figure 4B [href=#F4] and Table S3 [href=this file] ), consistent with the histological findings that epidermal hyperplasia and neutrophil infiltration were reduced in FADS/ mice, as shown in Figure 3 [href=#F3] .

Endocardial Notch Signaling Promotes Cardiomyocyte Proliferation in the Regenerating Zebrafish Heart through Wnt Pathway Antagonism
Endocardial Notch Signaling Promotes Cardiomyocyte Proliferation in the Regenerating Zebrafish Heart through Wnt Pathway Antagonism

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
Embryos exposed to EtOH were devoid of GFP expression ( Figures S1A–S1B′ [this file] ), whereas those treated with 4-HT displayed GFP expression in endocardial and endothelial cells ( Figures S1C–S1D′ [this file] ). 
While control hearts consistently contained regenerated muscle and minimal fibrosis (Figures 1E, 1G [rid=F1] , S1E–H, S1M–S1P, and S1U [this file] ), hearts displayed myocardial deficits (Figures 1F [rid=F1] and S1I–S1L [this file] ) and prominent scar tissue where the ventricle was wounded (Figures 1H [rid=F1] and S1Q–S1U [this file] ). 
Because heat shocking animals induces DN-MAML expression not only in the endocardium, but also in vascular endothelial cells ( Figures S1C–S1D′ [this file] ), we evaluated injured and heat-shocked animals for coronary artery abnormalities ( Figure S2A–S2H′ [this file] ) and for evidence of surface bleeding ( Figure S2I–S2S [this file] ) to predict the likelihood that a vessel defect might contribute to the regenerative failures. 
Using a strict significance threshold (p < 0.0001), we identified 131 downregulated and 123 upregulated transcripts in Notch-suppressed hearts (Figures 2A [rid=F2] and S3A [this file] ; Table S1 [rid=SD2] ). Consistent with the non-regenerative nature of heat-shocked hearts ( Zhao et al., 2014 [rid=R57] ), gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis identified “mitosis,” “cell cycle,” and “chromosome segregation” categories as overrepresented in the downregulated gene cluster (Figures 2B [rid=F2] and S3B [this file] ). We surveyed the list of downregulated genes to identify secreted factors whose production relies on Notch signaling ( Figures S3A and S3C [this file] ; Table S1 [rid=SD2] ) and were intrigued to find transcripts encoding the secreted Wnt antagonists Wif1 and Notum1b (Figures 2C [rid=F2] , S3A, and S3C [this file] ; Table S1 [rid=SD2] ). 
In both cases, prominent staining was observed adjacent to the ventricular myocardium ( Figures 2H–2I′ [rid=F2] ) in what we confirmed to be endocardial cells through colocalization with a transgenic reporter ( Figures S4A–S4B″ [this file] ). In addition, we observed significant overlap between each Wnt antagonist and pan-cytokeratin+ (PCK+) epicardial cells both proximal ( Figures S4H–S4H″ and S4J–S4J″ [this file] ) and distal ( Figures S4I–S4I″ and S4K–S4K″ [this file] ) to the wound. Last, we learned that neither protein is co-expressed with collagen, type I, alpha 1 (Col1a1) ( Figures S4L–S4M″″ [this file] ), which marks wound fibroblasts ( González-Rosa et al., 2012 [rid=R11] ). 
We used qPCR to compare the relative expression levels of and between 5 dpa control and animals in two regions of the injured ventricle that contain proportionally more epicardium or endocardium ( Figure S5A [this file] ). We observed significant declines in and levels exclusively in the tissue adjacent to the wound ( Figures S5B and S5C [this file] ). Therefore, like global Notch pathway suppression ( Figures 2C and 2D [rid=F2] ), endocardial-specific Notch pathway inhibition also results in significant decreases in and levels ( Figures S5A–S5C [this file] ), which is likely confined to the endocardium of the heart. 
While one target, ( Alexander et al., 2014 [rid=R1] ), showed highly variable expression between replicates, the other two targets, ( Alexander et al., 2014 [rid=R1] ) and ( Nery et al., 2014 [rid=R39] ), were found to be significantly increased in injured hearts ( Figure S6A [this file] ), suggesting that endocardial Notch signaling functions to restrain Wnt signaling during heart regeneration. 
Injections of IWR or BIO into uninjured animals caused , , and levels to drop or increase, respectively, by approximately 50% ( Figure S6B [this file] ), which validates the use of these small molecules to modulate Wnt signaling during regeneration. 
While the majority of DMSO-treated (87.5%; Figures 4B, 4E [rid=F4] , S6C–F, S6O–S6R, and S6AA [this file] ) and Wnt-inhibited (IWR treated; 57%; Figures 4C, 4F [rid=F4] , S6G–S6J, S6S–S6V, and S6AA [this file] ) hearts contained regenerated segments of muscle with minimal fibrosis, 75% of those with augmented Wnt signaling (BIO treated; Figures 4D, 4G [rid=F4] , S6K–S6N, and S6W–S6AA [this file] ) failed to regenerate as evidenced by discontinuities in the myocardial wall ( Figure 5D [rid=F5] ) that were filled with fibrin and collagen ( Figure 4G [rid=F4] ). 
By contrast, Wnt hyperactivation reduced myocardial proliferation by 42% ( Figures 4H, 4H′, 4J, 4J′, and 4K [rid=F4] ), consistent with the lack of regeneration observed at 30 dpa (Figures 4D, 4G [rid=F4] , S6K–S6N, and S6W–S6AA [this file] ). 
Boxplots in Figures S1U and S6AA [this file] and volcano plot in Figure S3A [this file] were generated using RStudio.
pub_title: Endocardial Notch Signaling Promotes Cardiomyocyte Proliferation in the Regenerating Zebrafish Heart through Wnt Pathway Antagonism

Crosstalk between androgen receptor and WNT/β-catenin signaling causes sex-specific adrenocortical hyperplasia in mice
Crosstalk between androgen receptor and WNT/β-catenin signaling causes sex-specific adrenocortical hyperplasia in mice
Crosstalk between androgen receptor and WNT/β-catenin signaling causes sex-specific adrenocortical hyperplasia in mice

title: No Title
caption: Click here for additional data file.
description: 10.1242/dmm.050053_sup1  Supplementary  information  Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
By contrast, mice showed expression throughout the adrenal cortex ( Fig. 1 [rid=DMM050053F1] B) and dramatically increased total mRNA levels regardless of sex ( Fig. S1A [this file] ). 
By 3 months of age, degenerative areas expanded significantly in all the male adrenals ( =3), leading to cortical thinning ( Fig. S1B [this file] ). These degenerative changes affected female adrenals to a much lesser degree (2/3 adrenals examined at 3 months displayed only a few abnormal cells) ( Fig. S1B [this file] ). zG expansion is a known consequence of the constitutive activation of β-catenin in the adrenal cortex ( Berthon et al., 2010 [rid=DMM050053C5] ; Pignatti et al., 2020 [rid=DMM050053C56] ). However, in adrenals, the zG was not expanded in either sex, as shown by immunostaining with the zG markers DAB2 and LEF1 ( Fig. S1C,D [this file] ). 
Levels of the glucocorticoid corticosterone and another steroid hormone precursor, 11-deoxycorticosterone, showed a mild decrease in female and increase in male mice, although none of these changes reached statistical significance ( Fig. S2 [this file] ). Analysis of the adrenocorticotropic hormone-responsive differentiation marker AKR1B7 ( Sahut-Barnola et al., 2000 [rid=DMM050053C60] ) showed loss of expression in subpopulations of cells of the inner cortex, which explains the absence of hormone overproduction despite the striking hyperplasia ( Fig. S1E [this file] ). Plasma levels of the androgens testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT) did not differ significantly among control and mice ( Fig. S2 [this file] ). 
As the animals aged, the diffuse hyperplasia and cortical thinning gave way to increased frequency of well-circumcised benign nodules and adenomas ( Fig. S3 [this file] ) (6/8 males and 6/8 females of 12 months). Importantly, 1/8 aging females had a well-differentiated adrenal carcinoma with capsular invasion ( Fig. S3 [this file] ). 
To further investigate its molecular underpinnings, we conducted mRNA sequencing and differential expression analysis of whole adrenals from control and mice of both sexes during puberty (at 4 weeks), a timepoint before the occurrence of male-specific degeneration of adrenals ( Fig. S4A [this file] ) [data available at NCBI's Gene Expression Omnibus ( Barrett et al., 2013 [rid=DMM050053C3] ) with the accession number ]. Genes enriched in animals of both sexes compared to controls (corresponding to cluster 1 of the heatmap in Fig. S4B [this file] ) were related to β-catenin upregulation ( Fevr et al., 2007 [rid=DMM050053C22] ; Sansom et al., 2007 [rid=DMM050053C61] ) or targets of the β-catenin-associated transcription factor LEF1 ( Xie et al., 2005 [rid=DMM050053C70] ), a finding consistent with an hyperactivation of canonical WNT signaling by . Genes specifically upregulated in female adrenals (corresponding to cluster 3 of the heatmap in Fig. S4B [this file] ) were found to be primarily related to cell cycle regulation, DNA replication and repair, and cell division ( Fig. 2 [rid=DMM050053F2] B). On the contrary, genes highly expressed in male adrenals (corresponding to cluster 2 of the heatmap in Fig. S4B [this file] ) were associated with the regulation of the immune system and defense response ( Fig. 2 [rid=DMM050053F2] B). Moreover, an unbiased comparison of differentially regulated genes between male and female adrenals via GSEA confirmed that ‘DNA replication’ and ‘immune response’ were among the top enriched pathways in female and male adrenals, respectively ( Fig. S4C [this file] ). 
Sex-specific proliferation was not observed before puberty, as male and female GOF adrenals both showed increased proliferation rates during embryogenesis ( Fig. S5A,B [this file] ), whereas ordinary two-way ANOVA analysis showed the absence of interactive effect between sex and the presence of the transgene at this early stage ( =0.8311). 
In order to test whether the phenotype we observed was specific to , we analyzed the effect of ectopic expression in the adrenal cortex, taking advantage of a previously published allele in the locus ( Hilkens et al., 2017 [rid=DMM050053C34] ) and the system ( Fig. S6A [this file] ). overexpression phenocopied our model in terms of sex-specific hyperplasia and ectopic proliferation at 6 weeks of age ( Fig. S6B,C [this file] ). However, we were not able to compare the two models directly because the expression of the transgene was not uniform ( Fig. S6D [this file] ). 
Several genes expressed in macrophages and monocytes, as well as pan-immune cell markers, were upregulated in male adrenals ( Fig. S7A [this file] ). Moreover, IBA1 ( ), a macrophage marker that has been shown to be induced in knockout animals ( Ishii et al., 2012 [rid=DMM050053C36] ), was strongly expressed in male adrenals, but not in their female counterparts ( Fig. S7B [this file] ). On the contrary, male-specific foamy cell formation was not observed when overexpression was activated by the adrenal cortex-specific aldosterone synthase (AS) - line ( Freedman et al., 2013 [rid=DMM050053C26] ) (more details about this genetic model are provided in the ‘AR signaling determines sexual dimorphism in Rspo1GOF adrenals’ section) ( Fig. S7C [this file] ). 
Expression analysis revealed a slight reduction of the AR gene ( ), as well as a dramatic increase in the expression of , a putative androgen-responsive gene in the adrenal cortex (as suggested by our RNA-seq data and previous transcriptomic analyses; El Wakil et al., 2013 [rid=DMM050053C21] ) ( Fig. S8B [this file] ). Moreover, DHT treatment dramatically reduced normalized adrenal weight and proliferation levels in the adrenal cortex ( Fig. 4 [rid=DMM050053F4] D,E) but did not lead to histological changes such as cytoplasmic vacuolization ( Fig. S8A [this file] ). However, the expression of cell cycle genes that are also known β-catenin targets ( and ) ( Shtutman et al., 1999 [rid=DMM050053C64] ; Van de Wetering et al., 2002 [rid=DMM050053C66] ) did not show statistically significant changes after treatment, suggesting that the effect of the androgens on cell cycle progression is not due to direct regulation of β-catenin targets ( Fig. S8B [this file] ). Furthermore, DHT treatment led to an increase in expression levels and to a decrease in expression levels ( Fig. S8B [this file] ), similarly to what RNA Scope ISH analysis suggested regarding the effect of sex on the expression of WNT-related genes ( Fig. 3 [rid=DMM050053F3] C,E). Interestingly, long-term DHT treatment did not cause consistent changes in the subcellular localization of β-catenin in the inner cortex ( Fig. S8C [this file] ). 
Moreover, male / and female adrenals appeared similar on the histological level, characterized by cortical hyperplasia ( Fig. S9A [this file] ). The observed variability among different animals ( Fig. 5 [rid=DMM050053F5] C,D) is likely due to incomplete deletion of the allele in clusters of adrenocortical cells ( Fig. S9B [this file] ). Surprisingly, deletion led to a mild increase of β-catenin accumulation in cells in certain areas of the inner cortex of male adrenals ( Fig. S9C [this file] ). However, quantification of expression in the outer and inner cortex using RNA Scope ISH ( Fig. S9D [this file] ) revealed no significant changes, suggesting that deletion does not translate into a change of transcriptional activity of β-catenin. 
This discrepancy might reflect the differential rates of Cre activation, as is active during embryogenesis, whereas the line results in cortex-wide recombination only at 5[this file] weeks of age ( Freedman et al., 2013 [rid=DMM050053C26] ). 
Primary antibodies were applied overnight at 4°C diluted in 3% normal donkey serum, 3% BSA and 0.1% Tween-20 as explained in Table S2 [this file] . The next day, sections were incubated at room temperature with secondary antibodies donkey anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor 647, donkey anti-goat Alexa Fluor 555, donkey anti-mouse Alexa Fluor 555, donkey anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor 555 and donkey anti-mouse Alexa Fluor 647 diluted 1:400 in PBS (see Table S2 [this file] ). For anti-AR and anti-IBA1 immunohistochemistry, sections were incubated with biotinylated donkey anti-rabbit secondary antibodies (see Table S2 [this file] ) and the signal was revealed using the Vectastain Elite ABC-HRP peroxidase kit and the ImmPACT NovaRED HRP substrate (Vector Laboratories). 
The primers used are listed in Table [this file]S1 [this file] .
pub_title: Crosstalk between androgen receptor and WNT/β-catenin signaling causes sex-specific adrenocortical hyperplasia in mice

For mouse NAT1 targeting, we generated targeting vectors by introducing 5’ and 3’ homologous arms which were amplified from mouse genomic DNA by PCR using same strategy into pBS-Puro-bGHpA and pBS-Bsd-SV40pA, respectively (see Table S3 [href=this file] ).
The probe for the confirmation of homologous recombination was generated by PCR using the primer set; hNAT1-southern-probe-S/hNAT1-southern-probe-AS (see Table S3 [href=this file] ).
We introduced PB-U6-CNCB encoding each gRNA sequence (see Table S3 [href=this file] ) for gene of interest along with pCW-hyPBase into 1 × 10 of 1B4 iPSCs by using Nucleofection.
Primer sequences were provided in Table S3 [href=this file] .

title: NIHMS1701674-supplement-4.pdf
context_description:
To understand the role of NAT1 in human PSCs, we targeted the translation start site in exon 2 by using CRISPR/Cas9 DNA digestion and a knocked-in neomycin-resistance gene (Neo) ( Figures S1A [href=this file] – S1C [href=this file] ). Using the heterozygous mutant human iPSC line (NAT1 ), we performed a second round targeting the other NAT1 allele by knocking-in a puromycin-resistance gene (Puro) ( Figure S1A [href=this file] ). Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) screening to detect homologous recombinants indicated that all clones had Puro but not Neo even though the targeted alleles no longer had the guide RNA (gRNA) recognition site for CRISPR excision ( Figures S1B [href=this file] and S1C [href=this file] ). We introduced a doxycycline (Dox)-inducible NAT1 transgene (Tg) into NAT1 human iPSCs and performed second round targeting in these cells (NAT1 + Tg) in the presence of Dox ( Figure S1D [href=this file] ). Southern blotting showed that both NAT1 alleles were successfully deleted with the support of exogenous NAT1 expression ( Figure S1E [href=this file] ). Western blotting confirmed the precise regulation of NAT1 transgenes by Dox ( Figure S1F [href=this file] ). Time course analysis and quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR) showed that the expression of NAT1 in cKO human iPSCs dropped to less than 0.5% on day 3 after Dox removal, and Dox addition quickly recovered NAT1 expression to the endogenous level within one day ( Figure S1G [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S1 [href=this file] .
See also Figure S2 [href=this file] .
These HERV-H KD iPSCs remained undifferentiated on day 6 after the removal of Dox (NAT1) in F/A condition ( Figures 3E [href=#F3] and S2A) although they failed to self-renew by day 12 ( Figure S2B [href=this file] ). As we predicted, HERV-H suppression enabled NAT1-deficient human iPSCs to differentiate into neural lineage by EB formation ( Figures S2C [href=this file] and S2D [href=this file] ) and dSMADi ( Figures 3F [href=#F3] and 3G [href=#F3] ).
To address if the role of NAT1 in primed pluripotency is conserved in different species, we generated a NAT1 cKO mouse EpiSC line, which possesses similar characteristics to human iPSCs, such as the dependency on FGF and Activin A (F/A) ( Figures S3A [href=this file] – S3D [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S3 [href=this file] .
CRISPRi-induced NAT1 KD was also accompanied by decrease in TUT7 protein ( Figure S4 [href=this file] ).
See also Figure S4 [href=this file] .
See also Figure S5 [href=this file] .
See also Figure S6 [href=this file] .
To test if the decreased TUT7 protein expression contributed to the neural differentiation defect phenotypes in NAT1-depleted cells, we generated a Dox-inducible TUT7 cKD human iPSC line by CRISPRi with more than 99.9% efficiency ( Figure S5A [href=this file] ). TUT7 KD human iPSCs could expand normally while maintaining pluripotency marker expression ( Figures S5A [href=this file] and S5C [href=this file] ). In contrast, TUT7-depletion lowered the neural differentiation potential of human iPSCs ( Figures S5D [href=this file] – S5G [href=this file] ). On the other hand, we did not observe significant effects of TUT7-depletion on endoderm or mesoderm differentiation ( Figures S5D [href=this file] and S5E [href=this file] ).
As expected from the protein expression, the vector without 5’UTR rescued neural differentiation, suggesting that 5’UTR of TUT7 mRNA is responsible for the NAT1-dependent regulation ( Figures S6A [href=this file] and S6B [href=this file] ).
Also, the strength of NAT1’s effect on TUT7 translation varied in NAT1 cKO and cKD human iPSC lines, suggesting other mechanisms and/or pathways contribute to the regulation ( Figure S4 [href=this file] ).
On the other hand, in the NAT1 cKD iPSC line, we detected a significant increase of HERV-Hs despite a residual expression of TUT7 proteins ( Figures 5G [href=#F5] and S4 [href=this file] ).
In addition, NAT1 protein level in cKO cell line was roughly two-fold higher than that in cKD line ( Figure S4 [href=this file] ). This difference can be seen in their parental iPSC lines ( Figure S4 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Critical roles of translation initiation and RNA uridylation in endogenous retroviral expression and neural differentiation in pluripotent stem cells - PMC
A possible role of gas-phase electrophoretic mobility molecular analysis (nES GEMMA) in extracellular vesicle research
A possible role of gas-phase electrophoretic mobility molecular analysis (nES GEMMA) in extracellular vesicle research

title: No Title
caption: (DOCX 802 kb)
context_description:
nES GEMMA enables to analyze a size range from single digit up to several hundred nanometers, and instrument settings have to be adapted for smaller and larger sample components (refer to Supplementary Information Figure S1 [this file] for a schematic overview on the targetable analyte size range via nES GEMMA and NTA, respectively). 
Such a co-purification would usually go unnoticed, as most analysis methods other than nES GEMMA concentrate on a size region of EVs rather than focusing on co-purified proteins (refer to Supplementary Information Figure S1 [this file] for a schematic comparison of the nES GEMMA and NTA sizing range).
pub_title: A possible role of gas-phase electrophoretic mobility molecular analysis (nES GEMMA) in extracellular vesicle research

caption: Supplementary information
context_description:
Doxycycline-controlled Pax3 expression in differentiating mouse embryonic stem cells enables the robust activation of the skeletal myogenic program (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1a–d [this file] ). Among these, we identified known PAX3 binding sites, such as the −111 kb and −57 kb elements controlling expression, a well-known Pax3 target gene during embryonic myogenesis (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1e, f [this file] ). 
Functional annotation of the loop anchors demonstrated enrichment for multiple biological process categories associated with embryonic and muscle development (Supplementary Fig. 1g, h [this file] ). Furthermore, 140/442 (33%) and 1615/4647 (35%) of 1-day and 6-day differentially expressed genes , respectively, overlap with anchor-annotated genes (Supplementary Fig. 1i, j [this file] and Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ). Chromatin looping was also observed for several other genes, including , , , , , and (Fig. 1e [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] and see below). Establishment of long-range interactions at these sites coincided with a time-dependent increase in gene expression (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ), and in the case of the locus, epigenetic remodeling at the TSS region ( +0.7 kb—Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] ). 
Visual inspection of the region and other genomic loci characterized by long-range chromatin interactions upon Pax3 induction showed an increased deposition of the epigenetic marks associated with gene activation, in agreement with our ChIP-qPCR data for H3K4me3 (Fig. 2a [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 2b, c [this file] ). Using a k-means clustering algorithm, PAX3 binding sites can be categorized into four distinct types of chromatin state (clusters 1–4 in Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ), which displayed also different genomic distribution relative to the closest annotated gene (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] and Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM6] ). PAX3 had no effect on the epigenetic status of clusters 2 and 3 loci (565 and 135 peaks, respectively—Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ), which based on their histone marks profile can be categorized as elements proximal to TSS and repressed loci. These results were consistent across biological replicates (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). In agreement with Pax3 function in the epigenetic reprogramming of its binding sites, comparison of ChIP-seq data in mesodermal cells (1-day) and myogenic progenitors (6-day) for these histone marks revealed a time-dependent increase in H3K4me1 and H3K27Ac at 83% (3132/3780 total) of PAX3 binding sites (clusters 1A and 4A in Supplementary Fig. 3d, e [this file] ). 
Out of 52 enhancers annotated as active in the somites, 9 overlapped with PAX3 ChIP-seq peaks (Fig. 2d, f [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 5a–c [this file] ). Overlapping of PAX3 binding sites was also observed for elements active in the developing limb and in the neural tube (Supplementary Fig. 5a, d [this file] ), which represent known Pax3-expressing tissues . 
For this, we generated a Pax3-tagged cell line (iPax3HaFlag), which displayed equal myogenic activity as the untagged protein (Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ). Consistently, reciprocal co-immunoprecipitation using anti-LDB1 antibody confirmed interaction with PAX3 and the closely related myogenic transcription factor PAX7 (Supplementary Fig. 6c, d [this file] ). Importantly, we observed co-localization of PAX3-LDB1 and PAX3-SMC1 in the nuclei of E9.5 mouse embryo somites (Fig. 3f [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 6e [this file] ). 
This analysis yielded 4483 LDB1 and 13377 SMC1 peaks in Pax3-induced mesodermal cells (1-day), whereas non-induced displayed 6317 LDB1 and 19082 SMC1 peaks (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] and Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM6] ). This analysis yielded 55177 and 53669 CTCF peaks in 1-day Pax3-induced and non-induced cells, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] and Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM6] ). Comparison of these ChIP-seq data demonstrated a high degree of overlap between SMC1 and CTCF peaks (92% and 87% in dox-induced and non-induced iPax3 cells, respectively; Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). On the other hand, only a small percentage of LDB1 sites overlapped with SMC1 and CTCF peaks (22% and 25% in dox-induced and non-induced iPax3 cells, respectively; Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). Whereas SMC1 appeared to be bound independently of PAX3 induction (cluster 3 in Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] ), this was not the case for LDB1 as PAX3-dependent LDB1 recruitment at cluster 1 loci was evident (Fig. 4a, b [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 7e [this file] ), which we confirmed by ChIP-qPCR (Supplementary Figs. 7b [this file] and 8a [this file] and see below). Following annotation to the nearest TSS, this last group of loci includes genes essential for myogenesis, such as and , as well as multiple differentially regulated genes based on RNA-seq data (185/539 gene annotated peaks; Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] ). These results were consistent across biological replicates (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). Importantly, our data show that PAX3 bound elements are occupied either by LDB1 or SMC1/CTCF but not both (Fig. 4a, b [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 7e [this file] ), implying a differential role for these proteins in the regulation of Pax3-mediated myogenic activation. 
This was clear in both clusters characterized by H3K4me1 + low and high H3K27Ac levels (Fig. 4c [rid=Fig4] ), and was consistent across biological replicates (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). In contrast, PAX3 only loci displayed an enrichment for a more heterogeneous group of biological process categories (Supplementary Fig. 7g [this file] ). 
Examples of such interactions involve the + 135 kb and + 158 kb elements characterized by PAX3-mediated LDB1 recruitment (Fig. 4b, d [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 7e, f [this file] ). 
Recruitment of Ldb1 occurs at a subset of Pax3 sites overlapping with in vivo functional enhancers characterized by epigenetic remodeling (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] and Supplementary Fig. 7d [this file] ). 
Visual inspection of the HiChIP matrices confirmed the reduced long-range interactions at loci characterized by PAX3-dependent LDB1 recruitment ( and loci in Fig. 5g [rid=Fig5] and in Supplementary Fig. 7h [this file] ). 
The Pax3-inducible ES cell system represents the ideal tool for these studies as derivation of skeletal muscle cells is entirely dependent on Pax3 induction (Supplementary Fig. 1a–d [this file] ). Importantly, we show here that the ΔTAD mutant is incapable of recruiting LDB1 nor inducing H3K4me1 deposition at PAX3 binding sites (Fig. 6c [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 8a, e [this file] ), while still maintaining its DNA binding capability (Supplementary Fig. 8b [this file] ). We generated dox-inducible ES cell lines expressing ΔTAD fusion proteins in frame with the cDNA encoding for Ldb1, Ash2l, Cxxc1, and Pagr1a (Fig. 6b [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 8c [this file] ). This was consistent with gene expression data of mesodermal cells (1-day induced), as most Pax3 target genes are efficiently upregulated only by WT and ΔTAD-LDB1 proteins (Fig. 6e [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 8d [this file] ). 
Since Pax3 expression induces deposition of H3K4me1 at a subset of enhancers (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] ) and co-immunoprecipitation using LDB1 antibody shows interaction with PAX3, ASH2L, and WDR5 (Supplemental Fig. 5c [this file] ), we next investigated the effect of ΔTAD-LDB1 and ΔTAD-ASH2L proteins on histone 3 posttranslational modification. Consistently, ChIP using the H3K4me1 antibody demonstrated increased levels of this mark at PAX3 bound elements (e.g., −111 kb enhancer) following induction of full length PAX3, whereas the ΔTAD mutant lacked this activity (Supplemental Fig. 7e [this file] ). Similar results were obtained following induction of ΔTAD-LDB1, whereas ΔTAD-ASH2L was able to induce H3K4me1 only at a subset of Pax3 sites (Supplementary Fig. 8e [this file] ). Inspection of genomic tracks for dox-induced and non-induced WT, ΔTAD, and ΔTAD-LDB1 lines confirmed our ChIP-qPCR data at important myogenic loci ( , −111 kb and ; Supplementary Fig. 8f [this file] ). On a global scale, using the list of 1-day PAX3 bound elements, k-means clustering identified that only a subset of sites (3725/7508) display a ΔTAD-LDB1-dependent increase in H3K4me1 levels (Fig. 6g, h [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 8g [this file] ). 
We confirmed deletion by immunostaining for LDB1 in E9.5 embryos (Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] ). 
Interestingly, this effect was specific for LDB1 as fusion proteins involving subunits of the HMT complex failed to robustly induce myogenesis, regardless of their ability to increase H3K4me1 levels at a subset of Pax3 sites (Supplementary Fig. 8e [this file] ). 
Co-immunoprecipitation of LDB1 in iPax3 cells showed the interaction with the HMT complex subunits ASH2L and WDR5 (Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] ), and expression of the PAX3 ΔTAD-LDB1 fusion protein was able to induce an increase in H3K4me1 at a subset of PAX3 bound sites (Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
The HaFlag G-block sequence is provided in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
The list of antibodies used in this study and relative dilutions are provided in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
The list of antibodies used in this study and relative dilutions are provided in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . The primer sequences used for qPCR are provided in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
However, upon validation by qPCR (Fig. 6c [rid=Fig6] and Supplementary Fig. 1e [this file] ), this region was included in the list of 1-day PAX3 and LDB1 peaks. 
List of antibody used in this study is provided in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
For heatmap in Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] , differentially expressed genes were determined by annotation of each ChIP-seq peak to the closest gene.

After subtracting the HiChIP contacts called in non-induced Pax3 cells, we identified 3227 and 7987 loops in Pax3-induced mesodermal cells and myogenic progenitors, respectively (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
In independent replicates, we detected fewer significant contacts upon Ldb1 knockdown (Fig. 5e [rid=Fig5] ), which resulted in diminished numbers of chromatin loops (9565 and 6885 in control vs. Ldb1 knockdown, respectively; Fig. 5f [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
This analysis detected 2798 looping interactions induced by ΔTAD-LDB1 within 24 h (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ) and, as shown in Fig. 6f [rid=Fig6] , several of these chromatin looping events occurred at the genomic loci associated with ΔTAD-LDB1 upregulated genes ( , , , and ).

Cardiomyocytes stimulate angiogenesis after ischemic injury in a ZEB2-dependent manner

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
K-medoids clustering of 1-Pearson correlation showed that based on gene expression similarities, these cells could be clustered in 14 different cell populations (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). Using the expression of well-established marker genes, we were able to identify all main cardiac cell types, such as cardiomyocytes, fibroblasts, endothelial cells, and immune cells (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1b-g [this file] and Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM4] ). 
To study the function of ZEB2 in cardiomyocytes, we generated cardiomyocyte-specific Zeb2 knockout mice ( cKO) (Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ). QPCR analysis indicated approximately a 50% reduction in cardiac expression levels in cKO mice compared to control ( fl/fl) (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ). Under baseline conditions deleting from cardiomyocytes did not appear to induce any gross morphological or functional changes (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] , and Fig. 2c–g [rid=Fig2] ). 
Compared to the fl/fl mice, cKO mice experienced a greater cardiac dysfunction as measured by fractional shortening (FS) and a non-significant increase in left ventricular internal diameter in systole (LVIDs) post-MI (Fig. 2d, e [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). We also observed an increase in infarct size in cKO compared with fl/fl mice, assessed by the percentage of the infarcted area of the total LV circumference (Supplementary Fig. 3b-c [this file] ). A decrease in capillary density and expression of endothelial markers was also observed in Zeb2 cKO mice after sham, implying a vascular difference at baseline (Supplementary Fig. 3d–j [this file] ). 
In doing so, we found 2339 (-0,2 Log2 fold change) downregulated and 1599 (0,2 Log2 fold change) upregulated genes (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] and Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM6] ). The differential expression of the top regulated genes could be confirmed by qPCR in a larger sample set ( = 7) (Supplementary Fig. 4b-c [this file] ). Pathway analysis showed that upregulated genes were mainly linked to metabolic pathways (Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] ), whereas downregulated genes were involved in, among others, focal adhesion, PI3K-Akt signaling, and regulation of actin cytoskeleton (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ), suggesting a decline in cell survival and angiogenic response in cKO hearts compared to wild type littermates . This overrepresentation of pathways involved in ECM and vasculature maintenance indicated that deleting did not only affect cardiomyocytes but also other cell types, suggesting a cell non-autonomous function mediated by ZEB2 (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ). 
To this end, we inhibited ZEB2 in hypoxic neonatal rat cardiomyocytes (NRCMs), after which we collected the conditioned medium and added it on either freshly cultured NRCMs or the non-cardiomyocyte fraction of cells (non-CMs) from the same isolation (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). We did not observe any significant differences in the cardiomyocyte fraction when exposed to the conditioned medium from treated cardiomyocytes (Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] ). However, in using the same conditioned medium, the non-CMs cells did show a decrease in ECM/fibrotic and endothelial genes (Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). 
While the expression of many factors did not change in cKO mice post-MI, we observed a significant downregulation for and (Fig. 4a–b [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 6a–i [this file] ). These data imply a possible regulation of and by ZEB2 most likely due to multiple ZEB2 binding sites present in close proximity to the transcription starting site (TSS) in and in mouse and human (Supplementary Fig. 6j [this file] ). Additionally, we made use of existing ChIP-seq data ( https://www.encodeproject.org/targets/ZEB2-human/ (https://www.encodeproject.org/targets/ZEB2-human/) ) and identified ZEB2 binding motifs in enhancer regions of both TMSB4 and PTMA (Supplementary Fig. 6k-l [this file] ), indicating that ZEB2 protein can directly bind to those enhancers causing an increase in TMSB4 and PTMA expression. 
To examine the secretory and pro-angiogenic effect of TMSB4 and PTMA from cardiomyocytes, we infected human iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes with adeno-associated viruses overexpressing either ZEB2, TMSB4 or PTMA in the absence or presence of a siRNA targeting ZEB2 or a control (Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ). This resulted in an increase or decrease in expression compared to control cells, as indicated by qPCR analysis (Supplementary Fig. 7b-e [this file] ). Conditioned medium from cardiomyocytes overexpressing ZEB2, TMSB4 or PTMA enhanced the migration of endothelial cells, with no apparent additive effect when overexpressing both TMSB4 or PTMA (Supplementary Fig. 7f-g [this file] ). Conversely, exposing endothelial cells to conditioned medium from iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes treated with a siRNA against ZEB2, lowered endothelial cell migration (Supplementary Fig. 7h-i [this file] ). However, this inhibitory effect could be rescued by the conditioned medium from cardiomyocytes, where ZEB2 inhibition was followed by overexpression of TMSB4 or PTMA (Supplementary Fig. 7h-i [this file] ). 
To do so, we crossed Rosa26-LoxSTOPLox-ZEB2 mice with mice overexpressing Cre recombinase under the control of the cardiac-specific α-myosin heavy chain promoter (αMHC-Cre Tg) (Supplementary Fig. 8a-b [this file] ). Overexpression of was confirmed by qPCR for (and ) (Supplementary Fig. 8c-d [this file] ). Compared to WT littermates, we did not observe any morphological or functional effects of ZEB2 overexpression under baseline conditions (Supplementary Fig. 8e–g [this file] and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
To study the function of ZEB2 overexpression during an ischemic event, we subjected cTg mice to MI for 14 days, after which we performed functional and molecular analyses (Fig. 7a [rid=Fig7] ). cTg-based overexpression was confirmed on mRNA (Fig. 7b–c [rid=Fig7] ) and protein level (Fig. 7d [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 9a [this file] ). Echocardiography showed an improvement in cardiac function (FS), a decline in left ventricular internal diameter (LVIDs), and smaller infarct size in mice overexpressing ZEB2 in cardiomyocytes (Fig. 7e–f [rid=Fig7] , Supplementary Fig. 9b–d [this file] and Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ). 
Additionally, we already observed a mild increase in capillary density and endothelial markers under sham conditions, which can potentially contribute to the enhanced angiogenesis post-MI (Supplementary Fig. 9e-k [this file] . In line with the protective consequences of overexpressing ZEB2 in cardiomyocytes, we observed an increase in the expression of the pro-survival gene BCL-XL in cTg mice post-MI (Supplementary Fig. 9l-m [this file] ). 
We generated AAV9-control and AAV9-Zeb2 (Supplementary Fig. 10a [this file] ) and tested different routes of delivery, including intraperitoneal (IP) injection into mouse pups, and intracardiac (IC) and intravenous (IV) injection into adult mice (Supplementary Fig. 10b–d [this file] ). Since intracardiac injection resulted in the strongest increase in expression of in the heart (Supplementary Fig. 10c [this file] ), we used this method for our subsequent experiments. 
ZEB2 expression was confirmed to be increased at both times points post-injection (Fig. 8b–d [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11a–c [this file] ). Increasing ZEB2 in cardiomyocytes improved cardiac function and morphology after MI at both time points as measured by FS and LVID (Fig. 8e–f [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11d-e [this file] , Supplementary Table 5 [this file] , Supplementary Table 6 [this file] ). We detected a significant increase in levels in response to ZEB2 delivery (Fig. 8g–j [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11f–i [this file] ). This corresponded with an increase in and expression (Fig. 8k–m [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11j–l [this file] ) and an overall increase in the PECAM1 positive area in cTg hearts (Fig. 8n [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11m [this file] ). Additionally, when increasing ZEB2, we observed a trend in elevated levels of the pro-survival gene BCL-XL 28 days post- MI (Fig. 8o–p [rid=Fig8] ) and smaller cardiomyocyte size in the remote area as indicated by WGA staining (Fig. 8q–r [rid=Fig8] and Supplementary Fig. 11n-o [this file] ). 
All mice were genotyped by PCR using primers shown in Supplementary Table 7 [this file] . 
Primer sequences are provided in Supplementary Table 7 [this file] . 
Cells were subjected to hypoxia (1%O and 5%CO ) for 6 h before collection (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ).
